TITLE II - Special Laws[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Title II consists of those Connecticut special laws affecting the City of New Haven which are of continuing effect and general interest. It does not include special laws which have been superseded by the 1952 Charter, nor does it include acts expressly amending said Charter. Words in brackets [], have been added by the editor to clarify meaning and correct obvious typographical errors. 
 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1. - Boundaries between New Haven and Hamden changed. 
(a)  That portion of the town line between the city of New Haven and the town of Hamden, lying easterly of and adjacent to Wintergreen avenue and southerly of the old Selden Farm shall be changed to a line running parallel with and 150 feet perpendicularly distant easterly thereof, said changed line running between the southerly side of Selden Farm and the present town line lying westerly of Fowler Street. 
(b)  That portion of the town line between the city of New Haven and the town of Hamden running along the center line of the highway known as Wooding street shall be changed to a line coincident with the southerly street line of said Wooding street as established at the time of the passage of this act. 
(c)  That portion of the town line between the city of New Haven and the town of Hamden running southerly a distance of 671.57 feet from the northeasterly corner of a lot of land originally laid out in the name of Richard Hickenbottom and afterward conveyed to John Hubbard, to a point in the easterly side of an old four rod highway known as Wintergreen avenue, said point being marked by a monument, shall be changed to a line running as follows: Beginning at the said northeasterly corner of the said Richard Hickenbottom lot and running easterly in a straight extension of the present town line for a distance of 100 feet, thence running southerly a distance of 638.84 feet to the point in the easterly side of Wintergreen avenue hereinbefore mentioned and marked by a monument. 
(Special Laws 1939, Act No. 97, §§ 1—3)  
Sec. 2. - Ivy street school considered in eighteenth ward. 
The provisions of an act dividing the city of New Haven into thirty-three wards, approved May 31, 1921, as amended by an act approved April 23, 1931, [2] to the contrary notwithstanding, the Ivy street school, located in the sixteenth ward in the city of New Haven, shall be considered a part of the eighteenth ward of said city, and may be used as a polling place by the electors of said eighteenth ward. 
(Special Laws 1945, Act No. 301) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1921, Act No. 342, enacted May 31, as amended by Special Laws 1931, Act No. 249, enacted April 23, established wards in the city. Said acts, as subsequently amended, are set out in § 3 of the 1952 Revised Charter. 
 
Sec. 3. - Thirty-second ward consolidated into city. 
On and after the 31st day of May, 1959, all that part and portion of the city of New Haven known as the thirty-second ward thereof, and more particularly bounded and described as follows: commencing at the point of intersection of the center lines of Ferry street and the easterly harbor line, thence following said harbor line to the center line of Fort Hale road extended, thence easterly through the center of Fort Hale road to the center of Munn road, thence through the center of Munn road to the city line, thence northerly following the city line to the center line of the old Shore line railway, thence westerly along the center line of said railway to the center line of Ferry street extended, thence westerly through the center of Ferry street to the point of beginning is hereby brought within the full jurisdiction of said city, and the inhabitants thereof shall have all the rights and be subject to all duties and responsibilities which appertain to the inhabitants of the other wards and areas within the territorial limits of said city. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, § 1) 
Charter reference— For provisions governing taxation and services in the 32nd ward prior to enactment of Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, which appears as §§ 3—9 of this compilation, see § 172 of the 1952 Revised Charter. For procedure for consolidating said ward, see § 173 of said charter.  
Sec. 4. - Thirty-second ward entitled to all public services. 
On and after the first day of June, 1959, said area which thereto had been known as the thirty-second ward, and more particularly described in section 1 hereof, shall have and receive any and all public services of every sort and description which every other area or part of said city shall have and shall be entitled to receive. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, § 2)  
Sec. 5. - Taxation of property in thirty-second ward. 
On and after said first day of June, 1959, all property in said thirty-second ward, whether real or personal, shall be subject to taxation, and to assessments for public purposes, upon the same terms and conditions and at the same rates as is all other such property within said city. 
(Special Laws, 1959, Act No. 138, § 3)  
Sec. 6. - Dissolution of Fairmount Association in thirty-second ward. 
As of the first day of June, 1959, The Fairmount Association, incorporated under the provisions of number 361 of the special acts of 1911, theretofore having certain powers and duties in respect to public affairs in said thirty-second ward, shall be dissolved and cease to exist, and the city of New Haven shall receive and have for public purposes all the property and assets of said Fairmount Association and shall assume all existing indebtedness of said Fairmount Association; except that, for all indebtedness incurred by said Fairmount Association between February 1, 1959, and June 1, 1959, the city of New Haven shall be liable for only such amount as the board of finance of said city may approve. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, § 4)  
Sec. 7. - Repeal of special act concerning sewerage plant in thirty-second ward: refund of taxes. 
Number 337 of the special acts of 1945, pertaining to the construction and maintenance of a sewer disposal plant and accessory pumping stations in the thirty-second ward of the city of New Haven and the levying of a tax upon the individual property in said ward therefor, is repealed. Any and all moneys paid before the effective date of this act [3] on account of any such tax shall be refunded to the property owner against whom such tax was levied or to any successor in title who has assumed and paid such tax. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, § 5) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138 was approved and effective May 15, 1959. 
 
Sec. 8. - Repeal of special act authorizing sewer assessments in thirty-second ward. 
Number 341 of the special acts of 1945 is repealed; provided the city may levy assessments against the owners of real property in the thirty-second ward for sewers constructed or to be constructed, in the same manner and to the same extent as it may levy assessment for sewers in remaining parts of the city. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, § 6) 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1945, Act No. 341 limited the services available to the thirty-second ward and prohibited city taxation therein for specified purposes. It is not included in this compilation.  
Sec. 9. - Consolidation of thirty-second ward not subject to Section 2-14 General Statutes. 
Section 2-14 of the general statutes shall not be applicable to this act. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 138, § 7) 
Editor's note— Section 2-14 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958) provides that the general assembly cannot enact local legislation unless requested by the affected municipality. "This act" refers to the provisions compiled as §§ 3 through 9 of this Article.  
Sec. 10. - City designated complying municipality under chapter 110 of general statutes. 
The city of New Haven is designated as a complying municipality under chapter 110 of the general statutes with the same effect, except as otherwise provided in sections 62 and 63 of the charter, as though it had become such pursuant to section 7-382 of said chapter and Chapters 111, 203, 204 and 205 of the general statutes are made applicable mutatis mutandis to said city. 
(Special Laws 1967, Act No. 437, § 1) 
Editor's note— Section 10 is derived from § 1, Act No. 437, Special Laws 1967.  
Secs. 11—19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 20. - Mayor—General powers. 
The mayor shall have power: 
(1)  To assume the entire control and direction of the police and fire forces of the city, or either of them, for a period not exceeding five days, at his discretion in case of emergency, and to exercise all of the powers conferred upon the fire and police departments in relation thereto. 
(2)  To exercise, whenever necessary in order to suppress tumults, riots, or unlawful assemblies, within the limits of said city, all the powers given by law to sheriffs in relation to riotous assemblages; and, at all times, when necessary, to require the aid of any sheriff, deputy sheriff, constable, or policeman, or any or all of them together, to assist him in executing the laws within the limits of said city. 
(3)  To make requisition for the several companies of the Connecticut national guard and divisions of naval reserve in said city, or any of them, whenever he shall have reason to believe that great opposition will be made to the exercise of his authority, and to exert all the force necessary to enable him to execute the laws within the limits of said city. 
(4)  To appoint, whenever he may deem it best to do so, three competent, disinterested persons, no more than two of whom shall be of the same political party, to examine without notice the affairs of any department, officer, or employee of said city, and submit the results of said examination to him. 
(5)  The mayor may at any time whenever he may believe any person appointed to office by him or any of his predecessors to be incompetent, or unfaithful to the duties of his office, or that the requirements of the public service demand his removal, summon said officer before him at a place and time specified in said summons, to show cause why he should not be removed from said office. With said summons he shall leave with said officer a written statement of the charges against him, and if, after a full hearing, he shall find that such officer is incompetent or unfaithful, or that the requirements of the public service demand his removal, he may remove such person from his office. Any such official so removed may appeal from the order of the mayor removing him from said office to the superior court or any judge thereof, which appeal shall be made returnable not more than six nor less than three days from the date of the order of removal of said mayor, and shall be served upon the mayor or at his usual place of abode at least forty-eight hours before the time fixed for a hearing. And said court or judge, having given such further notice as may be deemed necessary to all parties, shall forthwith hear said case, and may approve or revoke the order of said mayor and may award costs at his discretion. But no such official so removed shall exercise any of the powers of his office during the pendency of his approval to the superior court. 
(6)  The mayor shall have authority to administer oaths to duly elected and appointed officials of said city. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 12; Special Laws 1945, Act No. 117) 
Charter reference— The provisions of § 20 above are partially covered by § 7 of the 1952 Revised Charter. 
Annotation— Avery v. Studley, 74 Conn. 281 (1901) held hearings on removal under subsection (5) above are not subject to a motion to make the charges more definite and employee is not entitled to legal counsel as a matter of right.  
Sec. 21. - Same—Hindering, obstructing, refusing to aid prohibited. 
If any person shall hinder, obstruct, resist, or abuse the mayor in the execution of his office, or when ordered to render assistance to the mayor (being of sufficient age and ability) shall refuse or neglect to do so, such offender, being thereof duly convicted, shall pay a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars, or shall be imprisoned in the county jail not exceeding six months, or both, at the discretion of the court having cognizance of the offense. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 13)  
Sec. 22. - Same—Status of soldiers called into service by. 
Every commissioned officer and soldier, when called into service by the mayor, as aforesaid, shall have the same pay, and in case of disobedience be subject to the same penalties, as if called into service by the sheriff of the county. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 14)  
Sec. 23. - Office of corporation counsel; authority of mayor to employ additional counsel. 
The corporation counsel may have an office, to be provided by the city, which shall be kept open during such hours daily as may be by ordinance prescribed. The mayor may, if in his opinion the interests of the city require it, employ additional counsel, except with reference to matters pending before the general assembly. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 17) 
Charter reference— Section 15 of the 1952 Revised Charter authorizes the appointment of assistant corporation counsels and establishes their qualifications.  
Sec. 24. - Record commission. 
There shall be in the city of New Haven a record commission to consist of three citizens, to be nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the board of aldermen, each to hold office for the term of three years. When this act shall take effect [4] the mayor shall nominate three members of said commission, one for the term of three years from the first day of July 1907, one for the term of two years from the first day of July, 1907, and one for the term of one year from the first day of July, 1907, and thereafter shall nominate one member of such commission during the month of June in each year for the term of three years from the first day of July following. The members of said commission shall be chosen from such citizens as are especially qualified, by reason of their experience and knowledge concerning public records, to exercise an intelligent judgment in respect to matters liable to be submitted to them, and shall serve without pay. Said commission shall have charge of the preparation of the copy for printing and of the printing and distribution of such volumes of ancient or valuable records as the board of aldermen may, from time to time, order printed; shall designate the institutions, public bodies, and officials to whom copies may be distributed free of expense, and the terms on which copies may be obtained by private individuals; and shall from time to time make such recommendations to said board concerning the care, preservation, and printing of such records as it shall deem advisable. The board of aldermen may also refer to said commission for advice or action [on] any matter pertaining to said records. 
(Special Laws 1907, Act No. 186, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1907, Act No. 186, from which § 24 above is derived, was effective when passed May 14, 1907. 
 
Sec. 25. - Assistant registrars authorized to serve as absentee ballot counters. 
Notwithstanding any contrary provisions of sections 9-148 of the general statutes and 9-149 of the 1965 supplement thereto, the assistant registrars of voters in the seventh wards of the city of New Haven shall serve as absentee ballot counters for their respective wards. 
(Special Laws 1967, Act No. 358) 
Editor's note— Section 25 is derived from Act No. 358, Special Laws 1967. 
Charter reference— Elections and electors, §§ 4 and 5.  
Secs. 26—34. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING LINES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, which is codified as §§ 35—45 of this Article, is expressly adopted and declared a part of the charter by the 1952 Revised Charter, § 292. 
 
Sec. 35. - Building lines commission established; appointment, term, compensation, political affiliation of members. 
There shall be in the city of New Haven a special commission on building lines which shall consist of five members, who shall be tax-paying citizens of said city of New Haven, and shall be appointed by the mayor, one for a term ending February 1, 1913, one for a term ending February 1, 1914, one for a term ending February 1, 1915, one for a term ending February 1, 1916, and one for a term ending February 1, 1917, and in the month of January 1913, and annually thereafter, the mayor shall appoint a member of said commission for a term of five years from the first day of February next succeeding his appointment, until said commission shall have completed its work, when the terms of its members shall expire. No more than three of said members shall, at any time, be members of the same political party. The members of said commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 1)  
Sec. 36. - Clerk to building line commission. 
Said building line commission shall employ a clerk, who shall be a competent stenographer and typewriter, at a salary not exceeding one hundred dollars per month, which clerk shall make full and correct records of the hearings and doings of the commission, and otherwise serve the city, as directed by the mayor, when not in the immediate employ of said commission. The hours of service of said clerk shall be from ten to twelve o'clock a.m., two to four o'clock, and eight to ten o'clock p.m. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 2)  
Sec. 37. - Assistance rendered commission of other departments; submission of budgets to board of finance. 
Said commission may call upon the other departments of the city government for such assistance as they may be able to give, and shall also have authority, if necessary, to employ engineering or other services and fix the compensation therefor, and to incur all other expenses necessary to effectuate the purpose of this act [article], subject to the approval of the board of finance, which expenses shall be paid by the city of New Haven. 
Said commission shall submit an estimate of its expenses to the board of finance on or before August tenth in each year. Prior to the adoption of the estimates for 1912, the expenses of said commission shall be paid out of the contingent account or by transfers from other appropriations made for the year 1911. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 3)  
Sec. 38. - Authority of commission to establish, modify building lines. 
Said commission shall have authority, and it shall be its duty, on proper petition or the order or direction of the mayor and board of aldermen, to establish, modify, or re-establish building lines on any street or streets, or any part of any street, in said city, in existence at the time of the passage of this act [article], [6] in accordance with the methods provided in the charter of the city of New Haven, and said commission is hereby vested with all the powers, necessary for the purposes aforesaid, which have been heretofore conferred upon the board of aldermen of said city. Said commission shall also consider and take action regarding building lines upon any street, or part of a street, in existence at the time of the passage of this act,* when requested so to do by the board of aldermen. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 4) 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433 was approved August 24, 1911. 
 
Sec. 39. - Survey, public hearing required before establishing lines, assessing benefits or damages. 
Before said commission shall establish, modify, or re-establish any building line, or assess benefits or damages, it shall cause a survey, in writing, of such line to be made, and shall give notice to all owners and mortgagees of land which will be taken or affected by such building line of the time and place of a public hearing on such proposed establishment, modification, re-establishment, or assessment of benefits or damages. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 5)  
Sec. 40. - Procedure for giving notice of hearings before commission. 
All such notices shall be signed by the clerk of said commission, and a notice shall be delivered or mailed to each person interested, as aforesaid, in such land, who resides in said city, or to the agent in charge of such land, or left at the usual place of abode of such person or agent at least six days prior to such hearing. In case the person so interested shall not, at the time, reside in said city, or shall be under any legal disability, or in case the owner of such property is unknown, such notice shall be given as a judge of the superior court or court of common pleas shall order. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 6)  
Sec. 41. - Authority of commission to act after hearing. 
After such notice and hearing said commission shall determine and establish the building line, and shall assess damages, if any, to any person whose property or estate will be damaged by such building line, and the benefits, if any, to be paid by any person whose property or estate will be specially benefited by such building line. The assessment shall be for the excess of benefits over damages, if any, or vice versa, as the case may be. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 7)  
Sec. 42. - Records of official acts of commission. 
Said commission shall cause all its official acts to be fully recorded and shall deposit such record with the city clerk of the city of New Haven, who shall keep the same permanently on file as a record of said city; said city clerk shall cause to be recorded in the land records of the town of New Haven all building lines now established, or which are established hereafter. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 8)  
Sec. 43. - Reports by commission to mayor; effective date, collection of assessments. 
Said commission shall report in writing to the mayor, all its doings in the premises, and said mayor shall, in writing, approve or disapprove, said report; if he disapproves, he shall, within ten days, return said report, with the reasons for his disapproval, to said commission for further consideration. When any report of said commission establishing, modifying, or re-establishing any building line on any street is so approved by the mayor, he shall transmit said report to the city clerk, who shall record it in the records of the city; and when said report is so recorded, and is also recorded in the land records of the town, as provided in section eight of this act [section 42 of this article], and when the damages shall have been paid to the person whose property has been damaged by the establishment of any building line, or shall have been deposited with the city treasurer to be paid to such person when he shall apply for the same, then each of said assessments shall be legally deemed to have been made, and the land described in said survey and record of the establishing of said building line shall be devoted to the public use for which it shall have been designated. Within one week after compliance with the foregoing provision in regard to the payment of damages, or within one week after the recording of said report when no damages are to be paid to any person, the city clerk shall give notice to any person against whom an assessment has been laid, and said assessment shall be payable, and shall bear interest, as provided in section eighty-one of the charter of said city as amended by an act approved April 25, 1911. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 9; Special Laws 1913, Act No. 101, § 1) 
Editor's note— Section 81 of the 1899 charter, Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, as amended, is substantially the same as §§ 96—98 of the 1952 Revised Charter, and has been omitted from this compilation as superseded thereby.  
Sec. 44. - Appeals from building line assessments. 
Any person who shall be aggrieved by any assessment of benefits or damages made in establishing a building line by the special commission on building lines of the city of New Haven, may, within thirty days after recording a description of the location of such building line in the records of the city by the city clerk, make written application for relief to the superior court in the manner provided in section eighty-five of the charter of the city of New Haven as amended by an act approved June 6, 1913. 
(Special Laws 1915, Act No. 208) 
Editor's note— Section 85 of the 1899 charter, Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, as amended, is substantially the same as § 102 of the 1952 Revised Charter, and has been omitted from this compilation as superseded thereby.  
Sec. 45. - Authority of aldermen to establish, modify building lines. 
Nothing herein contained shall prevent the board of aldermen from establishing building lines in new streets, or in parts of streets hereafter widened or extended, in accordance with the provisions of the charter of the city of New Haven, or from transferring to said building line commission petitions, addressed to said board of aldermen, for their action, relating to the establishment, re-establishment, change, or modification of building lines. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 433, § 10) 
Charter reference— For authority of aldermen to establish building lines, see § 50(d) of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Secs. 46—54. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE AND TAXATION 
 
Sec. 55. - Records of back taxes. 
The city of New Haven is authorized to install cumulative delinquent tax register cards for each delinquent taxpayer for keeping records to show the amount of the delinquent tax and all types of assessment liabilities due, and the collection, adjustments, charges, interest and abatements thereon. The tax collector of said city shall not be required to post collection of back taxes and assessments in the back tax rate books or back tax rate bills, and the cumulative delinquent cards are to be used in lieu of the rate books when the tax becomes delinquent. 
Any provisions of the general statutes or of any special act inconsistent with the provisions of this act shall not apply to the city of New Haven and its tax collector. 
(Special Laws 1943, Act No. 251, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 56. - Adjustment of tax receivable accounts. 
The city of New Haven is authorized to adjust the general ledger tax receivable control accounts of the controller's office of all outstanding taxes so that the same will be in agreement with the tax collector's rate books of said municipality and with the auditor's report on his examination of such accounts. 
(Special Laws 1941, Act No. 133)  
Sec. 57. - Tax to liquidate current operating deficits. 
Upon the determination of the amount of any deficit occurring in the city of New Haven in any year hereafter, by reason of current expenditures exceeding current revenue, such deficit shall be liquidated through the proceeds of a tax to be laid and appropriated for such purpose, to be included in the general city rate in the estimated receipts and disbursements for the next succeeding year, as provided in section forty-four of the charter of said city. [7] Such amount shall be used only for the purpose for which it is appropriated and no transfers shall be made therefrom. The tax bills for the year in which such tax is to be collected shall be accompanied by a plainly printed statement as follows: "During the year 19___ the City of New Haven expended _______ more than it received. Of the tax laid, _____ mills are for the purpose of paying such deficit." 
(Special Laws 1937, Act No. 23, § 2; Special Laws 1933, Act No. 24, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Section 44 of the 1899 charter, Special Laws 1899, Act: No. 467, is substantially the same as § 62 of the 1952 Revised Charter, and has been omitted from this compilation as inconsistent therewith. 
 
Sec. 58. - Tax exemption granted Jewish Center. 
Said corporation [8] may purchase, receive, hold, lease, mortgage or otherwise encumber or convey any real or personal property, and all its real property, furniture and equipment, from which no rents, profits or income are derived, shall be exempt from taxation. 
(Special Laws 1955, Act No. 475) 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— "Said corporation" refers to the Jewish Community Center. The special law set out in § 58 above was an amendment to Special Laws 1925, Act No. 253, § 3 as amended by Special Laws 1947, Act No. 39, said acts being the charter of the center. The remainder of the charter has been omitted from this compilation. 
 
Sec. 59. - Due date of taxes. 
All taxes laid by said city or town on the grand list of 1933 shall become due and payable on the first day of January, 1934, and all taxes thereafter laid by said city or town shall become due and payable on the first day of January next after they are laid. If one-half in amount of such taxes be paid on or before the first day of February next after they become payable, no interest thereon shall be charged until after the first day of the next succeeding August, and then only on such amount of such tax as then remains unpaid; that is to say, if more than one-half of the tax assessed against any person or corporation shall remain unpaid on the first day of February next after such tax shall have become due and payable, interest shall be collected at seven per cent per annum from the first day of February on so much as then remains unpaid exceeding such one-half; and on all taxes remaining unpaid on the first day of August next after they shall have become due and payable, interest at said rate shall be collected from said first day of August until paid. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 61; Special Laws 1931, Act No. 330; Special Laws 1933, Act No. 349) 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1931, Act No. 330, Special Laws 1933, Act No. 349, from which § 59 above is derived, are expressly declared part of the charter of New Haven by § 293 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 59.1. - Payment of taxes in installments. 
The city's tax levy for the fiscal year commencing July 1, 1968, and for each succeeding fiscal year shall be due and payable in two installments, the first of which shall be due and payable on the first day of such fiscal year and the second of which shall be due and payable on the succeeding January first. 
(Special Laws 1967, Act No. 437, § 4) 
Editor's note— Section 59.1 is derived from § 4 of Act No. 437, Special Laws, 1967.  
Sec. 60. - Tax and assessment lists. 
(1)  The assessors of the town and city of New Haven shall, at least fifteen days before the first day of June, annually, post on the public sign post in said city, or publish in one or more newspapers published in said city, a notice requiring all persons therein liable to pay taxes, to bring in, between June first and July first, inclusive, written or printed lists of the taxable personal property other than motor vehicles belonging to them on the first day of June in that year. If July first shall be a Sunday, then the next business day following shall be the final day for filing said lists. 
(2)  The state tax commissioner shall, subject to the provisions of this section, prescribe the form to be used by property owners in the town and city of New Haven in filing lists under the provisions of section one of this act [subsection (1) of this section]. The assessors of the town and city of New Haven may prepare one or more tentative forms for individual assessment lists and for an abstract book and may make application to the state tax commissioner for his approval thereof. Any such form, which shall have been approved by the tax commissioner, may thereafter be used in the town and city of New Haven until the tax commissioner shall either revoke his approval thereof or until such form shall have been superseded by another form approved by said commissioner. No special form of abstract book for the town and city of New Haven shall be approved which does not permit all information to be shown thereon which shall be contained in the regular form of abstract book. 
(3)  The addition of ten per cent, to taxpayers' lists provided by law for failure to file lists shall not apply to any failure to file lists of real estate or motor vehicles. 
(4)  Any provision of the general statutes or of any special act inconsistent with the provisions of this act shall have no force and effect so far as they relate to the assessment of property for taxation in the town and city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1943, Act No. 520, §§ 1—4) 
Editor's note— Section 5 of Special Laws 1943, Act No. 520, declared that it should be effective May 31, 1944. Under the 1952 Charter, § 86, as amended effective January 1, 1961, the accessors have been replaced by a department of assessments under the direction of an assessor.  
Sec. 61. - Notice requiring tax lists. 
The assessors of the town and city of New Haven shall, on or before the first day of June, annually, post on the signpost in said city, or publish in one or more newspapers published in said city, a notice requiring all persons therein liable to pay taxes to bring in written or printed lists of the taxable property belonging to them on the first day of June in that year. (Sec. 1129 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Editor's note— The provisions of §§ 61-68 of this compilation are derived from the sections of the 1918 general statutes set out in the history notes appended to each section. 
Said provisions were ordered deleted from the general statutes and reprinted as special acts in the back of Vol. XXI, Part 1 of the special laws by Public Act 1929, Ch. 258. Though some of said sections refer to the town of New Haven, they are included at the request of the city. Section 61 above is in part inconsistent with § 60(1) and has been partially superseded thereby. Sections 12-40—12-42 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958) provided for tax lists. Section 12-40 requires notice that said lists are due to be published on or before October 15 of each year, but said section is only applicable in the absence of other provisions of law. An amendment to the 1952 Charter, effective January 1, 1961, abolished the offices of assessor and created a department of assessments headed by an assessor. See § 86 of said Charter.  
Sec. 62. - Due date for tax lists. 
Each resident of the city of New Haven liable to give in a list and pay taxes therein shall give in the list required by section 1126 of the general statutes (revision of 1930) on or before the first day of July, annually. When the first day of July shall be Sunday, the list may be given in on the day following. (Sec. 1139 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. The provisions of § 62 above are partially inconsistent with and superseded by § 60(1) of this compilation. Section 1126 Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1930), as amended, appear as § 12-42 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 63. - Notice of addition to town tax lists. 
The assessors of the town of New Haven shall give the notice required by section 1137 of the general statutes (revision of 1930), on or before the twentieth day of September next following the making of any addition to the list of any person. (Sec. 1145, Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. Section 1137 Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1930), as amended, appear as § 12-53 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). Under § 86, 1952 Charter, as amended effective January 1, 1961, the assessors have been replaced by a department of assessments, under the direction of an assessor.  
Sec. 64. - Perfected lists and abstracts for public inspection in town of New Haven. 
The assessors of the town of New Haven shall, on or before the thirtieth day of September, lodge the lists in the town clerk's or assessors' office, and make and lodge the abstracts in the town clerk's office, in the manner prescribed by section 1141 of the general statutes (revision of 1930). (Sec. 1150 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. Section 1141 Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1930), as amended, appear as § 12-55 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). Under § 86, 1952 Charter, as amended effective January 1, 1961, the assessors have been replaced by a department of assessments, under the direction of an assessor.  
Sec. 65. - Taxation of traders and manufacturers in town of New Haven. 
The property of any trading, mercantile, manufacturing or mechanical business, in the town of New Haven, shall be assessed and valued in all respects as provided by section 1152 of the general statutes (revision of 1930); provided the average amount of goods kept on hand for sale during the year, or any portion of the year when the business has not been carried on for a year previous to the first day of June, shall be the rule of assessment and taxation in said town (Sec. 1215 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. Section 1152 Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1930), as amended, appears as § 12-58 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 66. - Sessions of board of relief in town of New Haven. 
(a)  The board of relief in the town of New Haven shall meet on the first business day of October, annually, and may adjourn from time to time to a day not later than the last business day of October, on or before which day said board shall complete the duties imposed upon it; and said board shall give notice of its meetings as prescribed by law. 
(b)  In addition to the regular members of the board of assessment appeals who are appointed by the mayor and serve three-year terms in accordance with Article XII, Section 65 of the Charter of the City of New Haven, the board of aldermen may appoint two additional members to the board of assessment appeals in any assessment year for which it deems such appointments are necessary or appropriate, as provided under Connecticut General Statutes Section 9-199 (c) as that section may be re-codified from time to time. Each additional member shall be nominated by a member of the board of aldermen and confirmed by the aldermanic affairs committee and by the full board of aldermen and shall serve for one assessment year. 
(Sec. 1231 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918; Ord. No. 1648, 4-4-11 ) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. Under Section 68 of the 1952 Charter, the board of relief has been replaced by the board of tax review.  
Sec. 67. - Appeals from assessors in town of New Haven. 
No appeal from the doings of the assessors in the town of New Haven, or application for deduction of indebtedness from the list of any debtor, shall be heard or entertained by the board of relief unless preferred to it at its meeting held on the first business day of October or at some adjourned meeting held within twenty days thereafter. (Sec. 1238 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. Under § 86, 1962 Charter, as amended effective January 1, 1961, the assessors have been replaced by a department of assessments, under the direction of an assessor.  
Sec. 68. - Tax liens in town of New Haven. 
The lien for taxes provided by section 1233 of the general statutes (revision of 1930) shall, as to real estate situated within the town of New Haven, exist from the first day of June in the year previous to that in which such taxes become due and precedence of such lien shall be determined as of the first day of June and not of the first day of October, but in all other respects as provided in said section. (Sec. 1301 Gen. Stats. Rev. 1918) 
Note— See note following § 61 of this compilation. Section 1233 Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1930), as amended, appears as § 12-172 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Secs. 69—74. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - HEALTH AND WELFARE 
 
Sec. 75. - Amendments to contracts between city and General Hospital Society authorized. 
(a)  The city of New Haven and the General Hospital Society of Connecticut are authorized to amend a certain contract entered into by and between said city and said General Hospital Society of Connecticut on the seventeenth day of June, 1910, as amended by agreement of the parties on December 12, 1912, for the purpose of providing and equipping a pavilion for the care and treatment of contagious diseases, for which purpose, under said contract, said city was authorized to issue bonds by act approved June 13, 1911, and said city and said hospital society may, in such amendment, provide for an increase in the rate to be paid by said city to said General Hospital Society of Connecticut for the care of any patient having a contagious disease, and the action of said city and said society in executing and adopting said amendment of December 12, 1912, is ratified and confirmed. 
(b)  The city of New Haven and The General Hospital Society of Connecticut are authorized to amend a certain contract entered into by and between said city and said The General Hospital Society of Connecticut on June 17, 1910, as amended by agreements of the parties dated December 12, 1912, and January 25, 1924, which contract as amended is for the purpose of providing and equipping a pavilion for the care and treatment of contagious diseases, for which purposes, under said contract, said city was authorized to issue bonds by an act approved June 13, 1911, and said city and said hospital society may, in such amendment, provide for an increase or decrease in the rates to be paid by said city to said The General Hospital Society of Connecticut for the care of patients under said contract as so amended, and the parties are further authorized to provide by further amendments from time to time for further increases if agreed upon between the parties. 
(Special Laws 1923, Act No. 9; Special Laws 1927, Act No. 116) 
Editor's note— The act of June 13, 1911, Special Laws 1911, Act No. 270, authorizing a bond issue, has been omitted from this compilation.  
Secs. 76—84. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PARKING AUTHORITY 
 
Sec. 85. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this act [article], "parking facility" shall mean and shall include lots, garages, parking terminals or other structures and accommodations for the parking of motor vehicles off the street or highway and open to public use with or without charge. "Parking authority" shall mean the authority established under section 2 hereof [section 262 of this compilation]. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 1)  
Sec. 86. - Parking authority created; membership; personnel; records and reports; cooperation of traffic engineer; requirements for valid action. 
There shall be in the city of New Haven a parking authority, which shall consist of five members appointed by the mayor, not more than three of whom shall be members of the same political party, and the traffic engineer of the city of New Haven. The first appointments to said parking authority shall be made on or before September 15, 1951. Those first appointed shall be designated to serve one, two, three, four and five years respectively from said date, and thereafter members shall be appointed annually to serve for five years, except that any vacancy shall be filled by the mayor for the unexpired term. Said authority shall select from among its members a chairman and may employ necessary personnel and shall have available as consultant the traffic engineer of the city of New Haven to the end that he shall coordinate the development and operation of off-street parking operations with the activities of the traffic authority. The members of the authority shall serve without compensation as such members but may be reimbursed for necessary expenses. No action of said authority shall be valid unless authorized by a vote of the majority of its members taken at a meeting open to the public. Said authority shall maintain proper accounting and financial records and shall make an annual report to the mayor. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 2; Special Laws 1955, Act No. 8, § 1)  
Sec. 87. - Construction, operation of parking facilities. 
Said parking authority shall have the power in the name of the municipality to acquire, construct, reconstruct, improve, operate and maintain parking facilities in accordance with the provisions of this act [article]. Subject to the specific authorization and approval of the board of aldermen, after said board has received the report of the city planning commission on the suitability for parking use of any proposed real property or interest therein for use as a parking facility, said parking authority shall have the power, in the name of the municipality to acquire by purchase, gift, devise, lease, exchange or other contract or by the exercise of the power of eminent domain, real property or any interest therein necessary for or incidental to the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, improvement, operation or maintenance of said parking facilities, provided said authority shall not be empowered to take by eminent domain any property from a corporation which has the right of eminent domain, and this act [article] shall not affect the powers of eminent domain of any such corporation. Upon the approval, as hereinafter provided, of the method or methods of financing, said parking authority shall prepare necessary plans and drawings; acquire, construct, reconstruct or improve or contract for the construction, reconstruction or improvement of parking facilities; maintain and operate parking facilities; establish and collect reasonable off-street parking fees; lease parking facilities to any individual, firm or corporation, upon such terms and conditions as the public interest may warrant. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 3; Special Laws 1955, Act No. 8, § 2; Special Laws 1959, Act No. 575, § 1)  
Sec. 88. - Financing of parking facilities. 
Said parking authority, subject to specific authorization and approval of the board of aldermen, is authorized to finance the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, improvement, operation and maintenance of parking facilities, including costs incidental thereto and further including in the case of revenue bonds, reserves required by the vote authorizing such revenue bonds, by any one or more of the following methods: 
(a)  General obligation bonds to be issued as provided in the New Haven city charter; 
(b)  Revenue bonds as provided in this act [article]; 
(c)  Parking fees and special charges derived from the use of parking facilities; 
(d)  Appropriations duly authorized from the general fund of the city; 
(e)  Assessment of benefits against the owners of real estate specifically benefited by any parking facility, whether or not such real estate abuts upon such parking facility. Such assessment shall be made by the bureau of compensation and approved by the board of aldermen in the same manner as is provided in the charter of the city of New Haven for the assessment of benefits and damages for public improvements; 
(f)  Gifts, bequests, devises, grants in aid or otherwise; 
(g)  On-street parking meter revenues. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 4; Special Laws 1955, Act No. 8, § 3) 
Charter reference— Hearings and assessments by board of compensation, § 95 of 1952 Revised Charter; approval by aldermen, § 96 of 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 89. - Revenue bonds for parking facilities. 
(a)  Authorized; form. The board of aldermen is authorized to provide for the issuance of revenue bonds of the city of New Haven to finance said parking facilities. Any such revenue bonds may be issued in part for the purpose of redeeming bonds of the authority or of the city heretofore issued to finance parking facilities of the authority or for the purpose of reimbursing the city for money advanced by the city to the authority. The bonds of each issue shall be dated, shall bear interest at such rate or rates not exceeding six per cent per annum, shall mature at such time or times not exceeding thirty years from their date and may be made redeemable before maturity at such price or prices and under such terms and conditions, as may be provided by the board of aldermen prior to the issuance of the bonds. The board of aldermen shall determine the form of the bonds, including any interest coupons to be attached thereto, and the manner of execution of the bonds and shall fix the denomination or denominations of the bonds and the place or places of payment of principal and interest, which may be at any bank or trust company within or without the state. All bonds issued under the provisions of this act shall be negotiable instruments within the meaning of the general statutes. Such bonds may be sold in such manner and for such price as said board may determine to be for the best interest of the city of New Haven, but no such sale shall be made at a price so low as to require the payment of interest on the money received therefor at more than six per cent per annum, computed with relation to the absolute maturity or maturities of the bonds in accordance with standard tables of bond values, excluding from such computation the amount of any premium to be paid on redemption of any bonds prior to maturity. 
(b)  Debt limitation. Bonds issued under the provisions of this section shall not be subject to the debt limitation prescribed by section 807 of the general statutes, as amended by section 275c of the 1953 supplement to the general statutes, [9] or to any other debt limitation applicable to the city of New Haven, and the obligation evidenced by such bonds shall not constitute an indebtedness of said city. 
(c)  Nature of obligation. Revenue bonds issued under the provisions of this act shall not constitute a pledge of the faith and credit of the city of New Haven. Said bonds and the interest thereon shall be payable solely from the income derived from said parking facilities and, to the extent and in the manner provided in the vote authorizing said bonds, revenues derived from on-street parking meters and appropriations from the general funds of the city of New Haven and such bonds shall contain on the face thereof a statement to that effect. 
(d)  Security. The vote authorizing the issuance of said revenue bonds shall pledge the revenues to be received from said parking facilities for which such bonds are issued. Such vote may also provide, subject to any agreement with bondholders, for the pledging of revenues from other parking facilities and for the pledging of on-street parking meter revenues. Such vote to further effectuate the provisions of this act may contain a covenant with bondholders to maintain substantially the existing on-street parking meters and to collect the fees imposed in connection therewith. Such vote may also contain a covenant with bondholders to make annual appropriations, in amounts to be determined or limited as provided in such vote, which appropriations shall be pledged to the payment of said bonds and the interest thereon as the same become due. Such vote may also provide for mortgaging such parking facilities as additional security, and may contain such provisions for protecting and enforcing the rights and remedies of the bondholders as may be reasonable and proper and not in violation of law, including covenants setting forth the duties of the city of New Haven, the board of aldermen and the parking authority in relation to the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, improvement, maintenance, operation and insurance of such parking facilities, and provisions for the establishment and maintenance of appropriate sinking funds and reserves, including use of a part of the bond proceeds therefor, for the custody, safeguarding and application of all moneys, and for the employment of necessary personnel. Except as otherwise provided in this act, the board of aldermen may provide for the payment of the proceeds of the sale of the bonds and the revenues of the parking facilities to such officer, bank, trust company or other fiscal agent as it may designate for the custody thereof, and for the method of disbursement thereof, with such restrictions as it may determine. All expenses incurred in carrying out the provisions of such vote shall be treated as a part of the cost of operation, provided any engineering, legal, advertising, printing or other cost incurred in relation to parking facilities which are to be financed by the issuance of revenue bonds may be paid from the proceeds of said revenue bonds. 
(e)  Other limitation. The vote providing for the issuance of revenue bonds may also contain such limitations upon the issuance of additional revenue bonds as the board of aldermen may deem proper. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 5; Special Laws 1955, Act No. 8, § 4; Special Laws 1967, Act No. 88, § 1) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Act No. 88, Special Laws 1967, amended Act No. 8, Special Laws 1955, § 4 (a), (c), (d), codified as § 89 hereof, to read as set out. 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Note— Section 807 of the 1949 General Statutes, as amended by § 275c of the 1953 Supplement thereto appears as § 7-374 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 
 
Sec. 90. - Establishment of rates, fees for facilities. 
The board of aldermen shall, in the vote providing for the issuance of revenue bonds, fix the initial schedule of rates, rentals, fees and other charges for the use of, and for the services and facilities furnished or to be furnished by each parking facility. After any parking facility has been in operation, the board of aldermen may revise such schedule of rates, rentals, fees and charges from time to time, subject to the provisions of any lease theretofore made by the parking authority and then in force. The parking authority shall charge and collect the rates, rentals, fees and charges fixed or revised. Such rates, rentals, fees and charges shall be so fixed and revised as to provide funds sufficient at all times: 
(a)  To pay the cost of maintaining, repairing and operating the parking facilities, including reserves for such purpose and for replacement and depreciation; 
(b)  To pay the principal of and the interest on the revenue bonds as the same become due and to provide reserves therefor; and 
(c)  To provide a margin of safety for making such payments. 
Nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prohibit the board of aldermen, in fixing such initial schedule or any revision thereof, to make due allowance for any on-street parking meter revenue or appropriations available for any of such purposes pursuant to the vote authorizing such revenue bonds. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 6; Special Laws 1955, Act No. 8, § 5; Special Laws 1967, Act No. 88, § 2) 
Editor's note— Act No. 88, Special Laws 1967, § 2, amended Act No. 8, Special Laws 1955, § 5, herein codified as § 90, by changing the last paragraph thereof to read as set out.  
Sec. 91. - Rights of bondholders to enforce by suit. 
Any holder of revenue bonds issued under the provisions of this act or any of the coupons appertaining thereto, except to the extent that the rights herein given may be restricted by the authorizing vote, may, either at law or in equity, by suit, action, mandamus or other proceeding, protect and enforce all his rights under the provisions of the general statutes or under such vote, and may enforce and compel the performance of all duties required by this act or by such ordinance to be performed by the city of New Haven, the board of aldermen, the parking authority or any officer thereof, including the fixing, charging and collecting of rates, rentals, fees and charges for the services and facilities furnished by the parking facility or parking facilities and the making of appropriations pledged to the payment of said bonds and the interest thereon. 
(Special Laws, 1951, Act No. 437, § 7; Special Laws 1967, Act No. 88, § 3) 
Editor's note— Act No. 88, Special Laws 1967, § 3 amended Act No. 473, § 7, Special Laws 1951 to read as set out.  
Sec. 92. - Exemption of bonds from state taxes. 
Revenue bonds issued under the provisions of this act [article], their transfer and the income therefrom, including any profit made on the sale thereof, shall at all times be free from taxation within the state. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 8)  
Sec. 93. - Parking facility funds declared in trust. 
All moneys received under the provisions of this act [article] shall be deemed to be trust funds, to be held and applied solely as provided in this act [article]. The vote authorizing the issuance of revenue bonds shall provide that any officer to whom, or bank, trust company or other fiscal agent to which, such moneys shall be paid shall act as trustee of such moneys and hold and apply the same for the purposes hereof, subject to such provisions as this act [article] and such vote may provide. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 9)  
Sec. 94. - Leasing of parking facilities. 
Said parking authority shall have the power in the name of the municipality to lease any and all lots, garages, parking terminals or other structures or accommodations for the parking of motor vehicles. Said authority shall also have the power to lease portions of the first floor of any parking structure or any portion of its real property rights, including air rights above or areas below any such structure not to be used for parking purposes, for commercial use where in the opinion of the authority such leasing is desirable or feasible in order to defray the expenses of the authority and thereby facilitate the erection of off-street parking structures. Any such lease of any portion of the first floor of any parking structure or any portion of real property rights, including air rights above or areas below any such structure not to be used for parking purposes, for commercial use, shall contain a provision whereby the lessee shall be obligated to make a payment in lieu of taxes to the city of New Haven for each portion of the property in the possession of the lessee. Such payment shall be based upon its assessed valuation as of June 1 of each year and shall be at the rate of the tax rate set by the board of aldermen for that year. Before making or executing any contract for the leasing of such parking facility to be used for parking purposes said parking authority shall give an opportunity for competitive bidding, under such rules and regulations as shall be provided by the ordinances of said city, unless said authority and the board of aldermen find that the marking or executing of a contract for the leasing of such parking facility without an opportunity for competitive bidding is in the public interest. In the absence of such a finding all such leases or contracts to lease shall be based on competitive bids and shall be awarded to the highest responsible bidder, provided the authority shall make a finding that the parking facility or facilities shall be self-liquidating. 
If the authority and the board of aldermen find that making or executing a contract to lease without the opportunity for competitive bidding is in the public interest and prior to making or executing a contract to lease any portion of any parking structure not required for parking purposes, said authority shall: 
(1)  Hold a public hearing thereon, notice of which shall be published at least twice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city of New Haven, the first publication of which notice to be not less than two weeks before the date set for the hearing, and 
(2)  Subsequent to said hearing submit said contract of lease to the board of aldermen of the city of New Haven for its approval. 
(Special Laws 1951, Act No. 473, § 10; Special Laws 1955, Act No. 8, § 6; Special Laws 1959, Act No. 575, § 2)  
Secs. 95—99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PARKS AND RECREATION[10] 

Footnotes:
