Charter reference— For provisions concerning the department of parks and recreation, see 1952 Revised Charter, §§ 130—139. 
 
Sec. 100. - Accepting as a public park the land and buildings in New Haven known as Fort Hale. 
The conveyance of the land, with buildings thereon, known as Fort Hale, in New Haven, by the United States of America to this state, dated November 24, 1922, is accepted, subject to the provisions, reservations and conditions contained in the deed conveying the same, and the city of New Haven is authorized, at the expense of said city, to control, care for and improve the same, subject to such provisions, reservations and conditions, for the purpose of a public park under the name of Nathan Hale Park. 
(Ch. 106 P.A. 1923) 
Editor's note— Section 100 above is derived from Public Acts 1923, Ch. 106, which was ordered deleted from the public acts and reprinted as a special law in the back of Vol. XXI, Part 1 Special Laws 1931 by Public Acts 1929, Ch. 258. Acts authorizing the acquisition or sale of particular park property have been omitted from this compilation at the direction of the city, but are noted in the disposition table which follows the compilation.  
Sec. 101. - New Haven Illuminating Co.—Grant of easements, rights of way etc. by park board authorized. 
The board of park commissioners of the city of New Haven or the city of New Haven is authorized to grant to The United Illuminating Company, which was incorporated under the name of "The New Haven Illuminating Company" by resolution approved June 15, 1899, and to its successors and assigns, such perpetual easements, privileges and rights-of-way, with respect to park lands located on the east side of New Haven Harbor, as may be necessary, appropriate or convenient to extend any electric transmission line from and to New Haven Harbor to and from lands on the east side of New Haven Harbor now owned by said The United Illuminating Company and The Connecticut Light and Power Company. 
(Special Laws 1963, Act No. 269, § 1) 
Editor's note— Act No. 269, Special Laws 1963, has been codified as §§ 101 and 102 in the discretion of the editors.  
Sec. 102. - Same—Erection of poles, wires etc. for transmission of electricity subject to approval of city; limitation. 
The United Illuminating Company, for the purposes of conducting and transmitting electricity and adapting the same to the use of its customers pursuant to the rights, powers and privileges granted to it under its charter and the amendments thereto and acquired by it by purchase or consolidation or merger, shall have the right, subject to any requisite approval of any town, city or borough or other public authority having jurisdiction, to erect, lay, maintain and operate poles, towers, wires, conduits, cables, fixtures and other structures and apparatus of every kind either overhead or underground, over or under any waters of this state and in, over, under and upon the public highways, streets and grounds in any town, city or borough within the state; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to enlarge or diminish the territory within which the company is franchised to sell electricity. 
(Special Laws 1963, Act No. 269, § 2) 
Note— See editor's note following § 101.  
Secs. 103—109. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC WORKS, IMPROVEMENTS AND UTILITIES 
 
Sec. 110. - Operation of Tomlinson bridge by state authorized. 
(1)  The highway commission is authorized to maintain and operate as a part of the trunk line system of highways the Tomlinson bridge over the Quinnipiac river in the city of New Haven on United States route number 1. 
(2)  The personnel who are operating said bridge for the city of New Haven at such time as the highway commissioner assumes jurisdiction over the bridge shall be certified to the highway commissioner by the director of personnel as eligible appointees under the merit act for operation of the bridge. 
(Special Laws 1941, Act No. 380, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 111. - Water contract and stipulation declared obligatory. 
(1)  The terms of a certain contract entered into by and between the city of New Haven and the New Haven Water Company on the seventeenth day of February, 1902, concerning the supplying of water for the use of said city and its inhabitants, be and they are hereby made obligatory upon the said city of New Haven and the said New Haven Water Company as though specifically authorized in their respective charters. 
(2)  A certain stipulation executed and delivered by the New Haven Water Company to the city of New Haven on the seventeenth day of February, 1902, concerning the construction of the contract referred to in section one [subsection (1)] hereof, is hereby made obligatory upon the said New Haven Water Company whenever said city shall exercise its option to claim the construction, or any part thereof, in said stipulation particularly set forth. 
(Special Laws 1903, Act No. 335, §§ 1, 2) 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1903, Act No. 335, from which § 111 above is derived, is declared a part of the 1952 Revised Charter by § 294 thereof.  
Sec. 112. - Granting of right of way authorized. 
The city of New Haven is authorized, upon approval of its mayor and upon vote of its board of aldermen, to grant a right of way for all highway purposes, including public utilities, to property owners abutting the easterly side of Amrhyn road sometimes called Park road, in the town of Hamden, said Amrhyn road being a parcel of land fifty feet in perpendicular width running southerly from Ridge road, in said town of Hamden, to the public highway known as Park road, in said town of Hamden. Said city is further authorized upon approval of its mayor and upon vote of its board of aldermen, to take any and all steps necessary to turn said Amrhyn road over to the town of Hamden for the use of the same as a public highway under the absolute control and jurisdiction of said town of Hamden. Said city is further authorized, upon approval of its mayor and upon vote of its board of aldermen, to take any and all steps necessary to turn over to said town of Hamden for use as a public highway the land known as Farm road, being a parcel of land fifty feet in perpendicular width running westerly from State street, in said town of Hamden, to said Park road. The lands which are the subject of this act are at the time of the passage of this act used as a public park, and the authority herein granted is given subject to the provision that such authority be exercised only with the approval of the commission of public parks for the city of New Haven, and upon such terms as said commission of public parks may, in the public interest, deem it wise to impose. 
(Special Laws 1955, Act No. 23)  
Sec. 113. - Hamden authorized to connect with New Haven sewers. 
The town of Hamden is authorized to dispose of the sewage and drainage of said town by connecting any sewer, drain, system or systems of sewers or drains, that has been or may hereafter be constructed and maintained by the town, with any sewer, drain, system or systems of sewers or drains, that has been or may hereafter be constructed and maintained by the city of New Haven, and by discharging such sewage and drainage into and through any sewer, drain system or systems of sewers or drains, operated and maintained by the city of New Haven; but no such disposal of the sewage and drainage of the town shall be made until said town shall have first obtained the consent of the city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1919, Act No. 45, § 1)  
Sec. 114. - Sewage, drainage disposal contracts between Hamden, New Haven authorized. 
Said town of Hamden is authorized to contract with the city of New Haven and the city of New Haven is authorized to contract with the town of Hamden, for the purpose of disposing of the sewage and drainage of the town of Hamden in the manner provided in section one [section 113 of this compilation] of this act, which contract or contracts shall be in writing and shall stipulate the compensation to be paid by the town to the city of New Haven for the right to make such disposal of its sewage and drainage. No such contract shall become effective or binding upon either the town of Hamden or the city of New Haven until the same has been approved by a majority of the voters voting thereon at a meeting of said town of Hamden, which meeting shall be warned and held for that purpose, and until the same has been approved by a majority vote of all the members of the board of aldermen and by the mayor of said city in accordance with the provisions of the charter of said city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1919, Act No. 45, § 2)  
Sec. 115. - Hamden, New Haven authorized to acquire certain rights, privileges, related to sewers. 
The city of New Haven and the town of Hamden are authorized to acquire from each other all the necessary rights and privileges to connect any sewer or system or systems of sewers, and for the use of sewer mains and appurtenances, pressure mains, pumping stations and apparatus, sewage disposal plants and all other such sewage collection and disposal facilities that have been or may be constructed, operated and maintained by either municipality. 
(Special Laws 1927, Act No. 323, § 1)  
Sec. 116. - Contracts between New Haven, Hamden concerning acquisition of sewer rights, privileges. 
Said city of New Haven is authorized to contract with the town of Hamden, and said town of Hamden is authorized to contract with the city of New Haven, for the purposes of obtaining any or all of the rights and privileges provided for in section one of this act [section 115 of this compilation], which contract or contracts, when and as made, shall be in writing and shall stipulate the compensation or basic rates thereof or the shares of construction costs to be paid by either municipality to the other. No such contract shall become effective or binding upon either the city of New Haven or the town of Hamden, until approved by a majority of all members of the board of aldermen and by the mayor of the city of New Haven in accordance with the provisions of the charter of said city, and until the same shall have been approved by a majority of the voters thereon at a meeting of said town, which meeting shall be warned and held for that purpose. 
(Special Laws 1927, Act No. 323, § 2)  
Sec. 117. - Municipal airport—Acquisition, operation authorized. 
The city of New Haven is authorized to establish and maintain an airport within the limits of said city and the town of East Haven and to acquire property as a site for such airport, either by purchase or by condemnation proceedings under the provisions of the general statutes. 
(Special Laws 1927, Act No. 267, § 1; Special Laws 1929, Act No. 266, § 1)  
Sec. 118. - Same—Issuance of bonds for. 
Said city is authorized, from time to time, as shall be deemed advisable by its board of finance, to issue bonds, for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of section one [section 117 of this compilation], to an amount not exceeding five hundred thousand dollars. Such bonds shall be denominated, "Airport Bonds of the City of New Haven", shall be registered or with coupons attached, shall bear interest at a rate not greater than five per centum per annum, payable semiannually, and shall be issued in serial form, payable, as consecutively numbered, in such equal amounts each year, beginning not more than two years after their date, that the whole amount thereof shall be paid within a time not exceeding thirty years from their date. Subject to the provisions of this section, such bonds shall be of such denomination, payable at such time or times and prepared, signed and authenticated as the board of finance of said city shall determine. 
The amount of the bonds issued under the provisions of this act [sections 117 through 119 of this compilation], with the amount of the outstanding indebtedness of said city, shall not exceed, exclusive of the amount of bonds issued for water supply and of notes or other evidences of indebtedness placed in the sinking fund of said city, five per centum of the grand list of said city. 
(Special Laws 1927, Act No. 267, §§ 2, 3; Special Laws 1929, Act No. 226, § 2)  
Sec. 119. - Same—Use of park property authorized. 
Said city may use property acquired for park purposes for the purposes of an airport, provided a majority of the commission of public parks shall vote in favor of such use. 
(Special Laws 1927, Act No. 267, § 4)  
Sec. 120. - Overhead transmission lines—Board of Aldermen review. 
No overhead electric transmission lines and towers shall be allowed hereafter in the City of New Haven, except as follows: 
A public service company may petition the board of aldermen for approval of an overhead transmission line and tower proposal by filing with the city clerk detailed plans including a rendering of the proposed construction, together with a written application describing in full the compliance with the standards for review which are described below. The city clerk shall refer the applications and plans to the appropriate committee of the board of aldermen for a public hearing thereon after at least two (2) week's public notice. The board of aldermen shall obtain from the city plan commission an advisory report on the proposal, which report shall be available at the time of the public hearing. 
The board of aldermen shall approve the petition only upon specific findings that 
(a)  the proposed plans and application are in accordance with the public convenience and welfare, after taking into account the impact of such proposal upon neighboring uses in the surrounding area compared with the public need for the proposal at the particular location, 
(b)  the effect on present and future development of neighboring properties including existing redevelopment plans or foreseeable redevelopment and reclamation plans, 
(c)  the proximity of dwellings, churches, schools, public buildings and other places of public gathering, 
(d)  the environmental impact of the proposed action, 
(e)  any adverse environmental effects which cannot be avoided should the proposal be implemented, 
(f)  alternatives to the proposed action, 
(g)  the relationship between local short term uses of the city environment and the maintenance and enhancement of long term productivity, 
(h)  any irreversible commitments of resources which would be involved in the proposed action should it be implemented, 
(i)  effect on the comprehensive plan of the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. of 12-7-70) 
Editor's note— The ordinance of Dec. 7, 1970, amended Art. VIII by adding § 120 thereto.  
ARTICLE IX. - RETIREMENT PLAN FOR CITY EMPLOYEES[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Art. IX is derived from an ordinance enacted and effective Dec. 1 and approved Dec. 8, 1969, which ordinance in its title states it is amendatory of Special Act 379 of 1965, previously codified as Art. IX, §§ 130—149, and in turn amendatory of Act 397 of 1939. In view of the fact the manner of amendment was not specified, and the fact the ordinance is a total new regulation of the subject of retirement, said ordinance has been codified as effectively superseding Act 397 of 1939, as amended by Act 379 of 1965, at the discretion of the editors. Nature and extent of the changes effected, renders detailed analysis impractical. As previously codified, Art. IX was derived from the following Special Acts in addition to Act 397 of 1939 and Act 379 of 1965: Act 418 of 1941, Act 248 of 1947, Act 456 of 1957, Act 326 of 1961 and Act 389 of 1963; also codified as part of said Art. IX was an ordinance enacted Oct. 23, approved Oct. 27, effective Oct. 1, 1967. 
Special Act 397 of 1939 contained provisions parallel to those in §§ 271—290 of the Revised Charter, hence amendments to said Act 397 operated to effectively supersede said Charter sections. 
Prior provisions concerning retirement of city employees are also contained in Special Act 449 of 1931, which failed to gain approval of the board of aldermen as required by § 16 thereof; and Special Act 66 of 1937 as amended by Special Act 564 of 1937, which Acts were expressly repealed by Special Act 397 of 1939. 
Cross reference— Pensions for former mayors, § 159; custodians and engineers employed after Jan. 1, 1948, declared subject to city employees' retirement fund rather than custodians' and engineers' retirement fund, § 161. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL INFORMATION 
 
Sec. 121. - General definitions. 
As used in this plan the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
The fund or said fund means the City of New Haven City Employees' Retirement Fund; 
The city or said city means the City of New Haven; 
The board of finance, treasurer and the city-town clerk mean, respectively, such board or officer of said city; 
Eligible employee or officer means any general fund or water pollution control authority of the City of New Haven full-time employee or paid full-time officer, elected or appointed, of said city, or person regularly employed by the department of education for services in a cafeteria or restaurant operated by a public school, except and employee or officer receiving benefits from or eligible for participation in any of the other Pension or Retirement Funds of the City or State of Connecticut; 
Member of said fund means an eligible employee or officer who contributes to said fund, or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service; 
Conditional member means a terminated employee who has ceased to contribute to the fund but who has retained eligibility rights for a deferred pension; 
He or his means "he" or "she" or "his" or "hers," as may be appropriate; 
The pay of a member means all compensation for services and includes living quarters or maintenance, or both, at such figures as may be determined by said board, but shall not include allowance for a motor vehicle or other transportation; 
Except as otherwise provided in Articles II through VIII [Divisions 2 through 8], as amended, a "year," in calculating the period of service necessary to qualify for retirement, means a complete successive year from the beginning of service during which at least nine months' compensation has been earned; 
Said board or the board means the retirement board created pursuant to the provisions of this plan. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 1; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 122. - Retirement fund; assets; administration. 
There is established a fund to be known as the "City of New Haven City Employees' Retirement Fund" for the benefit of the members as defined in this plan. Said fund shall consist of: 
(1)  All appropriations, gifts, or bequests made to the fund from public or private sources for the purpose for which said retirement fund is established; 
(2)  All contributions by participating members; and 
(3)  All assets of the city employees' retirement fund of said city heretofore created by an act approved April 28, 1937, and subsequent amendment thereof. 
The treasurer of said city shall be the treasurer of said fund. The retirement board shall be the trustee thereof and have full control and management of all its securities and assets, with power to invest and reinvest the same in accordance with the provisions of the general statutes governing the investment of trust funds. Said board may, by written certificate, approved by the controller and accepted by the appointee and filed with the city-town clerk, appoint an incorporated bank or trust company doing business in said city as financial agent of said controller for such period as said controller may decide. 
Such appointee shall be, until otherwise ordered by said board, the receiving and disbursing agent of said board and said fund. Said board may turn over to such appointee the custody and possession of all or any part of the assets of said fund to hold for and on account of said board for such time as said board may decide. For such services rendered by such appointee, reasonable compensation shall be approved by said board and paid to such appointee out of income of said fund, All annuities and all re-payments under this plan, and under any amendment hereof, shall be paid from said fund. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 2; Amd. of 7-6-87; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 123. - Retirement board. 
The retirement fund shall be administered by a retirement board of seven (7) members as follows: The mayor and controller of said city, ex officio, three (3) persons appointed by the mayor, and two (2) members of the fund nominated and elected by members of the fund (no more than one of which at any time shall be from the same collective bargaining unit). The terms of appointed and elected members of the retirement board shall be three (3) years, beginning on January first, the term. of one expiring at the end of each year. A member of the retirement board shall serve until his successor is named and has qualified, and the mayor shall make such appointments to the retirement board as may be necessary to fill vacancies occurring during the term, except a vacancy in the positions of member representatives which shall be filled by the members of the fund. No member of the retirement board shall incur any liability for any act, done or omitted in the exercise of his duty, except due to his own willful misconduct and/or lack of good faith. The retirement fund shall indemnify and hold harmless each member of the retirement fund for any and all claims or liabilities asserted against him by reason of his status as a member of the retirement board, except those claims or liabilities occasioned by his own willful misconduct and/or lack of good faith. 
The retirement board shall submit annually to the mayor of the City of New Haven a schedule of estimated appropriations of money necessary for the administration of this plan; and shall receive, control, manage and expend according to the provisions of this plan all of said fund, including any monies contributed by employees; and shall invest and reinvest all of said fund in accordance with the provisions of the general statutes governing trust funds. Said mayor shall determine the eligibility of a member of the retirement fund and his rights under this plan; shall make bylaws and regulations not inconsistent with law for the administration of this plan; shall hire and dismiss any employees necessary for the proper administration of this plan and fix their compensation and shall engage expert actuarial, legal, auditing, investment and medical service when, in the judgement of the retirement board, it shall be advisable. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 3; Amd. of 12-1-75; Amd. of 7-6-87; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 124. - Payment by city. 
The City of New Haven shall pay to the retirement board such amounts to fund the benefits provided by this article as shall be determined by the retirement board based on sound actuarial principles. For each fiscal year, the city's payments shall be a percentage of the estimated total payroll of all participating members of the retirement fund. The city's payment shall also include the total administrative and other expenses of the retirement fund for each year. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 4; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 125. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Sept. 23, 1998, provided for the deletion of § 125, Annual reports of retirement board, derived from an ordinance adopted Dec. 1, 1969, Art. I, § 5, as amended July 6, 1987.  
Sec. 126. - Exemption of fund and benefits from taxation, attachment, execution, etc.; fund and benefits declared unassignable. 
The rights of any person under the provisions of this plan to any payment from said fund and said fund, itself, shall be exempt from any state, municipal, transfer or inheritance tax and shall not be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution and shall be unassignable. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 6; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 127. - Limitations of actions. 
No action for any amount due under the provisions of this plan shall be brought but within two years after the right of action accrues. Any person legally incapable of bringing an action when the right accrues may sue at any time within the two years next after he becomes legally capable to institute suit. All amounts not claimed within said period shall remain absolutely a part of said fund. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 7; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 128. - Effect of worker's compensation. 
Any member receiving payments under the Worker's Compensation Act shall not, at the same time, receive an annuity provided by the retirement fund, except to the extent that such annuity for each month exceeds the worker's compensation benefit payable for the same month. If payment of an award or stipulation under the Worker's Compensation Act has been made and the time covered by such award or stipulation has ended, the member may thereafter receive annuities under the retirement fund to the extent that he is otherwise qualified to participate in the retirement fund at the time. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 8; Amd. of 12-1-75; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 129. - Accounts and reserves. 
The retirement board shall maintain proper accounts and actuarial reserves for all benefits provided by this plan. These actuarial reserves shall include the following items: 
(1)  A reserve to cover future payments on retirement annuities granted due to age and service; 
(2)  A reserve to cover future payments on annuities granted due to disability; 
(3)  A reserve to cover future payments of benefits granted to survivors; and 
(4)  The balance representing the remainder of the accumulated contributions made by the members and by the city, to be held as a reserve for benefits accruing in future years in accordance with the provisions of this plan. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 9; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 130. - Actuarial valuation. 
A complete valuation shall be made periodically (but at least every fifth year by a qualified actuary in order to determine the amount of the reserve prescribed in section 9 [129] of this article and the city's contributions prescribed in sections 2 and 4 [122 and 124] of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 10; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 131. - Cost-of-living adjustment. 
Effective after December 1, 1969, the monthly amounts of those service and disability annuities payable to members who retired to January 1, 1968, and the monthly benefits payable to the qualified survivors of these members who died prior to January 1, 1968, shall be increased by cost-of-living adjustments which will approximately reflect the percentage increase in the federal Consumer Price Index between the calendar year when the payments commenced in each case and the calendar year 1968. The amount of increase for each case will be determined by multiplying the monthly payment by the appropriate percentage increase set forth in the following table, except for cases where the monthly payment is for the minimum amount of $83.33 (or $1,000.00 annual) or for lesser amounts: 
Year payments commenced 	% of increase 	Year payments commenced 	% of increase 	Year payments commenced 	% of increase 
1968 	0.0 	1959 	19.4 	1950 	44.6 
1967 	4.2 	1958 	20.4 	1949 	46.0 
1966 	7.2 	1957 	23.7 	1948 	44.6 
1965 	10.3 	1956 	28.0 	1947 	56.6 
1964 	12.1 	1955 	29.9 	1946 	78.2 
1963 	13.6 	1954 	29.5 	1945 	93.3 
1962 	15.0 	1953 	30.0 	1944 	97.7 
1961 	16.3 	1952 	31.1 	1943 	101.0 
1960 	17.6 	1951 	33.9 	1942 	113.4 
 
For any case with monthly payments of the minimum amount of $83.33 or less, the amount of increase will be determined by multiplying the smaller annuity which would have been provided by the regular benefit provisions, before increase to the minimum amount, by the appropriate percentage of increase from the above table. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 11; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 132. - Membership classification. 
Articles II and VIII [Divisions 2 through 8] set forth additional provisions which apply specifically to the various classes of members of this pension plan. When a member's eligibility status changes from one class to another, he will automatically become covered by the provisions of the division which covers his new classification. His continuous service period and years of credited membership and/or years of credited service, as the case may be, will not be broken or diminished by reason of such change. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. I, § 12; Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 132.1. - Optional transfer of pension credits in event a member changes to, or from, permanent employment covered by the policemen and firemen's pension fund. 
In the event of such change of employment within the City of New Haven, the member can elect that the period of prior service for which he made contributions to the first fund shall be included in determining the amount of his pension benefits under the second fund to which he has transferred his participation. Such transfer of cash between the funds equal to the actuarial reserve for his participating service in the first fund, including both the employee's and the city's contributions therefor, and all rights to pension or other benefits under the first fund will be terminated by such transfer. 
(Amd. of 12-1-75; Amd. of 7-6-87) 
Editor's note— The amendments of Dec. 1, 1975 specifically amended the city employees retirement fund provisions pertaining to all bargaining units by adding § 13 which, in order to conform to existing style and at the discretion of the editor, has been redesignated § 132.1 as herein set out. Said section was enacted Dec. 1, 1975, approved by the mayor Dec. 5, 1975 and became effective Jan. 1, 1976.  
Sec. 132.2. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  In the event the fund merges or consolidates with, or there is a transfer of assets or liabilities to any other plan or trust, each member would (if the fund then terminated) receive a benefit immediately after the merger, consolidation or transfer which is equal to or greater than the benefit he would have been entitled to receive immediately before the merger, consolidation or transfer (if the fund had then terminated). 
(b)  Participation under the fund will not give any member any right or claim except to the extent such right is specifically fixed under the terms of the fund and there are fund available therefor. 
(c)  If the fund is terminated or if there shall be a complete discontinuance of the contributions under the fund, the assets held in the fund available for payment after provisions for payment of all expenses of final liquidation or termination shall be allocated pursuant to the direction of the board on the basis of actuarial valuations to the extent of the sufficiency of such assets for the purpose of providing retirement benefits determined by the fund to have accrued under the fund to the date of termination of the fund. The allocation of the available assets in the fund shall be in the manner and order described in the following paragraphs. If the amounts available shall be insufficient for a complete allocation in accordance with any paragraph, such amounts shall be allocated in a uniform manner to all persons in the group mentioned in such paragraph and no allocation shall be made under any subsequent paragraph. 
(1)  First, toward the payment of that portion of a member's benefit earned to date derived from his contributions (after reduction for annuity payments), whether to the contributing members, their survivors or beneficiaries. 
(2)  Second, an amount shall be allocated, which when added to the amount indicated in paragraph (1), will be sufficient to provide retirement benefits to all persons who were receiving benefits on the date of termination of the fund and members remaining in the employ of the city who have reached their normal retirement date. 
(3)  Third, an amount shall be allocated, which when added to the amount indicated in paragraph (1), will be sufficient to provide retirement benefits for members still in the service of the city who were eligible to retire on an early retirement date. 
(4)  Fourth, an amount shall be allocated, which when added to the amount indicated in paragraph (1), will be sufficient to provide benefits earned to date by those members who have earned ten (10) years of credited service (but are not identified in paragraphs (2) or (3)). 
(5)  Fifth, amounts then remaining shall be allocated to provide benefits for all members no provided for above. 
Amounts allocated in accordance with (1) through (5), above, may be applied in the discretion of the board to provide benefits through the purchase of paid-up annuities on an individual or group basis, through allocation of reserves within the then existing fund and/or under a separate trust instrument or through participation in any other retirement plan or by any combination of these alternative or other means. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87) 
Editor's note— The amendments of July 6, 1987, which amended Article IX, retirement plan for city employees, Division 1 (referred to as "Article I" in the amendment), general information, added new provisions designated as § 14 thereto, which, in order to conform to the numbering system used herein, have been redesignated as § 132.2, at the discretion of the editor. Said section was enacted July 6, 1987, approved by the mayor July 13, 1987, and became effective July 23, 1987.  
DIVISION 2. - PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED BY LOCAL 884 OF THE AMERICAN FEDERATION OF STATE, COUNTY AND MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 133. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
Local 884 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees or Local 884 member(s) means all of the full-time employees, of the City of New Haven, for whom Local 884 or its successor has a legal responsibility to represent according to Public Act 159, as amended, of the State of Connecticut 1965 General Assembly. Employees holding positions under new classifications, which shall come under the representation of Local 884 or its successor in the future, shall also accrue the terms and benefits of this division. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 1)  
Sec. 134. - Determination of contributions of participating members. 
The rate of contributions shall be five per cent (5%) of pay, said percentage to be deducted from each eligible participating member's pay and transmitted to said board. Computation of the average rate for use in determining benefits under this division shall be based on the employee's basic rate of pay except that total earnings including overtime if greater, will be used for any year when his contributions were based on such larger amount. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 2)  
Sec. 135. - Provision for refund of contributions or deferred pensions for members withdrawing from service; provision for refund of contributions upon death of member with no qualified survivors; effect of discontinuance of fund; nature of member's interest in fund. 
Withdrawal of contributions of a member shall not be permitted except in the event of discontinuance of employment. In the event of such discontinuance, the retirement board shall pay, upon request, to the member or to his representative, designated or otherwise, an amount equal to his total contributions to the retirement fund. 
In the event of discontinuance after ten (10) or more years of continuous service, and provided he does not qualify for greater benefits under the provisions of section 138, any terminating member who does not request a refund of his contributions will be retained as a conditional member and will be eligible for a deferred pension commencing when he attains age sixty-five (65). Such deferred pension shall be for an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the conditional member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his participating total service in the fund, subject to a maximum of seventy per cent (70%) of such average rate of pay. Such conditional member and his survivors will not be eligible for any disability, survivorship or other benefits which are provided for regular members by other sections of this division. 
In the event of a member's or a conditional member's death, the retirement board shall pay to his beneficiary, or to his estate if no named beneficiary is surviving, an amount equal to the excess, if any, of his total contributions over the total of any annuity payments made to him. 
In the event that a regular member is survived by a qualified widow or child or children under age eighteen (18), the retirement board shall, in lieu of such repayment of contributions, pay the survivorship benefits provided in section 139 of this division. If the total benefit payments to such member and his surviving widow and children shall be less than the amount of his total contributions, the amount of any excess shall be paid to the legal representative of the last survivor who received benefits. 
In the event of the discontinuance of the retirement fund, each member and conditional member shall be paid an amount equal to his total contributions less any annuity payments made to him. 
In no event shall a member or a conditional member have a vested interest in the funds of the retirement system, in the amount, or any portion thereof, of the contributions of the city, or in any contribution except his own. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 3; Amd. of 12-1-75)  
Sec. 136. - Eligibility for retirement. 
(a)  Any male member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty-five years; but, at the age of seventy years (sixty-five years if he became a participating member after September 1, 1967) his retirement shall be mandatory. 
(b)  Any female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty years (sixty-five years if she became a participating member after September 1, 1967); but, at the age of seventy years (sixty-five years if she became a member after September 1, 1967) her retirement shall be mandatory. 
(c)  After June 30, 1973 any male or female member who has completed thirty (30) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty (60) years. 
(d)  Any member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement on account of total permanent disability according to the provisions of section 137. 
(e)  "Continuous service" for the purposes of this division, shall mean uninterrupted service or employment, but absence from service or employment for any reason, followed by reinstatement within one year thereafter shall not be considered as breaking the continuity of the service. In the case of absence from said service or employment for more than one year, the retirement board shall determine the period within which the member may return without breaking the continuity of his service or employment. 
(f)  Reinstatement of such member's prior participating service in the retirement fund shall be conditioned upon such medical examination as the retirement board may prescribe, and upon payment to the retirement fund of contributions previously withdrawn with three (3) per cent interest compounded annually. Application for such reinstatement shall be made within six (6) months after his return to employment. 
(g)  In computing years of service to determine eligibility for retirement, no year shall be included in which the member has not been in actual service for at least nine (9) months. 
(h)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) through (g) of this section, veterans of the U.S. armed forces shall be granted credit toward the computation of their years of service to be eligible for city retirement pension for up to four years served in active duty in the U.S. armed forces. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 4; Amd. of 4-26-72; Amd. of 12-1-75; Amd. of 12-17-90, § 1)  
Sec. 137. - Disability annuities. 
Any member of the retirement fund who, after ten (10) years of continuous service for the city, is permanently disabled from performing duties of the nature required by his job shall be entitled to an annuity to be granted on the basis of the completed years of service, provided proof of such disability shall be submitted to the retirement board, which shall cause examinations to be made by at least two impartial medical examiners. The retirement board may, from time to time, call for similar medical evidence that the member continues to be permanently disabled and such member shall be required to submit himself to any medical examination requested by the retirement board. If the retirement board, upon competent medical evidence, concludes that the disability for which the member is receiving an annuity no longer exists, said board shall thereupon order a discontinuance of all such annuities payable to such member and he shall thereafter be entitled to any benefits for which he is eligible to receive as provided for in section 135. If such disability is shown to the satisfaction of the board to have arisen out of and in the course of his employment by the city as defined by the workmen's compensation act, a member of the fund shall be eligible for retirement irrespective of the duration of his employment. This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 138.1 for any member whose annuity is approved by the retirement board with an effective date later than June 30, 1973. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 5; Amd. of 4-26-72)  
Sec. 138. - Retirement and disability benefits. 
(a)  For employees retiring by reason of age and service or by reason of disability, the retirement board shall pay to each eligible member an annuity for life in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service; provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of his average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service. Such annuity shall be paid monthly at the rate of one-twelfth of the annual amount so determined. A minimum annual pension of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or eighty per cent (80%) of the employee's annual rate of pay at the time of his retirement, whichever is smaller, is hereby established for present and future annuities. Any pension payable by reason of disability arising out of and in the course of employment as defined in the workmen's compensation act or arising after the completion of ten (10) years of continuous service, provided such disability was not incurred as the result of any other gainful employment, shall not be less than one-half of the member's annual rate of pay at the time of disability. This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 138.1 for any member whose annuity is approved by the retirement board with an effective date later than June 30, 1973. 
(b)  Any member who is not otherwise eligible to receive a retirement allowance under the provisions of this section and who, after reaching the age of fifty-five years and being a member of the retirement fund at the time, and after at least fifteen (15) years of continuous service, is obliged to retire involuntarily from such service, which involuntary retirement is not due to malfeasance or misfeasance in office, shall receive an annual retirement allowance equal to forty per cent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service, plus two per cent (2%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service for each full year of service in excess of fifteen (15) years but in no event more than fifty per cent (50%) of his annual rate of pay for said last five (5) years of his service. This provision shall apply to any person retired on or after January 1, 1957, provided such person makes written application to the retirement board within one year after such involuntary retirement. 
(c)  A member who qualifies for benefits under subsection (b) and who has at least twenty-five (25) years of service may elect an alternative benefit in the form of an annuity for life commencing at age sixty-five (65) for male members and age sixty (60) for female members, or upon qualification for a disability annuity according to the provisions of this division, in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service, provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of such average annual rate of pay and provided the member may elect to have said alternative form of annuity commence at any earlier age after the age of fifty-five (55), but in such event the amount of annuity will be reduced so as to be equivalent in present value to the annuity payable at the age of sixty-five (65) on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for determining actuarial reserves for the retirement fund. 
(d)  Early retirement option prior to July 1, 1973: Any active member who has completed twenty (20) years of continuous service may elect to receive a reduced early retirement annuity to commence at any time after he has attained his sixtieth birthday. The reduced amount of such early retirement annuity shall be actuarially equivalent to the full retirement annuity normally payable commencing at a later date when he would have first attained the regular eligibility age for retirement in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of section 136, and shall be determined by the retirement board on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for actuarial valuations of the retirement fund. 
(e)  Early retirement option after June 30, 1973: Any active member may elect early retirement on any date which is ten (10) or less years prior to the date on which he would first become eligible for normal retirement as prescribed in subsections (a), (b) or (c) of section 136. In such event his annuity, as determined by subsection (a) of this section 138, shall be reduced in amount by four (4) per cent for each full year by which his early retirement date precedes his earliest eligibility date for normal retirement with a further proportionate reduction for any fraction of a year. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 6; Amd. of 4-26-72)  
Sec. 138.1. - Additional conditions for all disability annuities approved to commence after June 30, 1973. 
Any disability annuity which is approved by the retirement board with an effective commencement date later than June 30, 1973 shall be subject to adjustment on account of the member's earnings from employment or self-employment of any kind, and his pension shall be discontinued unless he files with the retirement board annually before April 30th a sworn statement of such earnings for the preceding calendar year as shown in his federal income tax return. The reduction in his disability annuity shall equal fifty (50) per cent of any excess of his earnings in the preceding calendar year over the sum of one thousand eight hundred dollars ($1,800.00) and such deduction shall be spread evenly over twelve (12) months, starting with the payment due on April 30th. No such adjustments for earnings shall be made after the disabled member attains the age of sixty-five. For anyone of these members whose period of credited membership shall have commenced after his fortieth birthday, the amount payable as a disability annuity (before adjustment for earnings) shall be limited to a percentage of his annual rate of pay at the time of disability; this percentage is to be determined by multiplying two (2) per cent by the number of years of membership which he could have accumulated up to his sixty-fifth birthday if he were able to continue his employment for the city until that date. 
(Amd. of 4-26-72) 
Editor's note— The amendments of April 26, 1972 specifically amended the city employees retirement fund provisions pertaining to Local 884 by adding new § 7 which, in order to conform to existing style and at the discretion of the editor, has been redesignated as § 138.1 as herein set out.  
Sec. 139. - Survivorship benefits. 
(a)  Upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has participated in the retirement fund for a period of not less than six (6) months or who had been retired by reason of age and service, or by reason of disability, there shall be paid to or on account of his or her surviving child or children under eighteen years of age, and, in the case of a male member, to his qualified widow, monthly benefits consistent with the following table: 
_____

_____
Any such widow, on her remarriage, shall receive only such benefits as are payable to her children alone. 
(b)  "Average annual pay," as used in computing survivorship benefits shall mean the average annual rate of pay received by the deceased member for the final five (5) years of his service or employment by the city, or the duration of such service or employment if less than five (5) years, subject to a maximum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) for such average annual pay. 
(c)  Upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service, a minimum monthly benefit will be paid to his qualified survivors if greater than the amount determined from the benefit table above. Said minimum monthly benefit shall be equal to fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of the monthly annuity to which the member would have been entitled if he had been permanently disabled on the date of his death, or fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of his actual monthly annuity in the case of a member who has been receiving retirement or disability benefits from the fund. The minimum monthly benefit when payable to a qualified widow without qualified child or children in her care shall be further reduced in amount by two per cent (2%) for each year that the age of the widow is less than the age of the deceased member. 
(d)  In order to qualify for benefits under this section a widow who does not have children of the deceased member under eighteen years of age in her care must have resided with him, except through no fault of her own, at the time of his death and, if such member had been retired due to age and service or disability, must have been married to him at the time of his retirement. Proof of dates of birth of the widow and children must be submitted before payment of benefits under this section. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 7)  
Sec. 140. - Requirements for participation. 
(a)  All members eligible under this division who were enrolled prior to December 1, 1969 shall continue to participate in the fund so long as they serve as eligible employees of the city. 
(b)  The following provisions shall apply to eligible employees whose service shall commence after December 1, 1969: 
(1)  Any employee who shall enter, or transfer to, the classified civil service prior to attainment of age fifty-five shall be required to participate in the retirement fund. 
(c)  No eligible employee entering service after December 1, 1969 shall be admitted to membership in the retirement fund unless he can complete at least ten (10) years of continuous service to qualify for a retirement annuity at his mandatory retirement age. 
(d)  In computing the benefits provided in section 138, and section 139 no credit shall be given for any period of service subsequent to January 1, 1938 for which the member has not made the contribution required for participation in the retirement fund. 
(e)  An open period of six (6) months starting December 1, 1969 is hereby established during which any eligible employee, who had not previously enrolled as a member, may make written application for membership provided his total period of continuous service will be at least ten (10) years on his mandatory retirement date. Such application should specify that his membership is to be effective either from the date of his application without payment of back contributions, or from the date on which his service commenced. On the latter basis he must agree to pay all back contributions which would have been required for his prior services with three per cent (3%) compound interest, the amount of which will be determined or estimated by the retirement board whose decision shall be final. Such payment must be made in a lump sum or in equal monthly installments of at least ten dollars ($10.00) over a period not exceeding thirty-six (36) months. Such admission to membership will entail the discontinuance of any Social Security coverage on the member's subsequent earnings. Further, any retirement or disability annuity to which he becomes entitled in accordance with section 138 will be subject to reduction by a Social Security adjustment in case he has elected retroactive membership on his prior service. This adjustment will be applied where the city has paid F.I.C.A. taxes for Social Security coverage on his prior earnings and will equal fifty per cent (50%) of a proportion of the Social Security primary benefit available to him on date of his retirement. Such proportion shall be determined as the percentage which the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from the city bears to the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from all sources since January 1, 1938. 
(f)  This open period and the provisions and requirements of paragraph (e) will also be available to any member who wishes to establish credit for any period of non-participating prior service which preceded the effective date of his membership, provided such prior period was of at least twelve months' duration. 
(g)  The provisions of paragraphs (e) and (f) for establishing retroactive membership credits will expire at the end of the open period on May 31, 1970. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 8; Amd. of 12-1-75)  
Sec. 141. - Benefits for periods of military service. 
In determining benefits under section 138 and 139 credit shall be given for periods of military service in World War II, or the Korean War subject to the following conditions: Any member who, after October 16, 1940, entered any branch of the armed forces of the United States or any service auxiliary thereto, or any civil emergency defense employment pursuant to requisition by the federal or state government, including those employees of the municipal airport who were displaced from their regular employment when the army took over the airport and who undertook duties connected with air forces, or any member who shall enter such services while the United States is at war, and who has been or shall be re-employed by the city within six months after the termination of such military service, shall qualify for credit for his period of military service, provided he resumes his participation in the retirement fund, with an effective date antedating his entry into such service. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 9)  
Sec. 142. - Preservation of benefits paid under previous acts. 
The provisions of this division shall not affect the benefits already in course of payment in accordance with the provisions of previous acts. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. II, § 10)  
Sec. 142.1. - Future cost-of-living adjustments. 
On July 1, 1973, and annually on each July 1 thereafter, the monthly payments on those service annuities, disability annuities and survivors' benefits on which at least eighteen (18) monthly payments have been made will be increased, or decreased, for changes in the cost-of-living as indicated by the Federal Consumer Price Index. For this purpose the retirement board will determine an adjustment percentage for July 1, 1973 by relating such index for the full calendar year 1972 to that for the full calendar year 1971, but such adjustment percentage shall be limited to a maximum of one hundred three per cent (103%) and to a minimum of ninety-seven per cent (97%); further, no adjustment will be made where the increase or decrease for the year is less than one-quarter (¼) of one per cent. For each case on which payments commenced prior to January 1, 1972, the monthly payment for June 1973, including any previous cost-of-living adjustments, will be multiplied by such adjustment percentage as determined by the retirement board in order to calculate the adjusted monthly payments for the twelve (12) months following July 1, 1973. A similar procedure will be repeated to adjust payments each year thereafter. However, the monthly benefit originally provided for a retired member or for a survivor shall never be reduced because of the accumulative effect of all cost-of-living adjustments. 
(Amd. of 4-26-72) 
Editor's note— The amendments of April 26, 1972 specifically amended the city employees retirement fund provisions pertaining to Local 884 by adding § 12 which, in order to conform to existing style and at the discretion of the editor, has been redesignated § 142.1 as herein set out.  
DIVISION 3. - PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED BY LOCAL 287 OF THE BOARD OF EDUCATION EMPLOYEES, AMERICAN FEDERATION OF STATE, COUNTY AND MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 143. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
Local 287 of the Board of Education Employees American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees, or Local 287 member(s) means all of the non-professional school employees, including probationary employees, of the City of New Haven, for whom Local 287 or its successor has a legal responsibility to represent according to Public Act 159, as amended, of the State of Connecticut 1965 General Assembly. New employees holding positions under new classifications, which shall come under the representation of Local 287 or its successor in the future, shall also accrue the terms and benefits of this division. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. III, § 1)  
Sec. 144. - Determination of contributions of participating members. 
The rate of contributions shall be five per cent (5%) of pay, said percentage to be deducted from each eligible participating member's pay and transmitted to said board. Computation of the average rate for use in determining benefits under this division shall be based on the employee's basic rate of pay except that earnings including overtime if greater will be used for any year when his contributions were based on such larger amount. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. III, § 2)  
Sec. 145. - Refund of contributions or deferred pension for members withdrawing from service; refund of contributions upon death of member with no qualified survivors; effect of discontinuance of fund; nature of member's interest in fund. 
Withdrawal of contributions of a member shall not be permitted except in the event of a discontinuance of employment. In the event of such discontinuance, the retirement board shall pay upon request, to the member or to his representative, designated or otherwise, an amount equal to his total contributions to the retirement fund. In event of discontinuance after ten (10) or more years of continuous service, and provided he does not qualify for greater benefits under the provisions of subsection (b) of section 148, any terminating member who does not request a refund of his contributions will be retained as a conditional member and will be eligible for a deferred pension commencing when he attains age sixty-five. Such deferred pension shall be for an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the conditional member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service, subject to a maximum of seventy per cent (70%) of such average rate of pay. Such a conditional member and his survivors will not be eligible for any disability, survivorship or other benefits which are provided for regular members by other sections of this division. In the event of a member's or a conditional member's death. the retirement board shall pay to his beneficiary, or to his estate if no named beneficiary is surviving, an amount equal to the excess, if any, of his total contributions over the total of any annuity payments made to him. In the event that a regular member is survived by a qualified widow or child or children under age eighteen, the retirement board shall, in lieu of such repayment of contributions, pay the survivorship benefits provided in section 149 of this division. If the total benefit payments to such member and his surviving widow and children shall be less than the amount of his total contributions, the amount of any excess shall be paid to the legal representative of the last survivor who received benefits. In the event of the discontinuance of the retirement fund each member and conditional member shall be paid an amount equal to his total contributions less any annuity payments made to him. In no event shall a member or a conditional member have a vested interest in the funds of the retirement system, in the amount, or any portion thereof, of the contributions of the city, or in any contribution except his own. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. III, § 3(b)) 
Editor's note— The introductory phrase to § 3(b) provides that effective July 1, 1970, § 3(a) is repealed and § 3(b) substituted therefor, hence § 3(a) has been omitted.  
Sec. 146. - Eligibility for retirement. 
(a)  Any male member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty-five years; but at the age of seventy years (sixty-five years if he became a participating member after July 1, 1970) his retirement shall be mandatory. 
(b)  Any female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty years (sixty-five years if she became a participating member after July 1, 1970); but at the age of seventy years (sixty-five years if she became a member after July 1, 1970) her retirement shall be mandatory. 
(c)  After June 30, 1974 any male or female member who has completed thirty (30) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty (60) years. 
(d)  Any member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement on account of total permanent disability according to the provisions of section 147. 
(e)  Continuous service for the purposes of this division shall mean uninterrupted service or employment but absence from service or employment for any reason, followed by reinstatement within one year thereafter shall not be considered as breaking the continuity of the service. In the case of absence from said service or employment for more than one year, the retirement board shall determine the period within which the member may return without breaking the continuity of his service or employment. 
(f)  Reinstatement of a member in the retirement fund shall be conditioned upon such medical examination as the retirement board may prescribe and upon payment to the retirement fund of contributions previously withdrawn with three per cent interest compounded annually. 
(g)  In computing years of service to determine eligibility for retirement, no year shall be included in which the member has not been in actual service for at least nine (9) months. 
(h)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) through (g) of this section, veterans of the U.S. armed forces shall be granted credit toward the computation of their years of service to be eligible for city retirement pension for up to four years served in active duty in the U.S. armed forces. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. III, § 5; Amd. of 12-17-90, § 2) 
Editor's note— Sec. 4, also outlining eligibility for retirement, provides that said section becomes null and void, effective June 30, 1970; hence the section has been omitted.  
Sec. 147. - Disability annuities. 
Any member of the retirement fund who, after ten (10) years of continuous service for the city, is permanently disabled from performing duties of the nature required by his job shall be entitled to an annuity to be granted on the basis of the completed years of service, provided proof of such disability shall be submitted to the retirement board, which shall cause examinations to be made by at least two impartial medical examiners. The retirement board may, from time to time, call for similar medical evidence that the member continues to be permanently disabled and such member shall be required to submit himself to any medical examination requested by the retirement board. If the retirement board, upon competent medical evidence, concludes that the disability for which the member is receiving an annuity no longer exists, said board shall thereupon order a discontinuance of all such annuities payable to such member and he shall thereafter be entitled to any benefits for which he is eligible to receive as provided in section 145. If such disability is shown to the satisfaction of the board to have arisen out of and in the course of his employment by the city as defined by the workmen's compensation act, a member of the fund shall be eligible for retirement irrespective of the duration of his employment. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. III, § 6) 
This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 148.1 for any member whose annuity is approved by the retirement board with an effective date later than June 30, 1974.  
Sec. 148. - Retirement and disability benefits. 
(a)  For employees retiring by reason of age and service or by reason of disability, the retirement board shall pay to each eligible member an annuity for life in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service; provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of his average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service. Such annuity shall be paid monthly at the rate of one-twelfth of the annual amount so determined. A minimum annual pension of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or eighty per cent (80%) of the employee's annual rate of pay at the time of his retirement, whichever is smaller, is hereby established for present and future annuitants. Any pension payable by reason of disability arising out of and in the course of employment as defined in the workmen's compensation act or arising after the completion of ten (10) years of continuous service, provided such disability was not incurred as the result of any other gainful employment, shall not be less than one-half of the member's annual rate of pay at the time of disability. This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 148.1 for any member whose annuity is approved by the retirement board with an effective date later than June 30, 1974. 
(b)  Any city employee who is not otherwise eligible to receive retirement allowance under the provisions of this section and who, after reaching the age of fifty-five years and being a member of the retirement fund at the time, and after at least fifteen (15) years of continuous service, is obligated to retire involuntarily from such service, which involuntary retirement is not due to malfeasance or misfeasance in office, shall receive an annual retirement allowance equal to forty per cent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service, plus two per cent (2%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service for each full year of service in excess of fifteen (15) years but in no event more than fifty per cent (50%) of his annual rate of pay for said last five (5) years of his service. This provision shall apply to any person retired on or after January 1, 1957, provided such person makes written application to the retirement board within one year after such involuntary retirement. 
(c)  A member who qualifies for benefits under subsection (b) and who has at least twenty-five (25) years of service may elect an alternative benefit in the form of an annuity for life commencing at age sixty-five for male members and age sixty for female members, or upon qualification for a disability annuity according to the provisions of this plan, in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service, provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of such average annual rate of pay and provided the member may elect to have said alternative form of annuity commence at any earlier age after the age of fifty-five, but in such event the amount of annuity will be reduced so as to be equivalent in present value to the annuity payable at the age of sixty-five on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for determining actuarial reserves for the retirement fund. 
(d)  Early retirement option prior to July 1, 1974: Any active member who has completed twenty (20) years of continuous service may elect to receive a reduced early retirement annuity to commence at any time after he has attained his sixtieth birthday. The reduced amount of such early retirement annuity shall be actuarially equivalent to the full retirement annuity normally payable commencing at a later date when he would have first attained the regular eligibility age for retirement in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of section 146, [12] and shall be determined by the retirement board on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for actuarial valuations of the retirement fund. 
(e)  Early retirement option after June 30, 1974. Any active member may elect early retirement on any date which is ten (10) or less years prior to the date on which he would first become eligible for normal retirement as prescribed in subsections (a), (b) or (c) of section 146. In such event his annuity, as determined by subsection (a) of this section 148, shall be reduced in amount by four (4) per cent for each full year by which his early retirement date precedes his earliest eligibility date for normal retirement with a further proportionate reduction for any fraction of a year. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. III, § 7) 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Note— Reference in the ordinance as enacted is to §§ 4 and 5. See the editor's note following § 146 for the disposition of § 4. 
 
Sec. 148.1. - Additional conditions for all disability annuities approved to commence after June 30, 1974. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of Special Act No. 379 and any amendment thereof, the following additional conditions are to apply to all disability retirement allowances for employees which are approved to commence after June 30, 1974. The amount of each such disability pension is subject to annual adjustment on account of the member's earnings from employment or self-employment of any kind, and his pension shall be discontinued unless he files with the retirement board annually before April 30th a sworn statement of such earnings for the preceding calendar year as shown in his federal income tax return. The reduction in his disability pension shall equal fifty (50) per cent of any excess of his earnings in the preceding calendar year over the amount which a Social Security beneficiary is entitled to earn without causing a reduction of his Social Security benefits. Such deduction shall be spread evenly over twelve (12) months, starting with the payment due on April 30th. No such adjustments for earnings shall be made after the disabled member attains the age of sixty-five (65).  
Sec. 149. - Survivorship benefits. 
(a)  Upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has participated in the retirement fund for a period of not less than six (6) months or who had been retired by reason of age and service, or by reason of disability, there shall be paid to or on account of his or her surviving child or children under eighteen years of age, and, in the case of a male member, to his qualified widow, monthly benefits consistent with the following table: 
_____
