_____
Any such widow, on her remarriage, shall receive only such benefits as are payable to her children alone. 
(b)  "Average annual pay," as used in computing survivorship benefits shall mean the average annual rate of pay received by the deceased member for the final five (5) years of his service or employment by the city, or the duration of such service or employment if less than five (5) years, subject to a maximum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) for such average annual pay. 
(c)  Upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service, a minimum monthly benefit will be paid to his qualified survivors if greater than the amount determined from the benefit table above. Said minimum monthly benefit shall be equal to fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of the monthly annuity to which the member would have been entitled if he had been permanently disabled on the date of his death, or fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of his actual monthly annuity in the case of a member who has been receiving retirement or disability benefits from the fund. The minimum monthly benefit when payable to a qualified widow without qualified child or children in her care shall be further reduced in amount by two per cent (2%) for each year that the age of the widow is less than the age of the deceased member. 
(d)  In order to qualify for benefits under this section a widow who does not have children of the deceased member under eighteen years of age in her care must have resided with him, except through no fault of her own, at the time of his death and, if such member had been retired due to age and service or disability, must have been married to him at the time of his retirement. Proof of dates of birth of the widow and children must be submitted before payment of benefits under this section. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. V, § 7)  
Sec. 157.13. - Requirements for participation. 
(a)  All members eligible under this division who were enrolled prior to December 1, 1969 shall be required to continue participation so long as they are employed by the city. Each new eligible employee who enters the service of the city may elect, within the first year of his service, to participate in the retirement fund and, failing such election, he shall not thereafter be admitted to said fund unless he makes the application to participate within five (5) years next following and then only with the consent of the retirement board and after having passed a physical examination to be prescribed by the retirement board. In such event he may choose to have the effective date of his entry be either the date of his application or the date following one year after the commencement of his employment, and if he shall choose the latter, he shall pay the amount which he would have been required to contribute during the interim, with interest compounded annually at three per cent (3%). No credit shall be given for service subsequent to January 1, 1938, for any period for which such employee has not made the contribution required for participation in the retirement fund. 
(b)  In no event shall an employee be admitted to membership in the retirement fund unless he can complete at least ten (10) years of continuous service to qualify for a retirement annuity at his mandatory retirement age. 
(c)  An open period of six (6) months starting on the date that the contract is signed is hereby established during which any eligible employee, who had not previously enrolled as a member, may make written application for membership provided he can complete at least ten (10) years of continuous service before he attains age sixty-five (65). Such application should specify that his membership is to be effective either from the date of his application without payment of back contributions provided his present age is less than fifty-five (55), or from the date on which his service commenced. On the latter basis he must agree to pay all back contributions which would have been required for his prior services with three per cent (3%) compound interest, the amount of which will be determined or estimated by the retirement board whose decision shall be final. Such payment must be made in a lump sum or in equal monthly installments of at least ten dollars ($10.00) over a period not exceeding thirty-six (36) months. Such admission to membership will entail the discontinuance of any Social Security coverage on the member's subsequent earnings. Further, any retirement or disability annuity to which he becomes entitled in accordance with section 157.11 will be subject to reduction by a Social Security adjustment in case he has elected retroactive membership on his prior service. This adjustment will be applied where the city has paid F.I.C.A. taxes for Social Security coverage on his prior earnings and will equal fifty per cent (50%) of a proportion of the Social Security primary benefit available to him on date of his retirement. Such proportion shall be determined as the percentage which the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from the city bears to the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from all sources since January 1, 1938. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. V, § 8; Amd. of 1-3-75 eff. 7-1-74)  
Sec. 157.14. - Benefits for periods of military service. 
In determining benefits under sections 157.11 and 157.12 credit shall be given for periods of military service in World War II, or the Korean War subject to the following conditions: Any member who, after October 16, 1940, entered any branch of the armed forces of the United States, or any auxiliary thereto, or any civil emergency defense employment pursuant to requisition by the federal or state government, including those employees of the municipal airport who were displaced from their regular employment when the army took over the airport and who undertook duties connected with the air forces, or any member who shall enter such services while the United States is at war, and who has been or shall be re-employed by the city within six (6) months after the termination of such military service, shall qualify for credit for his period of military service, provided he resumes his participation in the retirement fund, with an effective date antedating his entry into such service. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. V, § 9)  
Sec. 157.15. - Preservation of benefits under previous plans. 
The provisions of this division shall not affect benefits already in course of payment in accordance with the provisions of previous plans. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. V, § 10)  
Sec. 157.15.1. - Future cost-of-living adjustments. 
On July 1, 1975, and annually on each July 1 thereafter, the monthly payments on those service annuities, disability annuities and survivors' benefits on which at least eighteen (18) monthly payments have been made will be increased, or decreased, for changes in the cost-of-living as indicated by the Federal Consumer Price Index. For this purpose the retirement board will determine an adjustment percentage for July 1, 1975 by relating such index for the full calendar year 1974 to that for the full calendar year 1973, but such adjustment percentage shall be limited to a maximum of one hundred three per cent (103%) and to a minimum of ninety-seven per cent (97%); further, no adjustment will be made where the increase or decrease for the year is less than one-quarter (¼) of one per cent. For each case on which payments commenced prior to January 1, 1974, the monthly payment for June 1975, including any previous cost-of-living adjustments, will be multiplied by such adjustment percentage as determined by the retirement board in order to calculate the adjusted monthly payments for the twelve (12) months following July 1, 1975. A similar procedure will be repeated to adjust payments each year thereafter. However, the monthly benefit originally provided for a retired member or for a survivor shall never be reduced because of the accumulative effect of all cost-of-living adjustments. 
(Amd. of 1-3-75) 
Editor's note— The amendments of Jan. 3, 1975 specifically amended the city employees retirement fund provisions pertaining to Local 217 by adding a new § 13 to Art. V. In order to maintain existing Code format and at the discretion of the editor, said section has been redesignated § 157.15.1 as herein set out.  
DIVISION 6. - PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED BY LOCAL 24 OF THE UNITED BROTHERHOOD OF CARPENTERS AND JOINERS OF AMERICA, LOCAL 186 OF THE BROTHERHOOD OF PAINTERS AND ALLIED TRADES, LOCAL 90 OF THE INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF ELECTRICAL WORKERS, AND LOCAL 349 OF THE UNITED ASSOCIATION OF JOURNEYMEN AND APPRENTICES OF THE PLUMBING AND PIPE FITTING INDUSTRY OF THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note— By special request of the city, the scope of Div. 6 has been expanded to include Local 90 and Local 349. 
 
Sec. 157.16. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
Local 24 of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, Local 186 of the Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades, Local 90 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, and Local 349 of the United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipe Fitting Industry of the United States and Canada means all the nonprofessional board of education craft employees, including probationary employees, of the City of New Haven, for whom Local 24, Local 186, Local 90 and Local 349, or its successors, has a legal responsibility to represent according to Public Act 159, as amended, of the State of Connecticut 1965 General Assembly. New employees holding positions under new classifications, which shall come under the representation of Local 24, Local 186, Local 90 and Local 349, or its successors in the future, shall also accrue the terms and benefits of this division. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 1)  
Sec. 157.17. - Determination of contributions of participating members. 
The rate of contributions shall be five per cent (5%) of pay, said percentage to be deducted from each eligible participating member's pay and transmitted to said board. Computation of the average rate for use in determining benefits under this division shall be based on the employee's basic rate of pay except that total earnings including overtime if greater will be used for any year when his contributions were based on such larger amounts. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 2)  
Sec. 157.18. - Refund of contributions upon withdrawal of member or upon his death with no qualified survivors; effect of discontinuance of system; nature of member's interest in fund. 
Withdrawal of contributions of a member shall not be permitted except in the event of discontinuance of employment. In the event of such discontinuance, the retirement board shall pay, upon request, to the member or to his representative, designated or otherwise, an amount equal to his total contributions to the retirement fund. In the event of a member's death prior to the commencement of an annuity or a disability annuity, if no widow or dependent children survive, the retirement board shall pay to the member's beneficiary, or to his estate if no named beneficiary is surviving, an amount equal to his total contributions. Upon the death of a member, after commencement of an annuity or disability annuity, the amount of any excess of such total contributions made by him over the total annuity payments made to him shall be paid to his representative designated or otherwise, except that should he be survived by minor children or a wife, they shall receive annuities in lieu of such repayment of contributions, according to the provisions of this plan. If the total benefit payments to the member and his surviving widow and minor children shall be less than the amount of his total contributions, the amount of any excess shall be paid to the legal representative of the last survivor who received benefits. In the event of the discontinuance of the retirement fund, each member shall be paid an amount equal to his total contributions. In no event shall a member have a vested interest in the funds of the retirement system, in the amount, or any portion thereof, of the contributions of the city, or in any contributions except his own. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 3)  
Sec. 157.19. - Eligibility for retirement. 
(a)  Any male member who has completed twenty (20) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty-five years; but at the age of seventy years, his retirement shall be mandatory. 
(b)  Any female member who has completed twenty (20) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty years; but, at the age of sixty-five years, her retirement shall be mandatory. 
(c)  Any member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement on account of total permanent disability according to the provisions of this division. 
(d)  "Continuous service," for the purposes of this division shall mean uninterrupted service or employment, but absence from service or employment for any reason, followed by reinstatement within one year thereafter shall not be considered as breaking the continuity of the service. In the case of absence from said service or employment for more than one year, the retirement board shall determine the period within which the member may return without breaking the continuity of his service or employment. 
(e)  Reinstatement of a member in the retirement fund shall be conditioned upon such medical examination as the retirement board may prescribe and upon payment to the retirement fund of contributions previously withdrawn with three per cent (3%) interest compounded annually. 
(f)  In computing years of service to determine eligibility for retirement, no year shall be included in which the member has not been in actual service for at least nine (9) months. 
(g)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) through (f) of this section, veterans of the U.S. armed forces shall be granted credit toward the computation of their years of service to be eligible for city retirement pension for up to four years served in active duty in the U.S. armed forces. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 4; Amd. of 12-17-90, § 5)  
Sec. 157.20. - Disability annuities. 
Any member of the retirement fund who, after ten (10) years of continuous service for the city, is permanently disabled from performing duties of the nature required by his job shall be entitled to an annuity to be granted on the basis of the completed years of service, provided proof of such disability shall be submitted to the retirement board, which shall cause examinations to be made by at least two impartial medical examiners. The retirement board may, from time to time, call for similar medical evidence that the member continues to be permanently disabled and such member shall be required to submit himself to any medical examination requested by the retirement board. If the retirement board, upon competent medical evidence, concludes that the disability for which the member is receiving an annuity no longer exists, said board shall thereupon order a discontinuance of all such annuities payable to such member and he shall be entitled to any excess of his total contributions over the amount of disability annuities paid. If such disability is shown to the satisfaction of the board to have arisen out of and in the course of his employment by the city as defined by the workmen's compensation act, a member of the fund shall be eligible for retirement irrespective of the duration of his employment. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 5)  
Sec. 157.21. - Retirement and disability benefits. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 1961, for employees retiring by reason of age and service or by reason of disability, the retirement board shall pay to each eligible member an annuity for life in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service, provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of his average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service. Such annuity shall be paid monthly at the rate of one-twelfth of the annual amount so determined. A minimum annual pension of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or eighty per cent (80%) of the employee's annual rate of pay at the time of his retirement, whichever is smaller, is hereby established for present and future annuitants. Any pension payable by reason of disability arising out of and in the course of employment as defined in the workmen's compensation act or arising after the completion of ten (10) years of continuous service, provided such disability was not incurred as the result of any other gainful employment, shall not be less than one-half of the member's annual rate of pay at the time of disability. 
(b)  Any city employee who is not otherwise eligible to receive a retirement allowance under the provisions of this section and who, after reaching the age of fifty-five years and being a member of the retirement fund at the time, and after at least fifteen (15) years of continuous service, is obliged to retire involuntarily from such service, which involuntary retirement is not due to malfeasance or misfeasance in office, shall receive an annual retirement allowance equal to forty per cent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service, plus two per cent (2%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service for each full year of service in excess of fifteen (15) years but in no event more than fifty per cent (50%) of his annual rate of pay for said last five (5) years of his service. This provision shall apply to any person retired on or after January 1, 1957, provided such person makes written application to the retirement board within one year after such involuntary retirement. 
(c)  A member who qualifies for benefits under subsection (b) and who has at least twenty-five (25) years of service may elect an alternative benefit in the form of an annuity for life commencing at age sixty-five for male members and age sixty for female members, or upon qualification for a disability annuity according to the provisions of this plan, in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service, provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of such average annual rate of pay and provided the member may elect to have said alternative form of annuity commence at any earlier age after the age of fifty-five, but in such event the amount of annuity will be reduced so as to be equivalent in present value to the annuity payable at the age of sixty-five on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for determining actuarial reserves for the retirement fund. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 6)  
Sec. 157.22. - Survivorship benefits. 
(a)  On and after the effective date of this division, upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has participated in the retirement fund for a period of not less than six (6) months or who had been retired by reason of age and service, or by reason of disability, there shall be paid to or on account of his or her surviving child or children under eighteen years of age, and in the case of a male member, to his qualified widow, monthly benefits consistent with the following table: 
_____
MONTHLY BENEFIT 
Average 
annual 
pay 	Widow only 	Widow and one child 	Widow and two or more children 	One child 	Two children 	Three or 
more 
children 
$1,800 	$100 	$150 	$150 	$53 	$106 	$150 
 2,400 	 100 	 162 	 200 	 62 	 124 	 186 
 3,000 	 100 	 172 	 244 	 72 	 144 	 216 
 3,600 	 100 	 181 	 262 	 81 	 162 	 243 
 4,200 	 100 	 190 	 270 	 90 	 180 	 270 
 4,800 	 100 	 200 	 280 	100 	 200 	 280 
 5,400 	 105 	 210 	 290 	105 	 210 	 290 
 6,000 	 110 	 220 	 300 	110 	 220 	 300 
 
_____
Any such widow, on her remarriage, shall receive only such benefits as are payable to her children alone. 
(b)  "Average annual pay," as used in computing survivorship benefits shall mean the average annual rate of pay received by the deceased member for the final five (5) years of his service or employment by the city, or the duration of such service or employment if less than five years, subject to a maximum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) for such average annual pay. 
(c)  Upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service, a minimum monthly benefit will be paid to his qualified survivors if greater than the amount determined from the benefit table above. Said minimum monthly benefit shall be equal to fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of the monthly annuity to which the member would have been entitled if he had been permanently disabled on the date of his death, or fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of his actual monthly annuity in the case of a member who has been receiving retirement or disability benefits from the fund. The minimum monthly benefit when payable to a qualified widow without qualified child or children in her care shall be further reduced in amount by two per cent (2%) for each year that the age of the widow is less than the age of the deceased member. 
(d)  In order to qualify for benefits under this section a widow who does not have children of the deceased member under eighteen years of age in her care must have resided with him, except through no fault of her own, at the time of his death and, if such member had been retired due to age and service disability, must have been married to him at the time of his retirement. Proof of dates of birth of the widow and children must be submitted before payment of benefits under this section. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 7)  
Sec. 157.23. - Requirements for participation. 
(a)  All members eligible under this division who were enrolled prior to December 1, 1969 shall be required to continue participation so long as they are employed by the city. After December 1, 1969 any employee who shall enter, or transfer to, the classified civil service prior to the attainment of age forty-five, shall be required to participate in the retirement fund. Each eligible employee who enters the service of the city between the age of forty-five and fifty, may elect, within the first year of his service, to participate in the retirement fund and, failing such election, he shall not thereafter be admitted to said fund unless he makes the application to participate within five (5) years next following and then only with the consent of the retirement board and after having passed a physical examination to be prescribed by the retirement board. In such event he may choose to have the effective date of his entry be either the date of his application or the date following one year after the commencement of his employment, and if he shall choose the latter, he shall pay the amount which he would have been required to contribute during the interim, with interest compounded annually at three per cent (3%). No credit shall be given for service subsequent to January 1, 1938, for any period for which such employee has not made the contribution required for participation in the retirement fund. 
(c)  In no event shall an employee be admitted to membership in the retirement fund unless he can complete at least twenty (20) years of continuous service to qualify for a retirement annuity at his mandatory retirement age, unless the retirement board determines that it shall be in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 8)  
Sec. 157.24. - Benefits for periods of military service. 
In determining benefits under section 157.21 and 157.22 credit shall be given for periods of military service in World War II, or the Korean War subject to the following conditions: Any member who, after October 16, 1940, entered any branch of the armed forces of the United States, or any auxiliary thereto, or any civil emergency defense employment pursuant to requisition by the federal or state government, including those employees of the municipal airport who were displaced from their regular employment when the army took over the airport and who undertook duties connected with the air forces, or any member who shall enter such services while the United States is at war, and who has been or shall be re-employed by the city within six (6) months after the termination of such military service, shall qualify for credit for his period of military service, provided he resumes his participation in the retirement fund, with an effective date antedating his entry into such service. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 9)  
Sec. 157.25. - Preservation of benefits under previous plans. 
The provisions of this division shall not affect benefits already in course of payment in accordance with the provisions of previous plans. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VI, § 10)  
DIVISION 7. - MANAGEMENT AND PROFESSIONAL EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 157.26. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the following term shall have the following meaning: 
Management and professional member(s) means all the 
(a)  Municipal employees engaged in work 
(i)  Predominantly intellectual and varied in character as opposed to routine mental, manual, mechanical, or physical work; 
(ii)  Involving the consistent exercise of discretion and judgment in its performance; 
(iii)  Of such a character that the output produced or the result accomplished cannot be standardized in relation to a given time period; 
(iv)  Requiring knowledge of an advanced type in a field of science or learning customarily acquired by a prolonged course of specialized intellectual instruction and study in an institution of higher learning or a hospital, as distinguished from a general academic education or from an apprenticeship or from training in the performance of routine mental, manual, or physical processes; or 
(b)  Any employee who 
(i)  Has completed the courses of specialized intellectual instruction and study described in clause (iv) of subparagraph (a); and 
(ii)  Is performing related work under the supervision of a professional person to qualify himself to become a professional employee as defined in subparagraph (a) hereof; 
(c)  Any paid full-time elected or appointed official who is eligible for membership as provided for in this division. 
Specifically excluded are all those members who are eligible for retirement benefits of divisions 2 through 6 inclusive. New employee classifications, which shall come under the category of management and professional employees in the future shall also accrue the terms and benefits of this division. The terms and benefits of this division shall also apply to all other eligible full-time employees who are not specifically eligible for benefits under Divisions 2 through 6. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 1; Amd. of 12-1-75)  
Sec. 157.27. - Determination of contributions of participating members. 
The rate of contributions shall be five per cent (5%) of pay, said percentage to be deducted from each eligible participating member's pay and transmitted to said board. Computation of the average rate for use in determining benefits under this division shall be based on the employee's basic rate of pay except that total earnings including overtime if greater, will be used for any year when his contributions were based on such larger amount. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 2)  
Sec. 157.28. - Provision for refund of contributions or deferred pensions for members withdrawing from service; provision for refund of contributions upon death of member with no qualified survivors; effect of discontinuance of fund; nature of member's interest in fund. 
Withdrawal of contributions of a member shall not be permitted except in the event of discontinuance of employment. In the event of such discontinuance, the retirement board shall pay, upon request, to the member or to his representative, designated or otherwise, an amount equal to his total contributions to the retirement fund. 
In the event of discontinuance after ten (10) or more years of continuous service, and provided he does not qualify for greater benefits under the provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of section 157.31, any terminating member who does not request a refund of his contributions will be retained as a conditional member and will be eligible for a deferred pension commencing when he attains age sixty-five (65). Such deferred pension shall be for an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the conditional member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his participating total service in the fund, subject to a maximum of seventy per cent (70%) of such average rate of pay. Such a conditional member and his survivors will not be eligible for any disability, survivorship or other benefits which are provided for regular members by other sections of this division. 
In the event of a member's or a conditional member's death, the retirement board shall pay to his beneficiary, or to his estate if no named beneficiary is surviving, an amount equal to the excess, if any, of his total contributions over the total of any annuity payments made to him. 
In the event that a regular member is survived by a qualified widow or child or children under age eighteen (18), the retirement board shall, in lieu of such repayment of contributions, pay the survivorship benefits provided in section 157.33 of this division. If the total benefit payments to such member and his surviving widow and children shall be less than the amount of his total contributions, the amount of any excess shall be paid to the legal representative of the last survivor who received benefits. 
In the event of the discontinuance of the retirement fund each member and conditional member shall be paid an amount equal to his total contributions less any annuity payments made to him. 
In no event shall a member or a conditional member have a vested interest in the funds of the retirement system, in the amount or any portion thereof, of the contributions of the city, or in any contribution except his own. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 3; Amd. of 12-1-75)  
Sec. 157.29. - Eligibility for retirement. 
(a)  Any male who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty-five (65) years; but, at the age of seventy (70) years (sixty-five (65) years if he became a participating member after September 1, 1967) his retirement shall be mandatory unless he is a paid full-time elected officer. 
(b)  Any female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this article at the age of sixty (60) years (sixty-five (65) years if she became a participating member after September 1, 1967); but, at the age of seventy (70) years (sixty-five (65) years if she became a member after September 1, 1967) her retirement shall be mandatory unless she is a paid full-time elected officer. 
(c)  After June 30, 1973 any male or female member who has completed thirty (30) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty (60) years. 
(d)  Any member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city shall be eligible for retirement on account of total permanent disability according to the provisions of section 157.30. 
(e)  "Continuous service," for the purposes of this division, shall mean uninterrupted service or employment, but absence from service or employment for any reason, followed by reinstatement within one year thereafter shall not be considered as breaking the continuity of the service. In the case of absence from said service or employment for more than one year, the retirement board shall determine the period within which the member may return without breaking the continuity of service or employment. 
(f)  Reinstatement of such member's prior participating service in the retirement fund shall be conditioned upon such medical examination as the retirement board may prescribe and upon payment to the retirement fund of contributions previously withdrawn with three per cent (3%) interest compounded annually. Application for such reinstatement shall be made within six (6) months after his return to employment. 
(g)  In computing years of service to determine eligibility for retirement, no year shall be included in which the member has not been in actual service for at least nine (9) months. 
(h)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) through (g) of this section, veterans of the U.S. armed forces shall be granted credit toward the computation of their years of service to be eligible for city retirement pension for up to four years served in active duty in the U.S. armed forces. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 4; Amd. of 12-1-75; Amd. of 12-17-90, § 6)  
Sec. 157.30. - Disability annuities. 
Any member of the retirement fund who, after ten (10) years of continuous service for the city, is permanently disabled from performing duties of the nature required by his job shall be entitled to an annuity to be granted on the basis of the completed years of service, provided proof of such disability shall be submitted to the retirement board, which shall cause examinations to be made by at least two impartial medical examiners. The retirement board may, from time to time, call for similar medical evidence that the member continues to be permanently disabled and such member shall be required to submit himself to any medical examination requested by the retirement board. If the retirement board, upon competent medical evidence, concludes that the disability for which the member is receiving an annuity no longer exists, said board shall thereupon order a discontinuance of all such annuities payable to such member and he shall thereafter be entitled to any benefit for which he is eligible to receive as provided for in sections 157.28 and 157.31. If such disability is shown to the satisfaction of the board to have arisen out of and in the course of his employment by the city as defined by the workmen's compensation act, a member of the fund shall be eligible for retirement irrespective of the duration of his employment. This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 157.32 for any member whose participation in the retirement fund commences after January 1, 1970. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 5)  
Sec. 157.31. - Retirement and disability benefits. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 1969, for employees retiring by reason of age and service or by reason of disability, the retirement board shall pay to each eligible member an annuity for life in an amount determined as two per cent (2%) of the member's average rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service; provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy per cent (70%) of his average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service. Such annuity shall be paid monthly at the rate of one-twelfth of the annual amount so determined. A minimum annual pension of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or eighty per cent (80%) of the employee's annual rate of pay at the time of his retirement, whichever is smaller, is hereby established for present and future annuitants. Any pension payable by reason of disability arising out of and in the course of employment as defined in the workmen's compensation act or arising after the completion of ten (10) years of continuous service, provided such disability was not incurred as the result of any other gainful employment shall not be less than one-half of the member's annual rate of pay at the time of disability. This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 157.32 for any member whose participation in the retirement fund commences after January 1, 1970. 
(b)  Any city employee who is not otherwise eligible to receive a retirement allowance under the provisions of this section and who, after reaching the age of fifty-five years and being a member of the retirement fund at the time, and after at least fifteen (15) years of continuous service, is obliged to retire involuntarily from such service, which involuntary retirement is not due to malfeasance or misfeasance in office, shall receive an annual retirement allowance equal to forty per cent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service, plus two per cent (2%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service for each full year of service in excess of fifteen (15) years but in no event more than fifty per cent (50%) of his annual rate of pay for said last five (5) years of his service. This provision shall apply to any person retired on or after January 1, 1957, provided such person makes written application to the retirement board within one year after such involuntary retirement. 
(c)  Any paid full-time elected official whose period in office expires, or any paid full-time elected or appointed official whose service is terminated involuntarily, not due to malfeasance or misfeasance in office, after completion of ten (10) years of service and attainment of the age of forty-five shall subsequently receive, commencing upon the attainment of the age of sixty or upon qualification for disability annuity according to the provisions of this division, an annuity for life equal to forty per cent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service, plus two per cent (2%) of such average annual rate of pay for each full year of service in excess of ten (10) years, provided such annuity shall not exceed fifty percent (50%) of his average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service. 
(d)  A member who qualifies for benefits under either of the two preceding subsections and who has at least twenty-five years of service may elect an alternative benefit in the form of an annuity for life commencing at age sixty-five for male members and age sixty for female members, or upon qualification for disability annuity according to the provisions of this division, in an amount determined as two percent (2%) of the member's average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service for each year of his total service, provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy percent (70%) of such average annual rate of pay and provided the member may elect to have said alternative form of annuity commence at any earlier age after the age of fifty-five, but in such event the amount of annuity will be reduced so as to be equivalent in present value to the annuity payable at the age of sixty-five on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for determining actuarial reserves for the retirement fund. 
(e)  Early retirement option prior to July 1, 1973. Any active or conditional member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service may elect to receive a reduced early retirement annuity to commence at any time after he has attained his sixtieth birthday. The reduced amount of such early retirement annuity shall be actuarially equivalent to the full retirement annuity normally payable commencing at a later date when he would have first attained the regular eligibility age for retirement in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of section 157.29, and shall be determined by the retirement board on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for actuarial valuations of the retirement fund. 
(f)  Early retirement option after June 30, 1973. Any active or conditional member may elect early retirement on any date which is ten (10) or less years prior to the date on which he would first become eligible for normal retirement as prescribed in subsections (a), (b) or (c) of section 157.29. In such event his annuity, as determined by subsection (a) of this section 157.31, shall be reduced in amount by four percent (4%) for each full year by which his early retirement date precedes his earliest eligibility date for normal retirement with a further proportionate reduction for any fraction of a year. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 6; Amd. of 12-1-75)  
Sec. 157.32. - Additional conditions for disability annuities for members enrolled after January 1, 1970. 
The disability annuity payable to any member whose participation in the retirement fund commences after January 1, 1970 shall be adjusted by an amount equal to a percentage of his earnings from employment or self-employment of any kind; and his pension shall be discontinued unless he files with the retirement board annually before April 30th a sworn statement of such earnings for the preceding calendar year as shown in his federal income tax return; the percentage of his earnings, if any, for the preceding calendar year to be deducted from his disability annuity will be determined by the ratio of his disability annuity (before adjustment) to his annual rate of pay at the time of disability, and the amount of such deduction shall be spread evenly over twelve months, starting with the payment due on April 30th. No such adjustments for earnings shall be made after the disabled member attains the age of sixty-five. For any one of these members whose period of credited membership shall have commenced after his fortieth birthday the amount payable as a disability annuity (before adjustment for earnings) shall be limited to a percentage of his annual rate of pay at the time of disability; this percentage is to be determined by multiplying two percent (2%) by the number of years of membership which he could have accumulated up to his sixty-fifth birthday if he were able to continue his employment for the city until that date. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 7)  
Sec. 157.33. - Survivorship benefits. 
(a)  On and after the effective date of this division upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has participated in the retirement fund for a period of not less than six (6) months or who had been retired by reason of age and service, or by reason of disability, there shall be paid to or on account of his or her surviving child or children under eighteen years of age, and, in the case of a male member, to his qualified widow, monthly benefits consistent with the following table:

 2,400 	 100 	 162 	 200 	 62 	 124 	 186 
 3,000 	 100 	 172 	 244 	 72 	 144 	 216 
 3,600 	 100 	 181 	 262 	 81 	 162 	 243 
 4,200 	 100 	 190 	 270 	 90 	 180 	 270 
 4,800 	 100 	 200 	 280 	100 	 200 	 280

 6,000 	 110 	 220 	 300 	110 	 220 	 300
