Any such widow, on her remarriage, shall receive only such benefits as are payable to her children alone. 
(b)  "Average annual pay," as used in computing survivorship benefits shall mean the average annual rate of pay received by the deceased member for the final five (5) years of his service or employment by the city, or the duration of such service or employment if less than five (5) years, subject to a maximum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) for such average annual pay. 
(c)  Upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service, a minimum monthly benefit will be paid to his qualified survivors if greater than the amount determined from the benefit table above. Said minimum monthly benefit shall be equal to fifty percent (50%) of the amount of the monthly annuity to which the member would have been entitled if he had been permanently disabled on the date of his death, or fifty percent (50%) of the amount of his actual monthly annuity in the case of a member who has been receiving retirement or disability benefits from the fund. The minimum monthly benefit when payable to a qualified widow without qualified child or children in her care shall be further reduced in amount by two percent (2%) for each year that the age of the widow is less than the age of the deceased member. 
(d)  In order to qualify for benefits under this section a widow who does not have children of the deceased member under eighteen years of age in her care must have resided with him, except through no fault of her own, at the time of his death and, if such member had been retired due to age and service or disability, must have been married to him at the time of his retirement. Proof of dates of birth of the widow and children must be submitted before payment of benefits under this section. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 8)  
Sec. 157.34. - Requirements for participation. 
(a)  All management and professional members and elected or appointed officers who were enrolled in this plan prior to December 1, 1969 shall continue to participate in the fund so long as they serve as eligible employees or officers of the city in accordance with the terms and conditions then prevailing for membership. 
(b)  The following provisions shall apply to eligible elected or appointed officers and management and professional employees whose service commences after December 1, 1969: 
(1)  Any employee who shall enter, or transfer to, the classified civil service prior to attainment of age fifty-five shall be required to participate in the retirement fund. 
(2)  Each other new employee who shall be hired prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) may elect to be enrolled as a contributing member of the fund as of the first anniversary of the date of his employment by filing a written application before that date; such participation may also include the first year of his employment if the employee elects to pay the back contributions with three percent (3%) interest compounded annually on his first anniversary date or within six (6) months of the effective date of this amendment, if later. Failing this required application, he will be continued under the Federal Social Security program which will apply to all such noncivil service employees during their first year of service unless an application for immediate participation is filed with the retirement board during his first thirty (30) calendar days of service. Such Social Security coverage will be discontinued on the employee's earnings after the first year if he makes the application required for enrollment in the retirement fund. This provision for optional participation shall also apply to each appointed officer whose service commences prior to age fifty-five (55) and to each elected officer regardless of age. 
(c)  No eligible employee or officer entering service after December 1, 1969 shall be admitted to membership in the retirement fund unless he can complete at least ten (10) years of continuous service to qualify for a retirement annuity at his mandatory retirement age. 
(d)  In computing the benefits provided sections 157.31, 151.32 and 157.33 no credit shall be given for any period of service subsequent to January 1, 1938 for which the member has not made the contribution required for participation in the retirement fund. 
(e)  An open period of six (6) months starting December 1, 1969 is hereby established during which any eligible employee or officer, who had not previously enrolled as a member, may make written application for membership provided his total period of continuous service will be at least ten (10) years on his mandatory retirement date. Such application should specify that his membership is to be effective either from the date of his application without payment of back contributions, or from the date on which his service commenced. On the latter basis he must agree to pay all back contributions which would have been required for his prior service with three percent (3%) compounded interest, the amount of which will be determined or estimated by retirement board whose decision shall be final. Such payment must be made in a lump sum or in equal monthly installments of at least ten dollars ($10.00) over a period not exceeding thirty-six (36) months. Such admission to membership will entail the discontinuance of any Social Security coverage on the member's subsequent earnings. Further any retirement or disability annuity to which he becomes entitled in accordance with sections 157.31 and 157.32 will be subject to reduction by a Social Security adjustment in case he has elected retroactive membership on his prior service. This adjustment will be applied where the city has paid F.I.C.A. taxes for Social Security coverage on his prior earnings and will equal fifty percent (50%) of a proportion of the Social Security primary benefit available to him on the date of his retirement. Such proportion shall be determined as the percentage which the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from the city bears to the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from all sources since January 1, 1938. 
(f)  This open period and the provisions and requirements of paragraph (e) will also be available to any member who wishes to establish credit for any period of non-participating prior service which preceded the effective date of his membership, provided such prior period was of at least twelve (12) months' duration. 
(g)  The provisions of paragraphs (e) and (f) for establishing retroactive membership credits will expire at the end of the open period on May 31, 1970. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 9; Amd. of 12-1-75)  
Sec. 157.35. - Benefits for periods of military service. 
In determining benefits under sections 157.31, 157.32 and 157.33 credit shall be given for periods of military service in World War II, or the Korean War subject to the following conditions: Any member who, after October 16, 1940, entered any branch of the armed forces of the United States, or any auxiliary thereto, or any civil emergency defense employment pursuant to requisition by the federal or state government, including those employees of the municipal airport who were displaced from their regular employment when the army took over the airport and who undertook duties connected with the air forces or any member who shall enter such services while the United States is at war, and who has been or shall be re-employed by the city within six months after the termination of such military service, shall qualify for credit for his period of military service, provided he resumes his participation in the retirement fund, with an effective date antedating his entry into such service. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 10)  
Sec. 157.36. - Preservation of benefits under previous acts. 
The provisions of sections 157.26 through 157.35 of this division shall not affect benefits already in course of payment in accordance with the provisions of previous acts. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 11)  
Sec. 157.37. - Future cost of living adjustments. 
On July 1, 1970, and annually on each July 1 thereafter, the monthly payments on those service annuities, disability annuities and survivor's benefits on which at least eighteen (18) monthly payments have been made will be increased or decreased for changes in the cost-of-living as indicated by the Federal Consumer Price Index. For this purpose the retirement board will determine an adjustment percentage for July 1, 1970 by relating such index for the full calendar year 1969 to that for the full calendar year 1968, but such adjustment percentage shall be limited to a maximum of 103% and to a minimum of 97%; further, no adjustment will be made where the increase or decrease for the year is less than ¼ of 1%. For each case on which payments commenced prior to January 1, 1969, the monthly payment for June 1970, including any previous cost-of-living adjustments, will be multiplied by such adjustment percentage as determined by the retirement board in order to calculate the adjusted monthly payments for the twelve months following July 1, 1970. A similar procedure will be repeated to adjust payment each year thereafter. However, the monthly benefit originally provided for a retired member or for a survivor shall never be reduced because of the accumulative effect of all cost of living adjustments. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69, Art. VII, § 12)  
DIVISION 8. - PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EXECUTIVE MANAGEMENT AND CONFIDENTIAL EMPLOYEES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note— The amendments of July 6, 1987, specifically amended the city employees' retirement plan provisions by adding new material designated as Article VIII, §§ 1—12. In order to maintain existing Code format and at the discretion of the editor, the new provisions have been redesignated as Division 8, §§ 157.38—157.49, as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 157.38. - Definitions. 
As used in this article [this division] the following term shall have the following meanings: 
Eligible employee or officer means: 
(1)  Any non-bargaining unit employee appointed to a full time general fund position, scheduled to work at least 35 hours per week and employed in one of the position titles under Section II "Executive Management and Confidential Employees Personnel Policy and Procedures" manual. 
(2)  Any non-bargaining unit employees as defined in the decision of the Connecticut State Labor Board or defined as confidential employees by the Management Union Contract and employed in a position title under Section II, "Confidential Employees of the City of New Haven Executive Management and Confidential Employees Personnel Policy and Procedures" manual. 
Specifically excluded are all those members who are eligible for retirement benefits of Articles II through VII [Divisions 2 through 7] inclusive; all positions represented by any employee organization recognized by the city and/or board of education under the Municipal Employee Relations Act (CGS 4-474 et seq.) or the Teacher Negotiations Act (CGS 153(a) et seq.); all temporary, seasonal, contractual (including board of education administrators), or part-time personnel. Eligible employees holding positions under new classifications which shall come under the category of executive management and confidential employees in the future shall also accrue the terms and benefits of this article. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.39. - Determination of contributions of participating members. 
The rate of contributions shall be six percent (6%) of pay, said percentage to be deducted from each eligible participating member's pay and transmitted to said board. Computation of the average rate for use in determining benefits under this article [this division] shall be based on such member's basic rate of pay except that total earnings including overtime, if greater, will be used for any year when such member's contributions were based on such larger amount. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.40. - Provision for refund of contributions or deferred pensions for members withdrawing from service; provisions for refund of contributions upon death of member with no qualified survivors; recovery from disability. 
Withdrawal of contributions of a member shall not be permitted except in the event of discontinuance of employment. In the event of such discontinuance, the retirement board shall pay, upon request, to the member or to his representative, designated or otherwise, an amount equal to his total contributions to the retirement fund. 
Even if no such request is made, in the event of such discontinuance before the member has earned ten (10) or more years of credited service, the retirement board, in its sole discretion, may pay to the member or to his representative, designated or otherwise, an amount equal to his total contributions to the retirement fund. 
In the event of such discontinuance after ten (10) or more years of credited service, and provided he does not qualify for greater benefits under the provisions of section 157.43, any terminating member who does not request a refund of his contributions will be retained as a conditional member and will be eligible for a deferred pension commencing when he attains age sixty-five (65) or upon such earlier date as may be elected by the member pursuant to section 157.43(e) and (f). Such deferred pension shall be for an amount determined as two percent (2%) of the conditional member's average rate of pay averaged over those five (5) years of service producing the highest average, for each year of credited service, subject to a maximum of seventy percent (70%) of such average rate of pay and reduced as provided in section 157.43(d), if applicable. Such conditional member and his survivors will not be eligible for any disability, survivorship or other benefits which are provided for non-conditional members by other sections of this article [this division]. 
In the event of a member's or a conditional member's death, the retirement board shall pay to his beneficiary, or to his estate if no named beneficiary is surviving, an amount equal to the excess, if any, of his total contributions over the total of any annuity payments made to him. 
In the event that a member is survived by a widow, widower, or child or children under age eighteen (18), the retirement board shall, in lieu of such repayment of contributions, pay the survivorship benefits provided in section 157.45 of this article [this division]. If the total benefit payments to such member and his surviving widow or widower and children shall be less than the amount of his total contributions the amount of any excess shall be paid to the legal representative of the last survivor who received benefits. 
A member whose disability benefits are terminated by reason of the member's recovery shall be entitled to the benefits of this section, without regard to the amount of his credited service. Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, the retirement board shall not have the authority to pay any such member the amount of his total contributions to the retirement fund except upon such member's request. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.41. - Eligibility for retirement. 
(a)  Any male member who has completed ten (10) years of credited service for the city shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty-five years; but at the age of seventy years his retirement shall be mandatory. 
(b)  Any female member who has completed ten (10) years of credited service for the City shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this division at the age of sixty years (sixty-five years if she became a participating member after September 1, 1967); but at the age of seventy years her retirement shall be mandatory. 
(c)  After June 30, 1980 any (male or female) member the sum of whose age and years of credited service for the city equals or exceeds eighty-five (85) shall be eligible for retirement according to the provisions of this article [this division]. 
(d)  Any member who has completed ten (10) years of credited service for the city shall be eligible for retirement on account of total permanent disability according to the provisions of section 157.42. 
(e)  "Credited service" for the purposes of this article [this division] shall mean that number of full and fractional years (calculated on a daily basis) with respect to which a member's pay is reduced by the amounts provided in section 157.39; provided, however, that the number of full and fractional years of credited service of a member as of July 1, 1986 shall not be less than the member's continuous service as of such date, as calculated pursuant to this section as if in effect on June 30, 1986. 
(f)  Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, in the event a member separates from the city's service and receives a refund of his contributions pursuant to section 157.40, the member's credited service shall include only those full and fractional years (calculated on a daily basis), occurring after the latest such refund, with respect to which the member's pay is reduced by the amounts provided in section 157.39, unless: 
(1)  The member, within six (6) months of his return to the city's service, requests a reinstatement of his prior credited service, if any; and 
(2)  The member's prior credit service calculated as of the date of the latest refund exceeds the number of full and fractional years (calculated on a daily basis) falling between the date the member last separated from the city's service and the date first following such separation on which the member contributed to the fund pursuant to section 157.39; 
(3)  The member repays the latest refund together with three percent (3%) interest compounded annually; and 
(4)  The member passes such medical examinations as the retirement board, in its sole discretion, shall prescribe. The retirement board shall have the sole discretion to determine whether the member has passed such medical examinations, and its decision shall be final and conclusive on all parties. 
In the event a member satisfies all of the foregoing conditions, his credited service shall consist of those full and fractional years (calculated on a daily basis) occurring after the latest such refund with respect to which the member's pay is reduced by the amounts provided in section 157.39 plus his prior credited service. 
For purposes of this section the term "prior credited service" shall mean those full and fractional years (calculated on a daily basis) with respect to which the latest refund was made. 
(g)  "Credited service" shall also include those full and fractional years (calculated on a daily basis) during which a member receives a disability benefit, provided such member recovers from such disability, is rehired by the city and thereafter earns at least five (5) years of credited service. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.42. - Disability annuities. 
Any member of the retirement fund who, after ten (10) years of credited service for the city, is permanently disabled from performing duties of the nature required by his job; or, irrespective of the duration of his employment, suffers such a disability which is shown to the satisfaction of the board to have arisen out of or in the course of his employment by the city, as defined in the Worker's Compensation Act, shall be entitled to an annuity in an amount determined pursuant to section 157.43; provided satisfactory proof of such disability shall be submitted to the retirement board. 
The retirement board shall cause examinations to be made by at least two (2) impartial medical examiners initially to verify the existence of such disability. 
The retirement board may, from time to time, call for similar medical evidence that the member continues to be permanently disabled. Such member shall be required to submit himself to any medical examination requested by the retirement board. If the retirement board, upon competent medical evidence, concludes that the disability for which the member is receiving an annuity no longer exists, such board shall thereupon order a discontinuance of all such annuities payable to such member, effective on the date which is ninety (90) days after the board concludes that the disability no longer exists. Each member whose benefits are terminated in accordance with this paragraph, shall regardless of the number of his years of credited service, thereafter be entitled to those benefits provided in section 157.40. 
Disability annuity benefits shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 157.44 for any member whose annuity is approved by the retirement board with an effective date later than January 1, 1970. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.43. - Retirement and disability benefits. 
(a)  For employees retiring by reason of age and service or by reason of disability, the retirement board shall pay to each eligible member an annuity for life in an amount determined as two percent (2%) of the member's average annual rate of pay averaged over those five (5) years of service producing the highest average, for each year (or fraction) of credited service; provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy percent (70%) of his average annual rate of pay averaged over those five (5) years of service producing the highest average. Such annuity shall be paid monthly at the rate of one-twelfth of the annual amount so determined. A minimum annual pension of one thousand ($1,000.00) or eighty percent (80%) of the employee's annual rate of pay at the time of his retirement, whichever is smaller, is hereby established for present and future annuities. Any pension payable by reason of disability arising out of and in the course of employment as defined in the Worker's Compensation Act or arising after the completion of ten (10) years of credited service, provided such disability was not incurred as a result of any other gainful employment, shall not be less than one-half of the member's annual rate of pay at the time of disability. This disability annuity benefit shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 157.44 for any member whose annuity is approved by the retirement board with an effective date later than January 1, 1970. 
(b)  Any appointed official whose service is terminated involuntarily, not due to malfeasance or misfeasance in office, after completion of ten (10) years of service and attainment of the age of forty-five shall subsequently receive, commencing upon the attainment of the age of sixty or upon qualification for disability annuity according to the provisions of this article [this division], an annuity for life equal to forty percent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay for the last five (5) years of his service, plus two percent (2%) of such average annual rate of pay for each full year of service in excess of ten (10) years, provided such annuity shall not exceed fifty percent (50%) of his average annual rate of pay for his final five (5) years of service. 
(c)  Any member who is not eligible to receive a normal retirement or disability benefit under the provisions of this section and who, after reaching the age of fifty-five years and being a member of the retirement fund at the time, and after at least fifteen (15) years of credited service, is obligated to retire involuntarily from such service, which involuntary retirement is not due to malfeasance in office, shall receive an annual retirement benefit equal to forty percent (40%) of his average annual rate of pay averaged over those five (5) years of service producing the highest average, plus two percent (2%) of his average annual rate of pay averaged over those five (5) years of his service producing the highest average, for each full or fractional year of credited service in excess of fifteen (15) years but in no event more than fifty percent (50%) of his annual rate of pay for said (5) years of his service. This provision shall apply to any person retired on or after January 1, 1957, provided such person makes writing application to the retirement board within one year after such involuntary retirement. 
(d)  A member who qualifies for benefits under subsections (b) and (c) and who has at least twenty-five (25) years of credited service my elect an alternative benefit in the form of an annuity for life commencing at age sixty-five (65) for male and female members, but age sixty (60) for female members who became participating members prior to September 1, 1967, or upon qualification for a disability annuity according to the provisions of this article [this division], in an amount determined as two percent (2%) of the member's average annual rate of pay averaged over those five (5) years of service producing the highest average for each year of his credit service, provided such annuity shall not exceed seventy percent (70%) of such average annual rate of pay and provided the member may elect to have said alternative form of annuity commence at any earlier age after the age of fifty-five (55), but in such event the amount of annuity will be reduced so as to be equivalent in present value to the annuity payable at the age of sixty-five (65) in the case of male and female members, and at age sixty (60) in the case of female members who became participating members prior to September 1, 1967 on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for determining actuarial reserves for the retirement fund. 
(e)  Early retirement option prior to July 1, 1973: Any active member who has completed ten (10) years of credited service may elect to receive a reduced early retirement annuity to commence at any time after he has attained his sixtieth birthday. The reduced amount of such early retirement annuity shall be actuarially equivalent to the full retirement annuity normally payable commencing at a later date when he would have first attained the regular eligibility age for retirement in accordance with subsection (a) and (b) of section 157.43, and shall be determined by the retirement board on the basis of the interest and mortality tables used for actuarial valuations of the retirement board. 
(f)  Early retirement option after June 30, 1973: Any (i) active member or (ii) conditional member having ten (10) or more years of credited service or (iii) member whose disability benefits are terminated by reason of his recovery, may elect early retirement on any date which is ten (10) or less years prior to the date on which he would first become eligible for normal retirement as prescribed in subsections (a), (b) or (c) of section 157.41, in the case of an active member; or would have become eligible for normal retirement as prescribed in subsection (a) or (b) of Section 157.41 in all other situations covered by this section had he remained in the city's employ. In such event his annuity, as determined by subsection (a) of this section or section 157.40, as the case may be, shall be reduced in amount by two percent (2%) for each full year by which his early retirement date precedes the earliest eligibility date for normal retirement as prescribed in subsections (a) or (b) or (c) of section 157.41, in the case of an active member, or subsection (a) or (b) of section 157.41 in all other situations covered by this section, with a further proportionate reduction for any fraction of a year. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.44. - Additional conditions for all disability annuities payable to any member approved after January 1, 1970. 
Any disability annuity payable to any member whose participation in the retirement fund commences after January 1, 1970 shall be subject to adjustment on account of such member's earnings from employment or self-employment of any kind, and his pension shall be discontinued unless he files with the retirement board annually before April 30th a sworn statement of such earnings for the preceding calendar year as shown in his federal income tax return. The reduction in his disability annuity shall equal fifty percent (50%) of any excess of his earnings in the preceding calendar year over six thousand eight hundred dollars ($6,800.00), but in no event shall such reduction exceed the amount of disability annuity paid for the period during which such excess earnings were earned. Such deduction shall be spread evenly over twelve (12) months, starting with the payment due on April 30th. No such adjustments for earnings shall be made after the disabled member attains the age of sixty-five. 
For any one of these members whose period of credited membership shall have commenced after his fortieth birthday, the amount payable as a disability annuity (before adjustment for earnings) shall be limited to a percentage of his annual rate of pay at the time of disability; this percentage is to be determined by multiplying two percent (2%) by the number of years of membership which he could have accumulated up to his sixty-fifth birthday if he were able to continue his employment for the City until that date. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.45. - Survivorship benefits. 
(a)  Upon the death of a member who has participated in the retirement fund for a period of not less than six (6) months or who had been retired by reason of age and service, or by reason of disability, there shall be paid to or on account of his surviving child or children under eighteen years of age and, to his widow or widower, monthly benefits consistent with the following table. 
Column 1: Average Annual Pay 
Column 2: Widow or Widower Only 
Column 3: Widow or Widower and One Child 
Column 4: Widow or Widower and Two or More Children 
Column 5: One Child 
Column 6: Two Children 
Column 7: Three or More Children 
 1 	2 	3 	4 	5 	6 	7 
$2,400 	$130 	$200 	$200 	 $70 	$140 	$200 
 3,000 	 140 	 225 	 250 	
 85 	 170 	 250 
 3,600 	 150 	 250 	 300 	 100 	 200 	 300 
 4,200 	 160 	 270 	 320 	 110 	 220 	 320 
 4,800 	 170 	 290 	 340 	 120 	 240 	 340 
 5,400 	 180 	 310 	 360 	 130 	 260 	 360 
 6,000 	 190 	 330 	 380 	 140 	 280 	 380 
 6,600 	 195 	 345 	 400 	 150 	 300 	 400 
 7,200 	 200 	 360 	 420 	 160 	 320 	 420 
 7,800 	 200 	 370 	 440 	 170 	 340 	 440 
 8,400 	 200 	 375 	 460 	 175 	 350 	 460 
 9,000 	 200 	 380 	 480 	 180 	 360 	 480 
 9,600 	 205 	 390 	 500 	 185 	 370 	 500 
 10,200 	 210 	 400 	 525 	 190 	 380 	 525 
 10,800 	 215 	 410 	 550 	 195 	 390 	 550 
 11,400 	 220 	 420 	 575 	 200 	 400 	 575 
 12,000 	 225 	 430 	 600 	 205 	 410 	 600 
 
Any such widow or widower, on remarriage, shall receive only such benefits as are payable to his children alone. 
In the event that payments are made pursuant to this section to surviving children under eighteen years of age who are represented by more than one legal guardian, such payments shall be apportioned among such guardians in proportion to the number of children represented by each guardian, respectively. 
(b)  "Average annual pay," as used in computing survivorship benefits, shall mean the average annual rate of pay received by the deceased member averaged over those five (5) years of service or employment by the city producing the highest average, or the duration of such service or employment if less than five (5) years, subject to a maximum of twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) for such average annual pay. 
(c)  Upon the death of a member who has completed ten (10) years of credited service for the city or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service, a minimum monthly benefit will be paid to his qualified survivors if greater than the amount determined from the benefit table above. Said minimum monthly benefit shall be equal to fifty percent (50%) of the amount of the monthly annuity to which the member would have been entitled if he had been permanently disabled on the date of his death, or fifty percent (50%) of the amount of his actual monthly annuity in the case of a member who has been receiving retirement or disability benefits from the fund. 
(d)  In order to qualify for benefits under this section, a widow or widower must have been married to the deceased member at the time of his death and, if such member had been retired due to age and service or disability, must have been married to him at the time of retirement. Proof of dates of birth of the children must be submitted before payment of benefits under this section. 
(e)  These benefits in section 157.45 shall no longer apply should such widow or widower remarry. In such cases they shall receive only such benefits as are payable to his children alone. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.46. - Requirements for participation. 
(a)  All executive management or confidential employee members who were enrolled in a city pension plan prior to December 1, 1969 shall continue to participate in the fund so long as they serve as eligible employees or officers of the city in accordance with the terms and conditions then prevailing for membership. 
(b)  The following provisions shall apply to eligible appointed officers and executive management or confidential employees whose service commences after December 1, 1969: 
(1)  Any employee who shall enter or transfer to executive management or confidential employee status prior to attainment of age fifty-five shall be required to participate in the retirement fund. 
(2)  Each other new officer or employee who shall be appointed or hired prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55) may elect to be enrolled as a contributing member of the fund as of the first anniversary of the date of his appointment or employment by filing a written application before that date; such participation may also include the first year participation may also include the first year of his appointment or employment if the employee elects to pay the back contribution with three percent (3%) interest compounded annually on his first anniversary date or within six (6) months of the effective date of this amendment, if later. 
Failing this required application, he will be continued under the federal Social Security program which will apply to all such non-civil service employees during their first year of service unless an application for immediate participation is filed with the retirement board during his first thirty (30) calendar days of service. Such Social Security coverage will be discontinued on the employee's earnings after the first year if he makes the application required for enrollment in the retirement fund. This provision for optional participation shall also apply to each appointed officer whose service commences prior to age fifty-five (55) and to each elected officer regardless of age. 
(c)  Each eligible employee shall, upon entering service after approval of these pension provisions by the board of aldermen, submit to such medical examinations as the retirement board shall by regulation or bylaw require in order to determine whether the eligible employee is then permanently disabled from performing duties of the nature required by his job and for use by the retirement board in evaluating future claims for disability. In the event any such employee refuses to submit to any such medical examination, he shall bear the burden of providing by clear and convincing evidence that he is entitled to a disability benefit. 
(d)  No eligible employee entering service after December 1, 1969, shall be admitted to membership in the retirement fund unless he can complete at least ten (10) years of credited service to qualify for a retirement annuity at his mandatory retirement age. 
(e)  An open period of six (6) months commencing with approval of these provisions is hereby established during which any eligible employee who had not previously enrolled as a member may make written application for membership, provided his total period of credited service will be at least ten (10) years on his mandatory retirement date. 
Such application should specify that his membership is to be effective either from the date of his application without payment of back contributions, or from the date on which his service commenced. On the latter basis he must agree to pay all back contributions which would have been required for his prior service with three percent (3%) compound interest, the amount of which will be determined or estimated by the retirement board whose decision shall be final. 
Such payment must be made in a lump sum or equal monthly installments of at least ten dollars ($10.00) over a period not exceeding thirty-six (36) months. Such admission to membership will entail the discontinuance of any Social Security coverage on the member's subsequent earnings. Further, any retirement or disability annuity to which he becomes entitled in accordance with section 157.43 will be subject to reduction by a Social Security adjustment in case he has elected retroactive membership on his prior service. This adjustment will be applied where the city has paid F.I.C.A. taxes for Social Security coverage on his prior earnings and will equal fifty percent (50%) of a proportion of the Social Security primary benefit available on the date of his retirement. Such proportion shall be determined as the percentage which the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from the city bears to the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from all sources since January 1, 1938. 
(f)  This open period subject to the provisions and requirements of paragraph (e) will also be available to any member who wishes to reinstate prior credited service or to establish credit for any period of non-participating prior service which preceded the effective date of his membership, provided such prior period was of at least twelve month's duration. 
(g)  The provisions of paragraphs (e) and (f) for establishing retroactive membership credits will expire at the end of the open period which will be six (6) months after aldermanic approval of these pension provisions. 
(h)  An open period of six (6) months is established starting the day this amendment is legally enacted, during which any eligible employee who has not previously enrolled as a member may make written application for membership. Such application should specify that this membership is to be effective either from the date of this application without payment of back contributions, or from the date which his service commenced. On the latter basis he must pay all back contributions which would have been required for his prior services, the amount of which shall be determined or estimated by the retirement board, with three percent (3%) compound interest. The decision of the retirement board shall be final. Such payment must be made in a lump sum or in equal monthly installments of at least ten dollars ($10.00) over a period not exceeding thirty-six (36) months. Such admission to membership shall entail the discontinuance of any Social Security coverage on the member's subsequent earnings. Further, any retirement or disability annuity to which he becomes entitled in accord with section 6 [157.43] shall be subject to reduction by a Social Security adjustment in case he has elected retroactive membership on his prior service. This adjustment shall be applied where the city has paid F.I.C.A. taxes for Social Security coverage on his prior earnings and shall equal fifty percent (50%) of a proportion of the Social Security primary benefit available to him on the date of his retirement. Such proportion shall be determined as the percentage which the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from the city bears to the total F.I.C.A. taxes paid on his earnings from all sources since January 1, 1938. Employees who had previously worked for CETA in city jobs without a break in service of greater than two (2) years and/or special funds without a break in service of greater than two (2) years or for redevelopment (who were previously offered a chance to have such redevelopment time credited as pension time) shall specifically be included in this section and be given one last opportunity to buy back said periods of service. 
(i)  This open period subject to the provisions and requirements of paragraph (h) shall also be available to any member who wishes to establish credit for any period of non-participating prior service which preceded the effective date of his membership, provided such prior period was of at least twelve months duration. 
(j)  The provisions of paragraphs (h) and (i) for establishing retroactive membership credits shall expire six (6) months after the date on which the open period shall have commenced. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87; Amd. of 2-6-89)  
Sec. 157.47. - Benefits for periods of military service. 
In determining benefits under sections 157.43 and 157.44, credit shall be given for periods of military service in World War II, the Korean War, or the Vietnam War, subject to the following conditions: Any member who, after October 16, 1940, entered any branch of the armed forces of the United States or any service auxiliary thereto, or any civil emergency defense employment pursuant to requisition by the federal or state government, including those employees of the municipal airport who were displaced from their regular employment when the army took over the airport and who undertook duties connected with air force, or any member who shall enter such services while the United States is at war, and who has been or shall be re-employed by the city within six months after the termination of such military service, shall qualify for credit for his period of military service, provided he resumes his participation in the Retirement Fund, with an effective date antedating his entry into such service. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.48. - Preservation of benefits paid under previous acts. 
The provisions of this article [this division] shall not affect the benefits already in course of payment in accordance with the provisions of previous acts. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 157.49. - Future cost-of-living adjustments. 
On July 1, 1970, and annually on each July 1 thereafter, the monthly payments on those service annuities, disability annuities and survivors' benefits on which at least eighteen (18) monthly payments have been made will be increased, or decreased, for changes in the cost-of-living as indicated by the federal Consumer Price Index. Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, all Cities, revised (1967—100). For this purpose the retirement board will determine an adjustment percentage for July 1, 1970, by relating such index for the full calendar year 1969 to that for the full calendar year 1968, but such adjustment percentage shall be limited to a maximum of one hundred three percent (103%) and to a minimum of ninety-seven percent (97%); further, no adjustment will be made where the increase or decrease for the year is less than one-quarter (¼) of one (1) percent. For each case on which payments commenced prior to January 1, 1969, the monthly payment for June 1970, including any previous cost-of-living adjustments, will be multiplied by such adjustment percentage as determined by the retirement board in order to calculate the adjusted monthly payments for the twelve (12) months following July 1, 1970. A similar procedure will be repeated to adjust payments each year thereafter. However, the monthly benefit originally provided for a retired member or for a survivor shall never be reduced because of the accumulative effect of all cost-of-living adjustments. 
(Amd. of 7-6-87)  
Sec. 158. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IXA. - PENSIONS FOR FORMER OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 159. - Pensions for former mayor and surviving spouse. 
The City of New Haven shall grant to any former mayor of said city, who has served as mayor for not less than eight (8) years and is not entitled to a pension from said city under any other law, and upon his or her death, any surviving spouse thereof, a pension of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per annum, payable monthly, commencing for such mayor at age sixty-five (65) and for such surviving spouse upon the former mayor's death and upon the surviving spouse attaining age sixty-five (65) and continuing until the death of the former mayor and until the death of the surviving spouse. During the years for which said pension shall be payable, an appropriation therefor may be made annually in the New Haven city budget. The provision for a pension for a surviving spouse shall apply prospectively, and retroactively, to any surviving spouse of a deceased qualified mayor herein, which spouse is living at the date of passage hereof. 
(Special Laws 1967, Act No. 62; Ord. No. 1258, 3-21-00) 
Editor's note— Section 159 is derived from Act No. 62, Special Laws 1967.  
ARTICLE X. - RETIREMENT OF CUSTODIANS AND ENGINEERS[15]

Editor's note— Prior provisions concerning retirement of janitors and engineers may be found in Special Laws 1911, Act No. 366. Said 1911 act was expressly repealed by Special Laws 1925, Act No. 223, which established a custodians' and engineers' retirement fund and was subsequently amended by Special Laws 1941, Acts Nos. 358, 360 and 551; by Special Laws 1947, Act No. 324; and by Special Laws 1949, Act No. 500. The 1925 act and all amendments thereto were repealed by Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, which comprises Article X of this compilation, and have therefore been omitted. The editors have also omitted Special Laws 1927, Act No. 137, which provided for transfer of assets accumulated under the 1911 act to a fund established by the 1925 act. The provisions of §§ 260—267 of the 1952 Revised Charter were taken directly from these repealed acts establishing and amending the 1925 retirement fund, except that said revision omitted § 6 of the 1925 act providing that it should not be construed as preventing discontinuance of employment for cause. 
 
Sec. 160. - Definition of custodians and engineers. 
The term "custodian and engineer" or "custodians and engineers," as used in this act [article], shall include all custodians and engineers regularly appointed in the public day schools by the board of education, including the director of buildings and grounds. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 9)  
Sec. 161. - Personnel hired after January 1, 1948 to participate in city employees' retirement fund. 
No person who shall have been employed as a custodian or engineer after January 1, 1948 shall be eligible to participate in the custodians' and engineers' retirement fund but shall be eligible to participate in the city employees' retirement system. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 11) 
Cross reference— City employees' retirement fund, Art. IX, §§ 130—159.  
Sec. 162. - Custodians' and engineers' retirement fund established; assets. 
There shall be a fund known as the custodians' and engineers' retirement fund for the benefit of custodians and engineers of the public day schools of the City of New Haven, who were employed as custodians and engineers in the public day schools prior to January 1, 1948, which fund shall consist of moneys received from the following sources: 
(1)  All appropriations, gifts or bequests made to the fund from public or private sources, for the purpose for which said retirement fund is established; 
(2)  An assessment of one and one-half percent (1½%) on all moneys appropriated for custodians' and engineers' salaries, which shall be retained from such appropriations and paid into said fund, the custodians and engineers to pay an assessment of five percent (5%) on the salaries received by them from such appropriations; 
(3)  All compensation for services that may be unclaimed by any custodian or engineer for a period of six (6) months after the same shall have become due; 
(4)  An appropriation to said fund by the City of New Haven of an amount equal to the difference between the one and one-half percent (1½%) deducted from such appropriation for salaries and the amount required to meet the expenditures hereinafter provided for. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 1; Ord. of 4-6-70) 
Editor's note— The ordinance enacted April 6, 1970, approved April 15, 1970, and enacted May 5, 1970, amended § 162 by increasing 4% to 5% in (2).  
Sec. 163. - Duties of board of education, city treasurer; payment of order on fund; disposition of income. 
The board of education of the City of New Haven shall be trustee of said fund, and may invest and reinvest the same in accordance with the laws relating to investment of trust funds. The city treasurer shall be treasurer of said fund. All orders on said fund shall be signed by the secretary and countersigned by the president of the board of education. The unexpended yearly balance of said fund, if any, shall be set apart by said trustee and constitute a permanent fund to be invested by the trustee as aforesaid, and the income of such permanent fund shall be used in carrying out the provisions of this act [article]. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 2)  
Sec. 164. - Board of retirement created; duty to recommend personnel eligible for retirement. 
There shall be a board of retirement in said city which shall consist of the mayor, the president of the board of aldermen, the secretary of the board of education and two (2) members who shall be chosen by the custodians and engineers of said public day schools from their members, at a meeting held for that purpose. One (1) of such members shall be elected annually to serve for a term of two (2) years from the first day of October. Said board shall annually choose a secretary. It shall be the duty of the secretary to give proper notice to the custodians and engineers who are members of this retirement system to attend the annual meeting to be held on the third Monday of September for the election of one of their members to said retirement board and said secretary shall preside at and conduct such meeting. In the event of a vacancy in an elected position on said board, the secretary, within thirty (30) days thereafter, shall call a meeting of all members of the retirement system for the election of one of their number to fill such vacancy for the unexpired portion of the term. Said board shall investigate and recommend to the board of education, custodians and engineers eligible for retirement under the provisions of this act [article]. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 3)  
Sec. 165. - Engineers, custodians eligible for retirement. 
(1)  Upon the recommendation of the board of retirement, the board of education may retire: 
(a)  Any custodian or engineer who shall have been connected with the public day schools of the city of New Haven for a period of twenty-five years or more or 
(b)  Any custodian or engineer who may have become incapacitated while in the service from further duty as a custodian or engineer, and thereupon said trustee shall pay to such custodian or engineer during the rest of his life a sum equal to one-half his average salary for the five highest salaried years of his employment. 
(2)  Upon the written request of any custodian or engineer, when such custodian or engineer has performed twenty-five years of service and has attained the age of sixty-five or has performed thirty years of service and has attained the age of sixty, or has performed thirty-five years of service regardless of age, the board of retirement shall recommend the permanent retirement of such person, and the board of education shall permanently retire such custodian or engineer and thereupon, pay to such custodian or engineer during the rest of his life, a sum equal to one-half of his average salary for the five highest-salaried years of his employment. 
(3)  At the age of sixty-eight years, the retirement of any custodian or engineer shall be compulsory and no custodian or engineer shall be continued in service or employed after having reached such age of sixty-eight years, except that custodians and engineers already regularly appointed attaining the age of sixty-eight years before completing twenty-five years of service may continue in the service after reaching their sixty-eighth birthday until the completion of twenty-five years of service, at the expiration of which such employee shall then be retired and shall not continue to be employed in the service. Thereupon, said trustee shall pay to such custodian or engineer during the rest of his life, a sum equal to one-half of his average salary for the five highest-salaried years of his employment. As used in this act [article], the word "salary" shall mean all compensation for services paid by the board of education of the city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 4; Special Laws 1961, Act No. 238, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 166. - Additional pension payments for service more than twenty-five years. 
After twenty-five years of service for each additional full year of service, but in no event for a period of more than ten years, there shall be added to the retirement annuity of each custodian or engineer a sum equaling two percent computed upon his average salary for the five highest-salaried years of his employment. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 5)  
Sec. 167. - Retirement provisions not to affect authority of board of education to dismiss for cause. 
No provision of this act [article] shall be so construed as to prevent the board of education from discontinuing the employment of any custodian or engineer for cause. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 6)  
Sec. 168. - Board of examiners created; disability retirements. 
The board of retirement herein provided for shall annually appoint three physicians, or surgeons of the city of New Haven, of at least ten years' active practice, who shall be known as the board of examiners, who shall serve without pay and who shall, upon request of the board of education or the board of retirement, make such examinations as may be called for under the terms of this section and report their findings in writing to the board making such request. On recommendation by a majority vote of the board of retirement, the board of education may, by a majority of its members, place on the disability list for the remainder of his or her life, or any part thereof, any such custodian or engineer qualifying under subsection 1 (b) of section 4, [16] provided no custodian or engineer shall be placed upon the disability list until the board of examiners shall have filed a written report within thirty days of examination, certifying that such custodian or engineer is incapacitated for further service as a custodian or engineer. Any applicant for retirement to the disability list under the provisions of subsection 1 (b) of section 4* shall submit to a medical examination by the board of examiners before his or her application shall be considered. The board of education may, by a majority vote of its members and upon recommendation by a majority vote of the board of retirement, place such custodian or engineer on the disability list when such disability shall have been found to exist. No provision of this act [article] shall be construed as prohibiting the board of retirement from recommending, by a majority vote, to the board of education that the disability of any custodian or engineer retired as provided under subsection 1 (b) of section 4*; shall be declared ended. The board of education may, by a majority vote of its members, on such recommendation of said board of retirement, declare ended the disability of such custodian or engineer retired as provided under the terms of subsection 1 (b) of section 4*; and, upon delivery to such custodian or engineer, of a written offer of re-appointment to a position as custodian or engineer equal in remuneration to the one previously held by such custodian or engineer, the payment of the annuity of such custodian or engineer under the disability clause as provided in subsection 1 (b) of section 4*; shall be discontinued. No provision of this act [article] shall be construed as prohibiting a custodian or engineer who shall have been placed upon the disability list from applying once each year to be re-instated to active duty as custodian or engineer. On recommendation by a majority vote of the board of retirement after an examination of such applicant by the board of examiners, the board of education may, by a majority vote, restore such custodian or engineer to active duty, and the disability annuity shall cease on the day that such custodian or engineer shall resume his work at his former remuneration. The disability provided for in subsection 1 (b) of section 4*; shall not be declared ended until an examination shall have been made by the board of examiners and the board of examiners shall have certified, by a majority vote, that such custodian or engineer has been found to be physically and mentally fitted for further service in the public day schools of the city of New Haven. The provisions of this section shall not apply to ordinary cases of temporary disability. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 7) 
Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Note— Subsection (1)(b) of section 4 of Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518 appears as § 165(1)(b) of this compilation. 
 
Sec. 169. - Reports on retirement fund by board of education. 
Each September the board of education shall file with the board of aldermen an annual report showing the financial condition of the custodians' and engineers' retirement fund. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 8)  
Sec. 170. - Payments to widows, children, other beneficiaries. 
In the event of the death of a member of this retirement fund, prior to the commencement of an annuity, and no wife or dependent child or children survive, the trustee may pay to the member's beneficiary an amount equal to his total contributions. Upon the death of a retired member his beneficiary, designated or otherwise, may upon written request, withdraw the total amount of his contributions less the amount paid to him during his retirement except that should he be survived by a wife or dependent child or children they shall receive annuities in lieu of such repayment of contributions, according to the provisions of this act [article]. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 10; Special Laws 1961, Act No. 238, § 3)  
Sec. 171. - Effect of resignation before becoming eligible for retirement. 
Any member leaving the employment of the board of education before becoming eligible for retirement may, upon written request to the retirement board, withdraw the total of all contributions made by him, without interest, provided, if no request is made within one year of the date of termination of employment, such contributions shall revert to the fund. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 12)  
Sec. 172. - Computation of benefits. 
(1)  On and after October 1, 1961, upon the death of an active or retired member of this fund, there shall be paid to or on account of his child or children under 18 years of age and to his widow such monthly benefits, if any, as such person or persons may be entitled to receive in accordance with the provisions of this section as computed by the formula in Appendix A. 
(2)  [Repealed]. 
(3)  [Repealed]. 
(4)  "Average annual salary" as used in computing survivorship benefits shall mean the average annual salary received by the deceased member for the five highest-salaried years of his employment by the board of education, excluding, however, that portion in excess of $4,800. 
(5)  Upon the remarriage of a widow entitled to benefits under paragraph (1) of this section, the monthly payments to or on account of such person shall cease. When a child entitled to benefits reaches the age of eighteen, or marries before reaching the age of eighteen, or is adopted by anyone except his step-parent, grandparent, aunt or uncle, payments to or on account of such child shall cease. 
(6)  In each case where monthly survivorship benefits are payable under this section, the amount thereof corresponding to the deceased members' average annual salary shall be determined by the retirement board by use of the formula contained in Appendix A, and such determination based upon the formula shall be final and conclusive. 
(7)  No person shall be entitled to receive simultaneous benefits under paragraphs (2) and (3). 
(8)  In cases where it appears to the retirement board that the circumstances so warrant, the board may direct that payments of survivorship benefits under this section shall be made to parties other than the nominal beneficiaries to be applied to the benefit of such beneficiaries, and any such direction shall be final and conclusive. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 13; Special Laws 1961, Act No. 238, §§ 4—8)  
Sec. 173. - Pensioners under repealed acts declared members of custodians' and engineers' fund. 
On the effective date of this act [article] [17] all persons, members of or receiving benefits as pensioners from the custodians' and engineers' retirement fund which is repealed by the express provisions of this act [article] shall become and be members of the custodians' and engineers' fund created by this act [article] and all assets and rights belonging to this fund shall be transferred to the retirement fund created by this act [article]. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 14)

Sec. 174. - Appendix A, computation of survivorship benefits; repeals. 
APPENDIX A 
FORMULA FOR DETERMINING 
SURVIVORSHIP BENEFITS 
The Survivorship Benefit Base shall be derived from the average monthly salary as follows: Of the average monthly salary up to $400.00, add 55% of the first $110.00 to 25% of the remainder. The sum shall be the Survivorship Benefit Base. 
Three-fourths of the Survivorship Benefit Base shall be the monthly benefit paid to: 
(1)  A surviving widow; 
(2)  Each surviving dependent child. 
Total benefits shall be raised to the next highest multiple of ten cents. 
The maximum monthly benefit to families shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). Total monthly family benefits shall be reduced to the greater of (1) one and one-half (1½) times the Survivorship Benefit Base, or (2) 80 percent (80%) of the average monthly wage from which the Survivorship Benefit Base was determined. 
The following special acts are hereby repealed: 
(1)  Number 366 of the special acts of 1911 
(2)  Number 223 of the special acts of 1925 
(3)  Number 358 of the special acts of 1941 
(4)  Number 551 of the special acts of 1941 
(5)  Number 324 of the special acts of 1947 
(6)  Number 500 of the special acts of 1949; 
and any other acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act. 
(Special Laws 1959, Act No. 518, § 14; Special Laws 1961, Act 238, § 9) 
Note— For effect of these repeals, see note at beginning of this Article.  
Sec. 174.1. - Cost of living adjustments. 
Effective July 1, 1971, the monthly amounts payable to members who retired prior to January 1, 1968 and the monthly benefits payable to the qualified survivors of members who died prior to January 1, 1968 shall be increased by cost of living adjustments which will approximately reflect the percentage increase in the federal consumer price index between the calendar year when the payments commenced in each case and the calendar year 1968. 
The amount of increase in each case will be determined by multiplying the monthly payment by the appropriate percentage of increase set forth in the following table:

Sec. 175. - Survivorship benefits—Generally. 
(1)  On and after July 1, 1969 upon the death of a male or widowed female member who has participated in the retirement fund for a period of not less than six (6) months or who had been retired by reason of age and service, or by reason of disability, there shall be paid to or on account of his or her surviving child or children under eighteen (18) years of age, and in the case of a male member, to his qualified widow, monthly benefits consistent with the following table:
