Any such widow, on her remarriage, shall receive only such benefits as are payable to her children alone. 
(2)  "Average annual pay," as used in computing survivorship benefits shall mean the average annual rate of pay received by the deceased member for the final five (5) years of his service of employment by the city, or the duration of such service or employment if less than five (5) years, subject to a maximum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) for each average annual pay. 
(3)  On or after January 1, 1969, upon the death of a male or widowed female who has completed ten (10) years of continuous service for the city or who has qualified for a disability annuity or a retirement benefit by reason of age and service, a minimum monthly benefit will be paid to his qualified survivors if greater than the amount determined from the benefit table above. Said minimum monthly benefit shall be equal to fifty percent (50%) of the amount of the monthly annuity to which the member would have been entitled if he had been permanently disabled on the date of his death, or fifty percent (50%) of the amount of his actual monthly annuity in the case of a member who has been receiving retirement or disability benefits from the fund. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69) 
Editor's note— The ordinance from which §§ 175 and 176 are derived enacted Dec. 1, and approved Dec. 8, 1969, was enacted as adding §§ 13A and 13B of Special Act 518 of 1959, from which Art. X is derived, hence codification in this manner was at the discretion of the editors.  
Sec. 176. - Same—Withdrawal of contribution; application of provisions. 
On the death of any retired custodian or engineer, his designated beneficiary may on written request to the retirement board, withdraw the total of all contributions made by him, without interest, less the total amount paid to him during his retirement. If no such request is made within ten (10) years, such contributions shall revert to the fund. In the event that a deceased member is survived by a qualified widow or child or children under the age of eighteen (18), the benefits provided for in section 175 shall be paid in lieu of such withdrawal of contribution. 
The provisions of sections 175 and 176 shall apply to those members of the Custodians' and Engineers' Retirement Fund (established under Special Act No. 518, Article X of the Special Laws of the City of New Haven) not covered by the agreement between the New Haven Board of Education and New Haven Board of Education Employees Local 287, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO, as approved in accordance with the provisions of the Municipal Employees Relations Act of the State of Connecticut, and shall become effective upon passage. 
(Ord. of 12-1-69; Ord. of 4-6-70) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 175. The ordinance enacted April 6, 1970, approved April 15, 1970, and enacted May 5, 1970, amended § 176 by revising the parenthetical material and adding the word "not" before "covered".  
Secs. 177—179. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - RETIREMENT OF POLICE AND FIRE PERSONNEL  
DIVISION 1. - ORIGINAL POLICE AND FIRE RETIREMENT FUNDS[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Editor's note— Division 1, §§ 180—193 contains the provisions of the 1899 charter, Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, §§ 66—69 and §§ 71, 72, as amended, as well as pension provisions clearly applicable to the system there established. Section 70 of said charter was repealed by Special Laws 1929, Act No. 435, § 4, and is therefore not included. Special Laws, 1921, Act No. 376, which also dealt with police and fire pensions failed to gain approval at a required referendum, and has also been omitted from this compilation. This division is applicable only to firemen and policemen employed before December 31, 1957; for provisions concerning pensions for those employed subsequent to that date, see division 2 of this article §§ 200—214. 
Subsequently this division was designated "Police and Fire Plan No. 1" and div. 2 was designated "Police and Fire Plan No. 2." The plans were merged into a single new pension plan and fund known as the "Policemen's & Firemen's Pension Fund" by an ordinance adopted May 29, 1990. 
 
Sec. 180. - Policemen and firemen's relief funds—established. 
There shall hereafter be a fund for the policemen and a fund for the firemen of said city, known as the Policemen's Relief Fund and the Firemen's Relief Fund, to which shall belong: 
(1)  All moneys and securities included in the fund now existing in each department. 
(2)  All bequests and donations from public or private sources to either department on account of services rendered, or for the purposes for which the fund is established. 
(3)  Five (5) percentum of all fees collected on account of licenses issued to sell spirituous or intoxicating liquors within the city of New Haven until the Policemen's Relief Fund amounts to the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), and the Firemen's Relief Fund amounts to the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). When the funds of these departments equal the sums above named, no more fees from licenses to sell spirituous or intoxicating liquors within the city of New Haven shall be paid into said funds, but shall be paid into the city treasury to be used for ordinary expenses, except the funds at any time shall fall below the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in the Policemen's Relief Fund, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.) in the Firemen's Relief Fund, then the fees, to the amount of five percentum, collected on account of licenses to sell spirituous or intoxicating liquors within the city of New Haven, shall be paid into said fund until the amounts above named are reached, and the fee shall then cease to be paid, and revert to the city treasury. 
(4)  All moneys or property presented to any member of either department on account of special services, except such as may, by special vote of the board of commissioners of such department, and with the approval of the mayor, be retained by such member. 
(5)  Assessments on the salaries of members of the police department at the rate of two and one-half (2½) percent for the calendar year 1958, three (3) percent for the calendar year 1959, three and one-half (3½) percent for the calendar year 1960, four (4) percent for the calendar year 1961 and four percent per annum thereafter, payable monthly or quarterly as the trustees of such fund may determine. 
(6)  Such monthly assessments on the salaries of the members of the fire department, not exceeding two and one-half (2½) percent for the calendar year 1958, three (3) percent for the calendar year 1959, three and one-half (3½) percent for the calendar year 1960, four (4) per cent for the calendar year 1961, and four (4) percent per annum thereafter, as the trustees of such fund may determine. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 66; Special Laws 1901, Act No. 217, § 1; Special Laws 1957, Act No. 406) 
Editor's note— Section 180 above differs from § 252 of the 1952 Revised Charter in the following respects: (1) Said § 252 does not contain the provisions set out in subsection (3) above; (2) Section 252 contains a subsection (f) concerning estimates by the board of finance which does not appear in § 186 above; (3) The provisions of Special Laws 1957, Act No. 406, amending subsections (5) and (6) have been incorporated into § 186 above.  
Sec. 181. - Same—Official designations; police fund to include lost, confiscated property. 
Said funds shall be respectively known as the "Policemen's Relief Fund" and "The Firemen's Relief Fund," and the former shall also include all lost, abandoned, unclaimed, or stolen moneys in charge of the police department, and all moneys arising from the sale of lost, abandoned, unclaimed, or stolen property in charge of said department, now made available for the purpose by the statute laws of the state. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 67) 
Editor's note— Section 181 above is the same as § 253 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 182. - Same—Administration; officers of funds; signing of orders. 
The boards of commissioners of such departments shall respectively be boards of trustees of said funds, and may invest and reinvest the same as the laws relating to trust funds may permit. The mayor shall be president of each of said boards, the city treasurer shall be its treasurer, and the clerk of the department its clerk. All orders on said funds shall be signed by the clerk and countersigned by the president. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 68) 
Editor's note— Section 182 above is the same as § 254 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 183. - Retirement of police, fire personnel for job-connected disability. 
The board of police commissioners, with the affirmative vote of four commissioners and with the mayor's approval, and the board of fire commissioners, with the affirmative vote of three commissioners and with the mayor's approval, may permanently retire any member of the department who, while in the actual performance of duty and by reason of the performance of such duty, and without fault and misconduct on his part, shall have become permanently disabled, physically or mentally, so as to be entirely unfitted to perform such duties; and either of said boards may cause to be paid from the fund of said department to said member during his lifetime and in monthly installments, unless said vote is annulled by four of said police commissioners or three of said fire commissioners, as the case may be, a sum not greater than one-half nor less than one-fourth of his previous compensation; provided however, that in the cases mentioned in this section, such medical examiners as said board may appoint shall certify in writing that such disability exists, and in their opinion from such cause. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 69) 
Editor's note— The provisions of § 183 above are not included in the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 184. - Retirement of firemen after twenty-five years of service or reaching age of sixty-eight. 
Said board of fire commissioners shall permanently retire any member or employee of the fire department on his or her written request when such member or employee has performed twenty-five years of service in the department. Said board of fire commissioners shall permanently retire any member or employee of the fire department, except the chief thereof, when such member or employee shall reach the age of sixty-eight years, or is of the age of sixty-eight years or over. Said board of fire commissioners may at any time upon a certificate of the medical examiners of the fire department showing that such member is permanently disabled, physically or mentally, so as to be unfit for duty, retire said member from service and place him on the pension list. All persons retired and placed on the pension list under this section shall be awarded an annual pension during his life-time of a sum not less than one-half of the full salary or compensation of such member so retired, payable in monthly installments, irrespective of whether he was retired prior to the passage of this amendment or subsequent thereto. Each pension granted under this section shall be for the natural life of the pensioner and shall not be revoked, repealed nor diminished, provided no member having the right to retire on pension at the time this act [article] shall take effect shall be deprived of such right by reason of his remaining a member of said department or of any provisions of this act [article]. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 487, § 69; Special Laws 1917, Act No. 449, § 15; Special Laws 1927, Act No. 356; Special Laws, 1929, Act No. 435, §§ 2, 3; Special Laws 1931, Act No. 391; Special Laws 1941, Act No. 465) 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1941, Act No. 465, amended § 117 of the 1928 charter revision by adding the provisions which appear as § 184 above. Said § 117 was originally derived from § 69 of the 1899 charter so the editors have treated said 1941 act as an amendment to § 69. Section 184 above is the same as § 255 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 185. - Retirement of policemen, after twenty-five years of service or reaching age sixty-five. 
Said board of police commissioners shall permanently retire any member or employee of the police department on his or her written request when such member or employee has performed twenty-five years of service in the department. Said board of police commissioners shall permanently retire any member or employee of the police department, except the chief thereof, when such member or employee reaches the age of sixty-five, or is of the age of sixty-five or over. Said board of police commissioners may at anytime upon a certificate of the medical examiners of the police department showing that such member is permanently disabled, physically or mentally, so as to be unfit for duty, retire said member from service and place him on the pension list. All persons retired and placed on the pension list under this section shall be awarded an annual pension during his lifetime of a sum not less than one-half of the full salary or compensation of such member so retired, payable in monthly installments, irrespective of whether he was retired prior to the passage of this amendment or subsequent thereto. Each pension granted under this section shall be for the natural life of the pensioner and shall not be revoked, repealed or diminished, provided no member having the right to retire on pension at the time this act takes effect shall be deprived of such right by reason of his remaining a member of said department or of any provisions of this act. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 69; Special Laws 1937, Act No. 185; Special Laws 1941, Act No. 433; Special Laws 1967, Act No. 217, § 1) 
Editor's note— Section 185 above is the same as § 256 of the 1952 Revised Charter. Section 1 of Act No. 217, Special Laws, 1967, amended "Number 433 of the special acts of 1941, being section 256 of the charter of the city of New Haven, revision 1951," to read as set out, effective July 1, 1968. Formerly the mandatory retirement age was sixty-eight.  
Sec. 186. - Retirement of disabled police, fire personnel. 
Any regularly appointed officer or member of either the police or the fire departments of the city of New Haven who shall have served continuously therein for a period of at least ten years, and while still in the service of either department shall become totally and permanently, physically or mentally, disabled, and incapacitated for further service, may, with the affirmative vote of four commissioners of the police department, together with the mayor's approval, or with the affirmative vote of three commissioners of the fire department, together with the mayor's approval, be placed on the retirement list, and shall during the period of such incapacity be entitled to and awarded an annual pension to be paid in monthly installments during his disability of a sum not less than one-half of the full salary or compensation of such member so retired; provided such medical examiners as either board may appoint shall certify in writing that the disability as claimed by such member does in fact exist, and that in their opinion it appears to be of a permanent nature and does totally incapacitate the member from further service in the department. Either the board of police commissioners or the board of fire commissioners may, from time to time, appoint medical examiners to determine whether or not such member of the department to be retired under the provisions of this act continues totally and permanently disabled and incapacitated for further duties, and such member shall be requested to submit himself to any medical examination requested by the board of commissioners of the department of which he was a member. In the event that either the board of police commissioners or the board of fire commissioners shall, upon competent medical evidence, conclude that the disability for which a member is receiving pension no longer exists, it shall order a discontinuance of the payment of benefits as provided herein, and shall restore such member to active duty in the department with which he was connected at the time of his retirement on account of disability. The provisions of this act shall be effective so as to cover all persons who were members of either department as of January 1, 1940. 
(Special Laws 1941, Act No. 393) 
Editor's note— Section 186 above is the same as § 257 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 187. - Payment to widows, children of policemen, firemen. 
Upon the death of any member of the police or fire department, who shall have served continuously as a regular member of such department for at least ten years and who shall have actually contributed to said relief fund, the widow of such member shall receive, until her death or remarriage, out of said fund of such department, a monthly sum equal to one-fourth of the compensation received by such member at the time of his death, if in active service, or a monthly sum equal to one-half of the pension received by such member at the time of his death, if retired. Subject to the same conditions as to term of service and contributions to the relief fund, such sums shall likewise be so paid to the widow of any member of the police department who died subsequent to the first day of May, 1901, or of any member of the fire department who died subsequent to the first day of September, 1916. Such sums shall likewise be so paid to the widow of any member of either of such departments, including supernumeraries in the police department and substitutes in the fire department, who shall have been killed while in the actual performance of duty, or shall have died from the proximate effects of any injury received while in the actual discharge of such duty, irrespective of the length of service of such member at the time of his death or failure to contribute to said relief fund, provided such death shall have occurred on or after the first day of May, 1901. In any of the above cases, upon the death of such widow before or after remarriage, leaving a child or children of such deceased member, under the age of sixteen years, the board of police commissioners, with the affirmative vote of four commissioners and with the mayor's approval, and the board of fire commissioners, with the affirmative vote of three commissioners and with the mayor's approval, may cause to be paid monthly, to the legally appointed guardian of such child or children, for his or their use and benefit, a sum or sums not exceeding in total the amount hereinbefore provided to be received by such widow, and may, from time to time, apportion such sums between such children as it may deem best; provided, as each such child shall arrive at the age of sixteen years, the payments to such child shall cease. No such payments or pension shall be allowed or paid to such widow or children so long or for such period as such widow or children shall receive or be entitled to receive compensation under the provisions of the general status relating to workmen's compensation. The term "widow," as used in this section, shall be limited to (1) the surviving wife of such member who was married to him prior to his retirement from such department, if retired, and who was living with him at the time of his death or, if not so living with him, was absent by reason of his fault or (2) the surviving wife of such member who married him subsequent to his retirement from such department, if retired, and lived with him continuously thereafter until the time of his death but not less than five years or, if not so living with him at the time of his death, was absent by reason of his fault. The term "child" or "children," as used in this section, shall be limited in meaning to the child or children, born, before or after the death of such member, to such member and his wife to whom he was married prior to his retirement from such department, if retired. The widows or children affected by the provisions of this act shall only be entitled to any payments or pension from and after the time when this act shall take effect. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 69; Special Laws 1929, Act No. 435, § 3; Special Laws 1931, Act No. 391; Special Laws 1967, Act No. 129) 
Editor's note— Section 187 above is the same as § 258 of the 1952 Revised Charter. The term "widow" was redefined by Act No. 129, Special Law, 1967.  
Sec. 188. - Duties of clerk in police, fire departments concerning funds. 
The clerk in each department shall record all of the doings of the board of trustees, and all of the doings of the board of commissioners in relation to the fund of his department, and shall record the vote of each member on each question connected therewith. An itemized report of the condition of each fund and of all receipts and disbursements shall be submitted to the mayor on or before the fifteenth day of February, 1900, and annually thereafter, for the preceding fiscal year. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 72) 
Editor's note— Section 188 above is the same as § 259 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 189. - Retired policemen, firemen subject to order of commissioner, re-examination. 
All members on the retired lists in either department shall be subject to the orders of the board of commissioners of such department, which may at any time require any member to be re-examined, and in case he shall be reported capable of performing duty, may, by the affirmative vote of four of said police commissioners and with the mayor's approval, or of three of said fire commissioners, as the case may be, and with the mayor's approval, restore him to service in said department. 
(Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, § 71) 
Editor's note— The provisions of § 189 above are not contained in the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 190. - 1955 increase in police pensions, benefits. 
(a)  The board of police commissioners of the city of New Haven, as trustees of the Policemen's Relief Fund of said city, is directed to increase the pensions of members of the police department of said city retired prior to December 31, 1946, by twenty dollars per month. 
(b)  Said board shall also adjust the pensions of widows of former members of said department, which widows were receiving pensions on December 31, 1946, or whose husbands were receiving pensions on said date, by ten dollars per month. 
(Special Laws 1955, Act No. 647, § 1) 
Editor's note— The provisions contained in §§ 190—193 were enacted subsequent to the 1952 Revised Charter, and therefore are not included therein.  
Sec. 191. - 1955 increase in fire pensions, benefits. 
(a)  The board of fire commissioners of the city of New Haven, as trustees of the Firemen's Relief Fund of said city, is directed to increase the pensions of members of the fire department of said city retired prior to December 31, 1946, by twenty dollars per month. 
(b)  Said board shall also adjust the pensions of widows of former members of said department, which widows were receiving pensions on December 31, 1946, or whose husbands were receiving pensions on said date, by ten dollars per month. 
(Special Laws 1955, Act No. 647, § 2) 
Note— See note following § 190.  
Sec. 192. - 1957 increase in police pensions, benefits. 
(a)  The board of police commissioners, as trustees of the policemen's relief fund of the city of New Haven, are directed to adjust the pensions of members of the police department who retired prior to December 31, 1946, by increasing said pensions twenty-five dollars ($25.00) monthly. 
(b)  The pensions of widows of any retired member, regardless of their date of retirement, shall be adjusted so that the minimum pension shall not be less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 390, § 1) 
Note— See note following § 165.  
Sec. 193. - 1957 increase in fire pensions, benefits. 
(a)  The board of fire commissioners, as trustees of the firemen's relief fund of the city of New Haven, are directed to adjust the pensions of members of the fire department who retired prior to December 31, 1946, by increasing said pensions twenty-five dollars ($25.00) monthly. 
(b)  The pensions of widows of any retired member, regardless of their date of retirement, shall be adjusted so that the minimum pension shall not be less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 390, § 2) 
Note— See note following § 165.  
Sec. 194. - Voluntary retirement of police, fire personnel after twenty-five years service. 
When any regularly appointed officer, member or employee of either the police or fire department who has served more than twenty-five (25) years shall make written application requesting retirement from his department, the board of police commissioners for the police department or the board of fire commissioners for the fire department shall order immediate retirement of such applicant from his department, and such applicant shall be entitled to receive from the pension fund a yearly amount equal to one-half (½) of the yearly compensation received by such regularly appointed officer, member or employee; in addition thereto said regularly appointed officer, member or employee who has served more than twenty-five (25) years in his department shall receive an additional two per cent (2%) of his basic salary at the time of his retirement for each year over and above the twenty-five (25) years of service, but in no event shall his pension exceed seventy per cent (70%) of his basic salary at the time of his retirement. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 529, § 1) 
Editor's note— At the specific request of the city, for purposes of classification, former Divs. 3—5, §§ 215—223 of this article have been redesignated §§ 199—199.3 as herein set out. The provisions of §§ 194, 195 (formerly Div. 3, §§ 215, 216) are derived from Special Laws 1957, Act No. 529, approved May 28, 1957. The provisions of §§ 196—198 (formerly Div. 4, §§ 217—219) are derived from Act No. 265, Special Laws 1963. The provisions of §§ 199, 199.1 (formerly Div. 5, §§ 220, 221) are derived from Special Laws 1965, Act No. 61, approved May 24, 1965 and effective April 1, 1966. The provisions of § 199.2 (formerly Div. 5, § 222) are derived from Special Laws 1967, Act No. 141. The provisions of § 199.3 (formerly Div. 5, § 223) are derived from Special Laws 1969, Act No. 164.  
Sec. 195. - "Widows" construed as including "widowers." 
The provisions providing for payment of certain sums of monies to widows and child or children of widows shall likewise be paid to widowers and child or children of widowers. The term "widower," as used in this section, shall be limited in its meaning to the surviving husband of such member, who shall have been married to her prior to her retirement from such department, if retired, and who was living with her at the time of her death, or, if not so living with her, was absent by reason of her fault. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act 529, § 2) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.

The minimum pension paid to retired members shall not be less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per annum. The minimum pension paid to the widows of retired members of the police department shall not be less than twelve hundred dollars ($1,200.00) per annum. 
(Special Laws 1963, Act No. 265, § 1) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
Sec. 197. - Fire department members; monthly increase; minimum per annum.

The minimum pension paid to retired members shall not be less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per annum. The minimum pension paid to the widows of retired members of the fire department shall not be less than twelve hundred ($1,200.00) dollars per annum. 
(Special Laws 1963, Act No. 265, § 2) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
Sec. 198. - Inapplicability of provisions to designated members of police and fire department. 
Nothing in this act [sections 196 through 198] shall be construed to increase the pension of any policeman or fireman retired prior to the effective date of this act from the service of the City of New Haven whose pension is in a greater amount than fifty per cent (50%) of the salaries paid as of July 1, 1957. 
(Special Laws of 1963, Act No. 265, § 3) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
Sec. 199. - Police department members; monthly increase; minimum per annum. 
The board of police commissioners, as trustees of the policemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pensions of each retired male member of the police department whose pension, on the date of passage of this act [sections 199 through 199.3], is less than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) by fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month, provided no such pension as so increased shall exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per annum. Said board shall so increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the police department whose pension, on said date, is less than fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) by ten dollars ($10.00) per month, provided no such pension as so increased shall exceed fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per annum. 
(Special Laws 1965, Act No. 61, § 1) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
Sec. 199.1. - Fire department members; monthly increase; minimum per annum. 
The board of fire commissioners, as trustees of the firemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pensions of each retired male member of the fire department whose pension, on the date of passage of this act [sections 199 through 199.3] is less than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) by fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month, provided no such pension as so increased shall exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per annum. Said board shall so increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the fire department whose pension, on said date, is less than fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) by ten dollars ($10.00) per month, provided no such pension as so increased shall exceed fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per annum. 
(Special Laws 1965, Act No. 61, § 2)
