Sec. 199.2. - 1967 pension adjustments for retired police and fire department members and widows of retired members. 
The board of police commissioners as trustees of the policemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven and the board of fire commissioners as trustees of the firemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven shall: 
(1)  Effective January 1, 1968, increase by twenty dollars ($20.00) monthly the pension of each retired male member of the police or fire department, as the case may be, who on said date is receiving a pension in an amount less than twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) annually, increase by ten dollars ($10.00) monthly the pension of each such retired male member who on said date is receiving a pension in an amount equal to or in excess of twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) annually, and increase by five dollars ($5.00) monthly the pension of each widow of a retired member of either of said departments who is receiving a pension of less than fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) annually; 
(2)  Effective July 1, 1968, increase by twenty dollars ($20.00) monthly the pension of each retired male member of either of said departments and increase by five dollars ($5.00) monthly the pension of each widow of a retired member; 
(3)  Effective July 1, 1969, increase by twenty dollars ($20.00) monthly the pension of each retired male member of either of said departments and increase by five dollars ($5.00) monthly the pension of each widow of a retired member, provided no pension as increased under the provisions of this act [sections 199 through 199.3] shall exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per annum for a retired member of either department or fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per annum for a widow of a retired member. 
(Special Laws 1967, Act No. 141) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
Sec. 199.3. - 1970 pension adjustments for retired male police and fire department members and widows. 
(a)  The board of police commissioners, as trustees of the policemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pensions of each retired male member of the police department whose pension, on October 1, 1970, is less than thirty-two hundred dollars ($3,200.00) to thirty-two hundred dollars ($3,200.00). Said board shall so increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the police department whose pension, on said date, is less than sixteen hundred dollars ($1,600.00) to sixteen hundred dollars ($1,600.00). 
(b)  The board of fire commissioners, as trustees of the firemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pensions of each retired male member of the fire department whose pension on October 1, 1970, is less than thirty-two hundred dollars ($3,200.00) to thirty-two hundred dollars ($3,200.00). Said board shall so increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the fire department whose pension, on said date, is less than sixteen hundred dollars ($1,600.00) to sixteen hundred dollars ($1,600.00). 
(Special Laws 1969, Act No. 164) 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
Sec. 199.4. - 1978 pension adjustments for retired police and fire department members and widows. 
(a)  The board of police commissioners, as trustees of the policemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven are directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of the police department whose pension, on October 1, 1978 is less than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) per year by an amount up to but not exceeding six hundred dollars ($600.00), provided such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00). 
Said board shall increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the police department by the amount of six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year. 
(b)  The board of fire commissioners, as trustees of the firemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of the fire department whose pension on October 1, 1978 is less than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) per year by an amount up to but not exceeding six hundred dollars ($600.00), provided such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00). 
Said board shall increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the fire department by the amount of six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year. 
(Ord. of 7-2-79)  
Sec. 199.5. - 1982 pension adjustments for retired police and fire members and widows. 
(a)  The board of police commissioners, as trustees of the policemen's relief fund to the City of New Haven are directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of the police department whose pension on July 1, 1982, is less than seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) per year by an amount not to exceed eight hundred forty dollars ($840.00). Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) per year. 
(b)  The board of fire commissioners, as trustee of the firemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, is directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of the fire department whose pension on July 1, 1982, is less than seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) per year by an amount not to exceed eight hundred forty dollars ($840.00). Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) per year. 
(c)  The police and fire commissioners shall also increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the police or fire department by an amount of eight hundred forty dollars ($840.00). 
(Amd. of 4-5-82, effective 9-1-82)  
Sec. 199.6. - 1988 pension adjustments for retired police and fire members and widows. 
(a)  The board of police commissioners, as trustees of the policemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven are directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of the police department whose pension on December 31, 1987 is less than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year, by an amount not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year. Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year. 
(b)  The board of fire commissioners, as trustees of the firemen's relief fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of the fire department whose pension on December 31, 1987 is less than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year by an amount not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year. Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year. 
(c)  The police and fire commissioners, respectively, shall also increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of the police or fire department by an amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per year. Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year. 
Further, the board of the policemen and firemen's pension fund, as trustees of this retirement fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pension paid to each widow of a retired member of this fund whose pension on December 31, 1987 is less than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year by an amount not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00). Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year. 
All of the above increases are to [be] effective as of January 1, 1988. 
(Ord. of 12-13-84, effective 1-1-85; Amd. of 3-7-88, § 1, effective 1-1-88)  
DIVISION 2. - PENSION FUND FOR POLICEMEN AND FIREMEN EMPLOYED AFTER DECEMBER 31, 1957[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note— Division 2, §§ 200—208 is derived from Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, which was entitled "An Act Establishing A Pension Fund For New Haven Policemen And Firemen Employed After December 31, 1957." For pension provisions applicable to personnel employed before said date, see div. 1, §§ 180—199 of this article. 
Subsequently this division was designated "Police and Fire Plan No. 2," and div. 1 was designated "Police and Fire Plan No. 1." The plans were merged into a single new pension plan and fund known as the "Policemen's & Firemen's Pension Fund" by an ordinance adopted May 29, 1990. 
 
Sec. 200. - Pensions established; payment of assessments. 
Effective as of midnight December 31, 1957, all persons thereafter appointed to the police and fire departments of the city of New Haven shall belong to the policemen's and firemen's pension fund. Assessments on the salaries of the members of the police and fire departments shall be at the rate of five per cent (5%) per annum, payable as the trustees of such fund may determine. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 1)  
Sec. 201. - Administration by pension board; membership of board. 
The management and administration of the pension plan are hereby vested in a pension board, which shall consist of seven (7) members: Two (2) members of the board of police commissioners, two (2) members of the board of fire commissioners, two (2) employee representatives, one from each department appointed by vote of the membership of each department, and the mayor, who shall be president of the said board. Vacancies to the board shall be filled by the mayor with the exception of the employee members, which shall be filled by vote of the membership of the respective department in which the vacancy occurred. The term of each commissioner shall be for two (2) years. 
The pension board shall be trustees of said fund and may invest and reinvest the principal and income of said fund in bonds and other investments which at the time of purchase constitute legal investments as the laws relating to trust funds may permit. The city treasurer shall be its treasurer and the clerk of said fund shall be appointed by the board. All orders on said fund shall be signed by the clerk and countersigned by the president. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, §§ 2, 3)  
Sec. 202. - Estimates of expenses, reports by board. 
The pension board shall submit annually to the mayor, prior to the first of September, a schedule of its estimated expenses necessary to carry out the purpose of the fund and the mayor shall include said estimate in the estimates to be submitted to the board of aldermen in accordance with charter requirements relative to annual estimates and appropriations for the city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act 531, § 4; Amd. of 7-6-93; Amd. of 9-23-98)  
Sec. 203. - Persons eligible for retirement. 
(a)  Any member of the fire department shall be eligible for retirement from active service and for a retirement allowance who shall have attained the age of fifty-five (55) and shall have completed prior to retirement thirty (30) years of continuous service in the employment of the fire department. Any member of the police department shall be eligible for retirement from active service and for a retirement allowance who shall have attained the age of forty-eight (48) and shall have completed prior to retirement twenty-five (25) years of continuous service in the employment of the police department. Veterans of the U.S. armed forces shall be granted credit toward the computation of their years of service to be eligible for city retirement pension for up to four (4) years served in active duty in the U.S. armed forces. 
(b)  Any member who shall have attained the age of sixty-five (65) shall be retired on the day following attainment of such age. 
(c)  Any member shall be eligible for retirement from active service who shall have completed at least ten (10) years of continuous service, upon a certificate of the medical examiners appointed by the board showing that such member is permanently disabled, physically or mentally, so as to be unfit for duty. 
(d)  If such disability is shown to the satisfaction of the board to have arisen out of and in the course of his employment by the city as defined by the workmen's compensation act, a member of the fund shall be eligible for retirement irrespective of the duration of his employment, but any amount payable to him under the workmen's compensation act shall be deducted from the allowance hereinafter provided, except that in the case of a fireman no such deduction shall be made after the effective date of his disability retirement. The board may, from time to time, appoint medical examiners to determine whether or not such member of the department so retired under the provisions of this act [division] continues totally and permanently disabled and incapacitated for further duties, and if the board, upon competent medical evidence, concludes that the disability for which a member is receiving pension no longer exists, it shall order a discontinuance of the payment of benefits as provided herein and shall restore such member to active duty in the department with which he was connected at the time of his retirement on account of disability. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 5; Special Acts 1967, Act No. 218, § 1; Amd. of 11-20-75; Amd. of 12-17-90, § 7) 
Editor's note— Section I of Act No. 218, Special Laws 1967, amended subsection (a) of § 5 of Act No. 531 of Special Laws 1957, herein codified as § 203(a) to read as set out, effective July 1, 1968. Formerly, members were eligible for retirement when they attained the age of fifty-five years having completed thirty years of continuous service in the employment of the police or fire department.  
Sec. 204. - Payment, amount of benefits. 
After retirement, in accordance with the provisions of this act, each member of the fire department shall receive in lieu of any other compensation from the city an annual allowance, payable monthly during his lifetime and terminating at his death, in an amount equal to one and two-thirds (1 2/3 ) per cent of his average annual rate of pay during the ten (10) years immediately preceding his retirement for each full year of service, and each member of the police department shall receive in lieu of any other compensation from the city an annual allowance, payable monthly during his lifetime and terminating at his death, in an amount equal to two (2) per cent of his average annual rate of pay during the ten (10) years immediately preceding his retirement for each full year of service, provided such allowance for permanent and total disability arising out of and in the course of employment as defined in the workmen's compensation act shall not be less than one-half (½) of the member's annual rate of pay at the time of disability. The word pay" shall be deemed to mean wages or salary, including increases or decreases thereof, payments on account of overtime worked, and the value of maintenance, if any. Credit for service shall be determined by the time actually worked as a full-time employee except that credit for a full year of service shall be given where absences within the year due to disability and leave of absence do not exceed ninety (90) days. The board of the policemen and firemen's pension fund, as trustees of this retirement fund of the City of New Haven, are directed to increase the pension paid to each retired member of this fund whose pension on December 31, 1987 is less than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year by an amount [not] to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00). Such increase shall not cause such annual pension to be more than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 6; Special Laws 1967, Act No. 218, § 2; Amd. of 11-20-75; Amd. of 3-7-88, §§ 2, 3)  
Sec. 205. - Payments to widows, surviving children. 
Upon the death of any member of the police or fire department who shall have served continuously as a regular member for such department for at least ten years and who shall have contributed regularly to this fund, the widow of such member shall receive, until her death or remarriage, a monthly sum equal to one-fourth of the compensation received by such member at the time of his death, if in active service, or a monthly sum equal to one-half of the pension received by such member at the time of his death, if retired. Upon the death of such widow before or after remarriage, leaving a child or children of such deceased member, under the age of sixteen years, the pension board may cause to be paid to the legally appointed guardian of such child or children, for his or their use and benefit, a sum or sums not exceeding in total the amount hereinbefore provided to be received by such widow, and may from time to time apportion such sum between such children as it may deem best; provided, as each such child shall arrive at the age of sixteen years, the payments to such child shall cease. No such payments or pension shall be allowed or paid to such widow or children so long or for such period as such widow or children shall receive or be entitled to receive compensation under the provisions of the general statutes relating to workmen's compensation. The term "widow," as used in this section, shall be limited in its meaning to the surviving wife of such member, who shall have been married to him prior to his retirement from such department, if retired, and who was living with him at the time of his death, or, if not so living with him, was absent by reason of his fault. The term "child" or "children" shall mean child or children born before or after the death of such member, to such member and his wife to whom he was married prior to his retirement from such department, if retired. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 7)  
Sec. 206. - Payments to widows of policemen, firemen killed in line of duty. 
There shall be paid to a widow, as designated in section 7 of this act [section 205 of this compilation], of any member of either the police department or the fire department, including supernumeraries in the police department and substitutes in the fire department, who shall be killed while in the actual performance of duty or shall die from the proximate effects of any injuries received while in the actual discharge of such duty, irrespective of the length of service of such member at the time of his death or failure to contribute to the fund established by this act [division], a weekly compensation equal to the difference between the maximum weekly compensation to which a widow of any deceased member is entitled and received under the provisions of the general statutes relating to workmen's compensation, and the weekly earnings of her deceased husband at the time of his death as aforesaid. Such weekly compensation shall be paid to a widow as aforesaid for so long a period as she shall be entitled to and shall receive a weekly compensation under the provisions of the general statutes relating to workmen's compensation. The benefits provided for under this section shall be deemed to be benefits in addition to any otherwise granted. This section shall not be interpreted as affecting in any way the pension provision of this act [division] with respect to policemen and firemen, and the benefits provided in this section shall be paid by appropriation from the general funds of the city of New Haven. After the benefits under workmen's compensation have been exhausted a widow may continue to receive benefits as provided for under section 7 of this act [section 205 of this compilation]. The benefits of this section shall be deemed waived by the widow if the widow or her representative or the representative of the estate of her deceased husband shall bring any action for money damages for the death of her husband against the city of New Haven or against any fellow employee of her late husband whom the city of New Haven must indemnify by law. In the event that any money damages are recovered by suit, settlement or otherwise by a widow, as designated in said section 7 [section 205 of this compilation], or by her representative or by the representative of the estate of her deceased husband, for the death of her deceased husband, the city of New Haven shall be entitled to reimbursement from said money damages for any benefits it shall have paid under this section to said widow. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 8)  
Sec. 207. - Effect of resignation, death before receiving benefits. 
If a member of the fund shall terminate his service with the city before retirement, the total amount of his contributions shall be repaid to him, unless he is a policeman who qualifies for a vested benefit. After July 1, 1975, pension rights for members of the police department shall become vested after twenty (20) years of continuous service, conditioned upon the member leaving his contributions in the pension fund. Such deferred vested pension shall become payable on the date when such member would have first become eligible for retirement if he had remained in service, namely, upon his attainment of age forty-eight (48) or upon his completion of twenty-five (25) years of continuous service, if later. The amount of such vested pension shall be equal to two (2) per cent of his average annual rate of pay for his final ten (10) years of service for each full year of his actual service as a policeman. If a member shall die before retirement from active service and prior to completion of ten years of continuous service, the total amount of his contribution shall be paid to the beneficiary designated by him. If no designated beneficiary shall survive the member, said amount may be paid, in the discretion of the board, to the surviving widow, in equal shares to the member's surviving parents or parent or, if there be no surviving parent, in equal shares to the member's surviving brothers and sisters; if said amount is not so paid, it shall be paid to the member's executor or administrator. If a member shall die after retirement from active service and before he shall receive payments on account of his retirement allowance at least equal to the total amount of his contributions to the date of retirement, the difference between said payments and said contributions shall be paid to the beneficiary designated by him. If no designated beneficiary shall survive the member, said amount shall be paid as hereinbefore provided. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 9; Amd. of 3-18-75)  
Sec. 208. - Authority of board to make rules, employ assistance. 
The pension board shall have the power to make reasonable rules and regulations for carrying out the provisions of this act [division] and may employ such assistance as is necessary for the purpose. Such cost shall be borne by the city in its annual appropriation. 
(Special Laws 1957, Act No. 531, § 10)  
Sec. 209. - Benefits and conditions for certain employees of department of fire service excluded from membership in or representation by Local 825. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of Number 531 of the Special Acts of 1957 and any amendment thereto to the contrary, the following benefits and conditions shall be established for all employees of the department of fire service who are excluded from membership in or representation by Local 825, International Association of Fire Fighters, AFL-CIO, and who were appointed to the fire department on or after January 1, 1958 and who are members of the Policemen's and Firemen's Pension Fund, established by said Special Act Number 531, and for the survivors of such employees: 
(a)  Each fire department member of said policemen's and firemen's pension fund who has completed twenty-five or more years of continuous service with the fire department, and who is forty-six (46) years of age or older, upon his written application to the pension board, shall be entitled to retirement for superannuation on an annual pension to be paid in accordance with the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Each such member who is retired on super annuation under subsection (a) of this section, shall receive from said pension fund an annual pension, payable monthly, in an amount equal to two (2) per cent of his average total annual earnings of his five (5) highest years of earnings during the ten (10) years immediately preceding his retirement for each full year of service, up to a maximum of seventy (70) per cent of his average total annual earnings of such five (5) highest years of earnings. 
(c)  The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall take effect on July 1, 1969. 
(d)  Each such member of said pension fund who has completed five (5) or more years of continuous service with the fire department upon a certificate of the medical examiners appointed by said pension board showing that such member is permanently disabled, physically or mentally, so as to be unfit for duty, as the result of causes which are not related to his employment with the fire department, shall be entitled to retirement on an annual pension to be paid in accordance with the provisions of subsection (e) of this section. 
(e)  Each such member who is retired on nonservice connected disability under subsection (d) of this section, shall receive from said pension fund an annual pension, payable monthly, in an amount equal to fifty (50) per cent of his average total annual earnings of his five (5) highest years of earnings during the ten (10) years or less immediately preceding his retirement. 
(f)  The term "child" or "children" as it is used in this section and in said Special Act Number 531 and all amendments thereto, shall mean the child or children born, before or after the death of a fire department member of said pension fund, to such member and his wife to whom he was married prior to his death, if an active member at the time of his death, and/or the child or children who was or were legally adopted by such member and such wife prior to the date of his death, and prior to the date of his retirement, if retired. 
(g)  Benefits which are payable from said pension fund on account of or to each child of a member of said pension fund, in accordance with the terms of this Agreement and the aforesaid Special Act Number 531 and amendments thereto, shall be paid on account of or to each such child until he or she reaches eighteen (18) years of age, except that such benefits shall be paid on account of or to such child, regardless of age, if such child is physically or mentally disabled to the extent that he or she is unable to secure gainful employment, subject to certification of the existence of such disability by the medical examiners appointed by the pension board. 
(h)  The survivors of each such member of said pension fund who has completed five (5) or more years of continuous service with the fire department shall receive nonservice connected survivor benefits as follows: 
(1)  If such member, while in active service, dies as the result of causes which are not related to his employment with the fire department, his widow, if she has no children for whom benefits are payable, shall receive, until her death or remarriage out of said pension fund an annual sum payable monthly, equal to twenty-five (25) per cent of the basic annual salary rate which he is receiving at the time of his death. If such member is survived by a widow and one child for whom benefits are payable in accordance with subsections (f) and (g) of this section, such widow shall receive, until her death or remarriage, out of said pension fund an annual sum, payable monthly, equal to thirty-five (35) per cent of the basic annual salary rate, which he is receiving at the time of his death. If such member is survived by a widow and two or more children for whom benefits are payable in accordance with subsections (f) and (g) of this section, such widow shall receive, until her death or her remarriage, out of said pension fund an annual sum, payable monthly, equal to forty-five (45) per cent of the basic annual salary rate which he is receiving at the time of his death. 
(2)  If such member, while retired, dies as the result of causes which are not related to his employment with the fire department, his widow, if she has no children for whom benefits are payable, shall receive, until her death or remarriage, out of said pension fund an annual sum, payable monthly, equal to fifty (50) per cent of the pension which he is receiving at the time of his death. If such member is survived by a widow and one child for whom benefits are payable in accordance with subsections (f) and (g) of this section, such widow shall receive, until her death or remarriage, out of said pension fund an annual sum, payable monthly, equal to seventy (70) per cent of the pension which he is receiving at the time of his death. If such member is survived by a widow and two or more children for whom benefits are payable in accordance with subsections (f) and (g) of this section, such widow shall receive, until her death or remarriage, out of said pension fund an annual sum, payable monthly, equal to ninety (90) per cent of the pension which he is receiving at the time of his death. 
(3)  In any of the above cases, upon the death of such a widow, before or after remarriage, the pension board may cause to be paid monthly, to the legally appointed guardian of the child or children of such widow for whom or to whom benefits are payable in accordance with subsections (f) and (g) of this section, for the use and benefit of such child or children, a sum or sums not exceeding in total the amount hereinbefore provided to be received by such widow, and may, from time to time, apportion such sums between such children as it may deem best, provided as each child reaches the age or the condition when he or she no longer qualifies for benefits in accordance with said subsections (f) and (g), the payment to or for such child shall cease. 
(i)  No benefits shall be paid from said pension fund under subsections (b) and (e) of this section which exceed one hundred (100) per cent of the employee's average total annual earnings of his highest five (5) years of earnings during the ten (10) years immediately preceding his retirement. No benefits shall be paid from said pension fund under subsection (h) of this section which exceed one hundred (100) per cent of the basic annual salary rate which such member is receiving at the time of his retirement or death, as the case may be. 
(j)  The provisions of subsections (d) through and including (i) of this section, shall take effect on June 1, 1968. 
(k)  Effective July 1, 1969, each active fire department member of said pension fund shall contribute to said pension fund six (6) per cent of his total annual earnings. 
(l)  When used in this section, the term "basic annual salary rate of each member of said pension fund" is that annual salary rate which is set forth for such member in the contract between the City of New Haven and Local 825, International Association of Fire Fighters, AFL-CIO, or if such member's basic annual salary is not set forth or controlled by such contract at the time of his death, the basic annual salary rate which he is actually receiving at the time of his death, shall be considered as his basic annual rate for purposes of this section. 
(m)  All provisions of said Special Act Number 531 and all amendments thereto which are not in conflict with the provisions of this section shall remain in full force and effect. 
(n)  This section shall become effective upon its passage. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Amd. of 9-29-76) 
Editor's note— An ordinance enacted Dec. 2, 1968, approved by the mayor on December 4, 1968, operative and in effect December 19, 1968, amended Special Act No. 531 of 1957 by adding thereto a new section designated "10", which the editors have codified as § 209 of this compilation.  
Sec. 210. - Vested rights of fire department personnel after ten or more years of continuous service. 
In the event of the discontinuance of employment, after ten or more years of continuous service, any member of the fire department shall retain full vested rights to receive a monthly pension commencing on the date when he would otherwise have completed twenty-five (25) years of continuous service, but not prior to his attainment of age forty-six (46), conditioned upon the member leaving his contributions in the pension fund. The amount of his pension will be determined by the regular formula, provided in section 209, as it may be amended from time to time, based on his years of continuous active service as a contributing member of the fund. The regular provisions for survivorship benefits, as contained in section 209, will apply to the vested pension, namely, fifty (50) per cent continuance to a widow alone, seventy (70) per cent to a widow and one child, and ninety (90) per cent to a widow and two (2) or more children, but such payments will be deferred if death occurs prior to the normal commencement date for the vested pension. No disability benefits are provided for vested members. "Continuous service," for the purposes of determining eligibility for vesting under this provision, shall mean uninterrupted service or employment, but absence from service or employment for any reason followed by reinstatement within one year thereafter shall not be considered as breaking the continuity of the service. The effective date of this vesting provision is July 1, 1976. 
(Amd. of 9-29-76)  
Secs. 211—224. - Reserved. 
Note— See editor's note following § 194.  
ARTICLE XII. - RETIREMENT OF TEACHERS  
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 225. - Teachers credited for military service. 
Any member of the teachers' retirement association who served or is serving in the armed forces, who, immediately prior to such service, was employed in the public schools of the city of Hartford or the city of New Haven and who reenters such employment in such city upon discharge from the armed forces, shall be credited for retirement purposes with the period of such service. The board of education of such city shall pay to the annuity fund the amounts due from such member for such period. If any such member dies prior to the effective date of his retirement, or prior to the date on which the co-participant option becomes effective, as provided in section 10-167 of the general statutes, any amounts paid by the board of education of such city for the benefit of such member shall be used to finance death benefits to his survivors payable under section 10-168 of the 1967 supplement to the general statutes. Any board of education funds not used in the financing of survivorship benefits or retirement allowances shall be returned to the board of education of such city.  
Sec. 226. - Teachers re-entering teaching service after resignation or leave of absence—Payments to state retirement system by city required. 
In case a teacher who has taught in the public schools in the city of New Haven prior to September 1, 1943, and who has either resigned prior to said date or been granted a leave of absence prior to said date by the board of education and so recorded in the minutes of said board and which leave of absence existed on or after said date of September 1, 1943, but expired on or before September 2, 1947, and who has reentered or shall re-enter teaching in the said public schools of said city with the approval of said board of education in accordance with its rules and regulations, said city shall pay to the teachers' retirement board, as provided in chapter 78 of the general statutes, [20] a sum equal to the sum that would give such teacher a service credit for years of public school service rendered in said city prior to September 1, 1943, provided said teacher shall have made payments to the teachers' retirement system of said city up to the time of his resignation or leave of absence. 
(Special Laws 1949, Act No. 197, § 1; Special Laws 1951, Act No. 490, § 1) 
Editor's note— Section 226 above is the same as § 251 of the 1952 Revised Charter. 
Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Note— Ch. 78 of the 1949 General Statutes appears as §§ 10-160—10-183 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 
 
Sec. 227. - Same—Amortization payment of city for. 
Any payments required to be made by the city of New Haven under section 1 hereof [section 226 of this compilation] shall be amortized with the net amount specified in section 3 of number 340 of the special acts of 1947 [section 242 of this compilation] at such times and in such amounts as the teachers' retirement board shall require; and section 4 of said act [section 243 of this compilation], including its provisions as to regular interest, shall apply to any difference between credits to the account of any teacher because of the provisions of section 1 hereof [section 226 of this compilation] and the total assessments paid by him to the teachers' retirement system of said city. 
(Special Laws 1949, Act No. 197, § 2)  
Sec. 228. - Same—Refund of personal payments to. 
Any teacher to whom this act [sections 226 through 228 of this compilation] applies and who shall have made personal payments to obtain service credit with the teachers' retirement board for years of public school service rendered in said city shall have said payments refunded to him with regular interest by said board. 
(Special Laws 1949, Act No. 197, § 3)  
Sec. 229. - Retirement of teachers in Westville district at time of consolidation. 
(1)  Any teacher who was employed by the Westville school district at the time of the consolidation of the Westville school district and the New Haven city school district of the city of New Haven and who was at that time a member of the state retirement association for teachers and entitled to retirement under the retirement system of the state, shall continue to be a member of said state association and upon payment of any assessment or dues which may be due and unpaid, shall become entitled to retirement under said state system with enjoyment of all benefits under said state system to the same extent as if said Westville school district had not been abolished. 
(2)  Any teacher who was employed by the Westville school district at the time of said consolidation and who was at that time a member in good standing of said state teachers' retirement association and who was not then entitled to be retired, and who is employed in the schools of the New Haven city school district of the city of New Haven, may elect, prior to July 14, 1923, to share in the benefits of the state teachers' association or the New Haven teachers' retirement fund, by a written notice to both the secretary of the teachers' retirement board and the secretary of the board of education of New Haven. 
(3)  Any teacher electing to share in the benefits of the New Haven teachers' retirement fund shall, on or before September 1, 1923, pay to the secretary of the board of education of the city of New Haven, such sum as will be necessary to equal the assessments he would have paid had he been a teacher in the New Haven school district of the city of New Haven, during the time he was teaching in the Westville school district, with six per centum interest thereon. 
(4)  Any teacher electing to continue as a member of the state teachers' retirement association shall, on or before September 1, 1923, pay to the Secretary of the teachers' retirement board the sum necessary for membership in the association. 
(5)  The secretaries of the respective boards are authorized to compute and adjust the payments necessary to carry out the provisions of this act [section]. 
(Special Laws 1923, Act No. 336, §§ 1—5) 
Editor's note— The Westville school district was consolidated into the city by Special Laws 1921, Act No. 436, § 5.  
Secs. 230—239. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - 1947 ACT 
 
Sec. 240. - All teachers declared subject to Ch. 55 of general statutes, not subject to city teachers' retirement system. 
On and after September 1, 1947, all teachers employed in the city of New Haven and not then subject to the provisions of chapter 55 of the general statutes, [21] as amended, hereinafter called "said chapter", to which reference is hereby made for the meaning of words herein used which are defined in said chapter, shall become and be subject thereto with the same force and effect and with the same privileges and rights, except as provided in the second sentence in section 4 hereof [section 243 of this compilation], as if they had become subject thereto on the day they were first employed as teachers by said city, or on September 1, 1917, whichever day is later, and shall thereupon cease to be subject to the teachers' retirement system of said city. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Note— Ch. 55 of the 1930 General Statutes as amended appears as §§ 10-160—10-183, Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 
 
Sec. 241. - City to continue existing payments under city system. 
Said city shall continue to be liable for the payment of annuities to all who are receiving annuities on September 1, 1947, pursuant to the teachers' retirement system of said city, and shall retain, as a source of such payments and as a trust fund to be invested in accordance with the laws relating to the investment of trust funds, such portion of the teachers' retirement fund established by number 507 of the special acts of 1943, as shall be determined by a qualified actuary to be necessary for such purpose. Said city may retain and use for general purposes any part of said portion that may remain after discharge of all annuities. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 2) 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, which was an amendment to the 1911 retirement act, has been incorporated into Division 3 of this Article. Section 241 above is the same as § 250 of the 1952 Revised Charter.  
Sec. 242. - Balance in city fund to be paid to state. 
Said city shall pay to the retirement board on September 1, 1947, any balance in said teachers' retirement fund over and above such portion retained as aforesaid, and shall pay to said board an amount equal to the total assessments, with regular interest thereon to September 1, 1947, that would have been paid by such teachers becoming subject to said chapter had they joined the retirement association on the day they were first employed as teachers by said city, or on September 1, 1917, whichever day is later, less such amount as shall have been paid to said board on September 1, 1947, as aforesaid, such net amount to be amortized in annual installments, including regular interest to the date of final payment and beginning on September 1, 1948. The number of such annual installments shall be determined by the teachers' retirement board. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 3)  
Sec. 243. - Retirement board ordered to credit accounts of transferred teachers. 
As of September 1, 1947, the retirement board shall credit the account of each teacher transferred hereby from the teachers' retirement system of said city to the retirement system provided for by said chapter, with the amount necessary to transfer him. Any difference between the amount so credited and the total assessments paid by him to said city, with regular interest thereon, shall be credited in reduction of the total remaining indebtedness to the retirement board by said city if and when such teacher dies or for any other reason withdraws from the retirement association. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 4)  
Sec. 244. - Interpretation of "amount contributed" by teachers. 
For all purposes of section 247g of the 1943 supplement to the general statutes, [22] the amount contributed by any teacher transferred hereby shall be deemed to be the sum of the retirement assessments paid by him to said city and the assessments paid by him as provided in said chapter, both with regular interest. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 5) 
Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Note— Section 247g of the 1943 Supplement to the General Statutes appears as § 10-176 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 
 
Sec. 245. - Transfer of records from city to state. 
All New Haven teaching, salary and retirement deduction records, including check registers and cancelled checks affecting teachers, shall be transferred by New Haven to the teachers' retirement board on or before September 1, 1947. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 8)  
Sec. 246. - Appropriation to carry out retirement act. 
The sum of four hundred sixty-nine thousand eight hundred forty-eight dollars is appropriated to carry out the provisions of this act. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 9)  
Sec. 247. - 1911 act repealed. 
Effective September 1, 1947, sections 1, 3 to 10, inclusive, and 13 of number 340 of the special acts of 1911, as amended, are repealed. 
(Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 7) 
Editor's note— The provisions of §§ 1, 3—10, and 13 of Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, have been included as §§ 260, 261—268 and 271 of this compilation. Sections 11 and 12, which have not been repealed, appear as §§ 269 and 270.  
Secs. 248—259. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - 1911 ACT[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Editor's note— Division 3, §§ 260—272 is derived from Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, as amended. Section 2 of that act was repealed by Special Laws 1927, Act No. 247, § 2, and is not included in this compilation. Sections 1, 3—10 and 13, which appear as §§ 260, 261—268 and 271 were repealed by Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 7, which is codified herein as § 247. Though repealed, these 1911 provisions are included at the request of the city since the 1947 act makes frequent reference to them, and because the city remains liable for certain payments under the 1911 act as specified in § 241 of this compilation. 
 
Sec. 260. - Fund established; divided into two parts. 
There shall be a fund to be known as the "Teachers' Retirement Fund" for the benefit of the teachers of the public day schools of the city of New Haven. Said fund shall consist of two parts: First, the permanent fund, and second, the operating or general fund. The permanent fund shall consist of all assets of the teachers' retirement fund now in the custody of the sinking fund commission as trustee, or its authorized agent, with all additions made to the permanent fund annually, which additions shall be so made by transfer of such unexpended balances as may be in the general fund as of August thirty-first each year, provided there shall always be retained in said fund as of said day a balance not less than twenty-five thousand dollars: 
(1)  All interest accruals of the permanent fund shall be a part of the general fund. 
(2)  All appropriations, gifts or bequests made to the teachers' retirement fund from public or private sources for the purposes for which said retirement fund is established shall be a part of said general fund. 
(3)  For the years beginning January 1, 1944, and January 1, 1945, the city of New Haven shall make an appropriation of, and shall pay into the general fund, a sum equivalent to two and one-half per cent of the actuarial deficit of the teachers' retirement fund as established in the supplementary actuarial report dated April 17, 1943, plus an amount equal to the difference between a yield of two and one-half per cent on the permanent fund as of August 31, 1942, and its actual earned income if less than two and one-half per cent, plus fifteen hundred dollars for the operating expenses of the general fund. Annually thereafter, for a period of thirty years, the city shall appropriate and shall pay into the general fund such proportional part of the actuarial deficit existing in May of each such year as will, by certification of a qualified actuary, amortize such actuarial deficit of the teachers' retirement fund within the years then remaining of said thirty-year period. For the purpose of estimating the actuarial deficit, a triennial survey of said fund shall be made by a qualified actuary, appointed for the purpose of recalculating the required annual amortization payment. Said annual payment shall be certified to by the actuary in May each year for inclusion in the annual budget of the board of education. The actuary shall be paid from the general fund. 
(4)  For the years beginning January 1, 1944, and January 1, 1945, the city shall make an appropriation of and shall pay into the general fund a sum equivalent to not less than one-half the amount of net salary savings of the members of said fund as estimated and appropriated by the board of finance and the board of aldermen each year in the city budget, which estimates and appropriations shall be based on the actual experience of the immediately preceding five years. "Net salary savings", as used in this section, shall mean the net savings on any part of the appropriated salary of any teacher not paid to such teacher by reason of resignation, illness or absence, or for any other reason. 
(5)  Beginning January 1, 1944, an assessment of five per cent of the annual salaries of all teachers, which assessment shall, during the school year, be retained from the salaries of such teachers in equal monthly amounts; provided the amount deducted from any salary shall not exceed one hundred and twenty dollars in any year. 
(6)  In any year in which the general fund is insufficient to meet the disbursements therefrom provided for in this act [division], a transfer shall be made to the general fund from the permanent fund of an amount necessary to make good such deficiency. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 1; Special Laws 1927, Act No. 247, § 1; Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 1)  
Sec. 261. - Administration of fund. 
(1)  The city treasurer shall be treasurer of said fund, except as hereinafter provided. The board of education and the sinking fund commission of the city of New Haven shall be trustees of said fund, and the sinking fund commission shall have charge of the investment of the money of said fund and the custody of its securities and the handling of its assets, and may invest and reinvest the same in accordance with the laws relating to the investment of trust funds. The trustees may, at any time, designate an incorporated bank or trust company doing business in the city of New Haven to be, for such period as the trustees may deem to be wise, the financial agent of said trustees. Said trustees shall transmit a written certificate of such designation to the city clerk, and, when the board of finance shall have approved such designation and the bank or trust company so designated shall have signified to the city clerk in writing its acceptance thereof, such bank or trust company shall be, until otherwise ordered by the trustees, the receiving and disbursing agent of said trustees, and the trustees may confide to said bank or trust company the custody and possession of all moneys and securities, or of such of them as the trustees may deem wise, held for and on account of said trustees. For the services so to be performed, such compensation as is reasonable may be allowed and approved by the trustees to the bank or trust company so designated and may be a charge against the income of the permanent fund without specific appropriation therefor. The trustees shall, in the month of September in each year, and oftener if they deem it advisable, inspect and examine the securities and funds in the custody and possession of its treasurer or of any bank or trust company so designated. Upon the designation by said trustees of such financial agent, and when such financial agent shall have qualified as such as herein provided, the treasurer of the city of New Haven shall, for the time being, cease to be treasurer of said fund and his powers and duties as treasurer of said fund shall be suspended, and such powers and duties shall be revived only during intervals when there shall be no designated and qualified financial agent of the trustees, as herein provided. 
(2)  All annuities payable under the provisions of this act shall be paid from the general fund as defined in section one [section 260 of this compilation] of this act. All orders on said fund shall be signed by the secretary or, in case of his absence or incapacity, by the assistant secretary, and counter-signed by a member of the finance committee of the board of education of said city. 
(3)  The trustees of the retirement fund shall have power, in their discretion, to authorize the expenditure from the general fund of such a sum as it may deem necessary for clerical and other expenses incident to the administration of said fund, payment therefrom to be made on vouchers audited and approved by the board of finance of the city of New Haven in the manner prescribed by section forty-two of the charter of said city. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 3; Special Laws 1927, Act No. 247, §§ 4—7; Special Laws 1931, Act No. 231, § 1; Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 2) 
Editor's note— Section 42 of the 1899 charter, Special Laws 1899, Act No. 467, is identical with § 60 of the 1952 Revised Charter and has been omitted from this compilation.  
Sec. 262. - Membership of board of retirement. 
Two members of the board of education, to be chosen annually by said board at its organization meeting, one member of the board of aldermen, to be elected by the board of aldermen, the treasurer of the city of New Haven and three teachers chosen by the teachers of the public schools of New Haven who are subject to this act [division] shall constitute a board of retirement. The members of said board representing the teachers shall be first chosen on or before January 15, 1944, by said teachers for one year, and thereafter for two years; the first election for the selection of said members shall be conducted by said board of education, and each subsequent election shall be conducted by a committee appointed by the board of retirement, under such rules and regulations as said committee shall determine. Said committee shall have power to conduct special elections to fill any vacancy occurring in the teachers' representation on said board. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 4; Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 3)  
Sec. 263. - Teachers eligible for retirement. 
(1)  Upon a majority vote of the board of retirement and a majority vote of the board of education, any teacher who has taught in public day schools for a period of thirty years, of which period the last twenty years shall have been in said public day schools of the New Haven city school district, shall be placed on the retired list. 
(2)  Any teacher of the public day schools of the New Haven city school district who has reached the age of sixty years or over, and who has taught for a period of not less than thirty years, of which period the last twenty years shall have been in the public day schools of the New Haven city school district, shall be placed on the retired list, upon thirty days' notice to said board of retirement, given by said teacher, stating his or her desire to be placed on said retired list. If said application shall be approved by a majority vote of said board of retirement and a like vote of said board of education, the applicant shall be placed on the retired list. 
(3)  Any teacher who has taught in the public day schools of the New Haven city school district for a period of forty years previous to the date when this act [division] becomes operative shall, upon recommendation by a majority vote of the board of retirement and a majority vote of the board of education, be placed upon the retired list. 
No teacher shall be prevented from obtaining the benefits awarded under this section, by reason of his or her military or naval service during the last world war, or by reason of any future military or naval service for the United States of America. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 5; Special Laws 1927, Act No. 247, § 8; Special Laws 1941, Act No. 227)  
Sec. 264. - Retirement for disability. 
(1)  The board of retirement shall annually appoint three physicians or surgeons of the city of New Haven, of at least ten years active practice, who shall be known as the board of examiners, who shall serve without pay, and who shall, upon request of the board of education or the board of retirement, make such examinations as may be called for under the terms of this section and report their finding, in writing, to the board making such request. 
(2)  On the recommendation of a majority vote of said board of retirement, said board of education shall have power, by a majority vote of all of its members, to place on the disability list for the remainder of his or her life, or any part thereof, any teacher of the public day schools of the New Haven city school district who is found by said board of examiners to be mentally or physically incapacitated for the performance of duty, and who has been engaged in the work of teaching for a period of at least fifteen years, the last ten of which shall have been in the public day schools of the New Haven city school district. In no case shall a teacher be placed on the disability list until said board of examiners shall have filed a report, in writing, within thirty days from the date of examination, to the effect that said teacher has refused to submit to an examination or, after examination, if found by the board of examiners to be physically or mentally unfitted for further service in the day schools of New Haven. 
(3)  Any teacher of the public day schools of the New Haven city school district who has been engaged in teaching for a period of at least fifteen years, the last ten of which shall have been in said public day schools of the New Haven city school district, shall have the right to apply to the board of retirement to be placed on the disability list on the ground that he or she is mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty as a teacher. Any applicant for retirement on said ground of disability shall submit to a proper medical examination by said board of examiners before his or her application shall be considered. The board of education may, by a majority vote, upon recommendation by a majority vote of said board of retirement, place said teacher on the disability list. 
(4)  Nothing in this act [division] shall be construed as prohibiting the board of retirement from recommending, by a majority vote, to the board of education that the disability of a teacher retired under this section shall be declared ended. Said board of education may, by a majority vote, on such recommendation of said board of retirement, declare ended the disability of a teacher retired under the terms of this section, and upon delivery to said teacher of a written offer of reappointment to a position as a teacher equal in remuneration to the one previously held by said teacher, the payment of the annuity of such teacher under this disability clause shall be discontinued. 
(5)  Nothing in this act [Division] shall be construed as prohibiting a teacher who has been placed on the disability list from applying, once each year, to be reinstated to active duty as a teacher. On recommendation by a majority vote of the board of retirement, after an examination of said applicant by the board of examiners, the board of education may, by a majority vote, restore said teacher to active duty, and the disability annuity shall cease on the day that said teacher resumes his or her work as a teacher. 
(6)  In no case, however, shall the disability provided for in subsections (2) and (3) of this section be declared ended or finished until an examination has been made by said board of examiners or the teacher in question has refused to be so examined, and said board of examiners shall have certified, by a majority vote, either to said teacher's refusal to be examined, or that, after such examination, said teacher is found to be physically and mentally fitted for further service in the public day schools of the New Haven city school district. The provisions of this section shall not, however, apply to ordinary cases of temporary disability. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 6)  
Sec. 265. - Amount of annuities. 
(1)  The annuity paid to any teacher regularly placed on the retired list for the remainder of his or her life shall be one-half of his or her average annual salary for the five years last previous to the date of his or her retirement; provided such annuity shall be not less than eight hundred nor more than twelve hundred dollars per annum. Such annuity shall be payable to such teacher in monthly installments during the school year. The provisions of this section shall apply both to teachers on said retired list and to teachers to be placed on said retired list. 
(2)  Any teacher regularly placed on the disability list shall receive an annuity the amount of which shall be one-thirtieth part of the total annuity provided for in subdivision (1) of this section, for each year of service of said teacher, not exceding thirty years. 
(3)  No annuity shall be paid under the provisions of this act [Division], except as provided in subdivision (3) of section five [section 243(3) of this compilation], unless the retiring teacher shall have first paid into the retirement fund such sum or sums as shall make his or her total payments equal to the amount of the annuity paid for the first year; but should any retiring teacher be unable to pay the full amount of said sum before receiving an annuity, the board of trustees shall, in paying the annuity of such teacher, withhold, from each monthly payment, twenty per centum thereof until the full amount hereinbefore provided for shall have been so contributed to the fund. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 7; Special Laws 1927, Act No. 247, §§ 9, 10)  
Sec. 266. - Refunds for dismissal, resignation, death. 
Teachers who are dismissed from school employment shall have refunded to them, without interest as to contributions made before January 1, 1944, but with interest at two per cent per annum as to contributions or assessments made on or after said day, the total amounts which they have contributed to said retirement fund. Any teacher terminating school employment by resignation shall have refunded all assessments, with interest at two per cent per annum, paid on or after January 1, 1944. Any member of said fund who shall die while in service of the department or while on leave of absence or before receiving the first installment benefit under the terms of this act [Division] shall have refunded to his estate, or to such person as shall have been nominated by written designation, executed and filed prior to death, with the secretary of the board of education, all assessments paid, with interest at two per cent per annum, on or after January 1, 1944. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 8; Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 4)  
Sec. 267. - Definition of "teachers," "public day schools," "majority." 
The term "teacher" as used in this act [Division] shall include all teachers, the superintendent of schools, and the members of the supervising staff regularly appointed and employed in the public day schools of the city of New Haven by the board of education, whether on leave of absence or in service, prior to September 1, 1943. The public day schools of the city shall be deemed to be all public day schools maintained wholly or in part by the city of New Haven. The term "majority" shall mean a majority of the entire membership of the board referred to. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 9; Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 5) 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 5, amended section 9 of the 1911 teacher's retirement act to read as set out in § 267 above. Previously, said § 9 had provided that nothing in the act should be construed as preventing the board of education from discontinuing employment, nor as creating any right to receive the annuity until placed on the retired or disability list, and further provided that the acceptance of employment should be considered as subject to the act and authorizing deductions from salary pursuant thereto.  
Sec. 268. - Definition of "teachers," "public day schools," "majority." 
The term "teacher" as used in this act [Division] shall include all teachers regularly appointed and employed in the public day schools, by the board of education, including the superintendent of schools and the members of the supervising staff. The public day schools of the New Haven city school district shall be deemed to be all public day schools maintained wholly or in part by the New Haven city school district. The term "majority" shall mean a majority of the entire membership of the board referred to. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 10) 
Editor's note— Section 268 above is derived from § 10 of Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340. Apparently, said section has been superseded by the enactment of Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 5, which appears as § 267 of this compilation, but it has been included herein because never expressly repealed.  
Sec. 269. - Interest in 1911 retirement fund declared non-assignable, exempt from levy. 
Any pledge, mortgage sale, assignment, or transfer of, or of any right, claim, or interest in, said retirement fund or in any annuity granted under the provisions of this act [Division] shall be void and said retirement fund and all said annuities shall be exempt from attachment, levy, and sale, and from all legal process, at law or in equity, to sequester the same by or in behalf of any creditor of any person having an interest in said fund or entitled to any such annuity. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 11)  
Sec. 270. - Teachers employed after 1943 subject to state retirement system. 
On and after September 1, 1943, all new employments of teachers of the public day schools of the city of New Haven shall be made subject to the provisions of the state teacher's retirement act. Beginning September 1, 1947, the city of New Haven shall be subject to the provisions of the state teacher's retirement act as to teachers transferred from the teachers' retirement system of said city to the retirement system provided by said act and shall be exempt from the provisions of said act as to all who are receiving annuities on said day pursuant to the teachers' retirement system of said city; and any money due to said city under the provisions of section 1042 of the general statutes [24] shall be paid into the portion then remaining of the teachers' retirement fund established by number 507 of the special acts of 1943. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 12; Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, § 6; Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 6) 
Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Editor's note— Special Laws 1947, Act No. 340, § 6, effective September 1, 1947, amended Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 12, as previously amended, to read as set out in § 270 above. Section 270 above is the same as § 249 of the 1952 Revised Charter. Special Laws 1943, Act No. 507, which is referred to in the last sentence above, was an amendment to the 1911 act, and its provisions have been incorporated into this division. 
State Law reference— Section 1042 of the 1930 general statutes, as amended, appears as § 10-181 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 
 
Sec. 271. - Annual reports required. 
In the month of September, 1912, and annually thereafter during the month of September, the board of retirement shall file an annual report, showing the financial condition of the teachers' retirement fund, with the board of aldermen, which report shall be printed in the city year book of the city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, § 13)  
Sec. 272. - Applicability of 1911 teachers' retirement act. 
The provisions of an act amending the charter of the city of New Haven and establishing a teachers' retirement fund, approved July 18, 1911, [25] shall apply to all teachers of the public day schools of the city of New Haven. 
(Special Laws 1925, Act No. 468, § 5) 
Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Editor's note— The act referred to in this section is Special Laws 1911, Act No. 340, which comprises this division, §§ 260—272. 
 
ARTICLE XIII. - SELF INSURANCE[26] 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
Editor's note— Article XIII contains the provisions of Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, §§ 1—12, as amended. These provisions do not appear in the 1952 Revised Charter. 
 
Sec. 273. - Fund established; purposes, management. 
(1)  There shall be established in the city of New Haven a reserve fund for the city's self-insurance plan, the purpose of which shall be to equitably provide for the payment of claims against the city arising out of its compensation and public liability. 
(2)  Said fund shall be managed and controlled by the mayor and the controller of said city, subject to the conditions imposed by this article or the city ordinances. 
(3)  The treasurer of said city shall be the treasurer of said fund and shall receive no additional compensation for his duties other than the salary paid by said city to its treasurer. 
(4)  The clerk of said fund shall be designated by the controller. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, §§ 1—4; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 274. - Treasurer's bond. 
The controller shall require the treasurer of said fund to furnish a suitable surety bond in an amount to be determined by the controller, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his official duties as such treasurer. The premium for such bond shall be paid by said city. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, § 5; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 275. - Investment of resources. 
The resources of said fund may only be invested in certificates of deposit with either national or state banks located in the City of New Haven or any other city within this state, cash deposits with mutual savings banks located in the city of New Haven or any other city in this state, obligations of the City of New Haven, of the State of Connecticut and of the United States of America. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, § 6)  
Sec. 276. - Assets included in fund. 
Said fund shall consist of all moneys that may, from time to time, be appropriated thereto and paid into it by the board of aldermen of said city, and there shall be added to said fund accumulations as follows: From the estimated receipts and disbursements as appropriated in the annual budget of said city: 
(a)  The unexpended balance of the appropriation for compensation awards; 
(b)  The unexpended balance of the appropriation for public liability awards; 
(c)  The unexpended balance which may be appropriated for reserve or stop-loss purposes and, in addition, any costs collected by the city of New Haven in actions relating to its public liability or compensation duties wherein said city is a defendant and all funds paid into the city in third party responsibility cases for injury to employees of the city to whom the city has paid compensation allowances, hospitalization charges or medical and incidental disbursements for disability arising out of and in the course of their employment, and 
(d)  Interest or income or accrual thereon upon deposits, investments or other proper uses of said fund. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, § 7; Amd. 7-6-93)  
Sec. 277. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Sept. 23, 1998, provided for the deletion of § 277, Reports by treasurer, derived from Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, § 8, as amended July 6, 1993.  
Sec. 278. - Payments permitted. 
Said fund shall be used pursuant to section 279 hereinafter for the payment of any judgment, compromise, adjustment, award, or settlement under a voluntary agreement of compensation, including but not limited to workers' compensation agreements, that may be entered into between the city of New Haven and a claimant which is based upon a claim causing compensable injury and which arose in and is chargeable to a year preceding the year of withdrawal; any judgment, compromise, adjustment, award, or settlement that may be entered into between the city of New Haven and a claimant which is based upon the city's public liability responsibility and under a claim which arose and is chargeable to a year preceding the withdrawal; the payment of compensation or public liability claims within the current year aggregating in damages an amount greater than remains in the general fund appropriations for such purposes; or for legal services, when such services shall be provided by persons other than the corporation counsel and his assistants and when such services shall be obtained pursuant to the charter and ordinances, and expert witness services engaged by the city upon the recommendation of the corporation counsel which the litigation settlement committee may deem an emergency or a necessity involved in the efficient and expeditious carrying out of the city's self-insurance plan. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, § 9; Special Laws 1937, Act No. 149; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 279. - Budget adoption; procedure for payment. 
An annual budget shall be prepared and adopted for the self-insurance fund in accord with and as required by the ordinances for other special revenue funds. Amendments to such budget as adopted may be made during the year upon recommendation of the mayor and approval of the board of aldermen. When the mayor or board of aldermen, acting pursuant to and in accord with this article and the charter or ordinances, shall approve the use of the fund or any portion thereof for any purpose for which said fund may be used under the provisions of this article, the clerk shall notify the controller to prepare an order pursuant to such vote and said clerk shall send to the treasurer of said fund a certified copy of such vote and notify the treasurer to deposit into the funds of the city treasury such funds as have been called for by such vote. 
The treasurer of said reserve fund shall honor no order drawn on him except pursuant to the provisions hereof. A certified copy of all resolutions providing for disbursements from the reserve fund shall be filed with the controller of the city of New Haven by the clerk of said fund. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, §§ 10, 11; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 280. - Authority of mayor to contract to implement article. 
The mayor, upon approval of the board of aldermen, may enter into any contract incidental to or necessary for the carrying out of the purposes of this article and under its plan of self-insurance. 
(Special Laws 1935, Act No. 331, § 12; Amd. of 7-6-93)  
Secs. 281—289. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - TRAFFIC 
 
Sec. 290. - Appeals from orders of traffic authority in New Haven. 
Any provision of section 2530 of the general statutes [27] to the contrary notwithstanding, any person aggrieved by any order, rule or regulation made by any traffic authority under the provisions of chapter 112 of the general statutes, [28] relating to the establishment of through streets, the making of safety zones, the establishment of parking restrictions or the location of loading and unloading zones in the city of New Haven, or by the performance of any act pursuant to the provisions of said chapter relating to traffic regulation in said city, may appeal to the court of common pleas for New Haven county, which appeal shall be returnable to said court on the next return day or the next but one following the date of the action of tile traffic authority appealed from. Upon such hearing, such court shall determine whether the order, rule or regulation appealed from is reasonable, and shall thereupon sustain or revoke such order, rule or regulation. 
(Special Laws 1955, Act No. 546) 
Footnotes: 
--- (27) --- 
Note— Section 2530 of the 1949 General Statutes as amended appears as § 14-313 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 

--- (28) --- 
Note— Ch. 112 of the 1949 General Statutes as amended appears as §§ 14-297—14-317 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).
