TITLE III - CODE OF GENERAL ORDINANCES  
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances contained in the following Titles III, IV and V shall constitute and be designated the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut, and may be so cited.  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and construction. 
The ordinances contained in Title III of the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut shall be interpreted in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  In the construction of the ordinances, words and phrases shall be construed according to the commonly approved usage of the language; and technical words and phrases, and such as have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be construed and understood accordingly. 
(2)  And, or. The word "or" may be read "and," and the word "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
(3)  Words importing the singular number may extend and be applied to several persons or things, and words importing the plural number may include the singular. 
(4)  Gender. Words importing the masculine gender may be applied to females, and to other persons as herein defined. 
(5)  Words purporting to give a joint authority to several persons shall be construed as giving authority to a majority of them. 
(6)  Whenever a title which denotes gender is applied to an individual the title shall suit the gender of the individual. 
(7)  Shall, may. "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
(8)  The words "preceding", "following" and "succeeding", when used by way of reference to any section or sections, shall mean the section or sections next preceding, next following or next succeeding, unless some other section is expressly designated in such reference. 
(9)  Authority. Words purporting to give joint authority to several persons shall be construed as giving authority to a majority of them. 
(10)  City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of New Haven, Connecticut. 
(11)  Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, or any action taken, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had, or such action taken, shall not be counted. Whenever certain hours are named herein, they shall mean standard time as in current use in the city. 
(12)  General statutes. Reference to "the general statutes", "state law", "Connecticut General Statutes sect.", or any variation thereof shall be construed as referring to the General Statutes of the State of Connecticut. 
(13)  Charter. The term "charter" or "city charter" shall mean the charter approved by the voters of the City of New Haven on November 3, 1992, or any subsequent amendments or revisions thereof. 
(14)  Code. Reference to "code" or "this code" shall refer to the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut. 
(15)  Officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions or agencies. Whenever the title of an officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency is given, it shall be construed to refer to an officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency of the City of New Haven. 
(16)  Month, year. The words "month" or "year" shall mean a calendar month or calendar year. 
(17)  Number. Words importing the singular number may extend and be applied to several persons or things, and words importing the plural number may include the singular. 
(18)  Tense. Words used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well as the past or present. 
(19)  Owner. The word "owner" shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of the property to which reference is made. 
(20)  Person. The words "person" and "another" may extend and be applied to communities, companies, corporations, public or private, limited liability companies, societies and associations. 
(Ord. No. 1389, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface or italic type, and the chapter, article and division headings are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section, subsection, chapter, article or division and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles or a substantive portion of any such section, subsection, chapter, article or division, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any such sections, subsections, chapters, articles or divisions, including the catchlines or headings, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Ord. No. 1389, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect them, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are re-adopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city commission. 
Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut, is hereby amended to read as follows: _______." The new provisions should then be set out in full as desired. 
In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code, is to be added, the following language should be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _______, which said section reads as follows: _______." The new section should then be set out in full as desired. 
All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be.  
Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed.  
Sec. 1-6. - Severability of parts of Code. 
If any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining provisions of this Code.  
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the following with the intent to misrepresent or commit a fraud with reference to any ordinance(s) in the Code: 
(1)  Add or delete any portion(s) of any ordinance(s); 
(2)  Insert or delete any page(s) of the code; or 
(3)  Alter or tamper with the code in any way. 
(b)  Any violation of the above subsection shall result in a fine up to the maximum fine allowable under state statutes or this Code. Each act shall be regarded as a separate violation.  
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty. 
Every person who shall violate any provision of this Code, now or hereafter in force, shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by Conn. General Statutes section 7-148(c)(10)(A) or this Code, except where a different fine or penalty is expressly prescribed. 
(Code 1928, § 607; Ord. No. 1389, 9-19-05) 
Charter reference— Authority to prescribe penalty for violations of ordinances, § §§ 49, 50.  
Sec. 1-9. - Other punitive action not in lieu of penalties. 
No payment of expenses incurred, and no revocation of license, or removal from office, shall excuse any person from liability to the penalty prescribed for the breach of any provision of this Code or other ordinance. 
(Code 1928, § 609)  
Sec. 1-10. - Code not to extend liability of city. 
No provision of this Code shall be construed to render the city liable to any person for any breach of said provision, or for any injury to person or property any further than such liability is expressly provided in this Code, or in the state statutes as each is amended from time to time. 
(Code 1928, § 610)  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Office hours of officials. 
Unless otherwise provided, all city officials shall keep their respective office(s) open for the convenience of the public and/or to conduct regular business for at least seven (7) consecutive hours on every day except weekends and public holidays. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-1 amends and supersedes former § 2-1 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 606; Ord. of 8-7-50.  
Sec. 2-2. - Destruction of records. 
Any person who fraudulently abstracts, conceals, destroys, mutilates or alters any record, map or file belonging to the city, or is in the charge or custody of any city committee, board or officer shall be guilty of an offense, and shall be fined up to the maximum authorized by state statutes or this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-2 amends and supersedes former § 2-3 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 70.  
Sec. 2-3. - Regional council of governments. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes sections 4-124i—4-124p, New Haven is a member of the regional council of governments, and the mayor as the city's representative is authorized to exercise any and all of the powers, duties and functions as are set forth in the state statutes as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-3 amends and supersedes former § 2-23 which derived from Ord. of 6-3-68, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 7-5-83, § 2.  
Sec. 2-4. - Community Action Agency. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes sections 17b-885 to 17b-895, as amended from time to time, the Community Action Agency of New Haven, Inc. has been formed as a private nonprofit corporation, and is authorized to perform agency functions and otherwise operate in accordance with said statutes as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-4 amends and supersedes former §§ 2-133, 2-134 which derived from 6-13-77; Ord. of 8-1-77; Ord. of 5-30-78.  
Secs. 2-5—2-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF ALDERMEN 
 
Sec. 2-31. - Office of Legislative Services. 
There shall be an Office of Legislative Services with full time professional and secretarial staff to provide assistance to the board of aldermen. This office shall keep an annual journal of the board's actions and proceedings, and be responsible for printing and distributing a bound and indexed copy of the same to each member of the board of aldermen, city department heads, and all other appropriate persons, within four (4) weeks after the last board meeting of the year. A reasonable number of copies of said journal shall be kept in the city clerk's office. The city clerk shall certify under his/her hand one (1) copy to be a true record of the board of aldermen's actions and proceedings, which will be considered as the official journal. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-31 amends and supersedes the former provisions of §§ 2-2, 2-9, 2-10 which derived from the Code of 1928, §§ 68 and 72.  
Sec. 2-32. - Meetings of aldermen. 
(a)  The board of aldermen shall hold regular meetings on the first and third Mondays of every month from September through May except when such Monday is a holiday. If the day is a holiday, the board shall meet on the next business day thereafter. The mayor or the president of the board of aldermen may call a meeting on any other day if either person deems it expedient. 
(b)  No agency, authority, board, committee or commission of the city or its subdivisions regulated by the city code or charter shall meet at the same time as a regularly scheduled meeting of the board of aldermen unless it receives special dispensation from the president of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-32 amends and supersedes former § 2-4 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 63; Ord. of 3-22-82; Ord. of 8-2-93; Ord. of 8-14-02)  
Sec. 2-33. - Notice of meetings to aldermen. 
(a)  When the mayor, president of the board of aldermen, or a majority of aldermen as designated by petition, deems it proper to call a special board meeting, a sheriff or any other proper officer may be ordered to notify the board members of such meeting. 
The notice shall be effectuated in the following ways: 
(1)  If each board member receives personal notice; or 
(2)  If an attested copy of the order is left at each member's usual place of residence at least six (6) hours prior to the prescribed time of the meeting; or 
(3)  If the order is published in one (1) daily newspaper of general circulation in the city at least twelve (12) hours before the meeting. 
(b)  The city clerk shall record the order. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-33 amends and supersedes former section 2-5 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 65; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-34. - Contents of petitions to aldermen. 
Every petitioner shall provide his/her full name and complete address on all petitions brought to the board of aldermen. 
Editor's note— § 2-34 amends and supersedes former § 2-8 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 73.  
Sec. 2-35. - Compensation for aldermen. 
Each alderman, except the board president, shall be compensated in the amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each year of the term for which he/she is elected. The president of the board of aldermen shall be compensated in the amount of two thousand four hundred dollars ($2,400.00) for each year of said term. These amounts shall be paid in monthly installments, and are payable on or before the last day of each month of such service. 
Editor's note— § 2-35 amends and supersedes former § 2-34 which derived from Ord. of 9-6-88.  
Sec. 2-36. - Duty of employees to answer questions by aldermen. 
It shall be the duty of any department of the city government, or of the heads of such departments, of whom an inquiry shall be made by the board of aldermen, to answer the same in writing three (3) business days prior to the next regular meeting of said board. If the department employee or head of such department fails to provide the information requested in a timely manner as described above, the immediate supervisor or superior of said employee or department head shall appear in person before said board. 
(Code 1928, § 66; Ord. of 5-15-89, §§ 1, 2) 
Note— Formerly numbered as 2-6.  
Sec. 2-37. - Approval of contracts on behalf of the board of aldermen. 
Execution of any contract on behalf of the board of aldermen shall require approval of at least two (2) members of the leadership of the board of aldermen. 
Leadership is defined herein as the President, President Pro Tempore, the Majority Leader, Deputy Majority Leader, the Minority Leader, and the Chair and Vice Chair of the Black and Hispanic Caucus. 
At the beginning of the term or as needed leadership shall develop a list of attorneys with special expertise in various areas of law to be available to address any needs that may arise for which outside counsel has been deemed necessary in order for the board of aldermen to perform its duties. 
( Ord. No. 1675, 4-16-12 )  
Secs. 2-38—2-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CITY OFFICERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-61—2-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Duty to draw orders, keep books of claims against city, § 2-128. 
 
Sec. 2-81. - Qualifications. 
Pursuant to city charter section 33 as amended from time to time, there shall be a Town and City Clerk in the City of New Haven. Such clerk, otherwise referred to as the city clerk, shall have all the powers and duties conferred or imposed by law on city and/or town and/or municipal clerks. Such person shall act as clerk of the board of aldermen and all of its committees, and shall have such other powers and duties as are prescribed in the charter as amended from time to time. The city clerk shall reside in said city during his/her term of office. 
For purposes of this Code the city clerk may also be referred to as the city-town clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-82. - City clerk, official duties. 
The city clerk shall execute the following duties: 
(1)  Certify and maintain a copy of the annual official journal of the actions and proceedings of the board of aldermen and its committees; 
(2)  Record the orders of special board of aldermen meetings; 
(3)  Maintain copies of the latest city charter, ordinances, resolutions and orders of the board of aldermen and their revisions; 
(4)  Maintain a record of all elected officers and appointments made by the mayor and/or the board of aldermen; and 
(5)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes sect. 9-15a as amended from time to time, serve on the board of admission of electors with the registrars of voters. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— Similar provisions to § 2-82 were found in former Code §§ 2-5, 2-9, 2-11. These former sections derived from the Code of 1928, §§ 65, 72, 612; Ord. of 11-10-75; Ord. of 8-2-93. 
Cross reference— Board for admission of electors, § 2-346.  
Sec. 2-83. - Records of contracts. 
The city clerk shall keep a copy of all contracts entered into by the city, and its boards, commissions, departments and offices. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-83 amends and supersedes former § 2-41 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 462.  
Sec. 2-84. - Statutory notice of claims required. 
No claim for damages against the city shall be approved for payment without due notice given as required by the state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-84 renumbers former § 2-43 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 71; Ord. of 4-7-93. 
State Law reference— Notice of claims for damages due to action of mobs, § 7-108 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958); notice of claim for damages due to defective roads or bridges, § 13a-149 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958); notice of claim for negligence of employees, §§ 7-308, 7-465 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 2-85. - Duties of clerk, corporation counsel in all cases of notices of claims. 
The city clerk shall receive all notices of claims against the city, and maintain them as written records for public inspection. Upon receipt of such a claim, the city clerk shall transmit it immediately to the corporation counsel for investigation of all relevant circumstances, and examination of any legal questions. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-85 amends and supersedes former § 2-44 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 15; Ord. of 4-7-93. 
Cross reference— Duties of city clerk and corporation counsel regarding notice of claims, § 2-156  
Sec. 2-86. - Duties of clerk, public works department when claim arises from defective streets, sidewalks, bridges. 
Upon receipt of a notice of claim for damages arising from any alleged defect in any street, sidewalk or bridge, the city clerk shall timely notify the department of public works, corporation counsel and any other appropriate city authority. Upon receipt of other types of claims, the city clerk shall notify the appropriate department(s) of the claim in a timely manner. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-86 amends and supersedes former § 2-45 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 14. 
Cross reference— Duties of city clerk, corporation counsel, engineer and chief of police when claim arises from defective streets, sidewalks and bridges, § 2-157.  
Sec. 2-87. - Municipal liability for ice and snow on public sidewalks. 
(a)  The City of New Haven hereby adopts the provisions of Conn. General Statutes sect. 7-163a as amended from time to time, captioned "Municipal liability for ice and snow on public sidewalks." 
(b)  The City of New Haven shall not be liable to any person injured in person or property caused by ice and snow on a public sidewalk, unless the city owns or is in possession and control of the land abutting such sidewalk, other than land that is used as a highway or street. However, the city shall be liable for its affirmative acts regarding such sidewalk. 
(c)  [Responsibility of owner; time limitation re action for damages.] 
(1)  The owner or person in possession and control of land abutting a public sidewalk shall have the same duty of care with respect to the presence of ice or snow on such sidewalk abutting his/her property as the municipality had prior to the effective date of this section [Nov. 21, 1981], and shall be liable to persons injured in person or property where a breach of said duty is the proximate cause of said injury. 
(2)  An action to recover personal and/or property damages caused by ice or snow on a public sidewalk must be brought against a person who owns or is in possession and control of land abutting such sidewalk within two (2) years from the date of injury. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-87 amends and supersedes former § 2-50 which derived from Ord. of 10-26-81, § 1.  
Sec. 2-88. - Duties of city clerk, corporation counsel when assessment appealed. 
When there is an appeal from any assessment or apportionment of damages or benefits, the city clerk shall immediately notify the city's collector, controller and corporation counsel. 
The corporation counsel shall secure a speedy determination of such appeal, and immediately notify the city clerk of any withdrawal of appeal, or the final judgment of the Superior Court in the case. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-88 along with section 2-160 amends and supersedes former § 2-67 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 43. 
Cross reference— Duties of city clerk, corporation counsel when assessment appealed, § 2-160. 
State Law reference— Appeals from municipal assessments, § 7-142 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958); appeals from appraisal of damages, § 7-143 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958); correction of assessments on review, § 7-145 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 2-89. - Notice of elected officials. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 9-320 as amended from time to time, the city clerk shall return a statement to the Secretary of State of the name, post office address and term of all those elected in a municipal election within ten (10) days after the election. The violation of this ordinance shall constitute an offense, and subject the violator to a fine up to the maximum authorized by state statutes or this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-90. - Records and copies. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-23 as amended from time to time, the city clerk shall keep the records of the city including all votes of the city, and copies of all deeds and other instruments which he/she has recorded and attested. A certificate by said clerk or assistant city clerk of these recordings shall be conclusive evidence that the record was properly recorded. The city clerk or his/her legally qualified assistant shall affix the seal to all certified copies of record without charge. These records shall be entered by transcription, photographic, micrographic, electronic imaging, or any other process recognized by law. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-91. - City to pay expenses; reports required; bond. 
Pursuant to the city charter section 34 as amended from time to time, the city shall pay the expenses of the office of city clerk, including the staff's salaries as determined by the budget. During the first week of every month the city clerk shall make a report to the mayor of all receipts deposited into the city treasury for the previous month. On or before the fifteenth day of January the city clerk shall annually submit to the mayor an accounting of the office's actions during the preceding fiscal year. The report shall contain a statement of all moneys received and expended in said year. The city clerk shall be bonded in an amount set by the controller. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-92. - Index. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-25 as amended from time to time, the city clerk shall, within five (5) days after receipt of an instrument for record, enter the names of all the grantors in a grantor index and all the grantees in a grantee index, in alphabetical order, and cross-indexed as to the party first identified as grantor or grantee on the instrument, the nature of the instrument, the date of its receipt as endorsed upon the recorded instrument, and thereafter, when available for entry, the book and page of such instrument, or other suitable indication of its location, approved by the public records administrator. If such instrument is an assignment of mortgage, collateral assignment of mortgage, subordination of mortgage or other transfer of an interest in a mortgage, the mortgagor shall be deemed an additional grantor for purposes of this section. If such instrument is a grant or assignment of a mortgage to a party designated in the mortgage or assignment as the nominee for another, such nominee shall be deemed to be the grantee of such mortgage or assignment. For purposes of this section, if such instrument affects real property, the index shall include a reference to the location of such property if contained in such instrument. Such general index shall be a permanent public record. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-93. - Release or assignment of mortgage or lien; digitized images. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-29 as amended from time to time, when the city clerk has recorded any instrument that he/she knows to be a release, partial release or assignment of a mortgage or lien recorded on the records of the city, the city clerk shall make a notation on the first page where such mortgage or lien is recorded, stating the book and page where such release, partial release or assignment is recorded. If the land records are not maintained in a paper form, the city clerk shall make the notation on the digitized image of the first page of such mortgage or lien in a form or manner approved by the public records administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-94. - Assistant city clerks; notice to secretary of the state of appointment, vacancy. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-19 as amended from time to time, the city clerk may appoint assistant city clerks, who, having taken the oath provided for city clerks, shall, in his/her absence or inability, have all of the city clerk's powers and duties. Within ten (10) days after a city clerk appoints an assistant city clerk, the city clerk shall file a notice of such appointment with the Secretary of the State, indicating the name and address of the person appointed, the date and method of such appointment, and the law under which the appointment was made. Within ten (10) days after a vacancy occurs in the office of assistant city clerk, the city clerk shall notify the Secretary of the State of such vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-95. - Fees. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-34a as amended from time to time, the city clerk shall be authorized to collect fees as established by state statutes in connection with recording documents as well as in the performance of other lawfully designated duties. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-96. - Payment of damages against city for public improvements. 
When any assessment of damages against the city, for any public improvement, is due and payable to any person or persons, a bill for the amount of damages assessed to each, in excess of the benefits assessed to the same person for the same public improvement, shall be presented to the city clerk, and having been, by the city clerk, compared with the order of assessment and certified to be correct, shall be passed and paid in the same manner as other bills. 
(Code 1928, § 3) 
Note— Formerly numbered as 2-66.  
Secs. 2-97—2-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CITY CONTROLLER 
 
Sec. 2-121. - Controller, appointment. 
(a)  There shall be a city controller who is appointed in accordance with the city charter as amended from time to time, and serves as the director of the department of finance. Whenever the controller is absent or incapable of acting, a deputy controller shall be appointed, who shall exercise all powers and duties that the appointing authority designates to him/her. 
(b)  The city controller or deputy controller shall exercise all powers, duties and authority as provided by law, including but not limited to the city charter, municipal ordinances and state laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-122. - Notice to controller. 
The corporation counsel shall give notice to the controller of all sums that he/she or his/her assistants collect, and the controller shall enter the same in the city accounts. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-122 amends and supersedes former § 2-16 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 18.  
Sec. 2-123. - Records kept by the controller. 
The controller shall keep an account of all city departments, and such other accounts as directed by the city ordinances. The controller shall keep appropriate records pertaining to hours of work provided by city employees in accordance with current labor regulations and agreements. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-123 amends and supersedes former § 2-22 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 4; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-124. - Contents of bills against the city. 
Whenever possible, all bills against the city shall contain the items and their respective dates. Otherwise, the controller shall not approve them. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-124 amends and supersedes former § 2-36 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 1; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-125. - Offsetting amounts due against obligations. 
(a)  In case any person to whom a claim is due and payable shall be indebted to the city, the controller shall withhold the order for payment of such claim until such indebtedness is satisfied. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other city ordinance or regulation: 
(1)  The city controller shall not authorize the issuance of any payment to any person, business, partnership, firm or corporation for services, goods, or other purposes, unless and until the city assessor has certified to him/her that said person or entity has filed its list of all taxable personal property that is located in the city. In making this determination, the assessor shall use the city's most recent grand list. 
(2)  Nothing herein shall be construed to apply to payments from payroll accounts, annuities from any pension or retirement account, or any other payment when the delaying or holding thereof is contrary to state or federal laws or regulations. 
(3)  Nothing herein shall be construed to apply to any property that is located outside the City of New Haven. 
(4)  Nothing herein shall be construed to apply to any portion of property located in the City of New Haven for less than the period of time mandated by state law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-125 amends and supersedes former § 2-37 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 9; Ord. of 4-6-87, § 2; Ord. of 8-2-93)  
Sec. 2-126. - Preferences in paying claims when funds inadequate. 
When the controller finds that there is insufficient money to pay all the bills duly allowed, he/she shall determine the order of priority of payments, giving preference to the payroll of the city's regular officers and employees. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-126 amends and supersedes former § 2-38 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 10; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-127. - Authorization, records of obligations under seal. 
The board of aldermen must pass an order or resolution in due form before any bond, deed or other contract under seal can be issued in the name and on behalf of the city. The mayor shall cause the controller to keep a record of all such instruments. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-127 amends and supersedes former § 2-39 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 461. 
Charter reference— Authority of aldermen to prescribe manner and form of making contracts with the city, § 49(a).  
Sec. 2-128. - Duty to draw orders, keep books of claims against city. 
Pursuant to city charter section 24 as amended from time to time, the controller and city clerk shall draw orders on the treasurer to pay claimants the approved amount of their claims in accordance with applicable laws. These payments shall be recorded as required by the city charter. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-128 amends and supersedes former § 2-42 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 11; Ord. of 4-7-93.  
Sec. 2-129. - Duties of controller re public works records. 
(a)  Records of department. The controller shall keep the records of the proceedings and transactions pertaining to the public works department, and shall carefully file and preserve all books and papers connected with or transmitted to said department for execution. 
(b)  Records of contract awarded by department. The controller shall keep a contract book indicating the contracts awarded by the public works department, and their nature, amount and the recipient's identity. 
(c)  Amount of expenditure. The controller shall keep a set of books entered as a journal and ledger account of the moneys expended for all appropriate matters connected with the public works department. 
(d)  Bill-books. The controller shall keep a bill-book containing all approved bills pertaining to the public works department. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-129 amends and supersedes former § 2-59 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 681.  
Sec. 2-130. - Procedure for collecting due assessments. 
When there is any assessment or apportionment of item(s), including but not limited to taxes, damages, interest or penalties, the assessor shall transmit an accounting of the same to the controller noting the date payable. The controller shall record the same, and charge the collector with the duty to collect the amount due and payable. The collector shall proceed to collect the aforesaid amounts. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-130 amends and supersedes former § 2-63 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 44.  
Secs. 2-131—2-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CORPORATION COUNSEL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1391, adopted Sept. 19, 2005, repealed the following former provisions relating to the corporation counsel or legal services: 
Section 	Subject 	History

Sec. 2-151. - Corporation counsel—Appointment. 
The mayor shall appoint a corporation counsel who shall be the chief legal advisor of and attorney for the City of New Haven, and of all of its officers and departments in matters relating to their official duties. The corporation counsel shall be subject to the mayor's authority, and serve a term coterminous with the mayor that appointed him/her. The term "corporation counsel" shall include his/her designee(s). 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-152. - Duty to keep docket, settle claims. 
(a)  The corporation counsel shall keep a docket of all causes to which the city may be a party, and shall deliver it and all other appropriate papers pertaining to his/her office to his/her successor. 
(b)  Upon obtaining the mayor's written consent, and the litigation settlement committee's approval, the corporation counsel shall have the authority to settle, adjust or compromise any appeal, action or suit brought by or against the city, or to which the city is a party. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-152 amends and supersedes former § 2-13 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 597; Ord. of 6-6-32; Ord. of 4-2-34; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-153. - Certification of claims reduced to judgment. 
When a judge or court issues a final judgment against the city, the corporation counsel shall certify the claim's accuracy before it is transmitted to the controller. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-153 amends and supersedes former § 2-14 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 2.  
Sec. 2-154. - Corporation counsel—Compensation. 
In addition to the salary allowed by law, the corporation counsel shall be entitled to reasonable traveling costs and other necessary expenses that are incurred in the proper discharge of his/her official duties. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-154 amends and supersedes former § 2-15 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 598.  
Sec. 2-155. - Corporation counsel—Disposition of funds collected by. 
The corporation counsel shall transfer all sums that he/she and his/her assistants collect to the city treasurer, and notify the controller of these payments. The treasurer shall provide the corporation counsel with receipts for such payments, and the controller shall enter the same in the city accounts. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-155 along with section 2-122 amends and supersedes former § 2-16 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 18. 
Cross reference— Notice to controller, § 2-122.  
Sec. 2-156. - Duties of city clerk and corporation counsel regarding notice of claims. 
Upon receipt of a notice of claim, the city clerk shall immediately transmit it to the corporation counsel. He/she shall examine such claim, and investigate all the circumstances and any legal questions arising from it. The corporation counsel shall keep a written record or memorandum of the facts and results thus ascertained. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-156 along with § 2-85 amends and supersedes former § 2-44 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 15; Ord. of 4-7-93. 
Cross reference— Duties of clerk, corporation counsel in all cases of notices of claims, § 2-85.  
Sec. 2-157. - Duties of city clerk, corporation counsel, engineer and chief of police when claim arises from defective streets, sidewalks and bridges. 
Upon receipt of a notice of claim for damages arising from any alleged defect in any street, sidewalk or bridge, the city clerk shall immediately furnish the corporation counsel with a copy of it. The corporation counsel shall investigate the claim, and require the city engineer, department of public works, chief of police and/or any other relevant city department or official to cooperate and respond to said request within ten (10) days. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-157 along with § 2-86 amends and supersedes former § 2-45 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 14. 
Cross reference— Duties of clerk, public works department when claim arises from defective streets, sidewalks, bridges, § 2-86.  
Sec. 2-158. - Approval of claims for damages. 
No claim for personal or property damages against the city shall be considered without consultation with the corporation counsel, nor shall any such claim be approved and paid except in accord with the requirements of the state statutes, city charter and ordinances, as amended from time to time, and with procedures adopted by the corporation counsel to effectuate said requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-158 amends and supersedes former § 2-46 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 16; Ord. of 4-7-93.  
Sec. 2-159. - Corporation counsel—Collection of claims. 
The corporation counsel shall take all necessary actions to collect all sums due and owing from any third party that is liable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-159 amends and supersedes former § 2-48 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 599.  
Sec. 2-160. - Duties of city clerk, corporation counsel when assessment appealed. 
The corporation counsel shall exercise reasonable efforts to secure a speedy determination of appeals concerning an assessment or apportionment of damages or benefits, and notify the city clerk of any withdrawal of appeal, or final judgment of the appropriate court in the case. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-160 along with § 2-88 amends and supersedes former § 2-67 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 43. 
Cross reference— Duties of city clerk, corporation counsel when assessment appealed, § 2-88.  
Sec. 2-161. - Corporation counsel—Written employment contract forms, employment contract list. 
(a)  The corporation counsel shall approve all written employment contract forms executed by the mayor on behalf of any municipal department, authority, board, commission, bureau or office, or by the president of the board of aldermen on behalf of the board or aldermen. 
(b)  The office of the corporation counsel shall maintain a current list of all employment contracts pertaining to short term and part time municipal employees indicating thereon the following information: 
(1)  Name; 
(2)  Residence; 
(3)  Beginning and ending date of contract; 
(4)  Rate of compensation; and 
(5)  Total maximum amount of compensation. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-161 partially amends and supersedes former § 2-149 which derived from Ord. of 6-6-83; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-162. - Legal services contracts. 
No city official, employee or agency (except the board of education for contracts not exceeding one (1) year) shall engage any individual or firm to provide legal services to or on behalf of the city, nor shall any city funds be spent or obligated for such purpose, without prior aldermanic approval. The corporation counsel shall submit requests for such approval (other than those originating with the board of aldermen) to the president of said board on behalf of the originating agency, official or employee. All requests for such approval shall be accompanied by a draft of the contract to which the request pertains. Approval by said board shall be required unless approved by at least two (2) members of aldermanic leadership, which for these purposes shall be its president, majority leader and minority leader. A copy of each legal services contract executed on behalf of the city shall be filed promptly with the controller, city clerk and corporation counsel. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-162 amends and supersedes former § 2-182 which derived from the Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 3-15-99.  
Sec. 2-163. - Corporation counsel—Service contracts, living wage. 
The corporation counsel shall approve the form and correctness of the language used in all service contracts pertaining to the city's living wage program, and incorporate the provisions of the pertinent article as those provisions apply to such contracts. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-163 amends and supersedes former § 2-226 which derived from Ord. of 4-24-97.  
Sec. 2-164. - Corporation counsel—Annual report to the board of aldermen. 
The corporation counsel shall submit an annual report on the operations of the office for the previous fiscal year. The report shall be submitted to an official or office designated by the mayor on or before a date that he/she specifies. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Cross reference— Annual reports required by the board of aldermen, § 3-61.  
Secs. 2-165—2-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - TAX COLLECTOR 
 
Sec. 2-191. - Tax collector. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 12-130 and the city charter as they are amended from time to time, there shall be a tax collector in the City of New Haven, who shall have full powers and duties as state and local laws and regulations impose on him/her. This official shall be bonded. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-192. - Tax collector, powers and duties. 
The tax collector shall have powers and duties including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Receive and collect all taxes, assessments, and except where otherwise provided by charter or ordinance, all license fees owed to the city from all persons liable to pay the same as authorized by city charter section 30 as amended from time to time; 
(2)  Sign certificates of tax liens if assessments are not paid when they are due and owing; 
(3)  Sign certificates of the release and discharge of tax liens; 
(4)  Enforce payment of all taxes and assessments through the execution of tax warrants as provided by Conn. General Statutes sections 12-162—12-163 as either or both are amended from time to time; 
(5)  Notify the city's corporation counsel, or outside counsel when appropriate, to proceed to take legal steps as may be necessary to enforce payment of delinquent taxes or assessments, and to protect liens of same. The tax collector may need to obtain authorization to use outside counsel from the board of aldermen based on factors including the amount in controversy, and duration of such services; 
(6)  Provide each person from whom taxes are due with a bill containing the assessment amount, and an attachment with a statement of the year and amount of delinquent taxes, if any, as provided by Conn. General Statutes section 12-130 as amended from time to time; 
(7)  Refer tax deferrals with his/her recommendations to the mayor and board of aldermen pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 12-174 as amended from time to time; and 
(8)  Continue any tax lien upon any item of real estate by making out a certificate pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 12-175 as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-192 amends and supersedes former §§ 2-64, 65 which derived from the Code of 1928, §§ 45—47.  
Sec. 2-193. - Tax collector, daily deposits. 
Pursuant to city charter section 32 as amended from time to time, the tax collector shall deposit all moneys that he/she collects during each twenty-four (24) hour period with the city treasurer before 3:00 p.m. of each business day. The treasurer shall give a receipt for such deposit to the tax collector, who in turn files it with the controller. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Secs. 2-194—2-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CITY DEPARTMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-221—2-240. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ENGINEERING 
 
Sec. 2-241. - Department of engineering established. 
The department of engineering is hereby established as a functional unit of city government, and said department shall be under the charge of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-242. - Department of engineering—Books, records required. 
The department of engineering shall keep appropriate records pertaining to engineering. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-243. - Duties of city engineer. 
(a)  The city engineer shall serve as the city's technical advisor on matters concerning infrastructure improvements, roads, sidewalks, bridges, public facilities, public spaces, lighting, flood protection, drainage and other technical issues as deemed appropriate. 
(b)  The city engineer shall execute the duties imposed upon him/her by the city charter and other provisions of this Code as they are amended from time to time, and obey all proper orders that he/she receives from the mayor, the board of aldermen and any of its committees. 
(c)  The city engineer shall prepare all maps, surveys and plans in connection with litigation in which the city is a party when requested to do so by the mayor or corporation counsel. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-243 amends and supersedes former § 2-60 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 683.  
Sec. 2-244. - City engineer to prepare maps and charts, and provide information concerning property affected by public improvements. 
The city engineer shall maintain all maps pertinent to public rights of way and property owned by the city, except in cases where property is taken by tax foreclosure, or purchased for the purpose of resale or disposition not for private use. Such maps are to be used in connection with proposed public improvement developments. Where rights of way or property lines are in question, the city may cause survey(s) to be prepared to validate property street line divisions before such public improvements are made. If adjacent property is benefited or damaged by public improvements, the city engineer shall cause a map to be prepared identifying frontage, dimension and area of the affected property. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-244 amends and supersedes former § 2-61 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 42  
Sec. 2-245. - City engineer—Structural safety evaluations of bridges and other public infrastructure facilities. 
The city engineer shall maintain a list of city owned bridges, and periodically evaluate their structural conditions, and assess their safety for public use. Weight limits and the closing of unsafe structures will be based on the city engineer's structural evaluations. If asked to evaluate other structures, such as buildings, tunnels or other physical improvements on public property, or within the public right-of-way, the city engineer shall render an opinion dealing with its structural integrity, advise the appropriate public entity of such condition, and recommend any emergency measures to safeguard the situation. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Secs. 2-246—2-270. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-271. - Department of public works established. 
The department of public works is hereby created as a functional unit of city government, and said department shall be under the charge of the director of public works.

Sec. 2-275. - Supervision of railroad maintenance. 
(a)  When railroads cross public intersections, or are in parallel conjunction with other public uses, the city shall comply with railroad charters, and regulations governing such work. 
(b)  Where bridges cross railroads the director of public works shall support and implement directives that the board of aldermen set forth pursuant to city charter section 47 as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)

Sec. 2-276. - Authority over abandoned property. 
The department of public works shall be responsible for clearing the public right-of-way from abandoned property and for its disposal. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)

State Law reference— Authority of city over personal effects of ejected tenants when abandoned on sidewalks, § 47a-42 conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 2-277. - Record keeping. 
The department of public works shall keep copies of all notices emanating from or transmitted by it to parties in interest for encroachments upon streets, or laying sidewalks and setting curbs. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-277 along with § 2-129 amends and supersedes former § 2-59 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 681. 
Cross reference— Duties of controller re public works records, § 2-129.  
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC SAFETY COMMUNICATIONS 
 
Sec. 2-278. - Department of public safety communications established. 
The department of public safety communications is hereby established as a functional unit of city government and said department shall be under the charge of a department head appointed by the mayor. The department head shall report to the chief administrative officer who also has oversight of the police and fire departments. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-16-09)  
Sec. 2-279. - Department records. 
The department of public safety communications shall maintain appropriate and required records pertaining all city 911 calls and city emergency responses. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-16-09)  
Sec. 2-280. - Duties of the director of department of public safety communications. 
The director shall be responsible for all aspects of the department including development and enforcement of procedures, hiring and scheduling and training staff, budgeting, reporting, quality assurance and maintaining and upgrading communications and related equipment. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-16-09)  
Sec. 2-281. - Fiscal responsibility. 
The department of public safety communications shall prepare annual operating and capital budgets incorporating expenses previously budgeted in the communications-related portions of the police budget and the fire budget. The department of public safety communications shall be responsible for budgeting and administering emergency communications funds received from the state or federal governments for operational or capital purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-16-09)  
Secs. 2-282—2-300. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CITY EMPLOYEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1391, adopted Sept. 19, 2005, repealed the following former provisions of ch. 2 relating to employees: 
Section 	Subject 	History

2-76 	Political activity prohibited 	Ord. of 4-1-46 
2-78 	Establishment of grievance machinery 	Ord. of 6-4-45, § 5 
2-79 	Authority of mayor to intervene in disputes 	Ord. of 6-4-45, § 7 
2-86 	Special pensions established 	Ord. of 1-13-61 
2-87 	Permanent, full-time employees defined, mandatory retirement age 	Ord. of 5-4-87; Ord. of 8-2-93 
 
Charter reference— Department of personnel and civil service, §§ 200—220. 
 
Sec. 2-301. - Employee associations. 
Conn. General Statutes sections 7-466 to 7-477 as amended from time to time shall control employees' rights to organize and other employee organizational issues. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-301 amends and supersedes former § 2-77 which derived from Ord. of 6-4-45, §§ 1—4, 6.  
Sec. 2-302. - Waiver of pensions by employees. 
(a)  Any person entitled to: 
(1)  A pension from any of the city's pension funds who is under the age of seventy and one-half (70½); or 
(2)  Spousal survivorship benefits on account of the death of an active member who would have been younger than age seventy and one-half (70½) when such survivorship benefits are to be paid may decline to accept all or any part of such pension/survivorship benefits by a waiver signed and filed with the mayor or his/her designee. Such waiver may be revoked in writing at any time but no payment of the waived pension/survivorship benefits shall be made covering the period such waiver was in effect. The waiver shall be deemed revoked when the retiree becomes seventy and one-half (70½) or when the member, on whose account survivorship benefits would have been paid, would have become age seventy and one-half (70½) if he or she had not died. 
(b)  Except as provided herein, no person who leaves employment with the city and receives a pension benefit from one (1) of the city's pension funds, either due to retirement, due to disability or due to achieving the requisite age and/or years of service to qualify for city pension benefits, shall be, after March 1, 2017 re-employed full-time by the city or the city board of education, whether paid from the general fund budget, grants or any special funds. As a condition of re-employment with the city as a full-time employee, any such retiree shall sign a waiver of pension, as described in subsection (a) above and, except as provided in said subsection, shall not revoke such waiver of pension during the period of his or her re-employment. A full-time employee shall be defined as an employee occupying a position for the city requiring said employee to perform services for twenty (20) or more hours each week for a period of six (6) months or more. In order to be compliant with section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code, nothing herein shall be so construed so as to apply, to any rehired city retiree who is age seventy and one-half (70½) or older. 
(c)  The trustees or other authorized administrators of any of the city's pension funds are hereby authorized to amend their by-laws to include a provision therein in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05; Ord. No. 1813 , §§ 1—3, 1-17-17) 
Editor's note— § 2-302 amends and supersedes former § 2-85 which derived from Ord. of 10-23-56, §§ 1, 2.  
Sec. 2-303. - Use of city vehicles by officers and employees. 
(a)  Except as provided for in regulations that the chief administrative officer submits to the board of aldermen and files with the city clerk, no city employee, officer or official shall use a city leased or owned vehicle for personal use. 
(b)  On July 1 and January 1 of each year, the chief administrative officer shall provide the board of aldermen with a list of all city- leased or owned vehicles, and all persons who have used them during each six (6) month period. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-303 amends and supersedes former § 2-88 which derived from Ord. of 7-2-79, §§ 1, 2.  
Sec. 2-304. - Limitation on temporary appointments. 
No person may serve in a temporary employment position with the city beyond one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-304 amends and supersedes former § 2-147 which derived fromOrd. of 6-6-83; Ord. of 5-7-84.  
Sec. 2-305. - Bond fund limitation. 
No municipal employee shall have his/her compensation paid from bond funds unless that employee's work is related solely to the bonded project from which said compensation is paid, and only then until completion of the employee's work related to the project. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-305 amends and supersedes former § 2-148 which derived from Ord. of 6-6-83.  
Sec. 2-306. - Board of education, personal services. 
Unless otherwise provided, no ordinance in this chapter shall supersede any law or regulation of the city charter, state statute or other applicable law pertaining to the procurement of personal services by the New Haven Board of Education. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-306 amends and supersedes former § 2-150 which derived from Ord. of 6-6-83.  
Sec. 2-307. - Leaves of absence for military duty. 
(a)  Leaves granted. Every employee of the city, excepting temporary employees, upon enlistment or receipt of an order directing him to report for service with the armed forces of the United States, the national guard, naval reserve or other unit, or upon entering upon civil emergency defense employment pursuant to requisition by the federal or state government or both, shall be given a leave of absence from the employ of the city during the period of such service or employment. 
(b)  Reinstatement. Every such employee of the city shall be reinstated to the position occupied by him upon entering any of said forms of service, and such position shall be available to such person immediately upon his release or return from service, providing that such position has not been abolished for good and sufficient cause, providing such employee shall have contracted no physical or mental disability which would incapacitate him from performing his usual duties in such position, and providing such employee shall resume such employment, or advise the commissioner in charge of the bureau or department in which he has been employed, of his intention to return to his position in the city service, in which event the commissioner shall allow such time for such employee to return as he may deem proper under the circumstances, but in any event not more than ninety days shall elapse between the time of release or return from such federal or state service or employment, or both, and resumption of city employment period. 
(c)  Investigation of disability before reinstatement. The mayor is hereby empowered to appoint a nonpartisan commission of three members, one of whom shall be a physician, to pass upon all questions of physical and/or mental disability which may arise out of the application of any employee to resume his former employment by the city after being granted a leave of absence under this section. 
(d)  Rights not affected. Absence from employment by the city under the provisions of this section shall not operate to deprive any employee of any benefit of civil service or the benefits under the provisions of any statute or ordinance now existing or hereafter enacted relating to sick leave, vacations, or any other or similar benefits, and such employee shall be deemed to have been in continuous employ of the city during such absence for such service. 
(e)  Controller to furnish copies of section. It shall be the duty of the controller of the city to deliver to any employee of the city granted a leave of absence under the terms of this section, a copy of said section, expressing the policy of the board of aldermen, together with a copy of the authority granting leave to the particular individual named therein. The controller is hereby directed, upon delivery of the copy of said section and authority granting leave of absence, to obtain from such employee, in the manner and form approved by the controller, a signed receipt showing that said employee has received and acknowledges receipt thereof. Such receipt shall be in duplicate, one copy of which shall be filed in a permanent file by the controller, and a duplicate filed with the civil service commission of the city. 
(Ord. of 3-3-41, §§ 1—5) 
Note— Formerly numbered as 2-75. 
State Law reference— Reinstatement of employees after military service, § 7-462 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958); leaves of absence, compensation of reservists on training assignments, § 7-461 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 2-308. - Compensation to injured employees—Appropriation authorized. 
The board of finance shall make suitable provision and appropriation annually, for the payment of approved claims and awards against the city for compensation to its employees for injury arising out of and in course of employment or death resulting from injury so sustained, and for insurance premiums to cover such claims not otherwise provided for. 
(Code 1928, § 19) 
Note— Formerly numbered as section 2-80. 
Cross reference— Reimbursement of police for injuries, expenses, § 22-1; medical care for members of special constable unit injured on duty, §§ 22-1—22-8.  
Sec. 2-309. - Same—Duty of department heads to report claims; procedure. 
It shall be the duty of the head of each department to promptly obtain a statement, in triplicate, from the claimant, and give notice in triplicate on the forms provided by the controller, of all claims for such compensation, together with such other information as said forms may require. Said statements and notices shall be mailed or delivered to the office of the city clerk, who shall cause to be certified thereon the time and date received by him, and forthwith transmit two (2) copies of the same to the office of the corporation counsel, who shall, if necessary, cause said claim to be fully investigated. 
No compensation shall be paid, except in cases where an award has been made by the compensation commissioner, unless the corporation counsel or one of his assistants shall certify that in his opinion the claimant is entitled to compensation, and the rate thereof. 
(Code 1928, § 19) 
Note— Formerly numbered as § 2-81.  
Sec. 2-310. - Same—Notice to corporation counsel when employee resumes work. 
The head of the department in which the claimant was employed, shall promptly mail or deliver to the office of the corporation counsel notice of the return of the injured employee to work, if any time is lost, or the offer of suitable employment and the wage thereof and his failure or refusal, if any, to accept the same. 
(Code 1928, § 19) 
Note— Formerly numbered as 2-82.  
Sec. 2-311. - Same—Authority of clerk to execute agreements. 
The city clerk is hereby authorized to sign in behalf of the city all voluntary agreements affecting such claims, upon their approval by the corporation counsel or an assistant corporation counsel. 
(Code 1928, § 19) 
Note— Formerly numbered as 2-83.  
Sec. 2-312. - Same—Approval of bills, awards by corporation counsel; transmittal to controller. 
All bills, or awards, submitted to the city for payment, under any claims for such compensation, shall be submitted to the corporation counsel or either assistant corporation counsel for his approval and when so approved transmitted by him to the controller. A copy of the notice, of the statement of the claimant, of the report of the investigator and of the voluntary agreement shall be transmitted to the controller by the corporation counsel or either assistant. 
(Code 1928, § 19) 
Note— Formerly numbered as 2-84.  
Secs. 2-313—2-340. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1391, adopted Sept. 19, 2005, repealed former section 2-30 in its entirety which pertained to reports by commercial movers to the registrar of elections and derived from Ord. of 4-4-38. 
Charter reference— General election laws to be applied in city elections, § 8; officers to be elected, § 9; special elections on improvement bonds, §§ 68, 69. 
Cross reference— Loitering around polls prohibited, § 18-15. 
State Law reference— State elections laws, G.S. § 9-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-341. - Registrars of voters. 
(a)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-189a and notwithstanding city charter section 9 as each is amended from time to time, the registrars of voters shall be elected for a term of four (4) years from the first Wednesday following the first Monday of January succeeding their election. Each registrar shall reside in the city while in office. 
(b)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-192 as amended from time to time, each registrar of voters shall appoint a deputy registrar of voters immediately after his/her election. The deputy registrar will hold office during the registrar's pleasure. The registrars may fill any vacancy in said office at any time. 
(c)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-169 as amended from time to time, the registrars of voters shall keep separate lists of the electors residing in each district, and shall appoint a moderator for each district, and such other election officials as are required by law. Additionally, the registrars shall designate one of the moderators or any other elector of the city to be the head moderator for the purpose of declaring the results of elections in the entire city. 
(d)  The registrars shall comply with all other laws and regulations regarding their office duties. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-341 amends and supersedes former § 2-27 which derived from Ord. of 9-13-82, § 2, Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-342. - Checkers. 
Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-234 as amended from time to time, each registrar shall appoint some suitable person to check the list of eligible voters in each district. Each such person, who is so appointed checker, shall check the name of each elector on such list when he/she offers his/her vote. No voting machine tender shall permit any vote to be cast upon the voting machine until the name has been so checked. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-343. - Moderator. 
(a)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-312 as amended from time to time, there shall be a head moderator who will be the presiding officer for the purposes of declaring the voting result of the entire city, and of making returns to the Secretary of State and the city clerk. The moderators in each voting district shall be assistant presiding officers, who shall make returns of their polls as required by law. 
(b)  The moderator of the poll at any city election or vote shall see that the official checkers shall have full and free opportunity to exercise their office, that every voter shall have convenient and unobstructed opportunity to vote, that a free passage to the voting booth shall be kept open, and that the polls and voting booths shall be kept free from noise and disturbance. 
(c)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statute section 9-230 as amended from time to time, when any disorder arises during an election, and the offender refuses to submit to the moderator's lawful authority, the moderator may order any officer with power to arrest to take the offender into custody, and if necessary, to remove him/her from such election until he/she conforms to order or, if need be, until such election is closed, and thereupon such officer shall have power to command all necessary assistance. 
(d)  All moderators shall comply with all other laws and regulations regarding their duties of office. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-343 amends and supersedes former § 2-29 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 468. 
State Law reference— Appointment, duties of challengers, § 9-232 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958); authority of moderators to suppress disorder, compel obedience to orders, § 9-230 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 2-344. - Recording of returns. 
Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-314 as amended from time to time, the head moderator shall transmit complete election results for each contested office to the Secretary of State or state police, and the city clerk after all elections. The return shall include a statement of the total number of names on the city's official check list, and the total number checked as having voted. The city clerk shall procure a copy of the certified returns from the head moderator and record the same in the city records. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-344 amends and supersedes former § 2-28 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 466.  
Sec. 2-345. - Hours of voting. 
Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 9-174 as amended from time to time, the polls shall remain open for voting from six o'clock (6:00) a.m. until eight o'clock (8:00) p.m. at all regular and special municipal elections held on a day other than the day of a regular or special state election. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-345 supersedes former § 2-31 which derived from Ord. of 8-1-66.  
Sec. 2-346. - Board for admission of electors. 
(a)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes sect. 9-15a as amended from time to time, there is hereby created a board for admission of electors (herein called the "board") which shall carry out the duties and responsibilities assigned to such board by the constitution and the laws of the State of Connecticut relating to the admission of persons to the privileges of electors, and to the erasure from the voting registry list of the names of those who have forfeited these privileges. 
(b)  The board shall consist of the city clerk and the registrars of voters in accordance with state law. 
(c)  Any board member who is unable to attend a session for admission of electors shall designate another elected officer to act on his/her behalf by filing a statement of such designation in writing in the office of the city clerk at any time prior to the opening of the session unless a deputy of the city clerk is available to serve in the absence of the city clerk, and unless the deputy registrar of voters is available to serve in the absence of the registrar of voters. 
(d)  The bare majority of the board members shall constitute a quorum. A deputy of the city clerk or a deputy registrar of voters, or any other elected officer designated in the manner described in subsection (c), shall be included as a member of the board for the purposes of establishing a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-346 along with § 2-82 amends and supersedes former § 2-32 which derived from Ord. of 11-10-75. 
Cross reference— Duty of city clerk to serve on the board of admission electors, § 2-82.  
Sec. 2-347. - Petition requirements. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-9 as amended from time to time, whenever the provisions of the state statutes or any special act provides that an action is to be initiated by petition from registered voters, and be voted on by the city's electorate, the city clerk shall prescribe or approve of the petition form. Each page of the petition shall contain a statement, signed under penalties of false statement, by the person who circulated it, setting forth: 
(1)  The circulator's name and address; 
(2)  That each person whose name appears on said page signed it in the presence of such circulator, that the circulator either knows each such signer, or that the signer satisfactorily identified himself/herself to the circulator; and 
(3)  That all the signatures on each page were obtained not earlier than six (6) months prior to the filing of said petition. 
(b)  Any page of a petition that does not contain such a statement by the circulator shall be invalid. Any circulator who makes a false statement in the aforesaid statement shall be subject to the penalty provided for false statement. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-348. - Advisory referendum established. 
(a)  Upon a written request by any person, and a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) majority vote by the full board of aldermen, said board may submit a non-binding referendum to the city's electorate at the next regular state or municipal election. 
(b)  [Petition papers; action of board:] 
(1)  Any city elector may apply to the city clerk for petition papers for an advisory, non-binding referendum on any question. The application shall contain a statement of the question for which the referendum is sought. The city clerk shall provide the elector with sufficient copies of petition papers within five (5) business days of such request for soliciting signatures. All petition papers shall contain the same statement of the referendum question, bear the city clerk's certificate showing the date that the petition papers were issued, and shall indicate the name and address of the person to whom they were issued. In order to bring the referendum question to the board of aldermen for consideration, the petition papers must be signed by eight (8) percent of the city's electorate. 
(2)  The petition papers must be filed with the city clerk within ninety (90) calendar days of their issuance date. The papers must be the same as those that were provided or approved by the city clerk, and must contain the circulator's name and address, a statement that the circulator either knows, or was given satisfactory evidence of each signer's identity, and all the signatures on each page must have been obtained no earlier than six (6) months before the filing of the petition. The circulator must be a registered voter in the city, and must sign and date each petition paper under penalties of false statement. 
(3)  The city clerk shall certify to each petition paper's validity, and refer it to the registrar of voters on the next business day after its return. The registrar of voters shall verify the signatures to be those of registered voters, endorse the findings, and return all petition papers to the clerk within ten (10) business days of such referral. On the next business day after a sufficient number of verified signatures have been returned to the city clerk, the clerk shall submit the petition papers to the board of aldermen for its consideration at its next regular meeting. 
(4)  Upon receipt of the petition papers, the board shall refer the referendum question to the appropriate aldermanic committee for a public hearing before the next regular board meeting. At the board meeting following the public hearing, the board by a majority vote of those present may submit the referendum question to the city's electorate as described in subsection (a) above. If the board of aldermen takes no action on the referendum within forty (40) days after the board receives it, the referendum question shall be deemed approved. 
(5)  If a petitioner pursues the procedures described in this section, and the number of verified signatures equals or exceeds twelve (12) percent of the city's electorate, the advisory, non-binding referendum question shall appear on the ballot of the next regular state or municipal election. 
(6)  The form of petition papers provided by the city clerk under this section shall be substantially in the following form: 
We, the undersigned electors of the City of New Haven, hereby demand the following question be placed before the voters of the city in an advisory, non-binding referendum at the next state or local election. 
Name 	Address (on the last voting list) 	Date 
_______ 	_______ 	_______ 
_______ 	_______ 	_______ 
 
(7)  The circulator shall attest to the signature of all signers at the bottom of each petition page as follows: 
State of Connecticut       ) 
County of New Haven       ) 	ss. New Haven 
 
_______, being duly sworn, deposes and says that he/she is the circulator of the petition papers of which this page is a part, and that each signature subscribed hereon was made in his/her presence, and is the genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be. 
(signed) _____ 
Subscribed and sworn to this _______ day of _______ 
_____
Notary Public 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-348 amends and supersedes former § 2-33 which derived from Ord. of 5-3-82, § 2.  
Sec. 2-349. - Binding referenda. 
Notwithstanding the ordinance pertaining to any advisory referendum, all binding referenda shall be governed by appropriate federal, state and local laws. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-350. - Primary petition forms. 
The registrars of voters shall comply with all applicable requirements concerning petition forms for candidacies for nomination to municipal office, or for election as members of town committees as expressed in Title 9 Chapter 153 of the Connecticut General Statutes as amended from time to time, and all associated federal and state laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2-351. - Wards established. 
The 30-ward redistricting plan redistricting the wards of the City of New Haven in accordance with article III, section 3 et. seq. of the Charter of the City of New Haven, which plan is incorporated herein by reference, is hereby approved and adopted and that section 2-351 et. seq. of the Code of Ordinances be amended to reflect said plan which will take effect on January 1, 2013.
