(Ord. of 5-26-92; Ord. of 9-3-2002; Ord. No. 1676, 5-21-12 ) 
Note— Formerly numbered as § 2-35.  
Sec. 2-352. - Education districts, elected members of the board of education and student members of the board of education. 
(a)  Education districts . Pursuant to Article II, Section B of the Charter there are established two (2) education districts. Education District One shall include of Wards 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 23, 24, 25 and 26. Education District Two shall include Wards 1, 2, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 19, 20, 21, 22, 27, 28, 29 and 30. 
(b)  There shall be two (2) non-voting student members of the board of education. The student members shall be elected by vote of all students enrolled in New Haven public high schools including only those charter high schools whose governing boards choose to participate in the election and notify the committee on student elections to the board of education on or before January first (1st) of their schools that will participate. 
For the first implementation of the student memberships, one (1) rising junior and one (1) rising senior will be elected in the week that includes the first (1st) Tuesday after the first (1st) Monday in June 2015. The rising junior will serve a term from July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2017 and the rising senior will serve a term from July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2016. Thereafter, one (1) student will be elected during the first full week of April each year to serve a two-year term, such that the board of education shall include one (1) junior and one (1) senior high school student. 
After the first implementation, candidates eligible for the position of student member of the board of education shall be New Haven residents enrolled in New Haven public high schools in their sophomore year of high school. 
Board of education student member election committee . The election process for student member of the board of education shall be coordinated and administered by an election committee composed of seven (7) members: The chairs of the education committee and the youth services committees of the board of alders or their designees (2), two (2) community leaders in New Haven selected by the president of the board of alders, two (2) members of the new haven board of education or their designees and one (1) member of the mayor's staff chosen by the mayor. 
The election committee shall submit a written report to the board of alders assessing the first election process, including any recommendations for changes, no later than ninety (90) days after the 2015 election period. 
Filing of candidacies for student members of the board of education . A candidacy for election as a student member of the board of education may be filed by any New Haven resident enrolled in a New Haven public high school except charter schools in their sophomore year of high school. 
Any such candidacy shall be filed by filing with the election committee a petition signed by at least one hundred (100) students enrolled in New Haven public high schools including only those charter high schools whose governing boards choose to participate in the election and notify the committee on student elections to the board of education on or before January first (1st) of their schools that will participate, including signatures of students enrolled at no fewer than five (5) different schools, with at least fifty (50) signatures coming from schools other than the candidate's school. 
Time for filing of candidacies for student members of the board of education . Candidacies shall be filed with the election committee not later than four (4) o'clock p.m. on the twenty-eighth (28th) day preceding the election period for student members of the board of education. Said day and hour shall be specified on the petition forms. 
Petition form . Each petition for nomination shall be on a form prescribed and provided by the election committee. Such form shall provide lines for the signatures, schools, class years, dates of birth and the printing of the names of signators. A signator shall print their name on said line following the signing of the signator's name. Before issuing a petition form, the election committee shall, above the space provided for signatures, type or print the name and address of the candidate, the office sought for election and the election period thereof. The election committee shall give to any person requesting such form one (1) or more petition pages, suitable for duplication, as the election committee deems necessary. An original petition page may be duplicated by or on behalf of the candidate listed on the page and signatures may be obtained on such duplicates. The duplicates shall be filed in the same manner and shall be subject to the same requirements as original petition pages. 
Issuance of nominating petition forms; restrictions. Application requirements . The election committee shall make nominating petition forms available starting on the twenty-eighth (28th) day before the deadline for filing petitions. The election committee shall not issue any nominating petition forms unless the person requesting the nominating petition forms makes a written application for such forms, which application shall contain the following: (1) The name of the candidate to appear on such nominating petition, compared by the election committee with the candidate's name as it appears on their school record, and verified and corrected by the election committee; and (2) a signed statement by the candidate that the candidate consents to the placing of the candidate's name on such petition. 
Circulator . Each circulator of a nominating petition page shall be a student enrolled at a New Haven public high school including only those charter high schools whose governing boards choose to participate in the election and notify the committee on student elections to the board of education on or before January first (1st) of their schools that will participate. Any individual proposed as a candidate in any nominating petition may serve as circulator of the pages of such nominating petition. 
Signature pages . Before any signatures may be obtained on a petition signatures page, above the space provided for signatures shall be indicated the name and address of the candidate, the office sought for election and the election period thereof. Such indication may not be altered or amended after any person has signed the page. Each page of a nominating petition shall contain the names and street addresses of the signers. 
Statement by circulator . Each page of a nominating petition submitted to the election committee shall contain a statement as to the eligibility of the circulator and authenticity of the signatures thereon, signed by the person who circulated the same. Such statement shall set forth (1) such circulator's school, (2) the circulator's date of birth, and (3) that each person whose name appears on such page signed the same in person in the presence of such circulator and that either the circulator knows each such signer or that the signer satisfactorily identified himself to the circulator. 
Signing and certification of circulator's statement; receipt for pages; certification of signatures . The election committee shall not accept any page of a nominating petition unless the circulator thereof has signed the statement as to eligibility of the circulator and authenticity of the signatures thereon. 
The election committee forthwith give to each circulator submitting a page or pages of a nominating petition a receipt indicating the number of such pages so submitted and the date upon which such pages were submitted. 
The election committee shall certify on each such page the date upon which it was submitted to the election committee by the circulator and the number of names of electors on such petition page, which names were on the list of enrolled New Haven public high school students last-completed. The election committee shall certify on each such page the date upon which it was submitted to the election committee by the circulator and the number of names of electors on such petition page, which names were on the list of enrolled New Haven public high school students last-completed or the last completed list of enrolled New Haven students at the Charter Schools that opted to participate in the election. In the checking of signatures on such nominating petition pages, the election committee shall reject any name if such name is not the name of an elector as specified above. 
In the checking of signatures on such nominating petition pages, the election committee shall reject any name if such name is not the name of an elector as specified above. 
Rejection of defective pages. Approval of petitions . The election committee may not count for purposes of determining compliance with the number of signatures required the signatures certified on any petition page filed if: (1) The name of the candidate or their address has been omitted from the face of the petition; (2) the page does not contain a statement by the circulator as to eligibility of the circulator and authenticity of the signatures thereon. 
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the election committee shall approve every nominating petition which contains sufficient signatures counted and certified on approved pages. 
Election logistics . The election committee in conjunction with the board of education will manage the details of the election to minimize disruption to school functions and maximize opportunities for student participation and education through the election process. 
The election committee shall coordinate with the board of education to allow student campaigns access to schools. The board of education shall work with the election committee to ensure that student candidates have access to materials for campaigning. 
(c)  Student members of the board of education . There shall be two (2) non-voting student members of the board of education. The student members shall be elected by vote of all students enrolled in New Haven public high schools including charter schools. 
For the first implementation of the student memberships, one (1) rising junior and one (1) rising senior will be elected in the week that includes the first (1st) Tuesday after the first (1st) Monday in June 2015. The rising junior will serve a term from July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2017 and the rising senior will serve a term from July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2016. 
Thereafter, one (1) student will be elected in the week that includes the first (1st) Tuesday after the first (1st) Monday in June each year to serve a two-year term, such that the board of education shall include one (1) junior and one (1) senior high school student. 
After the first implementation, candidates eligible for the position of student member of the board of education shall be New Haven residents enrolled in New Haven public high schools in their sophomore year of high school. 
(d)  Board of education student member election committee . The election process for student member of the board of education shall be coordinated and administered by an election committee composed of seven (7) members: The chairs of the education committee and the youth services committees of the board of alders or their designees (2), two (2) community leaders in New Haven selected by the president of the board of alders, two (2) members of the New Haven Board of Education or their designees and one (1) member of the mayor's staff chosen by the mayor. 
The election committee shall submit a written report to the board of alders assessing the first election process, including any recommendations for changes, no later than ninety (90) days after the 2015 election period. 
(e)  Filing of candidacies for student members of the board of education . A candidacy for election as a student member of the board of education may be filed by any New Haven resident enrolled in a New Haven public high school in their sophomore year of high school. 
Any such candidacy shall be filed by filing with the election committee a petition signed by at least one hundred (100) students enrolled in New Haven public high schools, including signatures of students enrolled at no fewer than five (5) different schools, with at least fifty (50) signatures coming from schools other than the candidate's school. 
(f)  Time for filing of candidacies for student members of the board of education . Candidacies shall be filed with the election committee not later than four o'clock p.m. (4:00 p.m.) on the twenty-eighth (28th) day preceding the election period for student members of the board of education. Said day and hour shall be specified on the petition forms. 
(g)  Petition form . Each petition for nomination shall be on a form prescribed and provided by the election committee. Such form shall provide lines for the signatures, schools, class years, dates of birth and the printing of the names of signators. A signator shall print their name on said line following the signing of the signator's name. Before issuing a petition form, the election committee shall, above the space provided for signatures, type or print the name and address of the candidate, the office sought for election and the election period thereof. The election committee shall give to any person requesting such form one (1) or more petition pages, suitable for duplication, as the Election Committee deems necessary. An original petition page may be duplicated by or on behalf of the candidate listed on the page and signatures may be obtained on such duplicates. The duplicates shall be filed in the same manner and shall be subject to the same requirements as original petition pages. 
(h)  Issuance of nominating petition forms; restrictions—Application requirements . The election committee shall make nominating petition forms available starting on the twenty-eighth (28th) day before the deadline for filing petitions. The election committee shall not issue any nominating petition forms unless the person requesting the nominating petition forms makes a written application for such forms, which application shall contain the following: (1) The name of the candidate to appear on such nominating petition, compared by the election committee with the candidate's name as it appears on their school record, and verified and corrected by the election committee; and (2) a signed statement by the candidate that the candidate consents to the placing of the candidate's name on such petition. 
(i)  Circulator . Each circulator of a nominating petition page shall be a student enrolled at a New Haven public high school. Any individual proposed as a candidate in any nominating petition may serve as circulator of the pages of such nominating petition. 
(j)  Signature pages . Before any signatures may be obtained on a petition signatures page, above the space provided for signatures shall be indicated the name and address of the candidate, the office sought for election and the election period thereof. Such indication may not be altered or amended after any person has signed the page. Each page of a nominating petition shall contain the names and street addresses of the signers. 
(k)  Statement by circulator . Each page of a nominating petition submitted to the election committee shall contain a statement as to the eligibility of the circulator and authenticity of the signatures thereon, signed by the person who circulated the same. Such statement shall set forth (1) such circulator's school, (2) the circulator's date of birth, and (3) that each person whose name appears on such page signed the same in person in the presence of such circulator and that either the circulator knows each such signer or that the signer satisfactorily identified himself to the circulator. 
(Ord. No. 1765 , 3-16-15; Ord. No. 1783 , 11-16-2015)  
Secs. 2-353—2-370. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - BUDGETARY AND FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 2-371. - Definitions; limits of applicability. 
As used in this article: 
(a)  Agency means an agency, authority, board, commission, department, or office of the city over which the city exercises oversight responsibility. 
(b)  General fund means the city's general operating fund that is created by appropriating ordinances derived from sources including the city charter and this Code as amended from time to time. The general fund is controlled by a legal budget. This fund is used to account for all financial resources except those properly accounted for by another fund. 
(c)  Capital project means any physical public betterment or improvement, or any preliminary studies and surveys relative thereto, the acquisition of permanent property, equipment for any public betterment or improvement when first erected or acquired, major alterations and repairs to existing buildings or structures, and major pieces of equipment. 
(d)  Capital project fund means a city fund regulated by project budgetary control. It is used to pay for a capital project in accordance with the requirements of the charter and other ordinances. 
(e)  Special revenue fund means a fund used to account for the proceeds of one (1) or more specific revenue sources that are generally controlled by grant requirements, specific ordinances, statutes or other legal requirements. It is to be distinguished from such sources as special assessments or major capital project funds, and is generally not controlled by a legal budget. 
(f)  Internal service fund means a special revenue fund used to account for the financing of goods or services between city departments or agencies on a cost reimbursement basis. It is the source for the payment of self-insured public and auto liability, workers' compensation and medical claims. 
(g)  Appropriation means an authorization to make expenditures and incur liabilities for a specific purpose. It is made by enactment of or amendment to one (1) or more appropriating ordinances derived from the city charter or this Code. 
(1)  In the capital budget, an appropriation is the sum authorized for a single project. Its specific purpose is described in the project's narrative. 
(2)  In the general fund budget, (except as provided in the charter section 153 as amended from time to time, for the department of education), the terms appropriation, individual lines of appropriations and line item are synonymous. These terms are used in sections 22(d), 23, 58, 59, 60 and 61 of the charter. 
When used in conjunction with salaries and wages, an appropriation is the sum authorized within an agency; and 
When used in conjunction with any other type of expenditure, an appropriation is the sum authorized within an agency for one (1) or more estimates grouped together. The terms total appropriation and total appropriations are synonymous, and mean the sum of authorizations made for a number of specific purposes grouped together. 
(h)  Transfer of appropriation means an authorization to shift part or the entire sum budgeted for one appropriation to another general fund appropriation as provided by the charter and ordinances. 
(i)  In re the Housing Authority of the City of New Haven and the New Haven Parking Authority provisions of this article shall apply only to funds used to account for appropriations, if any, made for the use of such agency. 
(j)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to fiduciary funds held by the city in a trustee capacity, or as another's agent. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-371 amends and supersedes former § 2-176 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 6-16-94.  
Sec. 2-372. - Budget requests. 
Each agency shall begin preparing the annual general fund, special revenue fund and capital budget requests on the first business day of January, or earlier, as specified by the mayor for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-372 amends and supersedes former § 2-177 which derived from the Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Ord. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 2-373. - Programmatic information; inclusion in budget document. 
Each agency shall provide information, as prescribed by the mayor, setting forth its programs and their legal authority. This information shall be descriptive only, and accompany budget requests. The information shall not confer any legal rights, or additional powers not otherwise granted by the state statutes, city charter or ordinances as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-373 amends and supersedes former § 2-178 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-374. - Policy amendments. 
Each policy amendment approved by the board of aldermen shall be printed verbatim in the budget document as part of the ordinance, order, or resolution it amends. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-374 renumbers former section 2-179 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-375. - Payroll certifications. 
No payment to any person for personal service to the city shall be made to such person unless the personnel director or his/her authorized agent certifies on an appropriate payroll voucher that to the best of his/her knowledge, the payee has been appointed and compensated in accordance with all applicable provisions of law or contract. The payment voucher must bear such certification for payment to be made. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-375 amends and supersedes former § 2-181 which derived from the codification of 1985.  
Sec. 2-376. - Authorization of contracts to be executed one year from date, and non-bid contracts in excess of one hundred thousand dollars. 
(a)  Unless expressly authorized by law or by vote of the board of aldermen, the city shall not be bound by any contract executed after one (1) year from the date thereof. The board of aldermen's prior approval is necessary for any city contract that does not go to bid that costs more than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(b)  The determination of whether a contract is to be executed after one (1) year shall include its initial term plus all automatic renewals and options to renew. Any renewal which materially alters the terms or conditions of a contract shall be resubmitted to the board of aldermen for approval. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-376 amends and supersedes former § 2-40 which derived from the Code of 1928, § 462; Ord. of 9-4-90, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 3-12-01; Ord. of 4-2-01.  
Sec. 2-377. - Handling proceeds from fire insurance policies, other unexpected sources. 
(a)  Upon the mayor's recommendation, the proceeds of any fire insurance policies, or from the sale of any city property, shall be held as a special fund subject to the order of the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Unless received for a special purpose, any other unexpected income shall be deposited in the contingent fund account. If income is received for a special purpose, it shall be held and expended for that purpose. Any remaining balance shall be transferred to said account. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-377 amends and supersedes former § 2-49 which derived from the Code of 1928, §§ 5, 6; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-378. - Annual report distribution. 
City funds shall not be used to distribute the city's annual report on or during the sixty (60) calendar days before any primary or general municipal election. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-378 amends and supersedes former § 2-180 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-379. - Non-grant special revenue funds. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statute section 7-148(2)(K) as amended from time to time, which authorizes municipalities to establish funds which do not lapse at the end of the fiscal year, the controller may establish a special revenue fund to account for the non-grant revenues and expenditures associated with a city agency's activity, provided that the board of aldermen has authorized and directed such action. No activity currently accounted for in the general fund shall be removed from it, and placed in a special revenue fund, unless the board of aldermen has approved such action pursuant to a request from the mayor to do so. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-379 amends and supersedes former § 2-183 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-380. - Annual special revenue fund budgets. 
The mayor shall prepare a budget for each special revenue fund, and shall submit each such budget to the board of aldermen as part of the annual budget submitted on March 1 for the ensuing fiscal year. Each special revenue fund budget shall be accompanied by a statement of revenues, expenditures, and change in balance for each such fund for the preceding fiscal year, and a report of revenues and expenditures for the current fiscal year. When the grantor approves a submitted grant budget pursuant to an executed agreement with the city, the submission of such budget to the board of aldermen shall be for informational purposes only. When the mayor deems it impracticable for a non-grant special revenue fund to be budgeted, he/she shall submit a statement of anticipated revenues and expenditures for such fund for the ensuing fiscal year in lieu of a budget. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-380 amends and supersedes former § 2-183 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-381. - Expenses attributable to other funds. 
Each general fund, special revenue fund or capital project budget, which includes revenues or expenditures attributable to an activity budgeted in another fund or project account, shall identify such revenues or expenditures and their source of activity. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-381 amends and supersedes former § 2-185 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-382. - Provision for compensation expenses. 
Each general fund, special revenue fund and capital project budget shall include adequate provision for payments of all salaries and wages, social security, medical benefits, or other compensation expenses properly chargeable to such budget, unless a different distribution of such costs has been duly authorized. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-382 amends and supersedes former § 2-186 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 2-383. - Insufficient funds; interfund borrowing. 
No moneys from one fund or project account shall be used to pay expenses properly chargeable to another fund or project account, nor shall any moneys be loaned or advanced between funds or project accounts without prior approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. The following situations shall not require aldermanic approval: 
(1)  The payment of debt service or bonds; and 
(2)  Payments needed to meet payroll and/or grant expenses under state, federal or other grants already confirmed or awarded to the city, but for which the city has not yet received and/or finally executed the final grant documents. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-383 amends and supersedes former § 2-187 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-384. - General fund—Budget components. 
The general fund budget consists of: 
(1)  The appropriating ordinances, and supporting schedules and documents that specifically describe and justify each agency's appropriations; and 
(2)  The tax levy and revenue appropriating ordinance, and the revenue estimates upon which the ordinance is predicated. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-384 amends and supersedes former § 2-188 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-385. - Same—Transfers; transfer committee established. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 60 of the city charter as amended from time to time, the controller shall not transfer any appropriation if the transfer is in the amount of fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) or more in a line item, and is not subject to the provisions of section 2-386 of this Code as amended from time to time, unless he/she receives prior approval from the mayor and the transfer committee. No city agency, official or employee can expend or obligate transferred moneys without the mayor's and the transfer committee's approval. If the transfer is subject to the provisions of section 2-386 of this Code as amended from time to time, the board of aldermen's prior approval is necessary to effectuate such transfer. 
(b)  The transfer committee shall consist of two (2) aldermen of different political parties, and are chosen by the board of aldermen. Additionally, the mayor appoints two (2) persons to serve on the transfer committee, who serve at his/her pleasure. All members of this committee shall serve for two (2) year terms, concurrent with the aldermanic and mayoral terms of office. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-385 amends and supersedes former § 2-189 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 11-15-93.  
Sec. 2-386. - Same—Aldermanic approval of certain actions. 
The board of aldermen's prior approval shall be required for a transfer of appropriation or other action if the effect of such action would result in one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  To create a position not included in the budget as adopted, or to reclassify an existing and included position; 
(2)  To increase the total annual salary estimate included in an appropriation for any reason; or 
(3)  To change the board's previously approved appropriation by at least fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-386 amends and supersedes former § 2-190 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-387. - Financial reports from the controller. 
Pursuant to city charter section 22(c) as amended from time to time, the controller shall prepare monthly and/or quarterly reports, which shall include reports of the general fund and each special revenue fund. Additionally, quarterly reports shall include a report of each capital project appropriation existing for any part of the current fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-387 amends and supersedes former § 2-191 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-388. - Monthly reports. 
Pursuant to section 62 of the city charter as amended from time to time, the mayor shall prepare a monthly financial report, which shall have executive reports appended to it. The monthly financial report shall summarize certain monthly activities, which include the following subjects: 
(1)  Tax collector's report on collections, comparing actual to budget and to levy; 
(2)  Mayor's report on grants accepted by the city; 
(3)  Treasurer's report on investments of all city funds; 
(4)  Controller's report on all bonds, notes or other issued debt instruments; 
(5)  Controller's report on transfers approved pursuant to sections 2-385 and 2-386 of the ordinances; 
(6)  Personnel director's report on all non-educational hiring including new hires, transfers, promotions and compliance with budgeted salaries; 
(7)  Travel expenses incurred; and 
(8)  Overtime by department. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-388 amends and supersedes former § 2-192 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-389. - Action to eliminate a projected deficit. 
If the mayor projects a deficit and recommends its elimination in a monthly financial report submitted to the board of aldermen pursuant to section 62 of the city charter as amended from time to time, his/her recommendations shall be effected unless the following conditions occur: 
(1)  Two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the entire board of aldermen vote to consider such recommendations at the meeting at which such report is received; and 
(2)  The board of aldermen approves other action to eliminate the full amount of such projected deficit at the next board meeting following the mayor's monthly financial report submission. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-389 amends and supersedes former § 2-193 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-390. - Bond sale committee. 
There shall be a bond sale committee consisting of the mayor, the controller and the president, majority leader and minority leader of the board of aldermen The committee shall supervise and approve all issuances and sales of bonds, notes or other obligations of the city that the board of aldermen lawfully authorizes. Additionally, the committee shall approve interest rates, maturity schedules, and all other terms pertaining to the issuance and sale of city bonds, notes or other obligations, which are authorized by Conn. General Statutes section 7-370 as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-390 amends and supersedes former § 2-194 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-391. - Agency fund established; administration. 
(a)  The controller shall designate an agency fund for municipal collection services. The controller shall use this fund in his/her capacity as agent to account for transactions associated with the use of collection agencies, or other contractors used by the City of New Haven for collection of delinquent taxes and other receivables. The treasurer shall serve as the custodian of the fund's assets. 
(b)  The controller shall be the administrative director of this fund, and he/she shall create a complete set of accounting records for the purposes specified herein. 
(c)  When the controller determines that there is a need to establish a project or activity within said fund, he/she shall submit a project budget to the board of aldermen for its approval. The project budget shall comply with all applicable provisions of the city's charter and ordinances, and include provisions for contractual services, including a method of payment for such services. Additionally, said budget shall specify a basis and time frame for transferring net income resulting from the services from said fund to specific line items in the general fund. 
(d)  The controller shall provide a report on said fund to the mayor, board of aldermen and the financial review and audit commission on a quarterly basis, or more frequently if so requested. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-391 amends and supersedes former § 2-195 which derived from Ord. of 8-7-95.  
Sec. 2-392. - Capital budget—Components. 
The capital budget shall contain the following: 
(1)  A detailed cost estimate of each proposed project; 
(2)  A statement of anticipated revenues, and city funds required in connection with each project; 
(3)  A listing of all capital projects including a financial summary currently being carried out by the city; 
(4)  An annual report enumerating all vendors, city employees, private contractors, consultants and other personnel who have received capital project funds for services; and 
(5)  A multiyear capital project plan covering a period of not less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) years. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-392 amends and supersedes former § 2-201 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-393. - Same—Contents; surplus fund report. 
The capital budget for each fiscal year shall include specific project appropriations and narratives, bond authorizations and a proposed disposition of surplus capital project appropriations in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  The controller shall certify all funds remaining after completion of the project or the purpose for which the appropriation was made; 
(2)  Such surplus funds shall be: (i) used for retirement of existing debt or payment of debt service thereon, (ii) reappropriated to finance capital projects in the same manner as an original appropriation, or (iii) transferred to the school construction trust fund under section 2-334 of the ordinances; 
(3)  These surplus funds shall be used only as authorized by this section. The controller is authorized to lawfully invest such funds temporarily until they are disposed of in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-393 amends and supersedes former § 2-202 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 5-20-96, § 2.  
Sec. 2-394. - Same—Preparation of capital project estimates. 
The capital projects committee shall receive a detailed estimate for each agency's proposed capital projects for the next fiscal year. The estimates shall be in such form as prescribed by said committee or otherwise by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-394 amends and supersedes former § 2-203 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-395. - Same—Project maintenance program. 
A capital project submitted to the capital projects committee shall include a project maintenance program if said committee requires it, or if the project includes any of the following: 
(1)  A fixed or movable bridge; 
(2)  New construction or major alteration to any public building or structure whose total construction or renovation area exceeds thirty thousand (30,000) square feet; or 
(3)  A major piece of equipment or rolling stock which exceeds one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) on a per unit purchase price basis. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-395 amends and supersedes former § 2-204 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-396. - Same—Aldermanic amendments. 
The board of aldermen may increase, reduce or eliminate any capital project included in the proposed capital budget. Additionally, said board may amend any narrative or supporting language attached to, or contained within, the proposed capital budget, provided that the total of all such changes shall not increase the total amount of the capital budget as transmitted pursuant to city charter section 80 as amended from time to time. The board may not add any capital project to the capital budget submitted by the mayor except in accordance with the emergency certification procedure described in section 2-397 of the ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-396 amends and supersedes former § 2-205 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-397. - Same—Emergency certification procedure. 
Once the proposed capital budget is submitted to the board of aldermen, the mayor shall not propose further revisions to it without first obtaining a vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the board of aldermen certifying the proposed amendment or revision as an "emergency". Once certified, the mayor shall obtain the capital projects committee's approval of the proposed revisions. This approval must be done in the same manner that is required by the city charter and ordinances concerning the annual capital budget's preparation and submission as they are amended from time to time. Once the capital project committee approves the revisions, the mayor shall resubmit the revised capital budget to the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-397 amends and supersedes former § 2-206 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-398. - Same—Review of authorizations. 
The capital projects committee shall annually review all capital projects for which bonds or bond anticipation notes were authorized but not issued, for which two (2) complete years have passed from the board of aldermen's appropriation approval date. The purpose of the review is to determine which projects and purposes are no longer viable, and the reasons for their lack of viability. The committee shall transmit any recommendations regarding the abandonment of such capital projects to the mayor in accordance with section 2-402 of the ordinances as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-398 amends and supersedes former § 2-208 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-399. - Same—Aldermanic review. 
The board of aldermen may at its discretion review the progress of any capital project after two (2) complete fiscal years from the board's appropriation approval date. 
Editor's note— § 2-399 amends and supersedes former § 2-209 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-400. - Same—Appropriations to be frozen; exception. 
Unless bonds or bond anticipation notes have been issued in any amount pursuant to a capital project's appropriation, such appropriation shall be frozen on the last day of the municipal fiscal year occurring after four (4) complete years from the board of aldermen's appropriation approval date for such project. If bonds or bond anticipation notes have been so issued, the full amount of such appropriation shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-400 amends and supersedes former § 2-210 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-401. - Same—Action on frozen appropriations. 
The capital projects committee shall review all such frozen appropriations, and propose recommendations to the mayor in accordance with section 2-402 of the ordinances as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-401 amends and supersedes former § 2-211 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93.  
Sec. 2-402. - Same—Amendments. 
The capital projects committee may recommend amendments to capital budgets or projects previously approved by the board of aldermen. Such recommendations shall be proposed to the mayor. If the mayor approves such recommendations, he/she shall submit them to the board of aldermen as part of the annual capital budget unless circumstances warrant an earlier submission. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-402 amends and supersedes former § 2-212 which derived from Ord. of 7-6-93)  
Sec. 2-403. - School construction trust fund established; deposit to fund; uses of fund. 
(a)  There shall be a school construction trust fund (hereafter the "fund"). During each fiscal year the following sources shall provide deposits to the fund: 
(1)  The proceeds of the trust fund sale of October 1995; 
(2)  Any appropriations made to the fund in the general fund budget for such fiscal year; 
(3)  Any portion of general fund cash surplus transferred to the fund pursuant to the procedure set forth in ordinance section 2-385 as amended from time to time; 
(4)  Any portion of cash surplus from completed capital projects transferred in accordance with the procedures set forth in ordinance section 2-393; 
(5)  Any state or federal grants-in-aid of such school construction projects, and any gifts or contributions provided for such projects; and 
(6)  Any investment earnings allocated to the fund for such fiscal year. 
(b)  Moneys in the fund shall be used from time to time subject to the board of aldermen's approval for the following purposes: 
(1)  To meet appropriations in the city's capital budget, or in any amendment to ordinance section 2-402, for major school construction projects such as new school buildings and additions and renovations to existing buildings. This includes administration costs and planning expenses and costs in support of such projects; or 
(2)  Transferred to the general fund to meet appropriations for the payment of debt service on the city's bonded indebtedness issued for school construction projects. 
(c)  The fund shall continue until terminated, and its moneys that are kept on deposit shall be non-lapsing, and held separately from the moneys in the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-403 amends and supersedes former § 2-213 which derived from Ord. of 5-20-96, § 1)  
Sec. 2-404. - Audit; selection. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-392 as amended from time to time, the city shall have all of its accounts audited at least once annually. 
(b)  No independent firm of certified public accountants appointed pursuant to state law and the city charter shall perform any part of the annual city audit for more than four (4) consecutive years unless such independent firm is selected as the most qualified firm as a result of the quadrennial auditor selection process. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-404 amends and supersedes former § 2-22.1 which derived from Ord. of 10-21-85, § 1; Ord. No. 1267, 8-7-00.  
Sec. 2-405. - Process for transparent allocation and distribution of resources. 
A new four-member City Resources Allocation Subcommittee (hereafter referred to as the C.R.A. subcommittee will be formed consisting of two (2) aldermanic representatives, to be selected by the leadership of the Board of Aldermen as follows: one (1) from leadership, and one (1) from the members of the Board of Aldermen not in leadership, and two (2) members from the administration, to be appointed by the Mayor, each member of the subcommittee serving a two-year term beginning in 2012. 
In the FY 2012-2013 budget funds [shall] be allocated to have an independent, expert consultant complete an up-to-date survey rating condition of all of the city's streets and sidewalks, with said survey to be submitted to the City Resources Allocation Subcommittee, and to be undertaken at least once every four years. The City of New Haven shall maintain two lists, each produced by such independent, expert consultant, showing the block by block condition of (1) all sidewalks, and (2) all streets in New Haven. These lists shall be kept current and shall be posted on the city's website; and 
Aldermen are encouraged to and can choose to have an open and participatory process, in which their ward residents are involved in identifying and addressing needs in their respective wards. On an annual basis, each of the aldermen shall develop a list of projects for their ward ranked in order of greatest priority based on a scale which factors in public safety urgency, as well as the degree of constituent concern. Such list shall be submitted to the City Resources Allocation Subcommittee on a date determined by the allocation subcommittee in 2012 and annually no later than June 15 of each year thereafter. 
The appropriate type of paving treatment for a ward street to be repaved shall be determined by the city engineer and/or the director of public works. The subcommittee shall consult with and seek the advice and expertise of the city engineer, director of public works and director of parks, recreation and trees in expediting completion of the selected sidewalk, street and tree projects. 
The City of New Haven shall allocate and distribute all resources for sidewalk improvements, street paving, tree trimming or removal, and stump removal, equitably in the following manner. 
A.  Federal and State funding for specific streets, roads, and sidewalks will be coordinated with the aldermen in the affected wards. 
B.  Other funds designated for sidewalk improvements, street paving, tree trimming or removal, and stump removal shall be divided into two funds: An Emergency Street Paving Fund to be used for urgent unforeseeable projects to be done throughout the city, regardless of ward, which pose a public safety risk and require immediate remedial action; and a General Street Paving Fund, which addresses ongoing repair needs in the wards, as selected by the C.R.A. subcommittee, based on the consultant's ratings and Aldermanic input. 
The new resource allocation process for sidewalk improvements, street paving, tree trimming or removal, and stump removal shall take effect and commence operation beginning with the Fiscal Year budget 2012-2013 and that; 
A.  The funds for street paving consist of the: 
1.  Emergency Street Paving Fund: Each fiscal year funds shall be allocated for this purpose based on the average of the last five (5) years actual expenditures for urgent unforeseeable projects throughout the city which posed a public safety risk and required immediate remedial action. 
2.  General Street Paving Fund: Each fiscal year funds a minimum of seven hundred fifty thousand dollars ($750,000.00) shall be allocated for this purpose. The C.R.A. subcommittee may recommend that the board of aldermen increase the amount. 
B.  The funds for sidewalks consist of the: 
1.  Emergency Sidewalk Fund: Each fiscal year funds shall be allocated for this purpose based on the average of the last five (5) years actual expenditures for urgent unforeseeable projects throughout the city which posed a public safety risk and required immediate remedial action 
2.  General Sidewalk Fund: Each fiscal year a minimum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) shall be allocated shall for this purpose. The C.R.A. subcommittee may recommend that the board of aldermen increase this amount. 
C.  The funds for trees consist of the General Ward Tree Fund: Each fiscal year a minimum of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) from the park department's capital budget "street trees fund" shall be allocated for this purpose to be divided equally between all wards. The C.R.A. subcommittee may recommend that the board of aldermen increase this amount. 
Working within budgetary limits, the City Resources Allocation Subcommittee will select and approve all street and sidewalk work prior to any work commencing (with the exception of emergency repairs, which must be reported to the C.R.A. subcommittee for review no more than thirty (30) days from when such job commenced). The C.R.A. subcommittee shall prioritize and select all non-emergency projects to be scheduled, based on ratings by the consultant; recommendations and input on each ward's priorities based on lists supplied by individual aldermen; and based on advice and consultation with the city engineer, director of public works and other appropriate city officials. Emphasis is to be given to repairing those streets and sidewalks deemed to be in the worst condition or a greater safety risk. 
The C.R.A. subcommittee will communicate regularly with the board of aldermen on the selection and scheduling of the projects to be done on streets, sidewalks, and trees, as well as provide regular quarterly reports on all street, sidewalk and tree work to the entire board, upon submission such communication including but not limited to all quarterly reports shall also be posted on the city's website by the city staff on the C.R.A subcommittee; and 
The C.R.A. will report to the Finance Committee of the Board of Aldermen in November, 2012 and as needed to review this ordinance and make recommendations for amendment to the ordinance for future fiscal years. 
(Ord. No. 1684 , 7-2-2012) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1684 , adopted July 2, 2012, did not specificially set out provisions for inclusion in the Code. For purposes of classification, and per instruction from the city, these provisions have been included as § 2-405.  
Secs. 2-406—2-430. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PURCHASING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-431—2-450. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCUREMENT OF PERSONAL SERVICES 
 
Sec. 2-451. - Purchasing and bidding procedures. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. The City of New Haven hereby declares that it narrowly construes the types of personal services that can be provided through the bidding procedures set forth in city charter section 74 as amended from time to time. This policy is premised upon the following grounds: 
(1)  City charter section 156 as amended from time to time, provides for a civil service board and a department of personnel consisting of a personnel director and such other employees as shall be provided in the budget; 
(2)  City charter section 158 as amended from time to time, sets forth a broad mandate and duty of the civil service board to ascertain the competency of applicants for all positions or promotions in the city government by competitive examination except for specified exceptions; 
(3)  Unless city charter section 74 is narrowly construed, the purchasing agency could usurp the position and authority of the civil service board and the personnel director and their clear charter mandate to provide for employment based upon merit selection. 
(b)  Definitions. The following are defined terms for the purposes of this article: 
Municipal employee means any person who holds employment with the municipal government of New Haven for which such person receives financial compensation from the city: 
(1)  Whether such employment is in the classified or unclassified service; 
(2)  Whether such employment is part-time or full-time; and 
(3)  Whether such employment is permanent or temporary. 
Independent contractor means any individual(s), firm, partnership or corporation in business for himself/herself/itself who contracts to do certain specified work according to his/her/its own methods and means, and without being subject to the control or supervision of any municipal employee except as to the result of the work. 
The municipal government of the City of New Haven means: 
(1)  The City of New Haven, and all departments, agencies, authorities, boards, commissions, bureaus and offices created by and existing under the city charter; 
(2)  The City of New Haven and all departments, agencies, authorities, boards, commissions, bureaus and offices created by or existing under an ordinance or resolution of the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven (whether or not such ordinance or resolution was adopted pursuant to a state statute authorizing such ordinance or resolution). 
Expert professional consultant means any independent contractor as defined herein providing highly technical, specialized and advanced advice and/or work product, and whose responsibilities shall not include any job duties: 
(1)  For which a civil service test (or classification) currently exists; or 
(2)  Which are assigned to any current member of a city bargaining unit. 
(c)  Scope of purchasing agent's authority to bid contracts pursuant to city charter section 74: 
(1)  The purchasing agent shall process requests for proposals only for work to be performed by independent contractors, as defined herein. However, the following types of independent contractors are specifically excluded from the purchasing and bidding procedures set forth in charter section 74 as amended from time to time: 
a.  Architects; 
b.  Engineers; 
c.  Land surveyors; 
d.  Physicians/Medical doctors; 
e.  Dentists; 
f.  Lawyers/Attorneys; 
g.  Accountants; 
h.  Artists; 
i.  Actuaries; 
j.  Expert professional consultants; and 
k.  Such other professional or technical services as the board of aldermen may provide by ordinance. 
(2)  Contracts with the excluded classes of independent contractors shall only be entered into by the mayor on behalf of any municipal department, authority, board, commission, bureau or office, or by the president of the board of aldermen on behalf of the board of aldermen. 
(3)  The city's purchasing agent shall immediately cease and desist from utilizing the purchasing and bidding procedures of city charter section 74 as amended from time to time to procure personal services, except and unless the provider of the services is an independent contractor, as defined herein. Contracts with expert professional consultants shall be initiated through a written proposal describing the program and the personnel involved. 
(4)  For the purposes of requests for proposals for work performed by independent contractors for professional services, whether the business is a "city-based business," as defined in Code section 2-483(a), shall be a factor considered in the selection of such contractor. 
(5)  The City of New Haven's policy on city-based businesses shall be stated in the request for proposal. 
(d)  Authority of the purchasing agent to determine status as an independent contractor and/or exempt professional, subject to review: 
(1)  The purchasing agent shall determine in the first instance whether a "request for proposal" is properly seeking work to be done by an independent contractor as defined herein; 
(2)  Upon the determination that a "request for proposal" is properly seeking work to be done by such an independent contractor, the department initiating said request selects the proposing party to perform such work. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-451 amends and supersedes former § 2-146 which derived from Ord. of 6-6-83; Ord. of 12-21-92; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Secs. 2-452—2-480. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - COMPETITIVE BIDDING REQUIREMENTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1391, adopted Sept. 19, 2005, repealed former section 2-152 in its entirety which pertained to the scope of competitive bidding requirements and derived from Ord. of 10-15-90. 
 
Sec. 2-481. - Disability insurance required of bidders on city contracts. 
(a)  Whenever the city purchasing agent advertises for invitations to bid for contracts, he/she shall require that the contractors maintain a worker's compensation insurance policy, a binder for such a policy, or evidence of adequate self-insurance protecting company workers against injury. This requirement shall be a condition precedent to the award of any contract. The general contractor shall certify for all subcontractors. 
(b)  Any such worker's compensation insurance policy shall be issued by a company authorized to write such policies in Connecticut, and shall be in such form that is satisfactory to the city purchasing agent. 
(c)  The city purchasing agent shall require and affirm that no bidders, including all general contractors and subcontractors, are in arrears to the state's second injury fund. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-481 amends and supersedes former § 2-22.2 which derived from Ord. of 11-18-85; Ord. of 8-2-93.  
Sec. 2-482. - Minimum bidding requirements. 
(a)  Except as otherwise required by federal and/or state law or regulation, sealed bidding shall not be required for contracts or purchases of supplies, materials or equipment and non-construction related services having a value less than or equal to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). Contracts and purchases for said items and services having a value greater than five hundred dollars ($500.00) but less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be awarded in accordance with procedures established by the purchasing agent, which shall include preference for city-based businesses as defined in Code section 2-483 and consistent with the procedures set forth therein. 
(b)  Except as otherwise required by federal and/or state law or regulation, sealed bidding shall not be required for construction and construction related contracts and services having a value less than or equal to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). Contracts and purchases for construction and such related services having a value greater than five hundred dollars ($500.00) but less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall be awarded in accordance with informal quotation and informal bidding procedures established by the purchasing agent, which shall include preference for city-based businesses as defined in Code section 2-483 and consistent with the procedures set forth therein. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-482 amends and supersedes former § 2-151 which derived from Ord. of 10-15-90; Ord. of 12-21-92; Ord. No. 1292, § 5, 11-19-01.  
Sec. 2-483. - Preference for city-based businesses. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section "city-based business" shall mean a business with its principal place of business located within the City of New Haven. A business shall not be considered a "city-based business" unless evidence satisfactory to the purchasing agent has been submitted with each bid to establish that said business has its bona fide principal place of business in New Haven. Such evidence may include evidence of ownership of or a long-term lease of the real estate from which its principal place of business is operated, or payment of property taxes on the personal property of the business. A "city-based business" shall maintain such status throughout the term of any contract with the City of New Haven. Failure to maintain such status shall be grounds for the city to terminate said contract. 
(b)  On any contracts or purchases the lowest responsible bidder shall be determined in the following order: 
(1)  On contracts or purchases involving a total contract price of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or less: any city-based bidder that submitted a low bid not more than ten (10) percent higher than the lowest bid, provided such city-based bidder agrees to accept the award of the bid at the lowest bid amount. If more than one (1) city-based bidder has submitted bids not more than ten (10) percent higher than the lowest bid, and has agreed to accept the award of the bid at the lowest bid amount, the lowest responsible bidder shall be the city-based bidder that submitted the lowest bid. 
(2)  On contracts or purchases involving a total contract price of over a million dollars ($1,000,000.00) but less than five million dollars ($5,000,000.00): any city-based bidder that submitted a bid not more than five (5) percent higher than the lowest bid, provided such city-based bidder agrees to accept the award of the bid at the lowest bid amount. If more than one (1) city-based bidder has submitted bids not more than five (5) percent higher than the lowest bid, and has agreed to accept the award of the bid at the lowest bid amount, the lowest responsible bidder shall be the city-based bidder that submitted the lowest bid. 
(3)  On contracts or purchases involving a total contract price of over five million dollars ($5,000,000.00): any city-based bidder that submitted a bid not more than three (3) percent higher than the lowest bid, provided such city-based bidder agrees to accept the award of the bid at the lowest bid amount. If more than one (1) city-based bidder has submitted bids not more than three (3) percent higher than the lowest bid, and has agreed to accept the award of the bid at the lowest bid amount, the lowest responsible bidder shall be the city-based bidder that submitted the lowest bid. 
(4)  The responsible low bidder. 
(c)  The City of New Haven's policy on city-based businesses shall be stated in the invitation to bid. 
(d)  Paragraph (b)(1), (2) and (3) shall apply to any contracts or purchases that are put out to competitive bid, and the city and the contractor are to share in the revenue generated by the contractor's services. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-483 amends and supersedes former § 2-153 which derived from Ord. of 12-21-92.  
Sec. 2-484. - Definitions. 
[For the purposes of Code sections 2-485 and 2-486, the following definitions apply:] 
(a)  Contract means any public contract as defined hereafter. 
(b)  Person means one (1) or more individuals, partnerships, corporations, associations or joint ventures. 
(c)  Public contract means any agreement or formal commitment that the city enters into to expend funds in return for work, labor, services, supplies, equipment, materials or any combination of the foregoing, or any lease, lease by way of concession, concession agreement, permit or permit agreement whereby the city leases, grants or demises property that the city owns, or otherwise grants a right or privilege to occupy or use said property. 
(d)  City means any official, agency, board, authority, department, office, or other subdivision of the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-484 amends and supersedes former § 2-154 which derived from Ord. of 12-21-98)  
Sec. 2-485. - Obligations of persons seeking to contract with city; affidavits, disclosures and certifications. 
(a)  The city shall not award a contract to any person or entity until the bureau of purchases receives the following documents: 
(1)  Such person's affidavit attesting that he/she/it does not owe delinquent taxes or other financial obligation to the city, provided, if such person has entered into an agreement to pay delinquent taxes in installment payments satisfactory to the tax collector, and the payments under said agreement are not in default, the affidavit shall recite that agreement; 
(2)  Such person's affidavit attesting that he/she/it has either filed a list of taxable personal property with the assessor for the most recent grand list as required by state statute, or that he/she/it is not required to file such list; and 
(3)  Disclosures as required by Code section 2-486 as amended from time to time. 
(b)  If said affidavits and disclosures are not submitted as part of competitive bid provisions, the city agency, board, authority, office, department or official seeking the contract shall obtain them. 
(c)  The city shall not award a contract to any person until the following certifications have been obtained: 
(1)  A certification from the city assessor that such person has filed a current list of taxable personal property pursuant to Conn. General Statute section 12-40 as amended from time to time, or a certification that such person is not required to file such list; and 
(2)  A certification from the city's tax collector that such person or any affiliated entity, either directly or through a lease agreement, owes no back taxes; provided, that if the taxpayer owes back taxes, but he/she/it or another responsible party has executed an installment payment agreement with the city which is satisfactory to the tax collector, and such payments are not in default, then the fact that such person owes the city back taxes shall not be a bar to the contract. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-485 amends and supersedes former § 2-155 which derived from Ord. of 12-21-98.  
Sec. 2-486. - Disclosures required by persons seeking to contract with city. 
(a)  Any person seeking to enter into a contract with the city shall disclose all names under which he/she/it has provided services or materials to the city within one (1) year of the disclosure submitted for each such contract as required by this section. 
(b)  Any person seeking to enter into a contract with the city shall disclose: 
(1)  The names of all persons affiliated with such person's business; 
(2)  The names of all business organizations in which such person has an ownership interest; 
(3)  The names of all owners in such entity, provided, if such entity is a corporation, the names of its officers, and common stock holders who hold more than twenty-five (25) percent of its outstanding stock; and 
(4)  The identity of all affiliates, individuals or business entities that own or have owned taxable property situated in the city within one (1) year prior to the date of the disclosure required by this section. 
(c)  Any person doing business under a trade name that is seeking to enter into a contract with the city to provide it with goods, materials or services, shall disclose where such entity is incorporated or registered to conduct such business, and the address of its principal place of business. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-486 amends and supersedes former § 2-156 which derived from Ord. of 12-21-98.  
Sec. 2-487. - Observation of Martin Luther King Day. 
The city shall not award any contract to any person, as defined in Code section 2-484(b), until and unless said person provides a written statement to the city affirming that the contractor, all associated subcontractors and all employees thereof performing work on a city contract shall observe Martin Luther King Day as a national holiday. The statement shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the corporation counsel, and shall be filed with affidavits, disclosures and certifications required by Code section 2-485 as amended from time to time. The purchasing agent shall promulgate this section's provisions, and include it with bid documents, contract applications, and other materials given to city bidders and contractors. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-487 amends and supersedes former § 2-157 which derived from Ord. of 1269, 8-7-00.  
Sec. 2-488. - Performance and payment bond. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 49-41 as amended from time to time, and unless otherwise authorized, the city purchasing agent shall require that contractors obtain a payment bond and performance bond when their contracts involve the construction, alteration or repair of any public building or public work in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). The bonds must be in amounts that are satisfactory to the city purchasing agent. 
(b)  The city purchasing agent has discretion to require a performance bond for any contract exceeding twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for the provision of supplies, materials or equipment. 
(Ord. No. 1391, 9-19-05) 
Editor's note— § 2-488 amends and supersedes former § 2-158 which derived from Ord. No. 1292, § 6, 11-19-01.
