ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2½-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
Agency means each municipal board, commission, department, bureau, agency, administration or other entity authorized pursuant to federal law, state law, the city charter, ordinance (including, but not limited to, appropriating ordinances), executive order or any other law to make regulations or determine contested cases. This term does not include the mayor, (but does include the coordinators that the mayor appoints pursuant to city charter section 11(i) as amended from time to time, and other officials that are appointed to aid him/her in carrying out his/her duties as the city's chief executive and administrative officer), the board of aldermen and the corporation counsel. 
Applicant means a person, who desires to receive a direct loan or grant from an agency, and has submitted a completed application to the agency. 
Contested case means any proceeding that an agency conducts to determine a party's legal rights, duties, or privileges after an opportunity for hearing, or in which a hearing is in fact held pursuant to local law or regulation. This term does not include any proceeding conducted in accordance with federal or state law or regulation, the charter, any other ordinance, or any collective bargaining agreement, provided there is no otherwise established procedure. 
License includes the whole or part of any agency permit, certificate, approval, registration, charter, or similar form of permission required by law, but it does not include a license solely for revenue purposes. 
Party means such person or agency named or admitted as a party, or properly seeking or entitled as a right to be admitted as one. 
Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, association, governmental subdivision, or public or private organization of any character, other than an agency. 
Regulation means each agency statement of general applicability that implements, interprets or prescribes law. The term includes the amendment or repeal of a prior regulation, but does not include: 
(1)  Statements solely concerning the agency's internal management, which do not affect private rights or procedures available to the public; 
(2)  Intra-agency or inter-agency memoranda; 
(3)  Statements applying to a particular person or transactions not of general application. This term does not include investigatory techniques or procedures to be used for prospective law enforcement actions by the city's police and fire departments. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-1; Ord. of 8-2-93; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-2. - Annual performance evaluation of coordinators and agency heads. 
(a)  The mayor, or the head of a board or commission where appropriate, ("supervisor"), shall prepare the following documents pertaining to each executive position not included in a collective bargaining agreement: 
(1)  The complete position description, list of preferred or required qualifications, and a written statement of any other criteria that may be used in the selection of a person to fill the position; 
(2)  A statement of the goals of the evaluation process; 
(3)  A statement of the specific criteria to be used to evaluate the executive employee's ("incumbent's") annual performance; and 
(4)  A statement of the procedures which will be followed if the incumbent's performance is found to be unsatisfactory. 
The mayor or the supervisor shall prepare the above documents in conjunction with the personnel director's professional advice. 
(b)  The supervisor shall conduct an annual performance evaluation of the preceding calendar year for each incumbent. The annual performance evaluation shall be completed no later than January 31st. The incumbent shall be given written notice of the date, time and location of the evaluation meeting, and a copy of the evaluation process goals and criteria at least two (2) weeks before the evaluation date. The supervisor shall submit a letter to the board of aldermen indicating that the evaluation has been done. Such letter shall be submitted within ten (10) business days following completion of the annual performance evaluation. 
(Ord. of 5-7-90; Code of 1985, § 2½-1.1; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Secs. 2½-3—2½-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - AGENCY; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; FILINGS; BUDGETS; GRANT AND LOAN PROGRAMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Former Ch. 2½ contained a § 2½-2 titled, "Filings with city-town clerk; organizational chart; program descriptions; contact persons; other regulations." This former section was repealed by Ord. No. 1390, adopted Sept. 19, 2005. 
 
Sec. 2½-21. - Fiscal impact statements. 
Whenever an agency submits a matter involving the expenditure of general funds, special funds, bond funds or a commitment of the city's credit to the board of aldermen, it shall include a statement concerning the fiscal impact of the matter on the city. The statement shall be provided as prescribed by the controller, and shall identify the funding source to be expended, and the impact of the matter on the then existing general fund budget or capital budget. The agency shall file a copy of the statement with the controller concurrently with its submission to the board of aldermen. This provision shall not apply to the agency's annual budget request. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1, Code of 1985, § 2½-3; Ord. of 8-2-93; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-22. - Procedures for direct grant and loan program. 
(a)  No agency may provide a direct financial grant or loan, other than general assistance, to an applicant unless it has adopted regulations concerning application procedures for such assistance, and filed them with the city clerk. However, when the terms and conditions for applying for and receiving such assistance are governed by any other federal, state or local law, regulation or enactment, then the agency administering such assistance will be deemed to have satisfied this section by filing a notice setting forth the applicable reference to such legal authority with the city clerk. 
(b)  On or before January 1st and July 31st of each year, the agency responsible for administrating the grants or loans identified in subsection (a) of this section shall file a status report about them to the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Commencing with budget preparation relating to the city's community development plan, expenditures for physical and economic development, restoration and related activities shall be prepared. The five (5) year planning period shall be consistent with appropriate federal and state reporting requirements and funding authorization. The plan shall include the reprogramming of surplus funds from prior years. The board of aldermen shall propose the appropriation for the first year of the plan. Subsequent years of the plan shall be used for planning purposes only, and therefore be non-binding. 
(d)  There shall be a special revolving fund, as designated by the controller, under the administrative direction of the development administrator. Unless otherwise specified in the grant agreement, all of the repayments of direct loans to private developers and individuals made by the city, or from public and private grant proceeds, shall be deposited into the revolving fund. This shall not apply to general assistance or the community development block program. The city shall only use the deposited repayments for approved economic development and community development projects as follows: 
Any proposal for the use of the revolving funds shall be submitted to the board of aldermen for its approval. The proposal shall be filed with a capital projects committee report. This report shall advise the board as to the compatibility of the proposed use of the proceeds of the special revolving fund with the city's six-year capital program and the multi-year community development improvement program. The capital projects committee shall adopt necessary and appropriate procedures to prepare its advisory report. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Ord. of 9-17-84; Code of 1985, § 2½-5; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-23. - Certain contracts reporting. 
Within thirty (30) days of the close of each fiscal year, each agency shall file a copy of all contracts that the mayor executed on its behalf with the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-6; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-24. - Tax assessment deferral, abatement and exemption reviews and reports required. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), the controller, city assessor and tax collector shall review the fiscal impact of the grand list before the board of aldermen approves any tax deferral, assessment deferral, payment in lieu of taxes agreement or assessment exemption. Such review shall be conducted in the following manner: 
(1)  The assessor shall compare the existing assessment with the proposed adjusted assessment, and report the impact on the grand list to the controller; 
(2)  The tax collector shall compare the existing tax with the proposed adjusted tax, and report the tax impact on the grand list to the controller; and 
(3)  The tax collector and city assessor shall report their findings to the proper committee of the board of aldermen before final aldermanic action is taken on any such tax or assessment proposal. 
This process shall also apply to the aldermanic tax abatement procedure for "hardship" cases. 
(b)  Since no aldermanic action is required for individual applications under the city's rehabilitation assessment deferral program established pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 12-65(c) as amended from time to time, this ordinance section's requirements are limited to the preparation of the reports referenced in paragraphs (a)(1), (a)(2) and (a)(3). These reports shall be used to prepare the semi-annual reports submitted to the board of aldermen on the first day of every March and October. 
(c)  When the city assessor annually certifies the grand list, he/she shall prepare a report for the controller's review. This report shall: 
(1)  Indicate the tax deferral(s), tax abatement(s) granted for the year for which the grand list is being certified, and the effect on the grand list; 
(2)  Indicate the cumulative effect of such deferrals, abatements and exemptions on the grand list; and 
(3)  Include a schedule, developed with the development administrator's assistance, that calculates the increase resulting to each grand list from tax deferral programs, and annual payments in lieu of taxes for the budget year applicable to the grand list for that budget year for grand list certification, and nine (9) succeeding grand list years. 
After the controller reviews this report, the assessor shall submit it to the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 4-18-83; Ord. of 4-23-84; Ord. of 3-18-85; Code of 1985, § 2½-7; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-25. - Traffic impact studies. 
Except as provided in this chapter, a traffic impact study shall be submitted to the board of aldermen before it approves any tax deferral, tax abatement, assessment deferral, payment in-lieu of taxes agreement, land disposition agreement, assessment exemption or direct or indirect financial assistance for any development project involving new construction of more than fifty thousand (50,000) gross square feet of floor area in one structure, or the addition of two hundred (200) or more parking spaces. The study shall show the amount and direction of traffic to be generated by the proposed development, and shall estimate its effect on the roadway capacity and safety. Upon submission, the board shall refer the study to the department of traffic and parking. This department shall provide an advisory report on the traffic impact study to the board of aldermen before any approvals are granted. The department shall issue its advisory report no more than sixty (60) days after receiving the traffic impact study. 
(Code of 1985, § 2½-9; Ord. of 12-4-89, § 1; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Secs. 2½-26—2½-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PROCEDURES FOR CONDUCTING CONTESTED CASES 
 
Sec. 2½-41. - Contested cases. 
(a)  In a contested case, all parties shall be afforded an opportunity for hearing after reasonable notice. 
(b)  The notice shall include: 
(1)  A statement of the time, place, and nature of the hearing; 
(2)  A statement of the legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held; 
(3)  A reference to the particular section(s) of the charter, ordinance(s), or regulation(s) involved; and 
(4)  A short and plain statement of the matters asserted. If the agency or other party is unable to state the matters in detail at the time the notice is served, the initial notice may be limited to a statement of the issues involved. Thereafter, upon application by any party, a more definite and detailed statement shall be furnished. 
(c)  All parties shall have the opportunity to present evidence and argument on issues involved. 
(d)  Unless precluded by law or regulation, any contested case may be informally disposed of by stipulation, agreed settlement, consent order, or default. 
(e)  The record in a contested case shall include: 
(1)  The notice given pursuant to subsection (b) above; 
(2)  All pleadings, motions and intermediate rulings; 
(3)  Evidence received or considered; 
(4)  Questions and offers of proof, objections and rulings thereon; and 
(5)  Any decisions, opinions, or report by the officer presiding at the hearing. 
(f)  Oral proceedings or any part thereof shall be transcribed only on a party's written request. The requesting party shall pay, accordingly, the cost of such transcript or part thereof. 
(g)  Findings of fact shall be based exclusively on the evidence and on matters officially noticed. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-12; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-42. - Contested cases; evidence. 
In contested cases: 
(1)  The agency may receive any oral or documentary evidence, but may exclude that which is irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious. When claimed by a party, agencies shall give effect to legally recognized rules of privilege. Subject to these requirements, when a hearing will be expedited and the interests of the parties will not be substantially prejudiced, an agency may receive any part of the evidence in written form; 
(2)  If original documentary evidence is not readily available, it may be received in the form of copies or excerpts. Upon request, parties shall be given an opportunity to compare the copy with the original; 
(3)  A party may conduct cross-examinations; and 
(4)  Notice may be taken of matters within the public's general knowledge, and of generally recognized technical or scientific fact within the agency's specialized knowledge. Parties shall be notified of the material so noticed either before or during the hearing, or by reference in preliminary reports or otherwise. Parties shall be afforded an opportunity to contest the material so noticed. The agency's experience, technical competence and specialized knowledge may be utilized in the evaluation of the evidence. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82; § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-13; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-43. - Proposal for decision; procedure, waiver. 
When in a contested case, a majority of the agency officials who are to render the final decision have not heard the case or read the record, a decision adversely affecting a party other than the agency itself shall not be made until the parties are served with a proposal for decision, and each adversely affected party is given an opportunity to file exceptions, and present briefs and oral argument to the officials rendering the decision. The proposal for decision shall contain each issue of fact or law or other reason(s) that supported it. The proposal for decision must be prepared by the person who conducted the hearing, or one who has read the record. The parties may waive compliance with this section by written stipulation. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82; § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-14; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-44. - Final determination, notification of right of appeal. 
(a)  Each agency shall proceed with reasonable dispatch to conclude any matter pending before it, and shall render a final decision in all contested cases within ninety (90) days following the close of evidence, and the filing of briefs in such proceedings. 
(b)  A final decision or order adverse to a party in a contested case shall be in writing or stated in the record. The final decision or order shall state whether there is a right of appeal. Parties shall be notified either personally or by mail of any decision or order. Upon request, a copy of the decision or order shall be delivered or mailed forthwith to each party or to his/her attorney of record. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-15; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-45. - Possible communications between agency members and employees and parties in contested cases. 
Unless required by law or regulation, after commencement and during the pendency of a contested case, members or employees of an agency assigned to render a decision, or to make findings of fact and conclusions of law in a contested case, shall not directly or indirectly communicate with any person or party in connection with any issue of fact or law, except upon notice and opportunity for all parties to participate. Any agency member may communicate with other members of the agency, and may have the aid and advice of one (1) or more personal assistants. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-16; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Sec. 2½-46. - Matters involving licenses. 
(a)  This article concerning contested cases and licenses shall apply when notice and an opportunity for hearing must precede the grant, denial or renewal of a license, and there is no other procedure for such action. 
(b)  In those instances where a hearing is required to be held under this article: 
(1)  When a licensee has made timely and sufficient application for a license renewal, or a new license with reference to any continuing activity, the existing license shall not expire until the agency has made a final determination regarding it. If the application is denied, or the new license has limited terms, the existing license shall be in effect until the last day for seeking review of the terms of the agency order, or a later date fixed by a reviewing court order. 
(2)  Before any license is lawfully revoked, suspended, annulled or withdrawn, the agency must give the licensee notice by mail of the facts or conduct warranting the intended action. Additionally, the licensee must have been given an opportunity to show compliance with all lawful requirements for the retention of the license. If the agency finds that public health, safety or welfare imperatively requires emergency action, and incorporates a finding to that effect in its order, the agency may summarily suspend the license pending proceedings for revocation or other action. The agency shall notify the licensee of such action by mailing its order to the address listed in the license. These proceedings shall be promptly instituted and determined. 
(Ord. of 11-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 2½-17; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Secs. 2½-47—2½-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ANNUAL REPORTING REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 2½-61. - Annual reports required by the board of aldermen. 
(a)  Pursuant to city charter section 58 as amended from time to time, the mayor shall submit an annual budget document to the board of aldermen. The document shall include a summary of the operations of every board, bureau, commission, department, office, authority, agency or fund for the previous fiscal year. Copies of the document shall be filed and made available for public inspection at the city clerk's office and the public library. 
(b)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 10-220(c) as amended from time to time, the board of education shall annually submit a strategic school profile report for each school under its jurisdiction, and for the school district as a whole, to the state's Commissioner of Education. 
(c)  On January 15th or the next business day thereafter, the mayor shall annually submit a grantee performance report on the city's community development block grant program to the board of aldermen. 
(d)  Any person who willfully violates this section shall be fined up to the maximum authorized by state statutes or this Code per day that the violation continues. 
(Code of 1985, § 2½-18; Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 9-23-98; Ord. No. 1390, 9-19-05)  
Chapter 3 - DUST CONTROL AND SANDBLASTING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1399, adopted Jan. 3, 2006, amended and restated former Ch. 3 of the 1962 Code, reprinted in 1985, in its entirety. The legislative history notes in parentheses following the sections of this chapter include the section number formerly used in the 1985 reprinting, as amended. 
Cross reference— Health, Ch. 16 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and referred to as the "Dust Control and Sandblasting Ordinances." 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-2. - General definitions. 
When used in reference to this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings. 
(1)  Aerosol means a dispersion or any suspension of small solid or liquid particles, or any combination thereof, in the air or other gaseous medium. 
(2)  Air pollutant means dust, fumes, mist, smoke or other particulate matter, vapor, gas, aerosol, odorous substances or any combination thereof, but does not include carbon dioxide, uncombined water vapor or water droplets, or molecular oxygen or nitrogen. 
(3)  Air pollution means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one (1) or more air pollutants, or any combination thereof, in such quantities and of such characteristics and duration as to be, or likely to be, injurious to public welfare, to the health of human, plant or animal life, to property, or to unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life and property. 
(4)  Air pollution control equipment means any device that controls emissions from a process or fuel-burning or refuse-burning equipment, and thus reduces the creation of, and/or the emission of, air pollutants into the atmosphere. 
(5)  Air pollution source means any source at, from or by reason of which any air pollutant is directly or indirectly emitted into the ambient air space. 
(6)  Alteration means any modification or change in the design, capacity, process or arrangement, or any increase in the connected load of equipment or control apparatus which will affect the kind or amount of air pollutants emitted. 
(7)  Ashes include cinders, fly ash, or any other solid material resulting from combustion, and may include unburned combustibles. 
(8)  Control apparatus means any device which prevents, controls, detects or records the emission of air pollutants. 
(9)  Director of public health means the director of public health of the City of New Haven, or any duly or lawfully appointed member of the bureau of environmental health, as authorized by the board of health. 
(10)  Dusts means minute solid particles released into the air by natural forces, or by mechanical processes such as crushing, grinding, milling, drilling, demolishing, shoveling, conveying, covering, bagging, sweeping, etc. 
(11)  Dust-separating equipment means any device for separating dust from the air to a gas medium in which it is carried. 
(12)  Equipment means any device capable of causing the emission of an air pollutant into the open air, and any stack, conduit, flue, duct, vent or similar device connected or attached to, or serving the equipment. 
(13)  Excess air means air entering a combustion chamber in excess of the amount theoretically required to complete combustion of materials in the combustion chamber. 
(14)  Fly ash means particulate matter capable of being gas-borne or air-borne, and consisting essentially of fused ash and/or burned or unburned material. 
(15)  Fuel means any form of combustible matter—solid, liquid, vapor or gas excluding combustible refuse. 
(16)  Heat-transfer operation means contact between the combustion product gases and the process material. 
(17)  Installation means the placement, assemblage or construction of equipment or control apparatus at the premises where the equipment or control apparatus will be used, and includes all preparatory work at such premises. 
(18)  Load regulation period means a period of rapid fuel increase or decrease to a boiler or steam generator necessary to satisfy a change in output requirements, which change could not reasonably have been satisfied by a normal increase or decrease of the fuel supply. 
(19)  Mist means a suspension of any finely divided liquid in any gas or atmosphere. 
(20)  Noxious gases means gases which are, or may be, injurious, harmful, hurtful or unwholesome. 
(21)  Nuisance means the discharge into the open air of any smoke, soot, dust, fumes, odors, noxious gases or other emissions which cause injury, detriment or annoyance, or which endanger the comfort, repose, health or safety of any person or of the public, or which cause or are likely to cause injury or damage to business or property. 
(22)  Owner(s) means the owner(s) of the freehold of the premises or lesser estate thereof, a lessee or joint lessees of the whole thereof, an agent, or any other person in possession or in control of the premises. 
(23)  Particulate matter means any material, except water in uncombined form, that is or has been airborne, and exists as a liquid or a solid at standard conditions. 
(24)  Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, association, trust, estate, public or private institution, group, agency, political subdivision or agency thereof, or any legal successor, representative, agent, or any agency of the foregoing. 
(25)  Pollen means the fertilizing element of vegetation. 
(26)  Rubbish means all solid wastes other than garbage such as paper, rags, metal and cardboard containers, street sweepings and other solid commercial and domestic wastes. 
(27)  Soot means the dark substance, essentially carbon, resulting from the burning or heating of fuel or refuse. 
(28)  Standard commercial equipment means equipment manufactured in quantity for the purpose intended and completely specified as to size, type and rating in catalogs and other printed literature readily available locally to officials of the City of New Haven. 
(29)  Vapors mean the gaseous form of a substance normally in the liquid or solid state. 
(30)  Volatile or volatile matter means the gaseous constituents of solid fuels as determined by the procedure defined in the ASTM method amended or revised to the current date. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-9; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Secs. 3-3—3-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 3-21. - Establishment of dust control and sandblasting in the department of health. 
The director of public health shall have the power to designate the director of the bureau of environmental health and his/her staff to perform the duties required to carry out the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-12; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-22. - Director of public health to enforce dust control and sandblasting standards. 
(a)  The director of public health shall seek compliance with this chapter through the cooperation and conciliation among all concerned parties. If compliance is not obtained through such means, the director of public health shall: 
(1)  Issue an order of compliance with this chapter's provisions by identifying the provision that is being violated, as well as a description of the violation, and indicate the time allowed for such compliance; and/or 
(2)  Institute judicial process to impose penalties for noncompliance, or institute judicial recourse to enjoin further violation. 
(b)  No penal action shall be instituted against the City of New Haven, or any of its agencies, departments, bureaus, officers or employees for acts, omissions or violations done in their official capacities or performance of their official duties. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-13; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-23. - Additional functions and powers of the director of public health. 
The director of public health shall exercise the following powers and functions: 
(1)  Enter any property, premises or place at any reasonable time to enforce this chapter, thereby safeguarding the health, safety and welfare of the general public. 
If the owner deems the process or equipment under investigation to be secret, he/she may file an affidavit with the director of public health indicating that the process or equipment will comply with this chapter. Plans and specifications filed with the affidavit will remain the property of the owner, and shall be strictly for the confidential use of the director of public health, unless the owner or operator expressly agrees to their publication or availability to the general public. Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent any city department, agency or officer from using such records or information in compiling or publishing analyses or summaries relating to the atmosphere's general condition, provided that such records or information do not directly or indirectly identify any owner or operator, or reveal any confidential information under this section. 
(2)  Recommend that the board of aldermen adopt ordinances, rules or regulations to facilitate the equitable administration of this chapter. 
(3)  Advise the city's chief of the department of fire services of any relevant conditions existing in the city justifying the prohibition of open burning. 
(4)  Perform all other actions that he/she deems necessary or proper for the effective enforcement of this chapter. 
(5)  Advise, consult and cooperate with other agencies of the city, political subdivisions of the state, industries, state agencies, the federal government, and affected groups and persons to advance the purposes of this chapter. 
(6)  Encourage and conduct studies and research relating to dust control, sandblasting and conservation of air resources. 
(7)  Encourage voluntary cooperation by people, industries, city agencies and others in preventing and controlling dust in the city and metropolitan community. 
(8)  Accept, receive and administer funds, grants or gifts from public or private agencies, and the federal government to carry out the functions described in this chapter. Funds received by the director of public health shall be deposited with the city's fiscal officer, and held in a special account established for the department of health's dust control and sandblasting activities. 
(9)  The director of public health is specifically empowered to invoke all of his/her powers under the law if he/she finds that any person is causing or contributing to air pollution, thereby creating an emergency requiring immediate action to protect the public health or safety. 
(10)  Represent the city in any and all matters relating to dust control and sandblasting. 
(11)  Employ personnel, purchase equipment, supplies and materials, and enter into contracts to carry out purposes of this chapter in conformance with city practices in connection with the department of health. 
(12)  Carry out all other activities as may be necessary to enforce this chapter, and rules and regulations promulgated by the board of health and state regulations. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-14; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-24—3-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COMPLAINT OF VIOLATION 
 
Sec. 3-41. - Initial procedure on complaint of violation. 
Whenever the director of public health receives a complaint, or has cause to believe that any person is violating this chapter by causing or permitting air pollution or air contamination, he/she shall order an investigation into the matter. If he/she finds that there is a violation, he/she shall endeavor to eliminate it by conference, conciliation and persuasion. Such methods shall not extend beyond a ninety (90) day period from the date of the initial investigation. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-16; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-42. - Recommendation to department of environmental protection. 
In case conference, conciliation and persuasion fail to result in the correction of any cause of air pollution, the director of environmental health may report such violation to the State Department of Environmental Protection, and request it to take immediate action. 
(Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-43. - Issuance of an order. 
In case conference, conciliation and persuasion fail to result in the correction of any cause of air pollution, the director of environmental health shall issue a written order upon the violator. The order shall specify the article provision(s) violated, and include a statement describing the manner and extent to which the violation occurred. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-17; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-44—3-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RESPONSIBILITY FOR COMPLIANCE 
 
Sec. 3-61. - Manner of compliance. 
(a)  Standards. The director of public health has discretion to approve the means, methods, processes, equipment and operations used by one engaging in conduct covered by this chapter. 
(b)  Circumvention. Nothing in this Code authorizes any practice(s) intended or designed to evade or circumvent this regulation's basic requirements. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-18; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Secs. 3-62—3-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OPERATIONS EXEMPT FROM THE APPLICATION OF THIS CHAPTER 
 
Sec. 3-81. - Operations specifically exempt. 
The following operations are exempt from the application of this chapter: 
(1)  See Fire Code chapter section "Precautions against Fire, General"; 
(2)  Fires used only for recreational purposes, or occasional cooking of food for human consumption accomplished in a fireplace or barbecue; 
(3)  Exceptions in the form of experimental operations that arise from investigation, experiment or research to advance the state of knowledge or technique. In order for the exemption to apply, the director of public health and the chief of fire services must have approved such operations, and set a time limitation for them. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-20; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Secs. 3-82—3-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - TIME PERMITTED FOR ORIGINAL COMPLIANCE 
 
Sec. 3-101. - Time permitted for original compliance. 
The director of public health may grant an extension of time to those that will not achieve code compliance by the effective date. The extension shall encompass time for engineering, procurement, fabrication, installation and adjustment. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-21; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-102. - Application for time to comply. 
Persons responsible for emissions that will not be in compliance with this chapter on its effective date shall submit a written request to the director of public health for additional time, and estimate the additional time needed for such compliance. This estimate may be amended within ninety (90) days of the original request where the person submits written material facts indicating that additional time is required for compliance. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-22; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-103. - Failure to meet time for compliance requirements. 
If a person who was given additional time for compliance as stated in the above sections fails either to (1) comply with this chapter by the deadline, or (2) make progress toward compliance to the director of health's satisfaction, said director may require that person to make additional reports concerning the progress of such installations whenever the director deems necessary. If said director finds noncompliance with (1) and (2) of this section, he/she shall institute this chapter's directives. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-23; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-104—3-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - CONDITIONS NOT IN VIOLATION OF THIS CHAPTER 
 
Sec. 3-121. - Upset condition, breakdown or scheduled maintenance. 
Excessive emissions resulting from upset conditions in, or breakdown of, any operating equipment or related air condition equipment, or the shutdown of such equipment for scheduled maintenance, shall not be deemed as a code violation provided all the following requirements are met: 
(1)  Such occurrences shall have been reported to the office of the director of public health as soon as possible; for scheduled maintenance, such report shall be submitted at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to shutdown, and for upset conditions or breakdown, such report shall be made within four (4) hours of the occurrence. 
(2)  The person responsible for the excessive emission shall initiate and complete appropriate action to correct the conditions causing it, and reduce the frequency of such occurrence. Upon request by the director of public health, the person must submit a full written report of such occurrences, including a statement of all known causes, and the nature of the actions to be taken pursuant to this subsection's requirements. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-24; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-122. - Regulation of dissemination of dust. 
(a)  No person shall cause or permit materials to be handled, transported, or stored; or a building, its appurtenances, or a road to be used, constructed, altered, repaired or demolished without taking reasonable precautions to prevent particulate matter from becoming airborne. Such reasonable precautions shall be in accordance with good industrial practice, and the state's environmental protection laws, and shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Use, where possible, of water or chemicals for dust control in the demolition of existing buildings or structures, construction operations, the grading of roads, or the clearing of land; 
(2)  Application of asphalt, oil, water, suitable chemicals or coverage on materials, stockpiles and other surfaces which can give rise to airborne dusts; 
(3)  Installation and use of hoods, fans, and fabric filters to enclose and vent the handling of dusty materials. Adequate containment methods shall be employed during sandblasting or other similar operations; 
(4)  Covering, at all times when in motion, open bodied trucks and trains transporting materials likely to give rise to airborne dusts; and 
(5)  The prompt removal of earth or other material from paved streets onto which earth or other material has been deposited by trucking or earth- moving equipment, erosion of water or other means. 
(b)  Agricultural activities are exempt from the provisions of subsection (a). However, agricultural practices such as tilling of land and application of fertilizers shall be conducted in a manner as to minimize dust from becoming airborne. 
(c)  No person shall cause or permit the discharge of visible emissions beyond the lot line of the property on which the emissions originate when: 
(1)  The emissions remain visible and exist near ground level outside the property boundaries; or 
(2)  The emissions remain visible and impinge on a building or structure so that the public health, safety or enjoyment of life may be diminished. 
(d)  No particulate matter shall be emitted into the open air in such a manner as to cause a nuisance. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-33; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-123—3-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PENALTY, VALIDITY AND INTENT OF CHAPTER 
 
Sec. 3-141. - Penalty. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be deemed an offense. Each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of this chapter is committed shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision shall be punished by a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code per day in which the violation occurs. 
(c)  In the event that a firm or corporation violates a provision of this chapter, the officer(s) or person(s) responsible for the violation shall be subject to the penalty herein provided. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-40; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-142. - Validity of the chapter. 
If a judicial determination declares that any provision of this chapter is void or unconstitutional, all other parts of the Code not subject to this determination shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-41; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-143. - Chapter not intended as violation of any other statute or ordinance, or to impair civil remedies. 
(a)  Nothing in this chapter is intended to permit any practice which is otherwise a violation of any statute, ordinance, order or regulation. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter is intended to impair or abrogate any civil remedy or process which might otherwise be available to any person. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-42; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-144. - Effect of conflict between this chapter and other ordinance. 
When any provision of this chapter conflicts with any zoning, building, fire, safety, health or other ordinance or code of this city or state law, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of public health and safety shall prevail. 
(Ord. of 12-2-68; Code of 1985, § 3-43; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-145. - Sandblasting, definitions. 
The following words shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  Interested person means any owner of real property adjacent to the building for which sandblasting is proposed. 
(b)  Occupied building means one in which at least one (1) person, firm or corporation resides or maintains a commercial establishment. 
(c)  Sandblasting means the use of sand or any finely divided aggregate particles propelled in a high velocity of air for the purpose of cleaning the facade of a building. 
(d)  Vacant building means one in which no person, firm or corporation resides or maintains a commercial establishment. 
(Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 3-146. - Sandblasting, prohibited; permit required. 
(a)  Sandblasting shall not be performed on any occupied building in the city. Sandblasting shall not be performed on any vacant building in the city unless the owner obtains a permit from the city's director of public health. The owner must file an application listing the names of all interested persons, and a fee in the amount set out in the Licenses and Permits chapter of this Code. 
(b)  Once the application is filed, the director of public health shall notify all interested persons. No action shall be taken on the application for five (5) business days from the mailing date of the notice. The director of public health shall grant the application upon the written approval of the chief of the department of police services, the director of the office of traffic and parking, and the city's building inspector or their designees. However, no permit shall be granted unless the owner complies with the following conditions: 
(1)  Sandblasting shall only be performed between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., and shall not be performed on legal holidays; and 
(2)  Sandblasting shall be performed under conditions designed to protect the health, safety and property of interested persons. These conditions shall include, but not be limited to, encapsulation of the building for which sandblasting is proposed, wetting down of the building to stop the spread of dust, and any other proper methods required by the director of public health. 
(c)  Any person who performs sandblasting without obtaining the permit described in this section shall be subject to the penalties stated in this chapter. 
(d)  The department of police services is specifically authorized and directed to take all necessary or appropriate lawful actions to terminate any sandblasting in violation of this section. 
(Ord. of 6-17-85; Code of 1985, § 3-46; Ord. No. 1399, 1-3-06)  
Chapter 4 - AIRPORT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ch. 4 was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
Cross reference— Construction of airplane hangers, Building Code Pars. 608.4—608.41. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 4-1, 4-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1388, adopted Sept. 6, 2005, repealed former sections 4-1, 4-2, in their entirety which pertained to the airport zoning board and derived from Ord. of Jan. 15, 1954.  
Sec. 4-3. - Airport surfaces—Purposes; established. 
(a)  Purposes; map adopted. For the purpose of regulating the height of structures and trees for the protection of life and property in relation to the use of the Tweed New Haven Regional Airport, the airport surfaces identified in Title 14 U.S Code of Federal Regulations Part 77 (14CFR77), Objects Affecting Navigable Airspace, as shown on maps prepared for the Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority identified as FAR Part 77 Surfaces, are hereby adopted and established as the approach areas of the New Haven Municipal Airport, and said map with all additions and amendments is hereby adopted as a part of this Code of Ordinances in every respect as fully as though set out herein. 
(b)  Included on zoning map. A copy of said airport surfaces map (s) shall become a part of the zoning map of the city and shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 2-2-48, § 1; Ord. No. 1388, 9-6-05)  
Sec. 4-4. - Same—Height limitations. 
Within the airport surfaces described in section 4-3 hereof and shown on the airport surfaces map(s), no structure or tree shall be erected, altered or maintained, and no tree shall be allowed to grow above the applicable height limit herein established, pursuant to 14CFR77, for said airport surfaces, except that the board of zoning appeals shall have the power to grant a variance of this regulation where a literal application or enforcement of the same would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this section. 
(Ord. of 2-2-48, § 2; Ord. No. 1388, 9-6-05)  
Sec. 4-5. - Effect on other height regulations. 
The height regulations existing at the time of the adoption of the provision of sections 4-3 through 4-5 shall not limit the effectiveness or scope of the airport approach surfaces height regulations adopted under section 4-4 hereof. 
(Ord. of 2-2-48, § 3; Ord. No. 1388, 9-6-05)  
Secs. 4-6—4-9. - Reserved.

ARTICLE II. - FIELD RULES 
 
Sec. 4-10. - Federal license required. 
Only aircraft and airmen licensed by the administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency shall operate on or over the airport, provided however, that this restriction shall not apply to public aircraft of the federal government, or of a state, territory, or possession of a political subdivision thereof, or the aircraft licensed by a foreign country with which the United States has a reciprocal agreement covering the operation of such licensed aircraft. 
(Ord. of 9-3-30)  
Sec. 4-11. - Applicability of federal, state regulations. 
(a)  No person shall navigate any aircraft overland upon, or fly the same from, or service, maintain, or repair any aircraft on the airport, or conduct any aircraft operations on or from the airport otherwise than in conformity with the requirements of the Civil Air Regulations established by the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency under the authority of the Federal Aviation Act of 1958 and the regulations of the Department of Aeronautics of the State of Connecticut. 
(b)  The air traffic rules as established by the administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency under the authority of the Federal Aviation Act of 1958 and the regulations of the Department of Aeronautics of the State of Connecticut, are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of these rules. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-12. - Authority of airport commissioners. 
(a)  Personnel. The board of airport commissioners shall have full authority over the airport manager and all other city employed airport personnel. 
(b)  Fees, licenses. The board of airport commissioners shall promulgate such fees and licenses as it deems appropriate for use of the airport, airport facilities and concessions. The right is reserved to the board of airport commissioners to change, modify, rescind or supplement the matter of fees and licenses as the need may arise; provided, that no fee or license shall be effective until it shall have been first approved by the board of aldermen, and published at length in one or more of the daily newspapers published in New Haven, and also printed and posted in conspicuous places within the limits of the airport. 
(c)  Rules, regulations. The board of airport commissioners shall have full authority to establish rules and regulations to control all aircraft parking, ground movements and flight operations at the airport. All such rules and regulations shall be displayed on the bulletin board in lobby of administration building and all other flight operation offices. The right is reserved to the board of airport commissioners to revoke, rescind, abrogate, cancel, suspend, amend, change, modify or supplement rules and regulations for aircraft parking, ground movement and flight operations at the airport as the need may arise. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30; Ord. of 12-1-80, § 1)  
Sec. 4-13. - Authority of airport manager. 
(a)  Control public. The airport manager shall at all times have authority to take such action as may be necessary in the handling, conduct and management of the public in attendance at the airport. 
(b)  Remove damaged aircraft. In order to restore flight operations, the airport manager, with prior approval of the Federal Aviation Agency and state department of aeronautics, may immediately remove wrecked or damaged aircraft from the flight or ramp areas of the airport at the expense of the owner, and without liability for damage which may result in the course of such removal. 
(c)  Suspend operations. Except in the case of scheduled operators, the airport manager or his authorized representative shall have the authority to suspend flight operations on or from the airport when, in his opinion, the condition of the flight area and/or local meteorological conditions might make such operations unsafe. 
(d)  Enforce regulations. The airport manager or his authorized representative shall have full authority to enforce all ordinances and rules and regulations established by the board of airport commissioners. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-14. - Permit required for commercial use. 
No person shall use the airport as a base or terminal for the carrying on of commercial aviation, or the carrying of passengers, freight, express, or mail, or for student flying, or operation of club or group owned aircraft, communications, or other commercial or private purpose or transportation without first securing a permit from the airport manager and paying the fees and charges, if any, prescribed for such privileges, the use of the airport, its facilities, and for services rendered as established by the board of airport commissioners. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-15. - Permit to sell goods, services at airport. 
No person shall engage in the sale of refreshments or of any other commodity or service within the confines of the airport without previously having secured a permit from the board of airport commissioners and having paid or made satisfactory arrangements to pay such fees or other sums of money as the said board of airport commissioners may determine for such privilege. Any such sale or service shall be subject to any and all rules and regulations the board of airport commissioners may establish. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30, rule 5)  
Sec. 4-16. - Permission required to solicit, advertise at airport. 
(a)  No person or group shall solicit funds for any purpose at the airport without obtaining prior permission from the board of airport commissioners. 
(b)  No person or group shall install, post, distribute or display signs, advertisements, circulars, printed or written matter at the airport without obtaining prior permission from the board of airport commissioners.  
Sec. 4-17. - Permission for test flights. 
Persons must obtain prior permission of the board of airport commissioners before engaging in test flight operations from the airport with experimental aircraft. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-18. - Tampering with aircraft. 
No person shall interfere or tamper with any aircraft at the airport or enter or start the engine of such aircraft without prior consent of the owner. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-19. - Animals in buildings. 
Dogs or other animals entering any airport building must be on a leash or confined in such manner as to be under control. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-20. - Operation while intoxicated or possessing intoxicants. 
No person shall take any aircraft from the flight area or hangars or operate same while under the influence of or using or having personal possession of intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-21. - Duties of instructors. 
All persons instructing student pilots in flying at the airport shall fully acquaint such students with the rules and regulations in effect at the airport and shall be responsible for the conduct of said students while under their instruction. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-22. - Duty of pilots to register, report accidents. 
(a)  Registration. Pilots of itinerant aircraft landing or departing from the airport shall immediately register such arrivals and departures in the airport log which will be found on the operations desk in the lobby of the administration building. 
(b)  Accident reports. The pilot of the aircraft involved in any accident causing personal injury or property damage at the airport shall make a prompt and full written report of said accident and submit same to the airport manager. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-23. - Motorized vehicle and equipment. 
(a)  Parking areas. No automobiles or other motorized vehicles shall be parked on the airport except in areas designated for that purpose by the airport manager. 
(b)  Parking time limit. No automobile or other motorized vehicle shall be left parked on public roads and parking areas of the airport for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours unless prior permission has been obtained from the airport manager or his representative. 
(c)  Promulgation of parking, speed regulations. The board of airport commissioners has full authority to establish rules and regulations for use of the public parking areas and to set speed limits for public and service roads at the airport. 
(d)  Operation in certain areas. No automobiles or other motorized vehicles shall be allowed on flight areas service roads, flight area or ramps, with the exception of vehicles regularly employed servicing of aircraft and maintenance of the airport. 
(e)  Operation in, around hangars. No automobiles, motor trucks, or tractors shall enter hangars except in connection with operations on the airport, and then only with permission of manager, and hangar entrances shall be kept clear at all times. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-24. - Gliders prohibited. 
Airplane tow and other glider flight operations are not permitted at the airport.  
Sec. 4-25. - Repair areas. 
All repairs to aircraft and engines shall only be made in the spaces designated by the airport manager for that purpose. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-26. - Parking of aircraft. 
(a)  Location; compliance with regulations. Unhoused aircraft shall be parked in areas designated for such purposes and shall be left in a manner which fully complies with existing airport aircraft parking regulations as established by the board of airport commissioners. 
(b)  Designation of ramp plane lines. The ramp plane lines shall be designated by the airport manager. 
(c)  Designation of dead line. A dead line shall also be designated by the airport manager, and no person, excepting the pilot or mechanic attached to the airport or employed by the owner of a plane or an operator on said airport or an owner of such a plane, or such an operator, or duly authorized officers or officials charged with the duty of enforcing local, state, or federal laws or regulations shall cross the dead line or enter upon the flying field unless he is to participate in a flight. If such person is to participate in a flight he shall not cross the dead line until the plane in which he is to fly has come to a full stop and the pilot thereof has signalled that he is ready. Such person shall, upon alighting from the plane, leave the landing area by the shortest possible route. 
(d)  Dead line marking. The dead line will be indicated by suitable markers and may be changed from time to time as conditions require. 
(e)  Parking near administration building. Unless prior permission is obtained from the airport manager or his authorized representative, no aircraft shall be left parked on the ramp area in the vicinity of the gate positions of the administration building for a period longer than necessary to load or discharge passengers, baggage or cargo. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-27. - Regulations governing running engines. 
(a)  Wheel blocks. Blocks, equipped with ropes or other suitable means of pulling them, shall always be placed in front of the wheels before starting the engine, or engines, unless the airplane is provided with thoroughly adequate brakes. 
(b)  Operation in control. No aircraft engine shall be started or run unless a licensed pilot or competent mechanic is in the cockpit attending the controls. 
(c)  Running in hangars. No aircraft engine shall be run in hangars. 
(d)  Fueling. No aircraft on the airport shall be fueled while the engine is running. 
(e)  Location. Aircraft shall be started and warmed up only in the places designated for such purposes by the airport authorities. At no time shall engines be tuned up in such position that hangars, shops, or other buildings, or any group of people in the observation area, shall be in the path of the propeller stream. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-28. - Standing on runways. 
No aircraft shall remain standing directly on the end of any runway for pre-flight procedures or other reasons.  
Sec. 4-29. - Taxiing. 
(a)  No taxiing is permitted on runways except straight ahead to the next taxi-strip exit from the active runway used for landing. Taxi-strips shall be used only for taxiing of aircraft. 
(b)  Aircraft using taxi-strips shall come to full stop at yellow cross line markers before crossing any runway. 
(c)  No aircraft shall block other aircraft from use of taxi-strip entrance to active runway for an excessive period of time. 
(d)  All aircraft taxiing shall be done in a careful manner and at slow speed. On taxiing from flight area all taxiing shall stop at ramp plane line. 
(e)  No taxiing is permitted in or out of hangars. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-30. - Takeoffs, landings. 
(a)  All aircraft landings and take-offs shall be made on or from an airport runway. All take-offs shall be started directly from the end of runway in use at time of departure. No aircraft landings or take-offs until active runway is clear of other aircraft. No 180 degree turns on active runway by a landing aircraft. Landing aircraft shall immediately clear active runway via next taxi-strip exit ahead. 
(b)  A landing aircraft has the right-of-way over aircraft moving on the flight area or taking off, but this shall not excuse the pilots of either or both aircraft from the exercise of due care and diligence. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-31. - Flights conflicting with routine operations. 
Prior permission must be obtained from the airport manager or his authorized representative before engaging in any aircraft flight operation which will in any way conflict with aircraft traffic on the runway in active use by other aircraft for routine flight operations.  
Sec. 4-32. - Direction of air traffic. 
The direction of air traffic around the airport shall be counter-clockwise and shall conform to requirements of the established flight pattern for the airport. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-33. - Circling required. 
All aircraft shall circle field 360 degrees before landing. During the hours of daylight aircraft in Unicom or airline company radio contact with ground stations at the airport shall circle the field at least 180 degrees before landing. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-34. - Night lighting. 
Flight area night lighting facilities are only available on advance request or to an aircraft which enters the airport traffic pattern and circles the field 360 degrees or more.  
Sec. 4-35. - Duty of users to guard against fire, injury. 
All persons using in any way the airport area or the facilities of the airport shall exercise the utmost care to guard against fire and injury to persons or property. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-36. - Smoking. 
No person shall smoke in any hangar or building unless smoking is specifically authorized by airport manager. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-37. - Fire appliances required. 
All buildings on the airport shall be provided with first-aid fire appliances as required by the National Board of Fire Underwriters. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-38. - Heating, fuel-burning appliances. 
All heating equipment and fuel-burning appliances installed on the airport shall be in accordance with the requirements of the National Board of Fire Underwriters. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-39. - Repairs on storage floors. 
Repairs on storage floor of hangars shall be limited to inspection and replacement of parts and repairs incident thereto, provided such repairs do not involve appliances using open flames or highly heated parts other than electric soldering irons. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-40. - Maintenance of floors. 
Floors shall be kept clean and free from oil. The use of volatile flammable solvents for cleaning floors is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-41. - Use, handling of flammable liquids. 
(a)  Fueling, draining. No airplane shall be fueled or drained while in a hangar or other enclosed place. 
(b)  Heating of oil. The heating of oil shall be restricted to steam, hot water, hot air, or approved electric heaters. 
(c)  Cleaning parts. The cleaning of motor parts or other parts of the airplane shall preferably be with noninflammable liquids. If volatile flammable liquids are employed for this purpose, cleaning operations shall be carried on in the open air or in a separate room located in the repair shop section and separated therefrom by fire-resistive partitions and complying with the requirements of the National Board of Fire Underwriters. 
(d)  Doping. No doping shall be carried on in any hangar. Where a separate building is not feasible, the process may be carried on in a room located in the repair shop section of the hangar. Such building or room shall be constructed in accordance with the requirements of the National Board of Fire Underwriters and shall be protected with either a system of automatic sprinklers or a system employing a fire-retardant chemical or gas, which system shall meet the requirements of said board. 
(e)  Storage of flammable liquids. Gasoline, kerosene, ethyl, ether, or other flammable liquids, including those used in connection with the process of "doping" shall not be stored in hangars. The storage of such liquids shall be in compliance with the regulations of the National Board of Fire Underwriters for the construction and installation of containers for flammable liquids. Lubricating oils may be kept within hangars when stored in containers and provided with draw-off devices, both approved for this purpose by said board. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-42. - Flammable gases. 
No cylinders or flasks of compressed flammable gases shall be stored in hangars, without consent of airport manager. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-43. - Clothes lockers. 
All clothes lockers shall be constructed of metal or other suitable fire-resistive materials. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-44. - Rubbish, trash disposal. 
(a)  Receptacles. Suitable metal receptacles with self closing covers shall be provided for the storage of oily waste, rags, and other rubbish. The contents of these receptacles shall be removed daily. 
(b)  Empty oil, paint containers. All empty oil, paint, and varnish cans, bottles, or other containers shall be immediately removed from the premises and not allowed to remain on the floor or wall stringers. 
(c)  Litter. No boxes, crates, rubbish, paper, or litter of any kind shall be stored in or about hangars. 
(Ord. of 9-8-30)  
Sec. 4-45. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate the provisions of this article shall forfeit the privilege of using the municipal airport until reinstatement by the board of airport commissioners, and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 9-8-30; Ord. of 12-1-30)  
Secs. 4-46—4-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - POLICY FOR TAXICAB OPERATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Provisions of an ordinance enacted May 3, 1982, approved by the mayor May 4, 1982, and effective May 14, 1982, relative to operation of taxicabs at the airport, being nonamendatory of the Code, have been codified as Art. III, §§ 4-51, 4-52 at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 4-51. - Passenger dispatch; fare list; violation and penalty. 
(a)  It is a policy of the airport that no cab company or driver shall directly solicit business within the airport terminal building, on the aircraft ramp area, or in the passenger loading gate area. 
(b)  All taxis must line up in a queuing area designated by the airport manager and passengers needing a cab will be directed to the first cab in the line. Cab drivers must remain close to or in their vehicles while awaiting a customer. In addition, each cab company doing business at the airport must submit a list of representative fares to the airport manager on request; i.e., a trip to Park Plaza, City Hall, Long Wharf, etc. 
(c)  Violation of said policies will subject a cab company and/or driver to fine and/or prohibition of doing business on the airport for a period of time not to exceed sixty (60) days as determined by the board of airport commissioners. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82)  
Sec. 4-52. - Driver identification required; penalty for violation. 
(a)  All cab drivers shall wear some type of identifying apparel while in the terminal building; i.e., a uniform jacket or shirt, i.d. badge or patch, cap, or other item clearly identifying the individual's name and taxi company. 
(b)  Violators will be served a notice by the airport manager to appear before the board of airport commissioners for a hearing to determine circumstances and appropriate penalties consistent with this article. 
(c)  The maximum fines shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first offense and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82)  
Secs. 4-53—4-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - NOISE AND SAFETY STANDARDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Feb. 4, 1985, amended the Code by adding provisions which pertain to airport noise and safety standards, and which are designated as Art. IV, §§ 4-61—4-74, as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 4-61. - Statement of purpose. 
The goal for aircraft noise abatement shall be to reduce the area within the residential community which is exposed to aircraft noise in excess of Ldn 65, by implementing noise abatement actions that: 
(1)  Do not shift the burden of noise from one part of the surrounding community to another; and 
(2)  Do not inappropriately curtail operation of the airport. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-62. - Definitions. 
[As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
Advisory circular means the following publication by the U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration: Advisory Circular, AC No. 36-3C, Appendix 1, dated September 28, 1983, and future amendments to or replacements of such advisory circular. For aircraft based at Tweed-New Haven Airport, the applicable advisory circular shall be the advisory circular in effect as of the date such aircraft was based at the airport. 
Airport means Tweed-New Haven Airport. 
Day-night sound level (Ldn) means the twenty-four-hour equivalent sound level in decibels (dB) from midnight to midnight, obtained after the addition of ten (10) dB to sound levels from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 
Equivalent sound level means the level of a constant sound which, in a given situation and time period, has the same sound energy as does a time-varying sound. Technically, equivalent sound level is the level of the time-weighted, mean square, A-weighted sound pressure. The time interval over which the measurement is taken should always be specified. 
Maximum A-weighted sound level means the highest sound level of an event, as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated dB(A) or DBA. 
Engine run-up means any aircraft engine operation above an rpm setting required for forward movement of the aircraft at five (5) m.p.h., or any aircraft engine operation above idle RPM for more than one (1) minute duration. 
Auxiliary power unit (A.P.U.) means a generating device installed in an aircraft which provides electrical power for that aircraft while on the ground. 
Ground power unit (G.P.U.) means a mobile generating device to provide electrical power for an aircraft while on the ground. 
Flight means a takeoff and a landing, in either order. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-63. - Prohibited noise levels of aircraft taking off or landing. 
No person shall take off or land an aircraft at the airport if the "takeoff" noise level for that model of aircraft exceeds the following noise levels, as set forth in the advisory circular in the column entitled "EST DBA," for the following time periods: 
Time Period 	Maximum A-Weighted Sound Level 
12:00 a.m.—6:00 a.m. 	68.0 dB(A) 
6:00 a.m.—7:00 a.m. 	73.0 dB(A) 
7:00 a.m.—10:00 p.m. 	78.0 dB(A) 
10:00 p.m.—12:00 a.m. 	73.0 dB(A) 
 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-64. - Categorically exempt aircraft. 
The following categories of aircraft shall be exempt from the provisions of section 4-63: 
(1)  Aircraft operated by the United States of America or the State of Connecticut, including law enforcement, emergency, fire or rescue aircraft operated by any county or city of said state. 
(2)  Aircraft used for emergency purposes during an emergency which has been officially proclaimed by competent authority pursuant to the laws of the United States, said state or the city. 
(3)  Civil Air Patrol aircraft when engaged in actual search and rescue missions. 
(4)  Aircraft engaged in landings or takeoffs while conducting tests under the direction of the airport manager in an attempt to rebut the presumption of aircraft noise violation pursuant to the provisions of section 4-67. 
(5)  Aircraft involved in a bona fide emergency which requires a landing and/or takeoff for the preservation of life or property. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-65. - Exemptions due to circumstances. 
(a)  If an airline flight scheduled to land by or at the end of the time period during which it is permitted to do so under section 4-63 is delayed due to circumstances beyond the airline's control, such aircraft on such occasion shall be exempt from section 4-63 so long as such aircraft can land and take off again, if scheduled to do so, within one (1) hour from the end of such time period. 
(b)  If an aircraft owner believes that he or she is aggrieved in that during certain time periods section 4-63 operates in a manner to prevent an aircraft landing when such landing would otherwise be permitted based upon information contained in the advisory circular, said aircraft owner may appeal to the airport manager who may issue a waiver of section 4-63 based upon written evidence presented to his satisfaction. 
(c)  An aircraft which used the airport during calendar year 1984 (the "base year") but which exceeds the noise limits of section 4-63 may operate flights from the airport only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. and only in accordance with the following schedule, based upon submission of written records to the airport manager substantiating the number of flights made by such aircraft at the airport during the base year: 
Calendar 
Year 	Permissible Flights 
1985 	2/3 times number of substantiated base year flights, or 12, whichever is less. 
1986 	1/3 times number of substantiated Base Year flights, or 12, whichever is less. 
1987 and following: 	-0- 
 
(d)  An aircraft taxable by either the City of New Haven or the Town of East Haven which, as of January 21, 1985, was based at the airport and complies with the noise limits of section 4-63 between the hours of 7:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m. may also operate flights from the airport between the hours of 6:00 a.m. until 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-66. - Violation by aircraft owner/lessee. 
For purposes of this article, the pilot of an aircraft shall be deemed to be the beneficial owner or lessee thereof, and any violation of the provisions hereof shall be charged to said beneficial owner or lessee. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-67. - Presumption of aircraft noise violation. 
In the event that the airport manager determines to his reasonable satisfaction that the noise level indicated in the applicable advisory circular for the particular type or class of aircraft does not meet the noise levels set forth in section 4-63, it shall be presumed that operation of such aircraft will result in violation of the provisions of section 4-63, and said aircraft will not be permitted to land on, tie down on, be based at or take off from the airport, except in emergencies as set forth in section 4-64; provided, however, that the owner or operator of such aircraft shall be entitled to rebut such presumption to the reasonable satisfaction of the airport manager by furnishing written evidence to the contrary. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-68. - Appeals from decisions of airport manager. 
Any aircraft owner or lessee, or any member of the general public (including legal entities of any nature) may appeal an action of the airport manager under sections 4-65 or 4-67, or a penalty imposed under any provision of this article, in writing within seven (7) calendar days of notice of such action, or imposition of such penalty, to the board of airport commissioners. The board of airport commissioners shall meet within seven (7) calendar days to review such appeal, and shall issue a ruling thereon within ten (10) calendar days thereafter. Rulings of the board of airport commissioners hereunder are final and conclusive. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-69. - Run-ups, ground power units, auxiliary power units. 
(a)  Engine run-ups shall be conducted only at locations designated for such purpose in duly adopted airport rules and regulations. 
(b)  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., engine run-ups, use of G.P.U.'s, and use of A.P.U.'s are prohibited except for those essential to the operation of a scheduled flight. 
(c)  At such time as the city has installed noise barriers around a designated engine run-up area, or after January 1, 1986, whichever occurs sooner, the following noise limits shall prevail, measured at the property line between the airport and any residential use: 
Time Period 	Equivalent Sound Level For One Hour 	Maximum A-Weighted Sound Level 
7:00 a.m.—10:00 p.m. 	60.0 dB(A) 	70.0 dB(A) 
10:00 p.m.—7:00 a.m. 	50.0 dB(A) 	60.0 dB(A) 
 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-70. - Aircraft weight restriction. 
No fixed wing aircraft with a maximum certificated gross takeoff weight greater than one hundred sixty thousand (160,000) pounds shall land at the airport other than a landing necessitated by an inflight emergency. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-71. - Conflicts. 
Any provisions of the Code or regulations issued thereunder or any other ordinances of the city inconsistent herewith, to the extent of such inconsistencies and no further, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-72. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this article is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of the article. The board hereby declares that it would have passed this article and each section, subsection, sentence, clause and phrase thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-73. - Penalties. 
The following shall be the penalties for violation of this article: 
(1)  First violation: Written warning by certified mail to aircraft owner or lessee. 
(2)  Second violation: Fine of the maximum dollar amount permitted by City Charter imposed on aircraft owner or lessee. 
(3)  Third and subsequent violations: Impoundment of aircraft by the airport manager for seven (7) calendar days and fine of the maximum dollar amount permitted by City Charter imposed on aircraft owner or lessee. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Sec. 4-74. - Notification. 
(a)  The standards and prohibitions set forth herein shall be posted in such format as may be designated by the airport manager in at least two (2) prominent locations at the airport. 
(b)  Copies of the advisory circular and any determinations on noise level of aircraft pursuant to section 4-65 hereof shall be maintained in the office of the airport manager and shall be supplied to the Federal Aviation Administration tower operators at the airport. 
(c)  Requests for waivers, where such requests are expressly provided for by this article, and actions of the airport manager in response to such requests, shall be transmitted promptly to the board of airport commissioners and to the board of aldermen, and shall be posted in at least two (2) prominent locations at the airport. 
(Ord. of 2-4-85)  
Chapter 4½ - BURGLARY AND ROBBERY ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1607, adopted Nov. 16, 2009, amended former Ch. 4½, §§ 4½-1—4½-13, in its entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 3-22-82, §§ 1—13; Ord. of 6-18-84; Ord. of 4-15-85, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-89; Ord. of 5-24-99; Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 9-23-98, § 3; Ord. of 1-3-00, §s;; 1—3; Ord. No. 1345, 2-2-04. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4½-1. - Purpose. 
This chapter is intended to enhance emergency preparedness planning and facilitate timely and effective responses by the New Haven Police Department in order to protect the life and property of resident citizens and make New Haven a safer city.
