No. 1265, 7-5-00; Ord. No. 1323, 3-19-03; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 1556, 10-15-07; Ord. No. 1576, 12-15-08; Ord. No. 1643, 1-3-11 ; Ord. No. 1769 , 4-20-15)  
Sec. 19-17. - Golf course improvement revolving fund. 
(a)  A golf course improvement revolving fund is established to support capital expenditures for playing surface maintenance, repair, and reconstruction at the Alling Memorial Golf Course. Said fund shall derive its income from receipts of the surcharge on fees provided for in this chapter, and interest which may be earned on the balance in said fund. Relevant charter provisions and ordinances pertaining to capital projects shall govern appropriation of monies that accrue in said fund. 
(b)  Any new agreement, renewal or extension of the management agreement in effect on March 1, 1999, for operation of the Alling Memorial Golf Course shall specify that all sums collected in connection with the surcharge on fees provided for in the above section shall be deposited into the golf course improvement revolving fund. No sums collected in connection with said surcharge shall be included in calculations of fees or other compensation payable to the golf course operator. 
(Code of 1985, § 19-7.1; Ord. of 3-18-91; Ord. of 2-17-98; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-18. - Golf course enterprise fund. 
(a)  A fund entitled the Alling Memorial Golf Course Enterprise Fund ("the fund") is established, commencing with the 1997-98 fiscal year. This fund shall account for all revenues and expenses associated with the operations and management of the Alling Memorial Golf Course. 
(b)  All assets, liabilities and reserves (including depreciation reserves) applicable to the Alling Memorial Golf Course shall be transferred to the fund effective July 1, 1997. 
(c)  The accounts and records of the fund shall be maintained under the enterprise fund accounting, in which the golf course is operated and managed under a private self-sustaining fund, governmental accounting, auditing, financial reporting and generally accepted accounting principles. The controller or his/her designee shall prescribe the account and record forms, render reports and maintain such accounts and records pursuant to article VII, section 22(b) of the city charter as amended from time to time. 
(d)  The mayor shall submit the annual budget of the fund as a component of the annual city budget submission required by this Code, and such budget shall become effective upon approval by order of the board of aldermen. 
(Code of 1985, § 19-7.2; Ord. of 5-5-97; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-19. - Edgerton Park. 
(a)  Character of the park. Edgerton Park is to be maintained as an arboretum and botanical garden. The public's use of it is restricted to passive activities, which will not harm or change its essential character. 
(b)  Hours. Edgerton Park shall be open daily from 6:00 a.m. to sunset, or to the time specified by the director. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 19-8; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-20. - Ralph Walker Skating Rink at Blake Field. 
(a)  Hours of operation. Weather permitting, the rink shall be in operation from November 15th through March 15th. The director shall determine public skating hours, which shall be a minimum of seven hours per week with times on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. Hours of public skating shall be clearly posted in the rink. Peak hours shall be considered to be all hours from Monday through Friday, 2:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m., Saturdays, Sundays, holidays, and New Haven Public School vacation days. Contract ice rental rates shall be for fifty (50) minutes of ice time. 
(b)  Fee schedule. Rates for Ralph Walker Ice Rink ice rentals and skating shall be those authorized, approved and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen, and are listed in this Code. 
(c)  Rules of conduct. In addition to the rules of conduct found in this chapter, the following rules are applicable to the rink. The penalty for violation of these additional rules shall be forfeiture of use of the rink. 
(1)  No one shall be allowed on the ice without skates. 
(2)  Skaters must leave the ice when asked to do so by the rink operators. 
(d)  Skating Rinks Fund. 
(1)  A fund entitled the Skating Rinks Fund ("the fund") is established commencing with the 2000-01 fiscal year, to account for revenues and expenses associated with the operation, maintenance and improvement of any skating rinks owned by the city ("the facilities"). 
(3)  An annual report on the fund shall be provided pursuant to this Code. 
(4)  Sums appropriated by the board of aldermen for operation, maintenance or capital repairs of the facilities may be used to supplement expenditures from the fund, but such sums shall not be added to the fund unless the board has appropriated them. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-85, § 6; Code of 1985, § 19-9; Ord. of 3-7-88, § 1; Ord. of 6-6-88, § 4b; Ord. of 5-29-90; Ord. of 11-18-91; Ord. of 3-7-94; Ord. of 11-10-94; Ord. of 5-24-99; Ord. of 11-20-00; Ord. No. 1345, 2-2-04; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-21. - Athletic leagues. 
This section shall apply to all leagues operated by the recreation division of the parks department: 
Fees. Entry fees payable by each team each season in softball and basketball leagues shall be those authorized, established and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen, and are listed in this Code. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82, § 1; Code of 1985, § 19-10; Ord. of 6-6-88, § 4c; Ord. of 12-4-89; Ord. of 5-29-90; Ord. of 3-18-91; Ord. of 5-24-99)  
Sec. 19-22. - Swimming pools. 
Hours. The parks director or his/her designee(s) shall annually post hours of operation of all swimming pools operated by the recreation division of the parks department based upon their availability. 
(Code of 1985, § 19-10.1; Ord. of 5-29-90; Ord. of 5-24-99; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-23. - Use of stages and auxiliary equipment. 
(a)  Responsibility for costs. The parks department will assume all costs for use of the stages, bleachers, the public address system, generator and light tower when used for events sponsored by the city. All other entities requesting use of said stages or equipment must agree to assume all costs, including regular, overtime and other labor costs incurred by that use. 
(b)  Fees and costs. Rental or user fees for stages, bleachers, the public address system, generator and light tower shall be as authorized, established and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen, and are listed in this Code. 
(c)  Insurance. In addition to applicable fees and costs as referenced above, adequate accident and liability insurance as required by the parks director must be secured and supplied in advance of said rental or use. 
(d)  Permit. Persons or groups must obtain a permit in order to rent stages and equipment referenced in subsection (a). This applies to all city agencies and departments except the parks department. A permit fee as authorized, established and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen shall be imposed as listed in this Code. However, a city department is not required to pay the fee to use them. 
(e)  Restriction of use. Stages and equipment described in subsection (a) of this section shall be rented only for use on property within the limits of New Haven, or on property outside the city limits that the city loans or leases. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82, § 1; Ord. of 12-13-84; Code of 1985, § 19-19; Ord. of 5-5-86, § 3; Ord. of 6-6-88, § 4d; Ord. of 5-29-90; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-24. - Fees for building use. 
Fees for the rental use of the Coogan and Salperto building shall be those as are authorized, established and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen, and listed in this Code. 
(Code of 1985, sec. 19-19.5; Ord. No. 1345, 2-2-04; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 19-25. - Contractual relationships. 
The board of park commissioners may enter into contractual relationships with profit and nonprofit organizations for programmatic use of parks and park structures, provided that the programs are in accordance with the intended use of the parks, and that the organization's activities are open to the public. Such contractual relationships must be within the limits of charter section 117 as amended from time to time, and are to be distinguished from permits for activities elsewhere in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 5-3-82, § 2; Code of 1985, § 19-20; Ord. No. 1406, 3-6-06)  
Chapter 21 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ch. 21 was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
Charter reference— Planning and zoning, § 177 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 21-1. - Regional planning authority; New Haven membership authorized. 
Pursuant to the authority conferred by chapter 127, sections 8-31 through 8-37 of the General Statutes, Revision of 1958, the city is hereby empowered to join in the formation of the Regional Planning Authority of South Central Connecticut. 
(Ord. of 9-25-48, § 1) 
Editor's note— The ordinance of Sept. 25, 1948, from which § 21-1 above is derived, also set out the contract which the mayor was authorized to execute pursuant to said section. That contract has been omitted from this compilation.  
Sec. 21-1.1. - Mortgage disclosure; annual and supplemental reports. 
(a)  Title. This section shall be known as the "Mortgage Disclosure Ordinance of 1977." 
(b)  Definitions. When used in this section, the term: 
(1)  Financial institution shall mean any corporation, partnership, cooperative, proprietorship, or business entity subject to the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act of 1975, by virtue of sections 303(2) and 309 of that Act, 12 U.S.C. sections 2802(2) and 28058; 
(2)  Local financial institution shall mean any financial institution, as defined herein, with a branch or main office within the City of New Haven or within any of the following towns: Bethany, Branford, Clinton, East Haven, Guilford, Hamden, Killingworth, Madison, North Branford, North Haven, Orange, Wallingford, West Haven or Woodbridge; 
(3)  Local financial institution transacting business with the city shall mean any local financial institution, as defined herein, which; within the relevant calendar year, has: 
a.  Purchased, sold, underwritten or brokered, by itself or in cooperation with other financial institutions, a bond, note or other security issued by the City of New Haven, as defined herein; or 
b.  Received, for a period greater than twenty-four (24) hours, any time or savings deposit of the City of New Haven, as defined herein; 
(4)  City of New Haven shall mean all departments, bureaus, agencies, authorities, boards, commissions or offices: 
a.  Created by and existing under the Charter of the City of New Haven; or 
b.  Created by and existing under any ordinances or resolution of the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven (whether or not such ordinance or resolution was adopted pursuant to a state statute authorizing the same); 
(5)  Controller shall mean the controller appointed by the mayor pursuant to section 11(i) of the city Charter, or, if no such appointment is made under said section 11(i), the city official designated by the mayor to perform the duties of the controller under this section; 
(6)  Chief fiscal officer with respect to any department, bureau, agency, authority, board, commission of office not within the jurisdiction of the controller of the City of New Haven, shall mean the employee or official thereof who performs the equivalent duties therefor. 
(c)  The Annual Mortgage Report. On the first day of June, or on the first business day thereafter, the controller shall file with the city clerk the "annual mortgage report." Said annual mortgage report shall include: 
(1)  A listing of all local financial institutions and of all local financial institutions transacting business with the City of New Haven during the most recently-completed calendar year; 
(2)  A presentation of the date disclosed by those financial institutions during the most recently-completed calendar year pursuant to the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act of 1975 and the regulations promulgated thereunder; 
(3)  A listing of the transactions which took place during the most recently-completed calendar year between those financial institutions described in subsection (c)(1) of this section, and the City of New Haven, as defined herein; 
(4)  Additional data or analysis, if any, which will enable the board of aldermen to assess the availability of mortgage money within the City of New Haven; and 
(5)  Recommendations if any, for increasing the availability of such money. 
(d)  The Supplemental Mortgage Report. On the first day of December, or on the first business day thereafter the controller shall file with the city clerk the "supplemental mortgage report." Said supplemental mortgage report shall include all listings, data, analysis and recommendations which have been disclosed or become available during the preceding eleven (11) months of the types enumerated in subsection (c) for the annual mortgage report. 
(e)  Distribution of Copies by Clerk. Within forty-eight (48) hours after the annual mortgage report of the supplemental mortgage report, as the case may be, has been filed, the city clerk shall distribute a copy thereof to each member of the board of aldermen. 
(f)  Furnishing of Information by Chief Fiscal Officer. Any information required for the annual mortgage report or the supplemental mortgage report which is in the possession of any chief fiscal officer, as defined herein, including but not limited to the types of information referred to in section (c)(1) of this section, shall be furnished by such chief fiscal officer to the controller no later than one month before said controller is required to submit the annual mortgage report or the supplemental mortgage report, as the case may be. 
(Ord. of 8-1-77; Ord. of 8-2-93) 
Editor's note— An ordinance enacted Aug. 1, 1977, and formerly codified as § 21-15, has been redesignated by the editor as § 21-1.1 for purposes of classification.  
Sec. 21-1.2. - Disclosures required of financial institutions. 
(a)  Declaration of Policy. It is the policy of the City of New Haven to prevent the instability and decay of communities located throughout the city. Such prevention depends on actions by financial institutions to meet the credit needs of all communities within the city, and particularly low-income communities, and to promote lending practices based on fair and equitable considerations. To encourage financial institutions to meet their obligations, the performance record of a financial institution in servicing its local community will be considered by the city when depositories of city funds are designated. 
The City of New Haven hereby adopts a program requiring financial institutions holding funds for the city or its instrumentalities, or for organizations receiving city grants or city loans in an amount equal to or greater than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), to disclose certain information as set forth in this section. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  APR means the annual percentage rate as defined in the federal "truth in lending" laws. 
(2)  Applicant means any person who applies for a mortgage loan, commercial loan, or home improvement loan as defined in this section whether or not the loan is granted. 
(3)  Census means a standard statistical area as established most recently by the United States Bureau of the Census. 
(4)  City means the City of New Haven, Connecticut, and includes any agency, department, board, or commission of the City of New Haven. 
(5)  Commercial loan means a loan of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) or less which is secured by commercial property. 
(6)  Commercial property means all real property and buildings, structures, appurtenances, and improvements thereon, including residential property, owned by a business entity or individual with total assets of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) or less. 
(7)  Development administrator means the city official holding the office or acting in the capacity of development administrator of the city, or the designee of that official. 
(8)  Financial institution means any commercial bank, savings bank, savings and loan association, credit union, or other entity which makes mortgage, commercial, or home improvement loans and has total assets in excess of five million dollars ($5,000,000.00). 
(9)  Home improvement loan means a loan, secured or unsecured, the proceeds of which are to be used for the purpose of repairing, rehabilitating, or remodeling an existing residential dwelling. 
(10)  Instrumentalities means any agency, authority, board, or commission of the City of New Haven, Connecticut, including but not limited to the New Haven Coliseum Authority, the New Haven Municipal Golf Course, the New Haven Parking Authority, etc. 
(11)  Mortgage loan means a loan which is secured by residential property. 
(12)  Residential property means any building, structure or portion thereof which is occupied as, or designed and intended for occupancy as a residence by, one (1), two (2), three (3) or four (4) families, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure or portion thereof. 
(13)  New Haven SMSA means the Standard Metropolitan Statistical Area of the New Haven Region as defined by the United States Bureau of the Census. 
(c)  Disclosure of Community Reinvestment Performance Evaluations. 
(1)  Before the city deposits its funds in any financial institution, such institution shall disclose copies of the public section of its most recent community reinvestment performance evaluations, prepared by the appropriate federal regulatory agency and/or by the State of Connecticut Commissioner of Banking pursuant to the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, 12 USC 2901 et seq. (as amended), and the Connecticut General Statutes section 36-52a et seq. (as amended). 
(2)  The disclosures required herein shall be made to the development administrator annually within thirty (30) business days of receipt by the financial institution of the performance evaluations specified in paragraph (c)(1). 
(d)  Disclosure of Lending Information and Data. 
(1)  Before the city deposits its funds in any financial institution, such institution shall disclose the following information and data on forms approved by the development administrator: 
a.  The number and dollar amount by census tract for all mortgage loans made on or for residential property located within the New Haven SMSA and: 
(i)  Within the city. 
(ii)  Outside the city. 
b.  The APR by census tract for all mortgage loans made in or for residential property located within the New Haven SMSA and: 
(i)  Within the city. 
(ii)  Outside the city. 
c.  The average loan payment by census tract for all mortgage loans made on or for residential property located within the New Haven SMSA and: 
(i)  Within the city. 
(ii)  Outside the city. 
d.  The information and data referred to in paragraphs a. through c. of this subsection shall be itemized further by census tract to disclose the number, total dollar amount, average effective interest rate, and average down payments of: 
(i)  Mortgage loans made to applicants who did not at the time of execution of the loans intend to reside in the property securing the loan. 
(ii)  Home improvement loans. 
e.  The information and data specified in paragraphs a. through c. of this subsection shall also be obtained for commercial loans or mortgages on or for commercial properties. 
f.  The number of commercial, home improvement, and mortgage loan applicants for each census tract located within the New Haven SMSA, and the percentage of such applicants whose applications were denied, for each category: 
(i)  Within the city. 
(ii)  Outside the city. 
g.  The number and total dollar amount by census tract of all deposits held within the city by each branch of the financial institution, and the location of each such branch by census tract. 
(2)  The disclosure required herein shall be made to the development administrator annually on the first business day of June. 
(e)  Disclosure of 10-K Report or Annual Report. 
(1)  Before the city deposits its funds in any financial institution, such institution shall disclose a copy of its most recent 10-K report prepared and filed in accord with the federal securities laws. Where such report is not required, the institution shall disclose a copy of its annual report and its most recent "call report." 
(2)  The disclosures required herein shall be made to the development administrator annually within ninety (90) days after the close of the financial institution's fiscal year or on the first day of April, whichever is earlier. 
(f)  Disclosure of Additional Information. 
(1)  A financial institution shall disclose a copy of its written policy regarding branch closings. 
(2)  A financial institution is encouraged to disclose the total percentage, as well as the percentage by each job classification (e.g., teller, manager, etc.) of those employees who reside within the borders of the city. 
(3)  A financial institution is encouraged to disclose a list of names of board members residing within the borders of the city. 
(4)  A financial institution may include in its disclosure information regarding contributions it has made to city programs. Such information shall include the date, dollar amount, and recipient of the contribution. 
(5)  A financial institution may include in its disclosure information which in its opinion reflects upon the institution's community reinvestment record. 
(6)  The disclosure enumerated herein shall be made to the development administrator annually on the first business day of June. 
(g)  Compliance by Other Entities. Financial institutions currently holding funds for the city, its instrumentalities, or organizations receiving city grants or city loans in an amount equal to or greater than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall comply with all of the disclosure provisions as set forth in subsections (c), (d), (e) and (f). 
(h)  Failure To Provide Information. If any financial institution refuses to comply with the disclosure provisions as set forth in subsection (c), (d), (e) and (f), the development administrator shall report such refusal to the controller of the city. If such institution has previously been designated as a city depository, the controller shall consider withdrawing such designation. The development administrator shall maintain a list of those financial institutions refusing to comply, which list shall be a public record. 
(i)  Compilation and Usage of Financial Data. 
(1)  The development administrator shall compile the disclosures made by financial institutions pursuant to the provisions set forth in subsections (c), (d), (e) and (f). 
(2)  The development administrator shall file the compilation of disclosure information with the city clerk annually on January 15th or the next business day thereafter. 
(3)  The city clerk shall provide the public with access to the information and shall notify the board of finance and the board of aldermen of its availability. 
(4)  The board of finance shall consider the information in its determination of depositories for city funds. 
(5)  The instrumentalities of the city, as well as organizations receiving city grants or city loans in an amount equal to or greater than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), shall consider the information in their determination of depositories for funds which they control or with which they are entrusted. 
(j)  Severability. If any provision of this section or the application thereof shall be held invalid or unenforceable, the remainder of this section, or the application of such terms or provisions to persons or circumstances other than those as to which it is held invalid or unenforceable, shall not be affected thereby; and each remaining term and provision hereof shall be deemed valid and be enforced to the fullest extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. of 12-16-91; Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 8-2-93)  
ARTICLE II. - REDEVELOPMENT AGENCY 
 
Sec. 21-2. - Redevelopment agency established; membership, term, compensation. 
Pursuant to chapter 130 of the General Statutes, Revision of 1958, the city hereby establishes the New Haven Redevelopment Agency to be composed of five (5) residents appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen of the city. Members of the agency first appointed shall be designated to serve for one, two, three, four and five years respectively and thereafter shall be appointed annually to serve for five years. Any vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner of original appointment. Members shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed by the city for necessary expenses, within the limits of the appropriation approved therefor. 
(Ord. 8-7-50, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 21-3. - Selection of redevelopment agency officers, employees. 
The redevelopment agency shall select from among it members a chairman and a vice-chairman and may employ a secretary and such other officers, agents, technical consultants, legal counsel and employees as it may require, within the limits of its appropriations. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 3)  
Sec. 21-4. - Majority of redevelopment agency necessary to act. 
Action by the redevelopment agency shall be taken only on a majority vote of all of the members of the agency. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 4)  
Sec. 21-5. - Procedure by agency in passing on redevelopment. 
The redevelopment agency shall exercise its powers in the name of the city and is empowered, authorized and directed as follows: 
(a)  Refer plans to city plan commission. Upon submission to the redevelopment agency by a redeveloper of a proposed redevelopment plan, the redevelopment agency shall immediately transmit such plan to the city plan commission for its study and shall request and receive the written approval of the city plan commission thereon prior to taking action on the redevelopment plan. 
(b)  Public hearings. Before approving any redevelopment plan, the redevelopment agency shall hold a public hearing thereon, notice of which shall be published at least twice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, the first publication of such notice to be not less than two weeks before the date set for the hearing. 
(c)  Conditions for approval of plan. The redevelopment agency may approve the redevelopment plan if, following such hearing, the agency finds that: 
(1)  The area in which the proposed redevelopment is to be located is a redevelopment area; 
(2)  The carrying out of the redevelopment plan will result in materially improving conditions in such area; 
(3)  Sufficient living accommodations are available within a reasonable distance of such area or are provided for in the redevelopment plan for families displaced by the proposed improvement, at prices or rentals within the financial reach of such families; and 
(4)  The redevelopment plan is satisfactory as to site planning, relation to the comprehensive or general plan of the city, construction and financial ability of the redeveloper to carry it out. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 5)  
Sec. 21-6. - Approval of redevelopment plans by housing authority, aldermen. 
(a)  No redevelopment plan for a project which consists predominantly of residential facilities shall be approved by the redevelopment agency except with the approval of the housing authority of the city. 
(b)  The approval of the redevelopment plan shall be given by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, §§ 6, 7)  
Sec. 21-7. - Modification of redevelopment plans. 
A redevelopment plan may be modified at any time after the sale or lease of the area, provided the modification shall be consented to by the purchaser or lessee and approved by the city plan commission, the housing authority (as required by section 21-6(a)), the redevelopment agency, and the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 8)  
Sec. 21-8. - Authority of redevelopment agency to acquire and use real property. 
The redevelopment agency is authorized to acquire real property required for redevelopment purposes, by purchase, exchange, or gift. The redevelopment agency is also authorized to acquire real property by eminent domain in accordance with the provisions of section 8-129 through and including section 8-133 of the 1958 revision of the general statutes and subject to the prior approval of the board of aldermen. Real property may be acquired previous to the adoption or approval of the redevelopment plan for a project area, provided the property acquired shall be located within an area designated by the city plan commission as an appropriate redevelopment area and provided such acquisition is authorized by the board of aldermen. Title to all land acquired by the redevelopment agency for redevelopment purposes shall be solely in the name of the city. While such real property is in the possession of the redevelopment agency, the agency may clear, repair, operate or insure it, or may make site improvements essential to preparation for its use in accordance with the redevelopment plan. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 9) 
State Law reference— Sections 8-128—8-133 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958) authorize the acquisition of real property by redevelopment agencies and regulate certain aspects of condemnation for that purpose.  
Sec. 21-9. - Sales, leases of land by agency to redevelopers or public agencies. 
The redevelopment agency may sell or lease, for such sums as may be agreed upon, the whole or any part of a redevelopment area to the redeveloper, or, if the property is to be used for public purposes, to an appropriate public agency. The consideration paid for the sale or lease of the property shall be determined by the redevelopment agency, provided, if the cost or carrying charges of such land to the redevelopment agency are greater than such consideration, the redevelopment agency shall first have specific authorization from the board of aldermen for the sale or lease at any lesser consideration, and the city may appropriate and authorize the expenditure of money to compensate for any portion of the difference between the acquisition cost of such property and such sale or lease price of such property at a lesser consideration to a redeveloper, but in no case shall sale or lease price be lower than the use value of such property. Each contract for sale or lease to a redeveloper shall provide, among other things that the property transferred shall be developed and used in accordance with the redevelopment plan or such plan as modified with the approval of the redevelopment agency, that the building of the improvements shall be begun within a period of time which the redevelopment agency fixes as reasonable and that all transfers of properties by the redeveloper shall be subject to the consent of the redevelopment agency. Any contract for sale or lease shall be approved by the board of aldermen before its final approval by the redevelopment agency. 
Any contract for sale or lease to a redeveloper may provide, among other things: 
(a)  That the properties in the redevelopment area shall be maintained in accordance with the redevelopment plan; 
(b)  That the redevelopment agency shall have the right of inspection; 
(c)  That the redeveloper, as security for its fulfillment of the contract, shall make a cash deposit or give a bond with such surety as the contract may provide or make such other guarantee as the redevelopment agency may deem necessary in the public interest; 
(d)  That, if the redevelopment agency finds that the redevelopment is not being maintained in accordance with the contract terms and conditions, it shall notify the redeveloper or its successor in title in writing of the work which shall be done to meet the standards of maintenance agreed upon; 
(e)  That the city may contract to retain or accept, close, relocate, construct, reconstruct and maintain specified streets, playgrounds, parks or other public facilities within the area of the proposed redevelopment. 
Upon consummation of the contract for sale or lease of a site to a redeveloper, the city may provide for the extension of such streets, sidewalks and public utilities as are necessary to its use for residential purposes. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 10) 
State Law reference— Authority of redevelopment agency to sell or lease property, § 8-137 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 21-10. - Authority of redevelopment agency to accept aid from state, federal agencies. 
In order to carry out a redevelopment program the redevelopment agency may accept grants or other financial assistance from the state or federal governments and may do any and all things necessary or desirable to secure such financial aid, including obligating itself in any contract with the federal government to convey to the federal government the project to which such contract relates upon the occurrence of a substantial default. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 11) 
State Law reference— Acceptance of state, federal grants by redevelopment agencies, § 8-135 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 21-11. - Financing of redevelopment agency by city. 
The redevelopment agency may have funds appropriated to it by the city for administrative expenses and for the acquisition of real property in any redevelopment area. The city may issue bonds for redevelopment purposes, in accordance with state and federal laws for such purposes. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 12)  
Sec. 21-12. - Additional redevelopment powers provided by statute. 
In addition to the foregoing powers and authorizations, the redevelopment agency shall exercise all powers and authorities vested in redevelopment agencies by the general statutes or by any amendments or additions thereto which may hereafter be enacted by the general assembly. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 13) 
State Law reference— For provisions concerning redevelopment agencies generally, see §§ 8-124—8-145 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 21-13. - Redevelopment advisory board. 
There shall be an advisory group composed of five (5) persons, namely, a representative of the housing authority of the city, selected by said authority; a representative of the city plan commission, selected by said commission; a representative of the board of education, selected by said board; and two (2) representatives of the board of aldermen, selected by said board on a bipartisan basis. Any vacancy in this group shall be filled in the manner of original selection. The function of this group shall be to advise and assist the redevelopment agency in the preparation and execution of a redevelopment program for New Haven and to assist in coordinating with said program the activities of the agencies represented on said advisory group. The advisory group shall attend all meetings of the redevelopment agency but shall have no voting power. 
(Ord. of 8-7-50, § 14)  
ARTICLE III. - NEW HAVEN DEVELOPMENT 
 
Sec. 21-14. - Development commission. 
(a)  There shall be a New Haven development commission, pursuant to section 7-136, General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958 for the promotion and development of the economic resources of the city. It is hereby designated as a municipal development agency under Connecticut General Statute, Section 8-186, et seq., as they may from time to time be amended, the city's urban rehabilitation agency, under Connecticut General Statute, Section 8-290, et seq., as they may from time to time be amended; and the city's harbor improvement agency under Connecticut General Statutes 13b-56 and 13b-57, as they may from time to time be amended. It shall exercise all the powers and duties conferred by state law on such agencies including the power to acquire by eminent domain as may be provided for any of those agencies in the same manner as under Connecticut General Studies, Section 8-129 through 8-133, as they may from time to time be amended. 
(b)  Said commission shall consist of fifteen (15) members; a member of the board of aldermen elected by the board of aldermen in January of each year and fourteen (14) other members, which may represent the nonprofit community development organizations and any of the following sections of the New Haven community: Banking, public utilities, general business, education, private charitable, cultural or scientific organizations, real estate and city agencies, all of whom shall be residents of the city and all of whom shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen. The mayor shall fill the vacancies in membership, arising from expired terms, by appointments for a term of three (3) years. Any vacancy in the membership of the commission shall be filled for the unexpired portions of any member's term by the mayor. The mayor may appoint, if in said mayor's opinion the interests of the city require it, advisory representatives to the commission for specified terms from any of the above sections of the community. Such advisory representatives may not vote but may advise and participate in the business of the commission. 
(c)  The members shall elect annually one (1) member of said commission to be chairman, another to be vice chairman, and a third to be secretary. 
(d)  The members of said commission shall receive no compensation for their services as such, but shall be reimbursed, within the limits of any sum appropriated for such purpose, for their necessary, expenses incurred in the performance of their official duties. 
(e)  Said commission may appoint employees, hire consultants, and purchase material and supplies necessary for the discharge of its duties, within the limits of any sum appropriated for such purpose. 
(f)  In the implementation of its powers and duties conferred by state law, said commission shall engage in the following services related to municipal development, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  To have prepared, to review, to modify, and to approve all plans, including any amendments thereto required to be prepared and approved, by state law, by a municipal development agency, an urban rehabilitation agency, or a harbor improvement agency. 
(2)  To study, investigate and appraise economic conditions and trends affecting New Haven industry, business and commerce and its residential, recreational and municipal facilities. 
(3)  To promote, assist and encourage the preservation of a healthy business climate and aesthetically attractive physical environment in the city. 
(4)  To promote, assist and encourage the preservation, expansion and development of existing New Haven industry, business and commerce and its residential, recreational and municipal facilities. 
(5)  To promote, assist and encourage the location, expansion and development of new industry, business and commerce in the city, with due regard for the conservation and preservation of the ecology of the area. 
(6)  To prepare, collect, compile, advertise and distribute books, maps, charts, pamphlets and graphic material of every kind and description relative to the human and physical resources of the city. 
(7)  To cooperate with, and seek to coordinate the activities of, all official and unofficial civic, research and promotional agencies, commissions, groups, associations and organizations having like or kindred economic development, functions and concerns. 
(8)  To confer and cooperate with agencies of the state and federal governments in the exercise of the aforesaid powers and duties. 
(9)  To confer and cooperate with similar municipal economic development commissions in the greater New Haven Area in order to foster and maintain a proper balance among industrial, business, commercial, residential, recreational and municipal growth elements, with attention to protection and aesthetic improvement of the physical environment. 
(10)  To advise and make recommendations to appropriate officials, agencies, boards, departments and commissions of New Haven, including the mayor, the board of aldermen and the city planning commission, regarding actions which, in said commission's judgment, would affect or improve the economic condition and development, or physical environment, of the city. 
(g)  Each official, agency, board, department and commission shall cooperate with and assist said commission in the exercise of its powers and duties. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 5; Ord. of 9-26-83; Ord. of 10-19-87; Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 9-23-98, § 12)  
Secs. 21-15—21-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An Ord. of Aug. 5, 1996, repealed former section 21-15 in its entirety which pertained to the New Haven Housing Partnership which derived from an Ord. of July 2, 1990, and an Ord. of July 6, 1993.  
ARTICLE IV. - LIVABLE CITY INITIATIVE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— An Ordinance of May 20, 1996 repealed former Art. IV, §§ 21-21—21-27, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. IV pertained to the office of housing and neighborhood development and derived from an Ord. of July 6, 1981, § 1; an Ord. of May 29, 1990, § 2; and an Ord. of July 6, 1993. 
 
Sec. 21-21. - Establishment of bureau. 
The office of housing and neighborhood development is abolished and there is hereby established the livable city initiative bureau, hereinafter referred to in this chapter as the "bureau." 
(Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-22. - Powers and duties of the bureau 
The bureau is authorized to engage in any and all activities authorized by law which are related to the elimination and prevention of blight, as well as the rehabilitation of viable buildings and structures, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Demolition of unsafe and/or blighted buildings and structures and the ability to contract for the same; 
(2)  Acquisition and disposition of real estate, on behalf of the City of New Haven, by all methods permitted by law including, but not limited to, methods outlined in section 7-148(L)(3)(A) and (B) of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended from time to time, which authorizes a municipality to "take or acquire by gift, purchase, grant, including any grant from the United States or the state, bequest or devise and hold, condemn, lease, sell, manage, transfer, release and convey such real and personal property or interest therein absolutely or in trust as the purposes of the municipality or any public use or purpose…" as well as acquisition via tax foreclosure, deed in lieu of tax foreclosure, summary foreclosure, receivership and eminent domain. Property so acquired shall be disposed of in accordance with the land disposition guidelines approved by the board of aldermen on December 1, 1997, as amended from time to time, and in a manner consistent with applicable law. 
(3)  Relocation of displaced individuals in accordance with the state and federal relocation laws and regulations, as applicable; 
(4)  State building code enforcement, zoning ordinance enforcement and housing code enforcement in accordance with applicable law; 
(5)  Planning, technical assistance and other assistance in site assembly to promote a livable city in conjunction with the city plan department; 
(6)  Financial assistance to qualified individuals and entities to promote conservation of the city's neighborhoods, housing stock, and to encourage homeownership and maintenance; 
(7)  Planning, technical and financial assistance, training and information services to the extent provided by law, to build the capacity of neighborhood organizations to participate in neighborhood revitalization activities, and to increase the effectiveness of housing management; and 
(8)  To affirmatively pursue compliance with section 3 of the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968, as amended from time to time, with respect to empowerment of the target population including, but not limited to, employment and economic opportunities. 
(9)  To the extent allowed by law, inspecting, repairing, demolishing, removing or, to the extent applicable, otherwise disposing of any real estate in order to secure such real estate or to make it safe pursuant to section 49-73b of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. of 5-20-96, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-23. - Appointment of director; powers and duties. 
(a)  The mayor shall appoint a director of the bureau who shall serve at the mayor's pleasure. 
(b)  The director is responsible for administration of the bureau, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Personnel selection, supervision, management, training and development; 
(2)  Budget development and administration; 
(3)  Program planning, policy and execution; 
(4)  Oversight of office operations and procedures; 
(5)  Other related administrative and managerial functions; 
(6)  Staff support to the livable city initiative board established under section 21-24 of this chapter; and 
(7)  All other powers and duties of the bureau not expressly required by state law or ordinance to be exercised by the livable city initiative board established under section 21-24 of this chapter. 
(c)  The director shall manage and control the office of building inspection and enforcement in accordance with section 121 et seq. of the Charter of the City of New Haven, as amended from time to time. Such office shall hereinafter be referred to as the "building division" of the bureau for the purposes of this chapter. 
(d)  The director may hire, with the approval of the appropriate boards, commissions or authorities, employees, consultants and contractors, and purchase goods, supplies, services necessary for the discharge of the bureau duties, within the limits of any sums appropriated for those purposes. The director shall make every reasonable effort to employ city residents and engage the services of consultants and contractors whose principal place of business is located in the City of New Haven and to ensure a balance of such residents, staff consultants, including those providing professional services, that shall reflect the racial demographics of the city. 
(e)  No later than January 1, 2000, the director shall formulate and promulgate, in consultation with the livable city initiative board, written policies and procedures regarding the responsibility of contracts engaged by the bureau, including, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Davis-Bacon Act, 40 USC 276a et seq., as amended from time to time; 
(2)  Section 3 of the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968, 12 USC 1701u and implementing regulations at 24 CFR Part 135, as amended from time to time; 
(3)  Fair Housing Act, 42 USC 3601-3620, including implementing regulations at 24 CFR Part 100 and Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 (PL 90-284), as amended from time to time; 
(4)  Section 2-222(d) and 2-226 of this Code ("living wage ordinance"), as amended from time to time; 
(5)  Chapter 12½ of the this Code, as amended from time to time. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, all contracts used to engage consultants and contractors must contain the following provision: 
"The contractor agrees, warrants and represents that it shall comply with all applicable local, state and federal laws, rules, regulations, codes, ordinances and statutes." 
(f)  The director and members of the director's staff shall receive ongoing training appropriate to their job descriptions and to all programs they administer in accordance with applicable local, state and federal laws, rules, regulations, codes, ordinances and statutes, including ethical, conflict-of-interest, freedom of information and public records and meetings provisions. 
(g)  The director shall take actions necessary, including a market study, and the promulgation of policies and procedures as appropriate, to ensure that expenditures of City funds are not made when doing so for the purposes of housing acquisition and/or rehabilitation would make it unlikely or impossible for an end buyer to sustain affordable homeownership. 
(h)  As of July 1, 1999, the director shall require the execution of a conflict-of-interest/non-collusion affidavit, in a form and manner provided by the city, of all borrowers/grantees, consultants and contractors. Said affidavit shall indicate, at a minimum, conflicts resulting from a relationship, whether professional or familial, with city employees, board, commission, and/or authority members, and appointed and/or elected officials. 
(i)  As of July 1, 1999, the director shall provide, through the bureau or a consultant/contractor engaged by the bureau, a homebuyer/maintenance workshop, as the case may be, to all borrowers/grantees who apply for and/or obtain assistance from the bureau's program. Said workshop, should include preand post-purchase/rehabilitation topics, including, but not limited to, debt ratios, retention of independent legal counsel, property maintenance, truth-in-lending, financing agreements, mortgages, contractors, property insurance and landlord/tenant issues. 
(j)  As of July 1, 1999, The director shall ensure that prospective buyers/donees of city owned property are encouraged to retain independent legal representation, order a title search, perform their own due diligence (which means their own inspection of said property), and secure, at their sole expense, a phase I, II and/or III environmental study, if necessary. Additionally, such advice shall state that city-owned property is sold on an as-is basis and that the city makes no warranties, covenants, agreements, promises, conditions, acknowledgments, or representations relative to the marketability, mercantability, habitability, integrity or condition of the property. 
(k)  The director shall, in consultation with the livable city initiative board, administer the bureau's loan and grant programs and do all things necessary to implement such programs including but not limited to establishing the terms and conditions of said programs, within the limitations of sums appropriated for such purpose. 
(l)  The director shall file monthly reports with the board of aldermen of all activities of the bureau including loan, demolition and blighted buildings' or structures' reports, and conflict-of-interest/non-collusion affidavits for all borrowers/grantees, consultants and contractors. 
(m)  The director shall take the necessary action to establish a loan underwriting committee ("LUC") to ensure compliance with the City of New Haven's Residential Loan Assistance Program Policies and Procedure which shall include (without limitation) appointing committee members, establishing guidelines for the LUC and/or amending the guidelines and/or loan program policies and procedures 
(Ord. of 5-20-96, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-7-99; Ord. No. 1636, § 1, 9-7-10 )  
Sec. 21-24. - Establishment of board. 
(a)  The office of housing and neighborhood development board is abolished and there is hereby established the livable city initiative board within the bureau, hereinafter referred to as the "board." It shall consist of nine (9) regular members and two (2) alternate members. Seven (7) of the regular members shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the Board of Aldermen. The other two (2) regular members shall be members of the board of aldermen appointed by the president of the board of aldermen. The two (2) alternate members shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the board of aldermen. The board members shall serve without compensation and shall be elector residents in the City of New Haven. Board members may be reimbursed for necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their official duties, within the limitations of appropriations. 
(b)  Board members appointed by the mayor shall serve for three (3) years. Each of those members shall serve until his successor is appointed and has qualified. 
Board members appointed by the president of the board of aldermen shall serve for two (2) years or a portion thereof, coterminous with their aldermanic term. 
In the event of a vacancy in the board's membership, the successor shall be appointed to serve during the balance of the term remaining from the vacating member's term. 
(c)  All members of the board will undergo training and development relative to the activities of the bureau and all programs it administers, as well as the city ethics ordinance, and the state freedom of information and public records and meetings statutes. 
(Ord of 5-20-99, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-25. - Designation of livable city initiative board as urban homesteading agency, housing site development agency, and community development agency. 
(a)  The board is hereby designated as the city's urban homesteading agency under the Connecticut General Statutes sections 8-169, et seq., as amended from time to time; the city's housing site development agency under the Connecticut General Statutes section 8-123 through section 8-214, as they may from time to time be amended; and a city community development agency under Connecticut General Statutes section 8-169a et seq., amended from time to time, and may exercise, in accordance with said sections, all the powers and duties conferred by state law on such agencies. 
(Ord. of 5-20-96, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-26. - Livable city initiative board organization and voting requirements. 
(a)  The board shall elect a chairperson, a co-chairperson and a secretary from its membership who shall serve a one-year term. The board may further organize itself in whatever other manner it deems appropriate and may adopt such rules and regulations for its governance as it considers necessary. These rules shall determine the privileges and voting rights of the alternate members. 
(b)  A majority of all voting members of the board constitutes a quorum for conducting the board's business. All actions shall be taken by an affirmative vote of at least a majority of the members of the quorum. 
(c)  The board shall meet at least monthly and may be called into special session upon due notice by the mayor, the chairperson, or by a petition signed by a majority of the board. 
(Ord. of 5-20-96, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-27. - The board's role, powers, and duties. 
In addition to its powers and duties that may be conferred by state law, the board shall provide the following functions and perform the following duties; 
(1)  Long-range planning in policy formulation and program evaluation for the bureau; 
(2)  Review and comment to the director on annual budget recommendations prepared by office staff; 
(3)  Approve the bureau's acquisition and disposition of real property by all methods generally described herein excluding tax foreclosure and deed-in-lieu of tax foreclosure; 
(4)  Approve the disposition of real property in accordance with guidelines passed by the board of aldermen on December 1, 1997, as amended from time to time; 
(5)  Review, modify and approve all plans, including any amendments thereto, required to be prepared and approved by state law by the board when it serves as any of the agencies listed in section 21-25 of this chapter and all other plans as may be referred for approval by the director of the bureau; 
(6)  Submit to the board of aldermen a report as to the disposition of parcels on which properties have been demolished and a maintenance plan where necessary within ninety (90) days of demolition. Failure to submit such a report may result in the termination of this initiative. 
(Ord. of 5-20-96, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-28. - Loan underwriting committee. 
(a)  The LUC established by the director as described in subsection 21-23(m) above shall be charged with ensuring that loan recommendations from LCI are consistent with the City of New Haven's Residential Loan Assistance Program's Policies and Procedures. 
(b)  The LUC shall have seven (7) members appointed by the director. The director shall seek to appoint a balanced membership from the private, non-profit and public sectors, with an emphasis on individuals with expertise or experience in related fields such as banking/finance, architecture, real estate law loan programs, and/or community development. No member of the LUC shall be an officer or employee of the City of New Haven. 
(c)  Members of the LUC shall be appointed to a term of two (2) years, except that three (3) of the initial appointees shall have an initial term of one (1) year. Each member of the LUC shall be eligible for reappointment at the expiration of his or her term, provided that no member shall be permitted to serve for a period in excess of nine (9) consecutive years. 
(d)  The City of New Haven will indemnify and hold harmless the LUC members against and from any personal liability arising from their service on the LUC provided that such liability arises from actions taken by such LUC member within the scope of the authority of the LUC, as described in the loan underwriting advisory guidelines. 
( Ord. No. 1636, § 2, 9-7-10 )  
Sec. 21-29. - Mayoral declaration that land acquisition(s), land disposition(s) and demolition(s) are of an emergency nature and that immediate action is necessary. 
(a)  The mayor may invoke section 41 of the Charter to certify as an emergency all land acquisition(s), land disposition(s) and demolition(s) undertaken by bureau and a list of all such activities shall be submitted to the board of aldermen no later than one week before each regular board of aldermen meeting for inclusion on the regular agenda of said meeting; and said list shall be accompanied by the requisite city plan commission report, to the extent required by law, as well as all pertinent information about each land acquisition, disposition and demolition matter including but not limited to, as applicable, the square footage, purchase and/or sales price, name of purchaser and the purchaser's conflict of interest/non-collusion affidavit and proposed use for each parcel. 
(b)  All items on such list shall be deemed first readings proper for vote pursuant to the invocation of section 41 of the Charter unless the alderperson of the ward affected by the land acquisition or disposition contacts the president of the board prior to the start of the board meeting to request that an item be separated out for referral to the appropriate committee. 
(Ord. of 6-7-99)  
Sec. 21-30. - Emergency purchasing and bidding procedures for demolition of building(s) and/or structures by the bureau. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 74(d)(iii) of the Charter, the purchasing agent is hereby authorized to secure the services of contractors engaged to undertake the demolition of building(s) and structure(s) identified by the local building official to the bureau as said demolition is herein deemed by the board of aldermen to be an emergency involving a threat to the public health, safety or welfare. The purchasing agent shall award the demolition contract(s) to the lowest responsible bidder using the agent's informal bid process in manner consistent with purchasing policies and procedures which may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  The director of the bureau shall file a monthly report with the board of aldermen containing a list of all bids awarded in the preceding month for demolitions undertaken by the bureau, along with the names and addresses of the contractors, amount of the contract, funding source, and the completion dates of all demolitions, and all other pertinent information including a list of the racial and residential status of contractors' personnel working on said demolitions. 
(Ord. of 6-7-99)  
ARTICLE V. - OFFICE OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted July 6, 1981, § 3, added provisions designated Ch. 21C, §§ 21C-1—21C-3, which the editor has included herein as Art. V, §§ 21-31—21-33 for classification purposes. 
 
Sec. 21-31. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established the office of business development. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 3; Ord. of 4-17-89, § 1)  
Sec. 21-32. - Powers and duties of the office. 
The office of business development is authorized to engage in services related to the economic development of the city, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Retention and expansion of the city's tax base and employment; 
(b)  Programs necessary to encourage, assist and provide for economic development, including, but not limited to a land and building bank, small business assistance program, minority business assistance, a lending program through the New Haven development corporation, the neighborhood commercial revitalization program, and employment training program; 
(c)  Securing federal and state grants for economic development projects; 
(d)  Providing comprehensive and coordinated development planning services in partnership with appropriate public, private and nonprofit agencies; 
(e)  Assisting developers, owners, merchants and residents in identifying funding sources, making applications to public and private lenders, and complying with regulatory, statutory, or other permitting requirements; 
(f)  Gathering and disseminating information and data critical to investment decisions; 
(g)  Assisting in planning the coordinated delivery of public services; 
(h)  Developing marketing programs for publicly owned land; 
(i)  Reviewing the duly adopted and proposed physical development plans of the city and recommending amendments thereto; 
(j)  Assisting communication regarding the provision of services between public, private and nonprofit agencies concerned with the development of the city; 
(k)  Directing local implementation of the State "Coastal Management Act", Connecticut General Statutes Sections 22a-90 through 22a-112, as they may from time to time be amended. 
(l)  Developing marketing, promotional, and cultural programs, and providing staff support to the commission on cultural affairs. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 3; Ord. of 4-17-89, § 2; Ord. of 5-29-90, § 2)  
Sec. 21-33. - Appointment of director; powers and duties. 
(a)  The mayor shall appoint a director of the office of business development, who shall serve at the mayor's pleasure. 
(b)  The director is responsible for the administration of the office of business development, including but not limited to: 
(1)  Personnel selection, supervision, management, and development; 
(2)  Budget development and administration; 
(3)  Program planning, policy and execution; 
(4)  Oversight of office operations and procedures; 
(5)  Other related administrative and managerial functions; 
(6)  Staff support to the New Haven development commission and any other city entities regarding economic development projects and programs; and 
(7)  All other powers and duties necessary to carry out the services of the office. 
(c)  The director may appoint, with the approval of the appropriate entities, employees and staff, hire consultants, and purchase supplies, services, and construction, necessary for the discharge of the office's duties, within the limits of any sums appropriated for those purposes. 
(Ord. of 7-6-81, § 3; Ord. of 4-17-89, § 3)  
Sec. 21-34. - Acquisition of real estate to protect security for city loans or to realize value of city liens. 
If advised in writing by the corporation counsel of the city to do so, the mayor is hereby directed to take such action or actions as may be reasonably necessary in order to adequately protect the city's position with respect to any real estate which serves as security for any loan made by the city or for any liens, and that any such action may include the commencement of foreclosure proceedings and/or bidding for such real estate at any foreclosure sale, and (where any such bid is the highest bid) taking title to the same without further reference to the board of aldermen, provided that: 
(1)  In no circumstances shall any such bid be greater than the aggregate of the amount owed to the city and the sum of any other indebtedness secured by the real estate in question (the "property") where the lien securing such other indebtedness is superior to that held by the city; 
(2)  In no event shall the city bid any sum which is greater than ninety (90) percent of the appraised value of the property, as calculated pursuant to the appraised value set forth in an appraisal carried out not more than six (6) months prior to the foreclosure sale in question; 
(3)  The city shall have sufficient funds to complete the purchase of the property from an appropriate funding source in the event that the city is the successful bidder; 
(4)  In the event that the funds which may be used to purchase the property are derived from the federal or state government, all requisite governmental approvals of such action (if any) shall have been obtained prior to the foreclosure sale in question; and 
(5)  Reports of all activities by the city under this section 21-34 shall be filed quarterly with the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 12-6-99)  
Sec. 21-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - DOWNTOWN AND HARBOR DEVELOPMENT[4]

ARTICLE VII. - BENEFIT RECAPTURE 
 
Sec. 21-39. - Tax benefits. 
If the city directly grants a tax abatement, tax assessment deferral or other tax benefit to an industrial or commercial entity for the purpose of locating, maintaining, rehabilitating or expanding its manufacturing facilities in New Haven, and the entity relocates its manufacturing facilities from New Haven in whole or in part during the term of any such benefit, the tax benefits for the remainder of the term shall automatically be cancelled, and the tax benefits effected shall be repaid within thirty (30) days to the City of New Haven together with interest from the date the benefits accrued, such interest to be at the prime rate on the date of cancellation, and such industrial or commercial entity must notify the city six (6) months prior to its relocation. 
(Ord. of 12-16-85)  
Sec. 21-40. - Community development block grant float loan. 
If an industrial or commercial entity relocates its facilities in whole or in part from New Haven during the term of any community development block grant float loan directly granted to it by the city, the outstanding principal balance of the loan shall be immediately due and payable at the then prevailing prime rate, and such industrial or commercial entity must notify the City of New Haven six (6) months prior to its relocation. 
(Ord. of 12-16-85)  
Sec. 21-41. - Implementation. 
The requirements of section 21-39 and section 21-40 shall be implemented by appropriated provisions in tax benefit agreements and community development block grant float loan agreements, as the case may be. 
(Ord. of 12-16-85)  
Sec. 21-42. - Effective date. 
This Article VII shall apply to all affected agreements entered into by the City of New Haven following the effective date of this article [January 6, 1986]. 
(Ord. of 12-16-85)  
Secs. 21-43—21-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - CITY PLANNING COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— The provisions codified as Art. VIII, § 21-46, derive from an ordinance enacted April 7, 1986, approved April 14, 1986, and effective April 26, 1986. Said ordinance designated said provisions as Art. VII, § 21-39, and has been redesignated by the editor to avoid duplication of section numbers. 
 
Sec. 21-46. - Alternate members. 
(1)  Appointment of alternates; terms of service. In accordance with the provisions of Section 8-19a of the Connecticut General Statutes (P.A. 84-154), the mayor shall appoint three (3) alternate members to the New Haven city plan commission. Such members shall be electors of the City of New Haven, and shall not be employees of the City of New Haven or members of the zoning commission or the board of zoning appeals. They shall serve without compensation. 
The mayor shall designate one (1) member to serve until January 1, 1987; one (1) member to serve until January 1, 1988; one (1) member to serve until January 1, 1989. Thereafter, each alternate member shall be appointed by the mayor in a like manner for terms of three (3) years. Any vacancy created by any reason other than by expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired portion of that term in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member shall serve until a successor is appointed and has qualified. 
(2)  Powers and duties. The three (3) alternate members shall, when seated, have all the powers and duties assigned to the city plan commission and its members by the General Statutes, Special Act 243 (1913) and the City Charter. They may attend all commission meetings and executive sessions. If a regular member of the commission is absent or is disqualified, the chairman of the commission shall designate an alternate to so act, choosing alternates in rotation so that they shall act as nearly equal a number of times as possible. If any alternate is not available in accordance with such rotation, such fact shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
(Ord. of 4-7-86)  
Secs. 21-47—21-50. - Reserved.  
Chapter 22 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ch. 22 was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
Cross reference— Duty of chief of police when claims arise from defective streets, sidewalks, bridges, § 2-45; door-to-door sales, Ch. 22½; duty of police to assist sealers of weights and measures, § 31-1. 
Charter reference— Department of police services, §§ 109—117; general provisions concerning police services, §§ 122—129. For pensions, see Special Laws Compilation, §§ 180—216. 
State Law reference— Provisions concerning police departments generally, §§ 7-274—7-294 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958). 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Reimbursement of police for injuries, expenses. 
The board of police commissioners, may, after due inquiry, approve a bill against the city to reimburse any police officer, in whole or in part, for any unusual injury to his clothing and equipment received in the judicious and faithful discharge of his duty, or for any reasonable expense incurred by him in defending any suit for his acts done in the like discharge of his duty, and such bill, being approved and passed in the same manner as other bills, shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1928, § 613)  
Sec. 22-2. - Auditing and approval of police department expenses. 
The board of police commissioners shall each month audit all bills created in and for the police department, and cause those approved by them to be duly certified and passed over to the city clerk, for the approval of the board of finance. 
(Code 1928, § 614)  
Sec. 22-3. - Accounting, monthly reports by police chief; payment of bills. 
The chief of police shall keep an account of all incidental expenses of the police force, and station houses, including any expenses incurred by any member of said force in pursuing any alleged offender, or in securing and placing him in a station house, and any necessary expense incurred in recovering or restoring stolen property; and at the end of each month he shall make out a bill for the same against the city, certifying thereon that the same is correct, and present it to the board of police commissioners, furnishing vouchers if required; and such bill, being amended and approved by said board, shall be passed, approved and paid in the same manner as other bills against the city. 
(Code 1928, § 616) 
Cross reference— Contents of bills against the city, § 2-36; off-setting amounts due city against obligations, § 2-37; preferences in paying claims, § 2-38; presentation and procedures for claims for damages, § 2-46. 
Charter reference— Procedure for payment of claims, § 19.  
Sec. 22-4. - Special constables—Authorized; appointment, term, compensation. 
The board of police commissioners may authorize the chief of police to appoint and reappoint, for terms not exceeding five (5) years, as many auxiliary policemen to serve without pay or other compensation as may be deemed advisable by said board for service in connection with police duty in the city. These auxiliary policemen shall be known as a special constable unit. 
(Ord. of 7-7-47, §§ 1, 4)  
Sec. 22-5. - Same—Mobilization for active duty; powers, duties. 
Special constables may be mobilized for training at the call of the chief of police or any authorized member of said department that the said chief of police may designate, but they shall be mobilized for active service or called upon to perform active police duty only in the event that the mayor or acting mayor has declared that a serious emergency exists in the city and only upon the authorization of the mayor or the chief of police following such declaration. During such period of active service only, such special constables shall possess all the powers and privileges and shall perform the duties of the regular members of the police force assigned to them by the mayor or the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 7-7-47, § 2)  
Sec. 22-6. - Same—Badge, uniform required. 
Every special constable shall, at his own expense, provide himself with a metal badge, silver plated or nickel plated, in the form of a shield, not less than two inches (2") long at the longest part, nor less than one inch and a half (1½") wide at the narrowest part, and lettered thus, in capital letters. 
SPECIAL 
CONSTABLE 
NEW HAVEN. 
Every special constable shall wear said badge affixed to some conspicuous place upon his outer clothing whenever executing the duties of this office, and he shall also wear such uniform as may be prescribed by the board of police commissioners. It shall be unlawful for any special constable to attempt to carry out any order, rule or regulation promulgated by proper authority when he is not wearing said uniform and badge. 
(Code 1928, §§ 604, 605; Ord. of 7-7-47, § 3)  
Sec. 22-7. - Same—Medical care for members injured on active duty. 
The city, as soon as it shall have knowledge of any accidental personal injury sustained by any member of such special constable unit and arising out of and in the course of the performance of the duties of such member while on active service or active police duty, shall provide a competent physician or surgeon to attend the said injured special constable, and in addition shall furnish such medical and surgical aid and hospital service as such physician shall deem reasonable or necessary. 
(Ord. of 7-7-47, § 5)  
Sec. 22-8. - Same—Compensation of members incapacitated while on duty. 
If any member of the special constable unit shall sustain an accidental personal injury arising out of and in the course of the performance of the duties of such member while on active service or active police duty, and if such accidental injury shall result in the total incapacity of such member to carry on his usual work, there shall be paid to such member a weekly compensation of seven dollars ($7.00); and such compensation shall not continue longer than the period of such total incapacity, or in any event longer than five hundred and twenty (520) weeks. The injuries described in section 5236 of the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1930, as the same is now amended shall be considered as causing total incapacity and compensable for the purpose of this section. 
(Ord. of 7-7-47, § 6) 
Editor's note— Section 5236 of the 1930 Revision of the general statutes, as amended, appears as § 31-161 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Chapter 24 - SUBSURFACE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1408, adopted March 6, 2006, amended and restated former Ch. 24 in its entirety and retitled the chapter from "Septic Tanks, Cesspools and Privies" to "Subsurface Sewage Disposal Systems." The legislative history notes in parentheses following the sections of this chapter include the section number formerly used in the 1985 reprinting, as amended. 
Cross reference— Connection with either public sewers or conforming private disposal facilities required, Plumbing Code Par. 312.0; Recommendations of state Health Department concerning construction and maintenance of cesspools, septic tanks and privies adopted in absence of provisions of ordinance, Plumbing Code Par. 313.0; for public sewers generally, see Ch. 25 of the old volume (in 6? × 9? format). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24-1. - Definitions, interpretation. 
This article's provisions are cumulative and supplement other city ordinances relating to health, waste disposal, cesspools, septic tanks, subsurface sewage disposal systems and their connections, the State Public Health Code and technical standards for subsurface sewage disposal as published by the Commissioner of Health. 
(Ord. of 11-8-48, §§ 1, 6; Code of 1985, § 24-1; Ord. No. 1408, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 24-2. - Connecting cesspools, privy vaults to public sewers. 
No person shall connect any cesspool or detached privy vault with any public sewer without permission from the city engineer for good cause shown. A cesspool or detached privy vault must be watertight in order to allow for a connection with any public sewer. When a cesspool or privy vault is connected with a public sewer, the discharge pipe from the cesspool or vault shall be trapped, and located as directed and approved by the city engineer and health director. 
(Code of 1928, § 690; Code of 1985, § 24-1.1; Ord. No. 1408, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 24-3. - Permit to construct or use cesspools, septic tanks-required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, lay, use, or cause a cesspool, septic tank or subsurface sewage disposal system to be constructed, laid or used within city limits without a written permit from the health director. Similarly, no pipes may be connected to a cesspool or septic tank without a written permit from him/her. The health director is authorized to grant such permits. The fee for said permit shall be as set out in this Code as amended from time to time. 
(b)  No repairs, alterations or expansions of subsurface sewage disposal systems shall occur without the health director's approval. 
(Ord. of 11-8-48, § 2; Code of 1985, § 24-2; Ord. No. 1304, Pt. I(k)(7), 12-17-01; Ord. No. 1408, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 24-4. - Same—Application, conditions of issuance. 
All permit applications required by the foregoing section shall be in writing, and made in the name of the owner of the premises on which the work will be done. The application shall set forth the street address of said premises, the name and address of the person doing the work, and such other information as required by the health director. The application shall be accompanied by a signed, written statement of the person doing the work, acknowledging that the construction, material used, and workmanship will comply with all rules and regulations made by the State Department of Public Health and this Code of Ordinances, and that he/she assumes full responsibility for any variances in the matter of construction, material used and workmanship. 
(Ord. of 11-8-48, § 3; Code of 1985, § 24-3; Ord. No. 1408, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 24-5. - Approval of sewer plans before commencing building construction.
