When the city engineer or his/her agent deems excavations unavoidable, they will be subject to special restoration requirements according to standard detail regulations as established and promulgated by the city engineer or his/her agent. 
(Code of 1985, § 27-45; Ord. of 10-18-95, § 2; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-82. - Penalty for violation of this article. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation who which violates any provision of this article III shall be subject to a fine in an amount up to the maximum allowed under state statute. Each day that the violation continues shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(b)  In addition to the fine set forth in subsection (a) above, upon a second violation, the director of public works or his/her agent shall have the authroity to suspend for thirty (30) days, any license and/or permit issued pursuant to this article III. 
(c)  In addition to the fine set forth in subsection (a) above, upon a third violation, the licensee's/permittee's license/permit shall be automatically suspended for a period of sixty (60) days, so that the licensee/permittee shall be prohibited from carying on such business in the city for a sixty (60) day period. 
(d)  In addition to the fine set forth in subsection (a) above, upon the licensee's/permittee's fourth violation, the license/permit shall be automatically suspended for a peirod of twelve (12) months so that the licensee/permitte shall be prohibited from carrying on such business in the city for said twelve (12) month period. 
(e)  Failure to comply with all of the requirements and conditions of this article III may result in revocation of the license/permit issued hereunder and/or in the commencement of such legal proceedings as may be necessary to enforce all such obligations. 
(Code of 1985, § 27-46; Ord. of 10-18-95, § 2; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-83. - Public utilities. 
(a)  Any public utility utilizing the city right-of-way as defined by the state statutes shall restore the roadway surfaces in accordance with city engineering standards. 
(b)  Nothing in these regulations shall be construed to prevent the making of any necessary excavation, or the performance of any related work by any public service company or holder of a properly issued easement in the event of an emergency. In the event of an emergency, the public utility company shall notify the city immediately or, if after hours, the start of the next business day, and apply for the required permit. Any public service company which has complied with the provisions of Conn. General Statutes section 16-230 as amended from time to time shall be exempted from the requirement of posting a bond as herein set forth. 
(Code of 1985, § 27-47; Ord. of 10-18-95, § 2; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-84. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by the imposition of a penalty pursuant to this article III may appeal such action in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 17-1.16 of this Code as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Secs. 27-85—27-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE, AND DEDICATION OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
 
Sec. 27-101. - Standards for construction, curbing, drainage of dedicated streets. 
No street or street extension shall be accepted by the city unless said design of such street conforms to the city engineering standards, or to the satisfaction of the city engineer, and until the following minimum specifications concerning road construction, curbing and drainage are complied with to the satisfaction of the city engineer or his/her duly authorized representative(s). All work shall be under the supervision of the city engineer or his/her duly authorized representative(s): 
(1)  City standards shall be published by the city engineer; 
(2)  Where city standards do not cover items of technical detail, state Department of Transportation, (DOT), standard specifications for road bridges and incidental construction shall apply; 
(3)  All utilities, storm sewers, sanitary sewers and services intended to support such road improvements shall be approved by the respective utility or authority. Final approval of the location of such utilities shall be to the satisfaction of the city engineer; 
(4)  A bond satisfactory to the city engineer and the corporation counsel to be furnished by the owner of said property for the faithful performance of the work in accordance with the specifications as outlined above; and 
(5)  Monuments shall be set at street corners and other control points designated by the city engineer. 
(Ord. of 4-2-56; Ord. of 8-5-57; Ord. of 8-3-59; Code of 1985, § 27-48; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-102. - Notice, hearing on recommendations to repair or build new sidewalks. 
(a)  The city engineer in consultation with the director of the department of public works is responsible for the repair of sidewalks as funded by the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Where sidewalks do not exist, the board of aldermen, after a public hearing held by the director of the department of public works, shall approve such installation. Once funded, the city engineer shall design and install such walkway as approved. All recommendations from the department of public works to the board of aldermen for the laying of any new sidewalk in the city shall be accompanied by the name of the owner of the property adjoining such sidewalk, or his/her agent, and the street and number of such property. Whenever a hearing is to be held concerning the laying of new sidewalks as aforesaid, the city clerk shall cause an advertisement to be published in the daily papers of such hearing for at least two (2) days prior to the time fixed for the hearing. Additionally, the city clerk shall cause notice to be given to said property owners, their agents, or persons having charge of said property or estate. Such notice shall be left at the usual place of abode of such property owner or his/her agent. If any person so interested does not reside in the city at the time, or under any legal disability, or in case the owner of such property is unknown, such notice shall be given as ordered by a judge of the Superior Court in the Judicial District of New Haven. 
(Code of 1928, § 755; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-49; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-103. - Authority of the director of the department of public works to lay, repair sidewalks; lien for costs. 
After due notice is given to an abutting property owner to repair a structurally defective sidewalk, the director of the department of public works is authorized to cause such repairs to be made if such owner fails to do so within thirty (30) days after such notice has been given. Such repairs are to be those that he/she believes are necessary to insure reasonable and safe use by the public, including the laying of curbs, sidewalks and gutters. The cost of the laying of any such sidewalk and the making of such repairs shall become a lien upon such property collectible as in the case of sewers and permanent street pavements. 
(Code of 1928, § 756; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-50; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-104. - Residential sidewalk repair. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the above section, the director of the department of public works is authorized to enter into a written agreement on behalf of the city with the owner/occupant(s) of residential property having no more than six (6) dwelling units, to repair any portion of, or an entire, structurally defective sidewalk abutting the property. Under this agreement, the city and the abutting property owner/occupant(s) will each pay fifty (50) percent of the costs of such sidewalk repair. Such costs are to be computed based upon the contracted unit price for such repair, and the area to be repaired, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  There must be sufficient funds available in the budget to make such repair; 
(2)  The city engineer or his/her designee, must find that the repair is appropriate and necessary; 
(3)  The city engineer shall have sole discretion in the direction and supervision of procurement rules for a contractor to effect such sidewalk repair; and 
(4)  The abutting property owner/occupant(s) must enter into a written agreement with the city to have the sidewalk repaired. 
The abutting property owner's share of the sidewalk repair cost shall be due and payable in full no later than twelve (12) months from the date such repair is completed. If payment is made within said period, then no interest shall accrue on the abutting property owner's fifty (50) percent share of the repair cost. If the abutting property owner fails to pay his/her share of the sidewalk repair cost within that period, then interest shall accrue from the payment due date on the unpaid portion at the rate of one (1) percent per month. The city shall have a lien for the property owner's share of the repair cost as provided in section 92 of the city charter as amended from time to time. In order to perfect such lien, a certificate of lien shall be recorded within sixty (60) days after the date on which the sidewalk repair covered by this section was completed. The lien shall be released upon payment of the property owner(s)'s share of the repair costs. 
(b)  The benefits of this section shall not be available to abutting property owners who: 
(1)  By their acts, or those of their employees/agents, caused the damage to the sidewalk for which repair is sought; or 
(2)  Owe any delinquent taxes to the city; or 
(3)  Are delinquent in any other financial obligation owed to the city. 
(Code of 1985, § 27-50.1; Ord. of 4-2-01; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-105. - Walk and curb contractors—License required; exception. 
No person, firm or corporation shall as contractor, engage in the work of constructing, relaying or repairing sidewalks, curbs or combined curb and gutter upon the public streets of the city unless licensed by the director of the department of public works. However, a property owner or his/her agent may make minor repairs to an existing walk in an area the length of which shall not exceed two (2) feet and the width of which shall not exceed two (2) feet, or to a curb not to exceed two (2) feet in length in front of which such walk or curb is located. 
(Code 1928, § 757; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-51; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-106. - Same—Application for license; conditions, duties. 
Every person applying for a license as a walk and curb contractor must file a satisfactory bond of a surety company authorized to do business in the city, in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with the city. The bond shall be conditioned substantially on the applicant indemnifying and saving harmless the city, said director and his/her agents from all suits and actions against said city, or any of its officers, for or on account of any injuries or damages received or sustained by any persons resulting from any work performed by them, or of or from any negligence in guarding said work, or of or from any act or omission of said applicant, his/her servants or agents. The applicant shall faithfully perform said work in all respects; and shall also replace and restore that portion of any street in which said applicant, his/her servants or agents shall make any excavation, to as good condition as that in which the same was before said work was performed. Said applicant shall comply in all respects with the rules and regulations established by the department of public works relative to such work, and with the terms or the permits which may be issued to him/her, and shall also pay all fines imposed upon him/her for violation of any such rule or regulation. He/she shall state in his/her application his/her actual place of business, together with the name under which the business is done, and shall notify the director of the department of public works of any change in either thereafter. He/she shall give personal attention to the work done under his/her license. 
(Code 1928, § 759; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-52; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-107. - Licenses; expiration and fee. 
All licenses concerning walk and curb contractors shall expire December 31 next following their date of issue, unless sooner revoked. The board of aldermen shall approve such license fee, and said fee shall be included in the portion of the Code that contains all fees. Said license is not transferable. 
(Code 1928, § 758; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-53; Ord. No. 1304, Pt. I(k)(13), 12-17-01; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-108. - Same—Duty to give notice before commencing work; oral permits. 
No licensee shall commence the construction, relaying or resetting of any sidewalk, curb, or combined curb and gutter until he/she has applied for and received a permit for doing said work from the city engineer or his/her agent. In an emergency the director of the department of public works or city engineer may permit a licensee to begin work upon oral notice, which shall be followed immediately by written permit. The fee shall be included in the portion of the code that contains all fees. 
(Code 1928, § 760; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-54; Ord. No. 1304, Pt. I(k)(14), 12-17-01; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-109. - Same—Availability of permit on job; condition of permit, revocation. 
The permit must be available on the job during the continuance of the work, and must be shown to all authorized persons when required. The licensee will also agree to comply with the special conditions printed on the back of the permit, including the following: 
(1)  All materials shall be promptly removed from the street. 
(2)  Work shall be done to the satisfaction of the city engineer, and in conformity with the city standards. The city may revoke permission now granted for just cause after the permit has been issued without payment of compensation or damages, and the said grantee, his/her or their heirs and assigns shall save the city harmless from all loss, cost or damage on account of the construction, maintenance, operations and use of said work. 
(Code 1928, § 760; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-55; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-110. - Adoption of rules, regulations governing construction. 
The city engineer is authorized and empowered to adopt, from time to time, such reasonable rules, regulations and specifications for the conduct of the work relating to sidewalks and curbs as he/she may deem appropriate and in the best interests of the city. Rules and regulations are to be made consistent with the City's Complete Streets Policy and the Complete Streets Design Manual of March, 2010. 
(Code 1928, § 762; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-57; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09; Ord. No. 1638, 9-7-10 )  
Sec. 27-111. - Penalty for violations of this article. 
Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article inclusive, shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), or an amount up to the maximum allowed under state statute. In the case of a licensed contractor found guilty of an offense, the contractor's license may be suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1928, § 764; Ord. of 10-6-41; Code of 1985, § 27-59; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Secs. 27-112—27-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - BRIDGES 
 
Sec. 27-131. - Bridge safety. 
(a)  The city engineer shall maintain an accurate inventory of bridges that exceed twenty (20) feet in length. He/she shall also review or cause to be reviewed the condition of the bridge to support the loading of vehicle and/or pedestrian usage. 
(b)  Should the bridge be deemed unsafe for specific vehicle usage, the city engineer shall restrict traffic loads to the load limit of the bridge capacity. 
(c)  Should a bridge be determined unsafe for any usage, the city engineer shall declare the bridge unsafe, and close said bridge to all traffic. Closure of any bridge shall be adequately signed and fully restricted to avoid any possible inadvertent traffic movement on walkways over bridges. 
(d)  Any bridge replacement shall be designed by a professional engineer, and conform to engineering standards for the type of bridge being installed. 
(Code of 1928, § 789; Code of 1985, § 27-67; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Secs. 27-132—27-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - UNACCEPTED STREETS 
 
Sec. 27-151. - "Unaccepted streets," defined. 
For the purposes of this chapter, an "unaccepted street" is a street, (right-of-way), that has been identified for public use where no or only partial improvements have been made, and where the city has not formally accepted the perpetual maintenance of the same. 
(Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-152. - Building permits on unaccepted streets. 
No building permit shall be issued on unaccepted streets without the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 8-1-66, § 1; Code of 1985, § 27-76; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-153. - Acceptance of unaccepted streets. 
All unaccepted streets will be accepted by the board of aldermen only as provided herein. 
(Ord. of 8-1-66, § 2; Code of 1985, § 27-77; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-154. - Procedure for acceptance of unaccepted streets. 
(a)  The following procedures shall apply to all unaccepted streets: 
A property owner and/or developer may petition the board of aldermen for acceptance of an unaccepted street. Such petitions shall be referred by the board of aldermen to the city plan commission for preliminary review, and if deemed appropriate, site plan review. If the petition is denied, the city plan commission shall notify the board of aldermen. If the petition is acceptable, the city plan commission shall conduct a formal site plan review in a manner consistent with section 64 of the New Haven Zoning Ordinance as it is amended from time to time, and obtain from the owner/developer documentation assuring that the street shall be improved in accordance with all city engineering standards, and be designed by a professional engineer licensed in the State of Connecticut. The owner/developer's plan shall consider any and all unique characteristics of the land and surrounding neighborhood and will assure implementation of all public improvements that support development of property consistent with the zoning laws of the city. Further, unless otherwise approved by the board of aldermen, such improvements shall be made at no expense to the city. Upon approval of the site plan, the city plan commission shall refer it to the board of aldermen for approval. 
(b)  Upon completion of all public improvements in accordance with the approved site plan, the city engineer shall petition the board of aldermen to accept the street for perpetual maintenance. 
(Ord. of 8-1-66, § 4; Code of 1985, § 27-79; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-155. - Official basis for administering article. 
The most current right-of-way information as used by the city shall serve as the official basis for administering this article. 
(Ord. of 8-1-66, § 5; Code of 1985, § 27-80; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-156. - Administration of article. 
(a)  The building official shall be responsible for the administration of issuing building permits on unaccepted streets as approved by the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Unless otherwise stated, the city engineer shall administer all other provisions, and shall be responsible to provide all necessary data and information to the board of aldermen as it may require to effectuate this article's provisions. 
(Ord. of 8-1-66, §§ 6, 7; Ord. of 1-5-81, § 1, Code of 1985, § 27-81; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-157. - Waiver. 
(a)  An applicant requesting a waiver of the prohibition against building on an unaccepted street shall file such request with the city's board of aldermen on such forms and shall follow such procedures as are prescribed by the board. 
(b)  The applicant shall indicate whether access over an unaccepted street is not more than two hundred fifty (250) feet in length, and a right-of-way fifty (50) feet in width, or that access can only be gained by passing over a right-of-way which is not within the ownership or control of the applicant or the present owners. 
(c)  In determining whether to waive the prohibition against the issuance of a building permit on an unaccepted street the following conditions shall apply: 
(1)  The lot(s) in the designated area shall comply with zoning regulations; 
(2)  The travel way to the property is maintainable and safe, i.e. can be plowed adequately, and provide for emergency services; 
(3)  There are no practical alternatives available to the applicant and the present owners to enable them to meet the requirements of this section; 
(4)  The denial of a waiver would effectively prohibit the use of the property for any purpose; 
(5)  There are adequate provisions for utilities, sewers and fire equipment access; 
(6)  The granting of such waiver would not significantly affect public safety; 
(7)  A petition for acceptance of the unaccepted street was denied by the city plan commission or board of aldermen. 
In granting a waiver, the board may attach such additional conditions as are deemed necessary to protect the neighborhood. Failure to comply with such conditions shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(Ord. of 1-5-81, § 2; Code of 1985, § 27-82; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-158. - Procedure for construction of unaccepted street. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the term "unaccepted street" shall mean any street, highway, passageway, alley, lane, court or driveway which serves as access to one or more lots, and which is not an accepted and approved city street or state highway. 
(b)  No unaccepted street, which serves as access from an accepted city street to more than one (1) dwelling unit, and which is in excess of one hundred (100) feet in length, shall be utilized as access to any dwelling unless such unaccepted street is designed and constructed in accordance with the standards of construction for accepted city streets, established by the city engineer, as may be amended from time to time, and which unaccepted street is approved by the board of aldermen, in a manner consistent with section 27-154 captioned "Procedure for acceptance of unaccepted streets." Said standards of the city engineer are to be considered the standards of the City of New Haven. 
(c)  No dwelling shall be erected on any lot which does not have frontage on a street, which is an accepted city street unless the unaccepted street to which the dwelling fronts is constructed in accordance with this section. 
(Code of 1985, § 27-83; Ord. of 3-19-90, § 1; Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Sec. 27-159. - Penalties for violations of this chapter. 
Any person violating any section in this chapter shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or an amount up to the maximum allowed under state statute. 
(Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Secs. 27-160—27-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PROCEDURE FOR ABANDONMENT OF STREETS 
 
Sec. 27-181. - Abandonment of streets. 
The following procedures shall apply where abandonment of accepted streets is requested: 
A property owner/developer shall petition the board of aldermen with a copy to the director of the department of public works. The board of aldermen shall refer the request to said director, who shall obtain any additional information pertinent to the request from the owner/developer, and shall hold a public hearing after notifying adjacent property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the roadway. The director of the department of public works will prepare a report after the public hearing, and submit it to the board of aldermen for their consideration in granting the request to abandon the street. Upon approval by the board of aldermen, the city town clerk will publish a public notice announcing the abandonment of the street. Appropriate documentation including an A-2 survey map shall be filed with the city engineer, the town clerk and the assessor identifying the land transfers as approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1426, 9-28-06; Ord. No. 1587, 4-20-09)  
Chapter 27½ - PUBLIC SWIMMING POOLS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Sept. 26, 1983, §§ 1—8 relative to public swimming pools did not specify manner of codification, and therefore, has been included by the editor as Ch. 27½, §§ 27½-1—27½-8. 
Ch. 27½ was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
 
Sec. 27½-1. - Title and scope. 
(a)  Title. This chapter shall be known as the "public swimming pool ordinance" may be so cited, and will be referred to as this chapter. 
(b)  Scope. The provisions of the chapter shall apply to all public swimming pools as hereinafter defined including all facilities incident thereto. The purpose of this chapter shall provide a guide for the operation and maintenance of such pools so that health hazards will be minimized. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 1.1, 1.2)  
Sec. 27½-2. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter. The word "shall" as used herein indicates a mandatory requirement. 
(1)  Swimming pool. Any structure of concrete, steel, or other relatively impervious material intended for bathing, swimming, or therapeutic purposes, located either indoors or outdoors, provided with controlled water supply (filtration, recirculation and chlorination) and having a depth of two (2) feet or more at any point. 
(2)  Public swimming pool. Any swimming pool other than a private residential swimming pool, intended to be used collectively by numbers of persons for swimming, bathing or therapeutic purposes, operated by any person as defined herein, whether he be owner, lessee, operator, licensee, or concessionaire, regardless of whether a fee is charged for such use. 
(3)  Private residential swimming pool. Any swimming pool, located on private property under the control of the home-owner, the use of which is limited to swimming or bathing purposes by family members or their invited guests. (The operation and maintenance of such pools are not subject to the provision of this chapter.) 
(4)  Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, governmental agency, club or organization of any kind. 
(5)  Director of public health. The director of public health of the City of New Haven or any duly or lawfully appointed member of his staff, as authorized by the board of health. 
(6)  Health department. Is the health department of the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 2.1—2.6)  
Sec. 27½-3. - License to operate. 
(a)  No person as defined in section 27½-2(4) shall operate or maintain a public swimming pool unless said person has obtained a license to operate such pool from the director of health. Such license shall be required upon application and or subsequent inspection, the first year of this chapter and on January 1, each year thereafter and shall be valid for one (1) year unless otherwise revoked for cause. Only persons who comply with this chapter and Section 19-13B33a of the Public Health Code of the State of Connecticut, shall be entitled to receive and retain such a license. Such licenses are not transferable. 
(b)  The director of health is authorized to promulgate regulations and establish fees to cover inspections and other services in connection with the operation and maintenance of public swimming pools for the protection and promotion of public health and safety. The health department shall perform inspections at reasonable hours to ensure compliance. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 3.1, 3.2)  
Sec. 27½-4. - Suspension of license. 
(a)  If upon inspection, conditions detrimental to the public's health are found, either due to violation of Section 19-13-B33a of the Connecticut Public Health Code, including negligence, faulty equipment or inadequate operational procedures, the director of health may, by written order, immediately suspend the license to operate the pool until such time as the conditions for the suspension have been corrected. 
(b)  A suspended license may be reinstated by written permission of the director of health when, upon reinspection, the conditions causing the suspension of the license have been corrected. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 4.1, 4.2)  
Sec. 27½-5. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The director of health may revoke any license to operate a pool for failure to comply with a written order following suspension of the license, or where the license has been obtained through nondisclosure, misrepresentation, or mis-statement of a material fact. 
(b)  Before a license is revoked, the person to whom the permit has been issued shall have notice in writing enumerating the instances causing such revocation. 
(c)  After revocation, a license to operate shall be reissued upon proper reapplication and upon presentation of evidence that the deficiencies causing revocation have been corrected. A re-license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will be required for all reissued licenses. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 5.1—5.3; Ord. of 4-15-85, § 8; Ord. of 5-24-99)  
Sec. 27½-6. - Appeal. 
The person or persons to whom the license was issued may appeal a written order by the director of health. The appeal shall be made in writing and shall be received by the director of health within two (2) working days after receipt of the order. The director of health shall immediately review the case and may vacate, modify, or affirm such order. The licensee aggrieved by the action of the director of health, may within forty-eight (48) hours after the making of such decision, appeal to the state commissioner of health, who shall thereupon immediately notify the authority from whose order the appeal was taken, and examine into the merits of such case, and may vacate, modify, or affirm such action. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, § 6.1)  
Sec. 27½-7. - Inspection. 
(a)  The director of health is authorized to conduct such inspections as it deems necessary to insure compliance with all provisions of this chapter and shall have right of entry at any reasonable hour to the swimming pool for this purpose. 
(b)  After issuance of a license, water samples for analysis will be obtained from each pool on a schedule as determined by the director of health. Analysis of the water samples will include coliform, free chlorine, chlorine and pH level determination; in addition, a visual inspection of water clarity and the pool area will be effected. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 7.1, 7.2)  
Sec. 27½-8. - Fees for license. 
(a)  The fee for a license to conduct, operate and maintain a public swimming pool shall be as set out in section 17-20 of this Code. 
(b)  An owner or operator may request the director of health to perform an additional water analysis at any reasonable time. The fee for this request shall be as set out in section 17-20 of this Code. 
(c)  Also, as a public service to individual home owners with nonpublic pools, the director of health, will, upon request, during the months of June, July and August, analyze pool water taken from individual nonpublic pools for a fee as set out in section 17-20 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 9-26-83, §§ 8.1—8.3; Ord. of 4-15-85, § 8; Ord. of 6-6-88, § 6a; Ord. of 5-24-99; Ord. No. 1345, 2-2-04; Ord. No. 1386, 7-5-05)  
Chapter 28 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ch. 28 was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
Charter reference— Preparation, recommendation of annual appropriations and tax rate, § 58; board of tax review, § 65; department of assessments, § 81. See also Compilation of Special Laws, §§ 55—68. 
 
Sec. 28-1. - List of exempt property prepared by assessor. 
The assessor shall annually, on or before the first day of June, present to the mayor, to be by him presented to the board of aldermen, an accurate, detailed statement of all lands and buildings on which local taxes are not assessed, giving locations, descriptions, assessor's valuations, names of owners, and reason for exemptions. Said report shall include the results of an audit by the assessor of tax-exempt commercial activity undertaken by nonprofit entities to ensure conformance with local and state tax requirements, and said report shall also contain the valuation of personal property owned by tax-exempt institutions and utilities. Failure to comply with reports and information required by the assessor pursuant to this section shall result in a penalty payable to the City of New Haven of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per parcel per day of failure to comply. 
(Code 1928, § 840; Ord. of 8-5-85)  
Sec. 28-2. - Issuance of tax bills, warrants. 
Whenever any tax has been duly laid, the mayor and the controller shall prepare and sign a proper rate bill therefor; and the mayor shall cause such rate bill with a proper warrant for the collection of such tax to be delivered to the collector. 
(Code 1928, § 838; Ord. of 8-2-93)  
Sec. 28-3. - Due date for taxes not exceeding fifty dollars. 
Any property tax laid by said city and due on the grand list of 1954, or on the grand list of any year thereafter, and which does not exceed the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00), shall become due and payable in a single payment on the first day of January next after said tax is laid. If such tax shall not be paid on or before the first day of February next after the same becomes payable, interest shall be charged thereon, after said date, at the same rate that interest is legally charged on other delinquent property taxes due the city. 
(Ord. of 12-6-54) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to establish due date for taxes under $50.00, § 12-144 Conn. Gen. Stats. (Rev. 1958).  
Sec. 28-4. - Tax abatement on low and moderate income housing. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section 28-4: 
Low and moderate income housing means housing, the construction or rehabilitation of which is aided or assisted in any way by any federal or state statute, which housing is subject to regulation or supervision or rents, charges or sale prices and methods of operation by a governmental agency under a regulatory agreement or other instrument which restricts occupancy of such housing to persons or families whose incomes do not exceed prescribed limits. 
Owner means a person or persons, partnership, joint venture, or corporation who or which has executed, or will execute, a regulatory agreement or other instrument with a governmental agency, either federal, state or local, which limits occupancy of the low and moderate income housing owned or to be owned by such person or persons, partnership, joint venture or corporation to persons or families whose income do not exceed prescribed limits. 
(b)  Contracts for abatement. The mayor may, with the approval of the board of aldermen, enter into contracts for the city with owners of low and moderate income housing, granting abatement, in whole or in part, of the taxes on the real estate used for such low and moderate income housing. The amount of such abatement shall be established in each such contract, giving due consideration to the purpose or purposes to which the money equivalent of the taxes so abated is to be applied. Each such contract shall require that the owner apply the money equivalent of the taxes so abated to one or more of the following specified purposes: (1) to reduce rents below the levels which would be achieved in the absence of abatement; (2) to improve housing quality and design; (3) to effect occupancy by persons and families of varying income levels, within prescribed limits; or (4) to provide necessary related facilities or services. 
(c)  Term. The abatement shall become effective on the date specified in the contract between the city and an owner of low and moderate income housing. The term of abatement shall extend for the remainder of the fiscal year in which abatement becomes effective and may continue for a period not to exceed thirty-nine (39) consecutive fiscal years thereafter; provided, that such abatement shall terminate at any time when the property for which tax abatement has been granted is not used solely for low and moderate income housing; and provided, further, that the continuation of such abatement may be conditioned upon the continuation of state reimbursement to the city for such abatement. The abatement authorized herein shall be granted only for low and moderate income housing upon which construction or rehabilitation commenced after July 1, 1967. Any contract heretofore entered into between the City of New Haven and an owner of low and moderate income housing may be amended by the parties to extend the period of abatement up to thirty-nine (39) years in accordance with this section. 
(d)  State assistance. The mayor shall, with the approval of the board of aldermen, executed on behalf of the city contracts with the state for financial assistance by the state in the form of reimbursement for the tax abatement granted to an owner of low and moderate income housing in accordance with this section 28-4. 
(Ord. of 1-8-68; Ord. of 11-10-69) 
Editor's note— An ordinance enacted January 8, approved January 15, operative and effective January 25, 1968, amended this Code by adding § 28-4. An ordinance enacted Nov. 10, approved Nov. 14 and effective Dec. 4, 1969, amended § 28-4(c) by increasing the number of fiscal years from 19 to 39 and adding the authority to amend contracts with owners of housing to extend the period of abatement.  
Sec. 28-5. - Abatement of taxes on structures of historical or architectural merit. 
(a)  Authority to provide. In accordance with Section 12-127a of the Connecticut General Statutes, the City of New Haven may provide for the abatement in whole or in part of real property taxes on structures of historical or architectural merit, for such time as determined necessary by the committee on tax abatement, in accordance with the purpose of this section. 
(b)  Duty to determine eligibility of structures for abatement. Determination of which historical or architecturally meritorious structures shall be eligible for potential tax abatement shall be made by the aldermanic committee on tax abatement after written recommendation of the city plan commission and the New Haven Preservation Trust. 
(c)  To whom abatement available; committee to request advisory reports. Such tax abatement shall be available to the owners of real property which is so classified if upon petition and after public hearing it can be shown to the satisfaction of the aldermanic committee on tax abatement with the current level of taxation as a material factor which threatens the continued existence of the structure, necessitating either its demolition or remodeling in a manner which destroys the historical or architectural value. In reaching their decision, the aldermanic committee on tax abatement shall request from the city plan commission, the New Haven Preservation Trust and from the New Haven Historic District Commission, where appropriate, a written recommendation as to whether the required relief should be granted. Such advisory reports shall be available at the time of the public hearing. 
(d)  Payment of taxes, interest when structure demolished, remodeled. If, after taxes on such structure have been abated under the terms of this section, such structure is demolished or remodeled in a way which destroys its architectural or historical value, the then owners shall pay to the City of New Haven an amount equal to the total amount of taxes which had been abated under the provisions of this section, plus reasonable interest thereon as determined by the aldermanic committee on tax abatement. 
(e)  Contracts for state financial assistance. The City of New Haven may enter into a contract for state financial assistance for structures of historical and architectural merit in the form of reimbursement for tax abatement according to the terms of Section 12-127a of the Connecticut General Statutes. Such contract shall provide that payments shall be made annually in an amount equal to the difference between the taxes that would be paid on such property were there no abatement and the taxes actually paid by the owners and that in consideration of such grant-in-aid the municipality shall abate taxes to the agreed amount during the period of the contract. If an owner repays the tax abatement to the City of New Haven as provided in subsection (d) of this section, such repayment shall be returned to the state. 
(Ord. of 4-3-72, §§ 1—5) 
Editor's note— Ord. of April 3, 1972, §§ 1—5 did not specifically amend this Code, hence inclusion herein as §§ 28-5 was at the discretion of the editors.  
Sec. 28-6. - Admissions tax on certain places licensed by the State Commission of Revenue Services. 
(a)  Authority to impose. In accordance with Chapter 226a of the Connecticut General Statutes (sections 12-579 to 12-582), the City of New Haven hereby imposes a tax of ten (10) percent of the admission charge, as defined in subsection (3) of section 12-540, to any place licensed by the State Gaming Policy Board and containing a pari-mutuel system therein or to any off-tract betting facility located within the City of New Haven. 
(b)  Collection. The tax, as provided in subsection (a) above, shall be imposed, administered and collectable in accordance with Chapter 226a of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended (sections 12-579 to 12-582). 
(c)  Appeals. Any taxpayer aggrieved because of any order, decision, determination or disallowance of the tax collector of the City of New Haven under the provisions of Chapter 226A of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended (sections 12-579 to 12-582) and this section of the Code of Ordinances, may take an appeal therefrom to the Superior Court, Judicial District of New Haven at New Haven, in accordance with the provisions of said Chapter 226a of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended. 
(d)  Effective date; not to affect receipt of other taxes. This section shall take effect from its passage and shall apply to all monies already collected by the Teletrack off-track betting facility as a municipal admission tax in anticipation of the passage of this section. Further, nothing in this section shall be construed to repeal the election of the City of New Haven to receive a portion of the sales tax imposed upon sales within the meaning of subdivision (h) of subsection (2) of section 12-407 by any hotel or lodging house located within the City of New Haven, pursuant to section 7-136b(b) of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Ord. of 5-28-80)  
Sec. 28-7. - Staged increases in real property tax assessments. 
(a)  Any increase in assessed values on the list of October 1, 1991, shall be gradually phased in, according to the ratio set forth in 12-62c, Conn. Gen. Stats., as amended by P.A. 91-79. 
Said statute essentially provides for the excess of said excess assessment on any piece of real property shall be divided into five (5) equal increments, and each of said increments shall be effective on each of the succeeding five (5) list years, thereby successively increasing each such real property assessment increase until the full assessments originally fixed in October 1, 1991, is implemented. 
(b)  Any decrease in any property assessment shall be fully effective on the list of October 1, 1991. 
(c)  Notice of the amounts of each of said phased assessments of said five-year period shall be delivered to each taxpayer of real property simultaneously with each of the succeeding four (4) annual assessment notices. 
(Ord. of 10-4-78; Ord. of 12-12-78; Ord. of 10-7-91) 
Editor's note— An Ordinance adopted Oct. 4, 1978, which was nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified in Ch. 28 at the request of the city. Designation of said ordinance, as amended, as a new § 28-7 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Note— An Ordinance adopted June 23, 1994, exercised the option of the City of New Haven, pursuant to Section 51 of Bill No. 6003 entitled "An Act Modifying Certain Taxes Affecting Business and Individuals" (hereinafter referred to as the "Act"), to stay further implementation of the "Ordinance Providing for Staged Increases in Certain Real Property Tax Assessments" (hereinafter referred to as the "phase-in"), which ordinance is codified as section 28-7 of the Code of General Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut. 
Exercising the option to stay further implementation of the phase-in thereby ratifies the estimated Net Grand List of October 1, 1993, as specified in the Tax Levy and Revenue Appropriating Ordinance for Fiscal Year 1994-95, and as otherwise utilized for the preparation, estimation, and implementation of the budget, tax levy, and revenue estimates for the fiscal year commencing on July 1, 1994, as specifically allowed for in the Act.  
Sec. 28-8. - Limited exemption from real property taxation of certain solar energy heating or cooling systems, solar energy electricity generating systems and passive solar energy systems. 
(a)  Authority to provide. In accordance with subsections (56), (57) and (61) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended, the City of New Haven, hereby authorizes, commencing with the October 1, 1981, grand list, the exemption from real property taxation of eligible solar energy heating or cooling systems, solar energy electricity generating systems for private residential uses only and passive solar energy systems as set forth within this section. 
(b)  Eligibility, extent and duration. Solar energy heating or cooling systems, solar energy electricity generating systems for private residential use only and passive or hybrid solar energy heating or cooling systems, which meet the requirements of subsections (56), (57) or (61) of Section 12-81 of the General Statutes, as amended, and the regulations promulgated thereunder, respectively, shall be eligible for not more than fifteen (15) successive annual limited exemptions from real property taxation as set forth in said subsections and regulations. 
(c)  Procedure. The exemption shall be waived for any assessment year, unless any person who desires to claim said exemption files, with the assessor between October 1st and October 31st each year, a written application claiming such exemption on Form 12-246-28, entitled "Alternative Energy Systems," of the State Department of Revenue Services or such other form as is prescribed by the State Commissioner of Revenue Services. 
(d)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by the action of the assessors relating to a claim of exemption as provided herein may appeal the doing of the assessor to the New Haven Board of Tax Review and the Superior Court, Judicial District of New Haven at New Haven, as provided for in Sections 12-110 to 12-119 of the General Statutes, as amended. 
(Ord. of 1-5-81) 
Editor's note— Due to the prior existence of a § 28-7, the editor has redesignated as § 28-8, provisions originally adopted as § 28-7 by an ordinance of Jan. 5, 1981, approved Jan. 12, 1981, and effective Jan. 24, 1981.  
Sec. 28-9. - Fixed tax assessment in the enterprise zone. 
(a)  Authority to provide. In accordance with Public Act 81-445, as amended by Public Act 82-435, the City of New Haven, which has designated an area within the city as an enterprise zone, shall provide for the fixing of assessment on all real property in the zone. 
(b)  Eligibility. All real property within the enterprise zone which is improved during the period when such area is designated as an enterprise zone shall be eligible for the fixing of assessments. No improvements of any real property which qualifies as a manufacturing facility under Section 32-9p(d) of the Connecticut General Statutes shall be eligible for any fixed assessment pursuant to this section. 
(c)  Duration of fixed assessment. Fixed assessment on real property improvements shall be for a period of seven (7) years from the time of the completion of improvement. Any increase in assessment attributable to such improvements shall be fixed as follows: For the construction period and for the first and second years following completion of such improvements, the entire increase shall be deferred; for the third year following such completion, fifty (50) percent of the increase shall be assessed against the property; thereafter an additional ten (10) percent of the increase shall be assessed each year against the property until, in the eighth year, one hundred (100) percent of the increase has been assessed. 
(d)  Cessation of fixed assessment. Any fixed assessment on any residential property in the enterprise zone shall cease if: 
(1)  For any residential rental property, any dwelling unit in such property is rented to any person whose income exceeds two hundred (200) percent of the median family income of the City of New Haven; or 
(2)  For any conversion condominium declared after the designation of the enterprise zone, any unit is sold to any other person whose income exceeds two hundred (200) percent of the median family income of the City of New Haven. 
(e)  General revaluation. In the event of a general revaluation by the City of New Haven in the year in which such improvement is completed, resulting in any increase in assessment on such property, only that portion of the increase resulting from such improvement shall be deferred. In the event of a general revaluation in any year after the year in which such improvement is completed, such deferred assessment shall be increased or decreased in proportion to the increase or decrease in the total assessment on such property as a result of such evaluation. 
(f)  [Effective date.] This section shall not be in effect until the board of aldermen designate an enterprise zone within the City of New Haven. 
(g)  Administration. The enterprise zone assessment deferral program will be administered as described in the enterprise zone guidelines and enterprise zone administrative procedures, as approved. 
(Ord. of 1-24-83; Ord. of 9-4-84) 
Editor's note— Aldermanic designation of the enterprise zone was adopted January 24, 1983.  
Sec. 28-10. - Tax reports required of tax-exempt organizations. 
The assessor shall secure from any organization in the City of New Haven claiming an exemption from property tax, whether personal or real, under the provisions of Section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes, Revision of 1958, and which files a Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax (Form 990) or a Federal Unrelated Business Income Tax Return (Form 990T) with the federal government, a copy of said Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax (Form 990) and Federal Unrelated Business Income Tax Return (Form 990T) within three (3) months of its being filed. 
(Ord. of 8-12-85)  
Sec. 28-11. - Additional exemption from property taxation—For blind persons. 
Authority to provide. In accordance with the provision of PA 85-165 as approved by the General Assembly of the State of Connecticut on May 13, 1985, the City of New Haven hereby authorizes, commencing with the October, 1986 Grand List, the additional exemption from property taxation of up to two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) of assessed value for property belonging to, or held in trust for any blind person, resident of the State of Connecticut, or lacking said out of property in his own name, so much of the property belonging to or held in trust for his spouse, who is domiciled with him, as is necessary to equal said amount, who meets the following qualifications and procedures: 
(1)  The person qualifies for three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) of exemption of assessed value of property under the provisions of subsection (17) of section 12-81 of the general statutes of the State of Connecticut. 
(2)  The total of such persons's adjusted gross income as determined for purposes of the federal income tax plus any other income of such person not included in such adjusted gross income, individually if unmarried, or jointly if married, in the calendar year ending immediately preceding the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is allowed, is not more than fourteen thousand dollars ($14,000.00) if such person is married, or not more than twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) if such person is not married. 
(3)  Such person files an application, on a form prepared for such purpose by the assessor, not later than the date of the assessment list with respect to which such additional exemption is claimed. 
(4)  Each such application shall include a copy of such person's federal income tax return, or in the event a return is not filed, such evidence related to income as may be required by the assessor for the tax year of such person ending immediately prior to the approval of a claim for such additional exemption. 
(Ord. of 4-7-86)  
Sec. 28-12. - Same—For certain veterans and veterans' spouses. 
In accordance with the provisions of Public Act 85-432 as approved by the General Assembly of the State of Connecticut on June 25, 1985, commencing with the October 1, 1986 Grand List: 
(1)  a.  Any veteran who is entitled to an exemption from property tax in accordance with subsection (19) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes shall be entitled to an additional exemption applicable to the assessed value of property up to the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), provided that the total of such veteran's qualifying income, does not exceed twenty-six thousand five hundred dollars ($26,500.00), individually, if unmarried, or thirty-two thousand dollars ($32,300.00) jointly, if married, in the calendar year ending immediately preceding the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is allowed. 
b.  Any veteran's surviving spouse entitled to an exemption from property tax in accordance with subsection (22) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes shall be entitled to an additional exemption applicable to the assessed value of property up to the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), provided the total of such spouse's qualifying income does not exceed twenty-six thousand five hundred dollars ($26,500.00) in the calendar year ending immediately preceding the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is allowed. 
(2)  a.  Any veteran entitled to an exemption from property tax in accordance with subsection (19) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes shall be entitled to an additional local option exemption applicable to the assessed value of property up to the amount of ten (10) percent or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) whichever amount is smaller, provided that the total of such veteran's qualifying income, does not exceed thirty-nine thousand six hundred dollars ($39,600.00), individually, if unmarried, or forty-five thousand six hundred dollars ($45,600.00) jointly, if married, in the calendar year ending immediately preceding the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is allowed. 
b.  Any veteran's surviving spouse entitled to an exemption from property tax in accordance with subsection (22) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes shall be entitled to an additional exemption applicable to the assessed value of property up to the amount of ten (10) percent or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) whichever is less, provided the total of such spouse's qualifying income does not exceed thirty-nine thousand six hundred dollars ($39,600.00) in the calendar year ending immediately preceding the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is allowed. 
(3)  Any such veteran or spouse submitting a claim for such additional exemption shall be required to file an application on a form prepared for such purpose by the assessor, not later than the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is claimed. Each such application shall include a copy of such veteran's or spouse's federal income tax return for 2007, or in the event such a return is not filed, such evidence related to income as may be required by the assessor, for the tax year of such veteran or spouse ending immediately prior to the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is claimed. 
(4)  Any veteran with a condition of disability enabling such veteran to qualify for the exemption from property tax in accordance with subsections (20) or (21) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes shall be entitled to an exemption from property taxation of one hundred (100) percent of the assessed value of any one (1) motor vehicle, provided, however, that such motor vehicle must be specially equipped for purposes of adapting its use to the disability of such veteran. 
(5)  Pursuant to subsection (21)(c) of section 12-81 of the general statutes, and effective commencing with the grand list of October 1, 2000, the dwelling house and the lot whereupon the same is erected, belonging to or held in trust for any citizen and resident of the city, occupied as such person's domicile shall be fully exempt from local property taxation, if such person is a veteran who served in the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Coast Guard or Air Force of the United States and has received financial assistance for specially adapted housing under the provisions of Section 801 of Title 38 of the United States Code and has applied such assistance toward the acquisition or modification of such dwelling house. In the event that such acquisition or modification shall occur after October 1, 2000, then such exemption shall become effective on the date of such acquisition or modification. The same exemption shall also be provided on such housing unit owned by the surviving spouse of such veteran (i) while such spouse remains a widow or widower, or (ii) upon the termination of any subsequent marriage of such spouse by dissolution, annulment or death, or by such veteran and spouse while occupying such premises as a residence. 
(Ord. of 4-7-86; Ord. No. 1297, 12-3-01; Ord. No. 1444, 3-5-07)  
Sec. 28-13. - Same—For persons permanently and totally disabled. 
(a)  In accordance with the provisions of PA 85-294 approved by the General Assembly of the State of Connecticut on June 4, 1985, the City of New Haven hereby authorizes any person entitled to the exemption from property tax applicable to the assessed value of property up to the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), as provided under subsection (55) of section 12-81 of the Connecticut General Statutes, shall be entitled to an additional exemption from such tax in an amount up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of such assessed value, provided the total of such person's adjusted gross income as determined for purposes of the federal income tax plus any other income of such person not included in such adjusted gross income, individually if unmarried, or jointly if married, in the calendar year ending immediately preceding the assessment date with respect to which such additional exemption is allowed, is not more than fourteen thousand dollars ($14,000.00) if such person is married, or not more than twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) if such person is not married. 
(b)  Any person submitting a claim for the additional exemption as provided under (a), above, of this section shall be required to file an application, on a form prepared for such purpose by the assessor, not later than the date of the assessment list with respect to which such additional exemption is claimed. Each such application shall include a copy of such person's federal income tax return, or in the event a return is not filed such evidence related to income as may be required by the assessor for the tax year of such person ending immediately prior to the approval of a claim for such additional exemption. 
(Ord. of 4-7-86)  
Sec. 28-14. - Same—For businesses offering child day care services to residents. 
(a)  Authority to provide; eligibility. In accord with section 12-81n of the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958 as amended, there is established a program of property tax exemption for any business, subject to the corporation business tax imposed pursuant to chapter 208 of said statutes and operating on premises owned by it within the geographical boundaries of the City of New Haven, which offers child day care services on said premises to residents of the city, provided such business is not regularly engaged in the construction or operation of child day care facilities. No business shall be deemed ineligible for participation because it operates the child day care facility through a subsidiary incorporated and functioning solely to effect such operation when the only advantages to the business of such subsidiarization are (1) to enhance the administration of such facility and (2) to limit the liability of the business for the actions or negligence of the subsidiary or its employees or agents. 
(b)  Exemption provided. Any business which participates in the program shall receive exemption of one hundred (100) percent of the assessed value of the otherwise taxable real property of the business used exclusively in providing child day care services at a designated facility, provided that the business must be the taxpayer responsible for the payment of city taxes which (in the absence of the exemption provided by this section) would become due with respect to such property. Each such exemption shall be valid for a single year. No such exemption may be transferred to another business, facility, or location. 
(c)  Financial assistance. Any business which participates in the program shall provide financial assistance, in the form of reductions in the tuition payable by the parents or guardians of children enrolled in the child day care service, with a total value each year equal to not less than twenty-five (25) percent of the tax savings obtained by the business for the same year as a result of the exemption received under the program. The financial assistance required by this subsection shall be provided only to families, residing in New Haven, whose incomes do not exceed two hundred (200) percent of the poverty level determined by the appropriate state authority. The business shall advertise the requirement for and availability of the financial assistance. 
(d)  Application. Any business wishing to apply for participation in this program shall do so in writing, using such form or forms as the human resources administrator shall provide for such purpose or (if such forms are not provided) on the letterhead of the applicant. Each such application shall include: 
(1)  The name and address of the business, with the name, title, and telephone number of the owner or officer of the business authorized to represent the business in regard to the application and any matters pertaining thereto; and 
(2)  The name (if different) under which the child day care facility operates; and 
(3)  A description of the property for which the exemption is requested, including the street address, the assessment section-map-block-parcel number, and a diagram showing the location and square footage of interior and exterior spaces used exclusively by the child day care facility; and 
(4)  A copy of its valid license, issued by the appropriate state authority, to operate the child day care facility on the property for which the exemption is requested; and 
(5)  A list showing the name and address of each child presently enrolled in the facility, with one notation stating the number of such children who are minorities and a second notation stating the number of families of such children whose incomes do not exceed two hundred (200) percent of the poverty level; and 
(6)  Evidence that the facility is accredited by or is in the process of applying for accreditation by the National Association for the Education of Young Children; and 
(7)  Brochures, advertising copy, or other materials used to market the service; and 
(8)  A list of all property, real or personal, owned by it which is located within the city, with a statement that no tax payments pertaining to those properties are delinquent; and 
(9)  In an instance where the business has previously applied for or received the exemption, such other information as the human resources administrator may require to ensure that deficiencies, if any, have been satisfactorily addressed; and 
(10)  An oath, acknowledged in accord with chapter 6 of said statutes, that the statements made and information provided in or with the application is true and complete to the best knowledge of the owner or officer submitting the application. 
It shall be the responsibility of the human resources administrator, acting with the assistance of such other city officials as may be appropriate, to determine whether the business has satisfied the requirements, and is therefore eligible in principle for participation in the program as established by this section. The business shall provide such additional information or documentation as the human resources administrator may deem necessary to fulfill the responsibilities imposed by this section. The information and documentation enumerated hereinbefore shall be submitted to the human resources administrator within fifteen (15) days of the effective date of this section [February 6, 1992] for businesses requesting the exemption for the grand list of October 1, 1991, and no later than the fifteenth day of September annually thereafter for businesses requesting the exemption for the grand list next following that date. 
(e)  Assessment. The human resources administrator shall deliver to the city assessor, within fifteen (15) days following the applicable deadline specified in subsection (d) hereinbefore, the application of any business deemed eligible for participation in the program. The city assessor shall demarcate and value the real property of the business used exclusively in providing child day care services, and shall exempt the assessment on such property (if any) from taxation for the tax year corresponding to the grand list then in preparation. An applicant may be required to provide such other information or documentation as the city assessor may deem necessary to enable him to fulfill the responsibilities imposed upon him by this subsection or other applicable laws. A business dissatisfied with the determinations of the city assessor pursuant to this section may appeal those determinations in the manner provided by law. 
(f)  Reporting. For each exemption granted pursuant to subsection (e) hereinbefore, the business receiving it shall submit to the human resources administrator by the fifteenth day of June next following the grand list date, and by the fifteenth day of December and June during the tax year in which the exemption is effective, a report on its compliance with all of the requirements of this section. The human resources administrator shall compile all such reports and shall communicate them, with such comments as he may deem appropriate, to the board of aldermen promptly thereafter. The city assessor shall include each exemption granted pursuant to this section in the annual report required by section 2½-7(c) of this Code of General Ordinances. 
(g)  Voiding of exemption. Notwithstanding the preceding provisions of this section, the exemption granted to a business by the city assessor pursuant to this section shall be null and void: 
(1)  If, at the time of preparation of the tax bills for the tax year in which the business has been granted the exemption or at any subsequent time during such tax year, the business is or becomes delinquent in its payment of any taxes due to the City of New Haven; or 
(2)  If the business loses its license (by suspension, revocation, or expiration) from the state to operate the child day care facility; or 
(3)  If the business ceases to operate the child day care facility. 
(Ord. of 1-21-92) 
Editor's note— Ord. of April 6, 1987, § 1, approved by the mayor April 10, 1987, and effective April 23, 1987, repealed § 28-14, pertaining to personal property assessment list filing, as derived from an ordinance enacted Jan. 20, 1987, Provisions similar to those formerly contained in § 28-14 are set out in § 2-37(b). Subsequently an ordinance adopted Jan. 21, 1992, added a new § 28-14.  
Sec. 28-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Dec. 21, 1998, provided for the repeal of § 18-15, definitions, derived from an ordinance adopted Mar. 2, 1987, and similar provisions were designated as § 2-154.  
Sec. 28-16. - List of taxable property prerequisite to license, or permit. 
Effective with the passage of this section, no person shall be granted by the City of New Haven, a license or permit of the type enumerated in the sections 14-11, 17-20, 17-21, 23-1 or 23-8 of the [Code of Ordinances] unless that person has filed a list of taxable property if required to do so by Connecticut General Statutes section 12-42, provided that nothing in this section shall be so construed as to prohibit the issuance of any building permit issued pursuant to the Building Code of the State of Connecticut. 
(Ord. of 3-2-87; Ord. of 10-16-89, § 1; Ord. of 2-18-97, §§ 1—3; Ord. of 7-6-98; Ord. of 12-21-98)  
Sec. 28-17. - Exemption from personal property taxation of certain ambulance-type motor vehicles. 
(a)  Exemption. Effective commencing with the grand list of October 1, 1996, the city assessor, acting pursuant to Section 12-81c of the state statutes and in accord with the definitions, prerequisites, and limitations specified hereinafter, shall exempt from personal property taxation any ambulance-type motor vehicle which is used exclusively for the purpose of transporting any medically incapacitated individual, except any such vehicle used to transport any such individual for profit. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of implementing this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Ambulance-type motor vehicle means any motor vehicle which is (i) specially equipped or modified in a significant way for the purpose of transporting medically incapacitated individuals, including but not limited to the inclusion of lifts or handbrakes, the equipping with stretchers, beds or other special seating and equipment such as oxygen, or (ii) specially equipped for the physically disabled, including but not limited to lifts for wheelchairs, computer-type dash boards, braking and accelerating mechanisms for manual operation and other such devices designed to permit physically disabled persons to use and operate motor vehicles. 
(2)  Medically incapacitated individual means a person who has been certified by a physician as having a physical or other medical disability that justifies the special equipping of or modification to the ambulance-type motor vehicle. 
(3)  Any such vehicle used to transport any such individual for profit means the payment or receipt of money, goods, or services in exchange for conveying one (1) or more medically incapacitated individuals in an ambulance-type motor vehicle. 
(c)  Prerequisites. 
(1)  Before such exemption may be implemented, said assessor shall require the owner of such motor vehicle to file a written application for such exemption with the office of the city assessor no later than November 1st following the assessment year with respect to which such exemption is requested or, if such vehicle shall be purchased or relocated to the city on or after September 1st and on or before July 31st of the assessment year for which such exemption is requested, no later than sixty (60) calendar days after such purchase or relocation. With respect to the assessment year commencing on October 1st, 1996, such application shall be filed no later than December 2nd, 1996. 
(2)  Such application shall contain such information and be in such form as said assessor shall deem necessary for the proper implementation of this ordinance. 
(3)  Said assessor shall require the owner to submit documentation from a physician (i) explaining the physical or medical disability of the medically incapacitated individual to be transported and (ii) certifying that the special equipment installed in such vehicle and/or the modification made to such vehicle is justified by the physical or other medical disability of the individual to be transported. 
(4)  Said assessor may require the owner of such motor vehicle to submit additional documentation to substantiate the application for exemption. 
(5)  Said assessor shall require a physical inspection of such motor vehicle. 
(d)  Limitations. In order to ensure that such motor vehicle is and shall be used only for the purposes of this section, the following limitations are imposed: 
(1)  The owner of such motor vehicle must be an individual person, that is, the owner may not be a partnership, corporation, firm, business, etc. 
(2)  Such motor vehicle may not be used in the ordinary course of the business or other employment of the medically incapacitated individual, or of the owner or any operator of such vehicle if said owner or operator is not the medically incapacitated individual; nor may any use of such vehicle make such medically incapacitated individual, or owner or operator, eligible to obtain (i) any reimbursement for any costs associated with such use or (ii) any federal or state income-tax deductions or credits associated with such use. 
(3)  No more than one (1) such motor vehicle may be exempted with respect to the same medically incapacitated individual. 
(e)  Expiration. An exemption implemented pursuant to this section shall expire upon the earliest occurrence of one (1) or more of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Use of such motor vehicle which use does not conform to the requirements stated in this section; 
(2)  Change in ownership of such motor vehicle; 
(3)  Removal (except temporary removal for maintenance, repair, or replacement) from such motor vehicle of the special equipment or modification which made such motor vehicle suitable for exemption under this section; or 
(4)  Destruction or other permanent incapacitation of such motor vehicle. 
(f)  Report. On or before October 1st, 1997, said assessor shall submit to the board of aldermen a report listing each vehicle, and the assessment and tax impact with respect to each such vehicle, exempted pursuant to this section from personal property taxation for the grand list of October 1st, 1996 or the supplemental list thereof. 
(Ord. of 9-16-96)  
Sec. 28-18. - Abatement for surviving spouses of police officers and firefighters. 
Pursuant to section 12-81x of the general statutes, and effective commencing with taxes levied on the Grand List of October 1, 1999, taxes shall be and hereby are fully abated on the principal residence owned and occupied by the surviving spouse of any person who dies while in the performance of his or her duties as a city police officer or firefighter. 
(1)  In the event that such officer or firefighter died prior to July 1, 2000, taxes due or paid on the principal residence owned and occupied by his/her surviving spouse on or subsequent to that date shall be abated, and the tax collector shall refund such payments. 
(2)  In the event that such officer or firefighter died on or after July 1, 2000, taxes due or paid on the principal residence owned and occupied by his/her surviving spouse on or subsequent to the date of death of such officer or firefighter shall be abated, and the tax collector shall refund such payments. 
(3)  Once such surviving spouse has been determined to be eligible for the abatement provided by this section, no periodic reapplication shall be necessary. 
(4)  In the event that such surviving spouse shall not be the sole owner of his/her principal residence, the abatement shall be prorated to reflect such surviving spouse's interest in the property. 
(5)  If such surviving spouse shall change his/her principal residence, he/she may transfer the abatement to his/her new principal residence. 
(6)  If such surviving spouse remarries, the abatement shall cease commencing with taxes on the grand list next following the date of such remarriage. In the event that such remarriage shall terminate, such surviving spouse may apply for the abatement commencing with taxes due on the grand list next following the date of such termination. 
(Ord. No. 1298, 12-3-01)  
Sec. 28-19. - Property tax freeze or deferral for certain homeowners age seventy or over. 
(a)  Purpose. To provide a property tax "freeze" or "deferral" for residential property of certain homeowners age seventy or over under the provisions of Connecticut Public Act 
(b)  Effective date. The effective date of this section shall be the Grand List of October 1, 2006. 
(c)  Qualifications. Persons qualified for a benefit under this section are: 
(1)  Any person who owns real property located in the City of New Haven, and who occupies that property as his or her principal residence at least one hundred eighty-three (183) days of each year. However, a person eligible for a "freeze" of property taxes can also be a tenant for life or for a term of years who is liable for the payment of taxes thereon under Connecticut General Statutes (General Statutes), Section 12-48 or by contract. To be eligible for a "deferral" of property taxes, the person must own the real property. A tenant for life or for a term of years would not qualify for a deferral of property taxes. 
(2)  On December thirty-first of the calendar year preceding the year in which a claim for benefits afforded by this section is filed, such person is seventy (70) years of age or over; or whose spouse, domiciled with him or her is seventy (70) years of age or over, or who is sixty-two (62) years of age or over and the surviving spouse of a taxpayer qualified for relief under this section at the time of his or her death, provided such spouse was domiciled with such qualifying taxpayer at the time of his or her death; 
(3)  Such person or spouse has resided within the city for at least ten (10) years before filing a claim for benefits afforded by this section;
