(6)  Glass food container shall mean a glass bottle or jar of any size or shape used to package food and beverage products suitable for human or animal consumption. 
(7)  H.D.P.E. plastic container shall mean a high-density polyethylene bottle or jar of any size or shape used to package food, household laundry products, or crankcase oil. 
(8)  Intermediate processing center (IPC) shall mean a facility which can recycle an item or items and market or deliver the resulting material product(s) for reuse. Public and/or private entities may own such facilities, and offer service on a state, regional, municipal or submunicipal level. 
(9)  Lawn clippings shall mean grass or weed clippings resulting from the mowing of lawns. 
(10)  Leaves shall mean tree foliage. 
(11)  Make arrangements/provisions for shall mean to ensure the institution of a program to separate, collect and recycle designated recyclables, or to participate in a municipal program if the director of the department of public works deems the property eligible for participation. 
(12)  Market shall mean to sell or deliver a recyclable item to a customer, who will reuse it or dispose of it for reuse in a material product. 
(13)  Metal food container shall mean an aluminum, bi-metal, steel, tin-plated steel or other metallic can, plate or tray of any size or shape used to package food and beverage products suitable for human or animal consumption. 
(14)  Newspaper shall mean used or discarded newsprint, which is minimally contaminated by food or other material. 
(15)  Office paper shall mean used or discarded high-grade white paper and Manila paper, including, but not limited to, paper utilized for file folders, tab cards, writing, typing, printing, computer printing, and photocopying, which is suitable for recycling, and which is minimally contaminated. 
(16)  Person shall mean any individual, organization, company, corporation, trust, partnership, foundation, group, society, association, or establishment, or any combination of them. 
(17)  P.E.T. plastic food container shall mean a polyethylene terephthalate container of any size or shape used to package beverages. 
(18)  Recycling shall mean the process of separating, sorting, cleansing, treating, diverting and reconstituting an item or items, or other discarded material, from the solid waste stream for the purposes of processing it, or causing it to be processed, into a material product, including the production of compost, in order to provide for disposition of the item(s) in a manner, other than incineration or landfilling, which will best protect the environment. 
(19)  Recycling facility shall mean land and its appurtenances, and structures where recycling is conducted, including, but not limited to, an intermediate processing center, as defined by Conn. General Statutes section 22a-260 as amended from time to time. 
(20)  Scrap metal shall mean used or discarded items, which consist predominately of ferrous metals, aluminum, brass, copper, lead, chromium, tin, nickel or alloys thereof, including, but not limited to, white goods and metal food containers. 
(21)  Scrap tires shall mean discarded rubber or synthetic rubber tires used by or manufactured for vehicles including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, buses and trailers. 
(22)  Storage battery shall mean lead acid batteries or other batteries used in motor vehicles such as automobiles, airplanes, boats, recreational vehicles, tractors and like applications. 
(23)  Waste oil shall mean crankcase oil that has been utilized in internal combustion engines. 
(24)  Yard waste shall mean brush and the boughs of trees. 
(b)  Separation of materials. There is hereby established a program for the separation of items including, but not limited to, newspapers, glass food and beverage containers, metal food and beverage containers, leaves and yard waste, plastic food and beverage containers, cardboard, office paper, scrap metal, scrap tires, storage batteries, waste oil and leaves from solid waste. Provisions for the separation of the designated recyclable items shall be made by January 1, 1991. New Haven residents may bring cardboard, newspapers, glass food and beverage containers, scrap metal, scrap tires, and metal food and beverage containers to the city's residential recycling center at the transfer station, and listed by the director of the department of public works. 
(c)  Curbside collection of designated recyclables. 
(1)  All persons entitled to solid waste collection from residential buildings as set out in the immediately preceding section of this chapter shall place the following items for collection in a manner specified by the director of the department of public works: 
(i)  Newspaper; 
(ii)  Cardboard; 
(iii)  Office paper; 
(iv)  Glass food and beverage containers, which shall be rinsed clean of residue; 
(v)  Metal food and beverage containers, which shall be rinsed clean of residue; 
(vi)  Plastic food and beverage containers, which shall be rinsed clean of residue; and 
(vii)  Scrap tires. 
(2)  Items are not to be placed on the curb for collection earlier than twelve (12) hours before the next scheduled collection. The containers are to be removed from the curbside area within twelve (12) hours of collection. Containers shall not be located as to interfere with the public right of way. 
(3)  No person shall place any unauthorized items requiring special handling including, but not limited to, hazardous or other waste, demolition material, electronics or used electronic devices, and medical waste including syringes, containers of oxygen or other products for curbside collection. 
For purposes of this chapter, a waste is hazardous if it is known to be harmful to human health and the environment when improperly disposed of, treated, stored, transported, handled or otherwise managed. Words that signal hazards include toxic, flammable, ignitable, corrosive, caution, warning, danger, poison, volatile, combustible, explosive and harmful. 
(4)  The director of the department of public works is hereby authorized to issue additional reasonable regulations for voluntary and mandatory curbside separation of other materials suitable for recycling. This may include, but not be limited to, items defined in subsection (a) of this section. 
(5)  No person shall place any waste for curbside collection that exhibits a high level of ignitability, such as cartridges, shells, dynamite, or other ammunition which is regulated by the State Fire Marshal's Office. 
(6)  No person shall place any waste for curbside collection that exhibits a high level of corrosiveness, toxicity or reactivity which are regulated by the State Department of Consumer Protection, including but not limited to, gasoline, benzene, kerosene, turpentine, paint, radioactive material and medical devices and other waste. 
(d)  Unauthorized collection of designated recyclable materials. The following entities have exclusive authorization to collect designated recyclables in New Haven: the department of public works, vendors under contract with New Haven to provide this service, and private collectors licensed by the city. All organizations and other persons collecting designated recyclables within the city must be registered and licensed by the city in a similar manner as private collectors of solid waste. All designated recyclable material shall become the property of the city, or other authorized collector once it is placed at the curb or elsewhere for collection. It shall be a violation of this section for any unauthorized person to collect or pick up, or cause any designated recyclable or recycling container to be collected or picked up. (See subsection (c)(3), (5) and (6) above for list of unauthorized items.) Each unauthorized collection or pickup of at least one (1) container from at least one (1) residence, in violation hereof, shall constitute a separate and distinct violation punishable as hereinafter provided. 
(e)  Scrap metal for residents entitled to municipal collection. Except for metal food containers, scrap metal shall be separated from all other refuse collection items at the curb. Residents entitled to municipal collection service shall contact the department of public works for the collection of these materials. Alternatively, residents can drop off such items at the residential recycling center. 
(f)  Scrap tires for residents entitled to municipal collection. Scrap tires shall be separated from all other refuse collection items at the curb. Residents entitled to municipal collection service shall contact the department of public works for the collection of these materials. Alternatively, residents can drop off such items at the residential recycling center. 
(g)  Leaves. Leaves shall be placed in paper leaf bags, and separated from other refuse collection at the curb. Alternatively, residents can dispose of such items at the residential recycling center. 
(h)  Corrugated cardboard for residents entitled to municipal collection. Residents entitled to municipal collection service shall separate corrugated cardboard according to requirements of the city's cardboard collection program. Alternatively, residents can dispose of such items at the residential recycling center. 
(i)  Waste oil and storage batteries for residents. Waste oil and storage batteries shall not be mixed with other designated recyclables or residential solid waste. Residents shall bring waste oil and storage batteries to facilities that accept them, or to such locations as may be designated by the director of the department of public works. 
(j)  Recycling for residents not entitled to municipal collection. The owner of each residential building not entitled to city solid waste collection must comply with all federal, state and local recycling laws, and shall arrange for the separation, collection and recycling of the following designated recyclables in a manner that will prevent contamination or minimize their breakage: newspaper, glass food and beverage containers, metal food and beverage containers, plastic food and beverage containers, scrap metal, scrap tires, leaves, storage batteries and waste oil. Additionally, the owner of such residential buildings will communicate his/her mandatory recycling program to all occupants, and identify and address any sources of contamination. The occupants of such buildings shall comply with all such arrangements. 
(k)  Intermediate processing center. When the director of the department of public works so designates, all collectors of mandated recyclables, including but not limited to, cardboard, newspaper, office paper, glass food and beverage containers, plastic food and beverage containers, leaves and metal food and beverage containers from residential properties shall bring such designated recyclables to the state licensed intermediate recycling center, or any other entity selected by the appropriate city authority for sorting, cleansing, treating and reconstituting waste or other discarded material for the purpose of using the altered form as required by state statutes. If the director of the department of public works provides advanced written approval, processing or sale may occur elsewhere. Collectors of designated recyclables must arrange for their processing, marketing and recycling until such items are designated for processing at the intermediate processing center. 
(l)  Nonresidential recycling. Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes sections 22a-220a and 22a-241b as each is amended from time to time, the owners of nonresidential buildings including, but not limited to, places of business, industry, offices, public and private schools, not-for-profit companies and shelters shall make arrangements for the separation, collection and recycling of the following items in a manner that will prevent contamination, or minimize their breakage: corrugated cardboard, glass food and beverage containers, metal food and beverage containers, plastic food and beverage containers, newspaper, office paper, scrap metal, scrap tires, leaves, storage batteries and waste oil. Additionally, the owner will communicate his/her mandatory recycling program to all occupants, and identify and address any sources of contamination, and upon request, to report to the director of the department of public works or his/her designee. The occupants of such buildings shall comply with all such programs. 
(m)  Reporting of recyclable materials collected. 
(1)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 22a-220 as amended from time to time, each collector of recyclable materials licensed by the city shall provide quarterly reports to the director of the department of public works about the amount of each recyclable item as listed in this section, and any other materials collected, processed or marketed for the purpose of recycling, and solid waste that has been delivered to a recycling facility pursuant to regulations adopted by the director of the department of public works. Such items include corrugated cardboard, glass food and beverage containers, metal food and beverage containers, newspaper, office paper, mixed grade paper, plastic food and beverage containers, scrap metal, scrap tires, leaves, storage batteries and waste oil. 
(2)  If a recycling facility receives any of the following items generated from within New Haven for processing or sale, the facility's owner or operator shall provide a quarterly report for each one by its amount of weight or other method, and any other information required by the city, or the Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection: cardboard, glass food and beverage containers, metal food and beverage containers, newspaper, leaves, storage batteries, waste oil, plastic food and beverage containers, scrap metal, scrap tires, office paper, newly designated recyclables, and any other materials collected, processed or marketed for the purpose of recycling or composting. Such information shall be provided for residential and nonresidential properties. 
Such reports shall be filed in a timely manner with the city, and if so required, with the Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection. 
(n)  Notice of violations. 
(1)  Any collector, who reasonably believes that a person from whom he/she/it collects solid waste has violated the separation requirements of this section, shall not collect the same, and contact the director of the department of public works to report the violation. If the collector collects such waste, fines and penalties shall be issued and imposed against him/her/it. Additionally, collectors shall assist the director of the department of public works in identifying persons that unlawfully mixed solid waste with recyclables, which were later delivered to a resources recovery facility, transfer station, landfill or other solid waste facility. All collectors shall comply with state and city laws and regulations. Failure to do so shall subject them to penalties and fines up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code. 
(2)  The director of the department of public works shall develop warning notices, and notices of violation forms, in which to impose penalties on violators. He/she shall issue warning notices and forms for violations directly to property owners that are in violation of this section. Alternatively, collectors shall issue such notices at the request of the director of the department of public works. Said director shall be responsible for imposing such penalties. 
(o)  Violations at solid waste facilities. When the operator of the city's solid waste facilities reasonably believes that loads of solid waste that were substantially mixed with recyclables have been delivered to a facility, he/she shall promptly notify such belief to the vehicle's driver, and the director of the department of public works. The operator may base this belief on a visual inspection of such load. Collectors shall notify all persons from whom solid waste was collected to form such load, and may issue a warning notice as specified in subsection (n)(1), (n)(2) and other sections. 
(p)  Penalties. The director of the department of public works or his/her designee shall enforce the provisions of this section. In accordance with Conn. General Statutes sections 22a-220a and 22a-226d as each is amended from time to time, and unless otherwise provided, any person, firm or corporation that violates this section, or other related rules and regulations shall be fined up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code. 
(1)  Any resident or occupant of a nonresidential building who fails to source-separate designated recyclables from other solid waste shall be issued a written warning for a first offense. A fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code shall be imposed for each subsequent violation. 
(2)  The owner of any commercial or nonresidential establishment that fails to provide for separation of recyclables from other solid waste shall be issued a written warning for a first offense; a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code shall be imposed for a second and subsequent offenses. 
(3)  Any collector who knowingly mixes designated recyclable items with other solid waste shall be liable for a civil penalty up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code. 
(q)  Regulations. The director of the department of public works is authorized to issue reasonable regulations as needed to support this section in areas including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Establishing specifications for preparation, separation and collection of designated recyclables; 
(2)  Providing for curbside collection container replacements; 
(3)  Defining and adding new designated recyclables; 
(4)  Establishing locations for drop-offs of waste oil, storage batteries and corrugated cardboard; 
(5)  Establishing specifications for a corrugated cardboard collection program; 
(6)  Establishing collection specifications for leaves, yard waste and lawn clippings; 
(7)  Establishing reporting requirements including those for warning notices and notices of violation; and 
(8)  Establishing penalties for the failure to provide for the separation of designated recyclables, failure to comply with separation requirements, knowingly mixing designated recyclables; and otherwise failing to comply with state and local mandated requirements. 
Proposed regulations enacted affecting non-municipal collectors shall not become effective until a thirty (30) day comment period has expired. 
(r)  Severability. Subsections (a) through (q) of this section are to be construed as independent, separate and distinct. Notwithstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, if any subsection or its application to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the remaining portions and subsections and their applications shall not be affected thereby. It is hereby declared that this section would have been passed independently of any invalid provision. 
(Code of 1985, § 16-17.2; Ord. of 10-17-88, § 2; Ord. of 12-17-90, § 1; Ord. No. 1407, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 30¾-14. - Mandatory leaf collection program. 
There is hereby established an ordinance providing for the following: 
(1)  Mandatory separation of leaves from refuse; 
(2)  Placement of leaves into authorized paper bags or barrels by city residents; and 
(3)  The separate collection of leaves curbside by the department of public works. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  Barrel means any clean non-metal solid waste container with a thirty-two (32) gallon capacity, weighing no more than forty-five (45) pounds full, which are provided by the city. 
(2)  Leaf collection season means the period of time in which the director of the department of public works schedules leaf collection. 
(3)  Leaves mean foliage and deposition from deciduous and coniferous trees. 
(4)  Paper leaf bag means a sack having a thirty (30) gallon capacity, and two-ply fifty (50) pound wet-strength with decomposing glue, environmentally safe inks, and reinforced self-supporting square bottom closure. 
(5)  Yard waste means hedge trimmings or branches. 
(b)  Separation of leaves from solid waste and placement at the curb for removal. 
(1)  In accordance with Conn. General Statutes section 22a-241 as amended from time to time, leaves may not be disposed of in a landfill or incinerator. Leaves collected by persons, firms or corporations shall be processed for the purpose of composting in accordance with this section and the regulations. 
(2)  During the declared leaf collection season, city residents shall place all leaves into paper leaf bags or barrels as they are defined in this section. 
These paper leaf bags or barrels shall be placed at the curb on collection days specified by the director of the department of public works. Persons placing leaves at the curb that are not contained in said receptacles, or who placed them at the curb after the scheduled collection days, shall be in violation of this section. 
(3)  No other yard waste or other material shall be placed in paper leaf bags or barrels. 
(4)  Tape, staples and/or string shall not be used to close paper leaf bags. 
(5)  Leaves shall not be placed in plastic bags or barrels other than those described herein. 
(6)  Paper leaf bags and barrels of leaves shall be placed at the curb separate from any residential solid waste or bulk trash, and shall not obstruct any fire hydrant, sidewalk, driveway or street. 
(7)  No person or property owner shall rake, place, blow or cause leaves to be raked, placed or blown into any street within the city from private lands, property or sidewalk. 
(8)  Residents may bring leaves and small brush to specially designated recycling sites as long as they conform to the regulations specified by the department of public works. 
(c)  Leaves collected by commercial landscapers and other grounds maintenance personnel. 
(1)  Commercial landscape maintenance firms must be registered and permitted by the department of public works. These firms may bring leaves and small brush from New Haven residences to specially designed recycling sites as long as they conform to the regulations specified by the department of public works. 
(2)  Leaves collected by commercial landscapers and other grounds maintenance personnel for nonresidential properties shall be transported to a yard waste compost facility approved by the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection. A list of such facilities in the New Haven area will be available from the director of the department of public works. 
(d)  Regulations. The director of the department of public works may establish regulations pertaining to the matters of this section from time to time. 
(e)  Penalties. Every person who violates any provision of this section, including regulations established hereunder, shall be fined up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code for every such violation. Each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(f)  Reporting. This mandatory leaf collection program shall be evaluated every two (2) years. A report shall be made to the board of aldermen regarding the program's effectiveness, cost and efficiency. 
(Code of 1985, § 16-17.3; Ord. of 6-3-91, § 1; Ord. of 9-20-93; Ord. No. 1407, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 30¾-15. - Solid waste disposal facility regulated; duties of the director of the department of public works. 
(a)  Disposal site. Solid waste that is to be disposed of within the city limits shall only be done at such sites that are designated by the director of the department of public works, and subject to applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations. The director of the department of public works may regulate the types of solid waste disposed of at the city disposal facility, including, but not limited to, recyclable material and bulky waste, and may designate other areas for its disposal in accordance with federal, state and local laws and regulations. 
(b)  Hours. The director of the department of public works shall have discretion to set the actual hours of operation Monday through Friday, and as needed on Saturdays, and shall publish them. 
(c)  Days prohibited. Solid waste shall not be dumped on Sundays. 
(d)  Salvage removal. No individual company or corporation shall be allowed to salvage material from the solid waste disposal facility without the written permission of the director of the department of public works. He/she shall have discretion in rendering such permission. 
(e)  Duties of director of the department of public works. The director of the department of public works shall direct the operation of the solid waste disposal facility in conformance with contracts entered into by the city, and with applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations. 
(f)  User license permit and charge. No person, firm or corporation other than the City of New Haven shall dispose of any solid waste at the city's solid waste disposal facility without registering and obtaining a license to do so from the department of public works. In addition, all users shall obtain a permit from the department of public works for each vehicle used for such solid waste disposal. The director of the department of public works shall use his/her discretion in granting licenses and permits. Said director shall consider the applicant's record of compliance with this article, and any relevant state and federal laws and regulations in making this evaluation. The fee for such licenses and permits shall be in accordance with this Code as amended from time to time. Such license and permit shall have a one (1) year term, and shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance. The controller shall cause a cost of service study to be undertaken at least annually to establish the true costs of providing solid waste disposal services, and the establishment of a per unit fee sufficient to cover those costs for the city and the city's customers. City customers shall be governmental, quasi-governmental, private and other organizations that deliver or cause appropriate waste to be delivered to the solid waste disposal facility that the city bills in order to qualify for the solid waste disposal services. The director of the department of public works must approve of these customers before they can participate in this service. The board of aldermen must approve of any changes in the per unit fee for the city and city customers. Once such approval is given, changes will take effect thirty (30) days after the controller publishes notice of them in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The controller, in consultation with the director of the department of public works, shall have the option to require city customers to pay cash for services, or to allow customers to pay periodically. In the latter case, the controller may require customers to post a security deposit in a specified form and in an amount equivalent to between two (2) months and six (6) months of the city customer's average monthly disposal at the solid waste disposal facility. 
The total cost will be based on the average of charges imposed on the customer for the last six (6) months. Interest at the rate of one and one-half (1¾) percent per month, or any portion thereof, shall be imposed on the city customer for all such disposal charges not paid within thirty (30) days of the first billing date. Interest charges take effect thirty (30) days from the first billing date for said services. 
If the city does not receive payment within thirty (30) days of the first billing date, the customer shall be in violation of this subsection, and therefore subject to possible suspension or revocation of his/her/its license as set forth in subsection (g) herein. The controller, in consultation with the director of the department of public works, shall issue regulations concerning methods of payment and provisions for return of security deposits, and make all determinations concerning disputed billings. If the customer fails to comply with such determinations, he/she/it shall be in violation of this subsection, and therefore subject to the provisions of subsection (g). The board of aldermen's approval is needed to waive interest charges levied and accrued as provided for in this section. 
(1)  Contracts with other municipalities. The mayor, acting on behalf of the city, and consistent with any contractual obligations, may negotiate and execute agreements with other municipalities for solid waste disposal services at the New Haven transfer station. Such agreements shall not exceed one (1) year's duration. 
When the mayor negotiates such an agreement, he/she shall consider identified and predictable costs to the city of providing the services being contracted for, and he/she shall establish service fees which may reasonably be expected to cover such costs in full. The service fees established by the city in such agreements may vary from those set from time to time by the board of aldermen pursuant to this section. 
(2)  Transfer station enterprise fund established. 
(i)  The transfer station enterprise fund ("the fund") is established to account for all revenues and expenses associated with usage of the New Haven transfer station ("the facility") by private haulers, other municipalities, other governmental entities and not-for-profit businesses which pay the city for solid waste disposal services at the facility. 
(ii)  The mayor shall submit the annual budget for the fund as a component of the annual city budget submission required by this Code, and shall become effective upon the board of aldermen's approval. The fund's budget shall include estimates of the accrued unexpended balance which may be available from prior years' operations, revenues which may be earned, and expenditures which may be incurred during the fiscal year for which said budget is proposed. The director of the department of public works may adjust expenses to meet actual conditions at the facility, provided that expenditures incurred may not exceed the sum of revenues earned during the fiscal year plus unexpended balances available from prior years' operations. Personnel expenses incurred in the general fund, which are associated with the operation of the facility, and properly allocable to activities specified in subsection (a) hereinabove, shall be allocated at least annually to the fund. Any unexpended balance in the fund at the end of the fiscal year shall remain in the fund, and be carried forward as allowed by Conn. General Statutes section 7-148(2)(k) as amended from time to time. 
(iii)  The director of the department of public works shall prepare a quarterly report with the assistance of the controller or his/her designee, and submit it to the board of aldermen before the third Monday of October, January, April and July. The report shall state revenues earned and expenditures incurred through the end of the most recent quarter, project revenues and expenditures through the end of the fiscal year, and compare those to the budget approved by the board. 
(iv)  Sums appropriated by the board of aldermen for the facility's operation and/or maintenance may be used to supplement expenditures from the fund, but such sums shall not be added to the fund unless the board has appropriated them. 
(3)  Contracts for transfer station operations, maintenance, management, hauling and other services. 
(i)  The mayor, acting on behalf of the city, may negotiate contracts for private operation, maintenance, management, hauling and other services pertaining to the transfer station subject to the board of aldermen's approval. 
(ii)  If the transfer station is open on a holiday that the city observes, a city transfer station operator must be present, and the private transfer station contractor must pay any overtime and benefits owed to the operator for work performed during that holiday. 
(iii)  If a contractor requests that the site be open beyond the city's regular hours, he/she/it shall reimburse the city for all additional operational costs associated with the proper handling and disposal of wastes. 
(g)  Penalty. 
(1)  Any person or entity in violation of subsection (a), (b), (c), (d) or (f) of this section shall be subject to a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code 
(2)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 7-152d as amended from time to time, any person or entity that illegally disposes of solid waste at the city's solid waste disposal facility shall be liable for a civil penalty up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code for first, second and subsequent violations. These penalties may be added to those resulting from violations of other federal, state and local laws and regulations. Any person who is assessed a civil penalty pursuant to this subsection may appeal such assessment to the Superior Court in the manner provided in Conn. General Statutes sections 7-152b (g) as amended from time to time. 
(3)  The director of the department of public works shall have the authority to suspend or revoke a license to dispose of solid waste at the city's solid waste disposal facility from any person or entity if he/she/it, or his/her/its employee(s) violates subsection (a), (b), (c), (d) or (f) of this section within the scope of his/her employment. 
(h)  Regulations. The director of the department of public works may from time to time issue regulations concerning this section as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. of 4-10-61; Ord. of 12-1-69; Ord. of 3-5-79; Ord. of 4-15-85; Code of 1985, § 16-18; Ord. of 10-17-88, § 1; Ord. of 12-17-90, § 1; Ord. of 9-7-93; Ord. of 6-5-95; Ord. of 12-6-99; Ord. No. 1407, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 30¾-16. - Site cleanliness plans; dumpster regulations. 
(a)  Site cleanliness plans. The director of the department of public works may require a site cleanliness plan for any premises in the city. 
(1)  The person responsible for any premises subject to a site cleanliness plan shall file it in writing with the director of the department of public works on a form approved by him/her. The plan shall contain the address and specifications regarding the site on which solid waste collection for the premises will take place. The plan shall indicate the location of solid waste containers in relation to adjacent structures, and contain a regular weekly schedule, by days and hours, of solid waste collection. A similar schedule shall be provided for cleaning and maintaining the site of the solid waste containers, and any immediately adjacent sidewalk or public way from litter, rubbish and solid waste. A dumpster shall be used as the solid waste container unless it is impractical. 
(2)  If the director of the department of public works determines that the site maintenance is adequate to keep the site free from litter, he/she shall approve the plan. The director may consult with the director of the department of public health and the director of the building division of the Livable City Initiative in making this determination. 
(b)  Dumpsters: 
(1)  No dumpster may be placed or installed on any site in the city's right of way unless the person responsible for it has obtained a permit for it from the director of the department of public works or his/her designee. Such permit may be issued upon the payment of a fee, if any, as authorized, established and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen. Additionally, the dumpster must bear a number issued by the director of the department of public works or his/her designee in conjunction with the permit. No permit for a dumpster shall be issued unless the applicant provides the following written information on a form approved by the director of the department of public works or his/her designee: 
(i)  The address and a plan of the site on which the dumpster will be located, showing the location of the dumpster in relation to any structure on the site and on adjacent sites; 
(ii)  The site owner's name, address and telephone number; 
(iii)  The name, address and telephone number of the responsible person if the owner does not manage the site; 
(iv)  The name, address and telephone number of the person purchasing the dumpster service; 
(v)  The name, address and telephone number of the company which provides the dumpster; and 
(vi)  The name, address and telephone number of the company which empties the dumpster, if the provider does not empty it. 
(2)  If the director of the department of public works or his/her designee determines that the above information is accurate, he/she shall issue a permit for a dumpster on the site upon payment of a fee, if any, as established, authorized and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen. The permit shall be conditioned upon the compliance with the activities specified in such cleanliness plan. Nonperformance of any of the activities specified in the site cleanliness plan shall be a violation of the permit and of this section. 
(3)  All dumpsters, including, but not limited to, those transporting debris or solid waste within the city, must be covered at all times. 
(c)  Regulations. The director of the department of public works or his/her designee may establish regulations pertaining to the matters of this section from time to time. 
(d)  Penalties: 
(1)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code per day for each noncompliance. 
(2)  The director of the department of public works has sole discretion in determining whether a violation is punishable by revoking the approval of the site cleanliness plan, and/or any permits and licenses issued under this section. 
(Code of 1985, § 16-19; Ord. of 10-17-88; Ord. No. 1407, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 30¾-17. - Use of polystyrene packaging products regulated. 
(a)  The following restrictions shall apply to certain packaging materials in the City of New Haven. 
(1)  No vendor, commercial or retail user located and doing business within the city shall sell, give or provide eating utensils or food containers to any consumers within the city if such utensils or containers are composed of polystyrene. 
(2)  Any vendor, commercial or retail user may apply for exemption from this restriction if the establishment demonstrates to the mayor's designee that it is actively engaged in a comprehensive effort to recycle the polystyrene packaging materials which it generates. Such comprehensive efforts must include the following: 
(i)  Documented recycling of more than fifty (50) percent (by weight or volume) of the polystyrene materials generated as waste by the establishment on its premises; 
(ii)  A written recycling plan that contains a copy of a contract or agreement with the hauler transporting the recycled material to a legitimate facility; 
(iii)  A recycling plan on the premises showing that the establishment is in full compliance with federal, state and local recycling laws and regulations, including a written description of the recycling program for mandated items; and 
(iv)  The city may request additional documentation if necessary. 
(3)  Establishments wishing to use polystyrene packaging may apply in writing for the exemption to the designated city agency. Vendors or users must agree to provide the city agency responsible with all necessary documentation, and to allow city representatives access to the premises for verification. 
(4)  Retail food establishments will submit applications to the city's health department. All other retail establishments will submit applications to the city's department of public works. 
(b)  The directors of the departments of health and public works shall have the authority to issue reasonable regulations as needed to effect the provisions of this ordinance. 
(c)  This section's polystyrene packaging regulations shall not apply to the following items: 
(1)  Any flexible transparent covering for raw meat, poultry, fish, hard cheese, cold cuts, fruit and vegetable produce, baked goods or bread; 
(2)  Any polystyrene packaging which is used for display, storage or transportation of uncooked cut fresh meat, poultry or fish unless otherwise determined by the city's health director; and 
(3)  Any paper or other cellulose-based packaging that is coated with polyethylene plastic on only one (1) side. 
(d)  Enforcement. 
(1)  The city's health director or his/her designee(s), the director of the department of public works or his/her designee(s), or a sanitarian or his/her designee(s) employed by either department may enter the establishment of any vendor, commercial or retail user in the city where there is just cause to suspect the use of polystyrene packaging products prohibited by this section, and abate or cause such use to be abated. 
(2)  For the purposes of abating the use of such prohibited packaging, the city's health director or any entity serving as such shall have the same power and authority granted pursuant to Conn. General Statutes sections 19a-206(b) and (c) as amended from time to time. 
(e)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall be punishable by a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code for each day such violation continues to exist. 
(Ord. of 1-2-90, § 1; Ord. of 2-4-91, § 1; Ord. of 2-21-95; Code of 1985, § 16-21; Ord. No. 1407, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 30¾-18. - Plastic bags and paper bags at retail establishments. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 22a-255e as amended from time to time, each retail establishment offering plastic bags to customers for purchased goods shall offer them paper bags, and inform them that a choice is available. This section shall not be construed to require retail establishments to use plastic bags. 
(1)  The director of the department of public works or his/her designee shall prepare and promulgate appropriate signage for retailers informing them of this section. 
(2)  Retail establishments operating under this section are required to conspicuously display said signage in a location that is clearly visible to customers before packaging or transporting their purchases from the retail establishment. 
(b)  Enforcement. 
(1)  The director of the department of public works shall appoint such agents as are necessary for enforcement of this section. 
(2)  Failure to comply with this section shall result in a fine up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code for each day that such violation continues. 
(Code of 1985, § 16-22; Ord. of 2-21-95; Ord. No. 1407, 3-6-06)  
Sec. 30¾-19. - Designation of areas for all solid waste disposal. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 22a-220a, as amended from time to time, the city is authorized to designate an area, or areas, where all solid waste generated within the boundaries of the city shall be disposed and such area, or areas, so designated shall be the exclusive designated areas for disposal of such solid waste. 
(b)  The city hereby designates that all solid waste generated by residential, business, commercial or other establishments within the boundaries of the city shall be disposed of at the New Haven transfer station or such other area, or areas, as may be designated by the city. 
(c)  The director of the department of public works may designate a solid waste disposal area, or areas, for a specific type or classification of solid waste and may designate more than one area for the same type or classification of waste. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to amend or revoke such designation of solid waste disposal area, or areas as it determines is in the best interests of the city. 
(e)  In accordance with Conn. General Statutes section 22a-220a(b), this section 30¾-19 shall become effective following a sixty-day notice period, public hearing, and publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, such publication to provide the solid waste disposal area, or areas, and the effective date. 
(f)  Solid waste disposal areas so designated shall be subject to the requirements of all applicable provisions of Chapter 30¾ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, as may be amended from time to time. 
(g)  All ordinances, resolutions, regulations, rules or other documents inconsistent with the provisions of this section 30-¾ are repealed to the extent of such inconsistency. 
(h)  Failure to comply with this section 30¾-19 shall constitute an offense with a penalty up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code per occurrence. Each occurrence shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 1590, 4-28-09)  
Secs. 30¾-20—30¾-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE AND RECYCLING AUTHORITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1557, adopted April 16, 2007, repealed former Art. II, §§ 30¾-41—30¾-50 in its entirety, which pertained to refuse collection and derived from Ord. No. 1423, adopted July 6, 2006. The provisions of subsequent Ord. No. 1566, adopted April 22, 2008, have been included herein as a new Art. II at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 30¾-41. - Statement of purpose. 
(a)  The New Haven Solid Waste and Recycling Authority (the "authority") is created as a municipal resource recovery authority pursuant to CGS Sections 7-273aa to 7-273oo, inclusive. The authority is a public body politic and corporate of the state, and is a political subdivision of the state established and created for the performance of the essential public and governmental function of furthering the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the City of New Haven, Connecticut (the "city") by exercising supervision and control over the administration of solid waste in the city, including but not limited to the existing New Haven transfer station and recycling facility which currently exists in the city. 
(b)  Mission statement for the municipal solid waste and recycling authority. The municipal solid waste and recycling authority is an agency dedicated to achieving the most environmentally sound solid waste management and resource conservation program for the people of New Haven and the surrounding communities. Within this context, the agency is committed to achieving an increased diversion goal, with progressive benchmarks, and promoting sustainable consumption and disposal patterns. 
(1)  To achieve this goal, the agency will operate under the following hierarchy in order of priority: 
a.  Source reduction (avoiding the creation of waste). 
b.  Recycling and composting. 
c.  Environmentally safe transformation or land disposal. 
(2)  In achieving this goal, the agency will: 
a.  Provide strategic planning, research, education and technical assistance to the public, businesses and local governments. 
b.  Initiate innovative programs and facilities to maximize waste prevention, recycling and economic development opportunities. 
c.  Serve as a pro-active public policy advocate for long term solutions to our challenges. 
d.  Partner with organizations with compatible goals. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § I, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-42. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, each of the following terms shall have the meaning set forth below: 
Asset transfer agreement shall mean an agreement by and between the city and the authority which shall set forth the terms and conditions of the disposition by the city to the authority by sale or lease of the solid waste assets. 
Authority shall mean the New Haven Solid Waste and Recycling Authority established pursuant to this article. 
Bylaws shall mean the rules and regulations that, subject to statutory law and the articles of incorporation, govern the business and conduct of the affairs of the authority. 
Cause shall mean (a) conviction of a felony (other than a felony resulting from a traffic violation); (b) commission of an act of material fraud or embezzlement against the Authority; or (c) with respect to a director, willful failure to comply with the obligations set forth in the bylaws relating to duality of interest. 
CGS shall mean the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958, as amended. 
City shall mean the City of New Haven, Connecticut. 
Effective date shall mean the date upon which the ordinance from which this article derived becomes effective. 
Mayor shall mean the mayor of the City of New Haven. 
Solid waste assets shall mean such real and personal property utilized for solid waste and recycling, located at 256 Middletown Avenue, New Haven CT 06513, and commonly referred to as the "transfer station," such Solid waste assets to be further defined under the asset transfer agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § II, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-43. - Creation and powers. 
The city hereby adopts the provisions of CGS Chapter 103b and creates the board of directors of the authority as its municipal resource recovery authority. The authority shall have all the powers set forth in CGS Chapter 103b and the powers and duties of a municipal authority pursuant to CGS Chapters 446d and 446e. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § III, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-44. - Articles of incorporation of the authority. 
(a)  Name, address, authority for creation. The authority is created as a municipal resource recovery authority pursuant to CGS Sections 7-273aa to 7-273oo, inclusive, and shall be known as the "New Haven Solid Waste and Recycling Authority" with its principal office at 34 Middletown Avenue, New Haven, Connecticut 06513. 
(b)  Initial directors. names, addresses, terms of office. The names, addresses and terms of office of the initial directors of the authority are set forth on Exhibit A attached hereto. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § IV, 4-22-08) 
Editor's note— Exhibit A is not set out herein but is available at the office of the city clerk.  
Sec. 30¾-45. - Board of directors. 
The business of the authority shall be managed by or under the direction of the board of directors which may exercise all such powers of the authority and do all such lawful acts and things as are allowed by the CGS and the bylaws. 
(1)  Number and qualification of directors. The authority shall have a board of directors consisting of seven directors. All directors shall be resident electors of New Haven. Two of who shall reside in the ward in which the transfer station is located or the wards downstream from the transfer station. 
(2)  Compensation. The directors shall serve without compensation. 
(3)  Method of appointment and removal. 
a.  Six directors shall be appointed by the mayor. One director shall be appointed by the board of aldermen of the city and shall be a member of the board of aldermen. Upon termination or vacancy of a directorship appointed by the mayor, the mayor shall appoint a subsequent director. Upon termination or vacancy of a directorship appointed by the board of aldermen of the city, the board of aldermen of the city shall appoint a subsequent director. Beginning December 31, 2009 all subsequent mayoral appointments shall require approval of the board of aldermen. 
b.  The board of directors may remove a director only for cause. A director may be removed only at a meeting of the board called for the purpose of removing the director, and the meeting notice must state that the purpose or one of the purposes, of the meeting is the removal of the director. A director may be removed only upon the affirmative vote of at least two-thirds of the board. 
c.  The terms of directors shall be so arranged such that less than one-half of such terms of directors shall expire within any one calendar year. 
(4)  Term of office. 
a.  Except for the initial terms of the initial directors, the term of office of directors shall be for three years, commencing on January 1 of the first year of the term and expiring on December 31 of the third year of the term. 
b.  The initial term of office of each of the initial directors of the authority shall commence on the effective date and shall expire on December 31, 2009, December 31, 2010 or December 31, 2011, as set forth on Exhibit A attached hereto. Upon the expiration of each initial term of office for each of the initial directors, a new term of office of three (3) years shall commence for each subsequent director appointed. 
(5)  The formation of the board of directors shall comply with all other applicable state and local laws, as may be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § V, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-46. - Authorization of director of public works. 
The director of public works of the city is hereby appointed and authorized to serve as the executive director, or such other title as may be given to the chief executive, of the authority. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § VI, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-47. - Disposition and transfer of assets. 
The sale or lease of the solid waste assets to the authority is hereby approved, and the mayor and the controller are hereby empowered, authorized and directed to negotiate, execute and deliver, on behalf of the city, the asset transfer agreement and to approve all terms and conditions for the transfer of the solid waste assets by sale or lease, and any and all other agreements, documents and instruments related thereto, and to perform any and all acts necessary or appropriate to effectuate the disposition and transfer of the solid waste assets by sale or lease to the authority, all as shall be determined to be in the best interests of the city. Prior to the execution of the asset transfer agreement and the transfer of the solid waste assets to the authority, (i) the proposed transfer of the solid waste assets shall have been approved by the city plan commission of the city, and (ii) all notice and public hearing requirements shall have been complied with, including, without limitation CGS Section 7-163e. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § VII, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-48. - Financing. 
(a)  The issuance of not exceeding $10,500,000.00 of bonds by the authority is hereby approved (the "bonds"). The proceeds of the bonds shall be used by the authority for the purchase or lease of the solid waste assets and for the development and improvement of the solid waste assets (the "project"), including any and all costs of the project authorized to be paid under the provisions of CGS Section 7-273aa(a)(5). The bonds shall be secured by and payable from (i) its revenues generally, (ii) a pledge of revenues to be derived from the operation of the solid waste assets, (iii) a mortgage covering all or any part of the solid waste assets, (iv) a pledge of any lease of the solid waste assets or of any long-term agreements with the city for the disposal of solid waste and recyclables or (v) by any other revenues, receipts, funds or moneys of the authority, as determined by the authority. The authority may pledge and agree with the owners of the bonds and persons who may enter into contracts with the authority related to the issuance of the bonds that it will not limit or alter the rights thereby vested in such bond owners, or any contracting party, until the bonds, together with interest thereon, are fully met and discharged and such contracts are fully performed. The authority is further authorized and empowered to determine the form of the bonds, including provisions as to registration thereof, their date, the dates of principal and interest payments, the rate or rates of interest payable thereon, the manner of issuance and sale and by whom the bonds shall be signed and countersigned and all other details and particulars thereof. The bonds may bear interest includable in gross income for federal tax purposes if determined by the authority to be in the public interest. 
(b)  The mayor and the controller of the city are expressly empowered and authorized to enter into long-term contracts or agreements with the authority for the disposal of solid waste and recyclables and to make payments of fees or charges therefor based on a percentage of actual or projected tonnage or such other formula as such contract or agreement shall provide. Any such contract or agreement may require the continuation of such payments by the city whether or not the agreed services are being provided, but only until all of the bonds have been paid or provided for, and the inclusion of such a requirement in any agreement or contract entered into pursuant to this article is hereby approved in accordance with the provisions of CGS Section 7-273ee(d). Any such contracts or agreements entered into by the city under the authority of this section are deemed approved and shall be valid, binding and enforceable against the city and may be pledged as additional security for the payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds. 
(b)  The authority shall dedicate funds from its revenue to advance and promote activities by the authority or to engage the public that would: result in the diversion of solid waste through but not limited to public outreach campaigns, school based recycling education programs or recycling incentive programs; activities and community efforts to protect the Quinnipiac River and the wetlands adjacent to the transfer station. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § VIII, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-49. - Other ordinances and repealer. 
(a)  Sections 30¾-1 through 30¾-18 and Article XVI of Chapter 17 (sections 17-121—17-135) of the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven (the "Code") and any other ordinances in the Code that pertain to solid waste and recycling shall, for the purposes of this section 30¾-149 be referred to as the "solid waste ordinances." The authority is hereby expressly empowered and authorized to administer and/or enforce the solid waste ordinances to the extent necessary to effectuate this article and to the extent of the authority's powers as set forth in this article, and provided that there shall at all relevant times be a furtherance of the purpose for which the authority has been created. Nothing herein gives the authority sole and exclusive control over the administration and/or enforcement of all of the solid waste ordinances. To the extent that the authority adopts regulations or rules that conflict with the solid waste ordinances, the solid waste ordinances shall govern. 
(b)  This article shall supersede and replace ordinances of the city in existence to the extent that they are inconsistent with this article. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § IX, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-50. - Flow control. 
The city hereby agrees to adopt and maintain an ordinance, to the extent lawful pursuant to the CGS and all other applicable law, for the purpose of designating an area or areas where all solid waste generated within the boundaries of the city shall be disposed. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § X, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-51. - Dissolution. 
The city retains the right to dissolve the authority. Upon dissolution, the city agrees to assume, or satisfy, the liabilities and outstanding obligations of the authority, including without limitation, the bonds and all of the authority's interest in all assets of the authority shall be transferred to and vest in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § XI, 4-22-08)  
Sec. 30¾-52. - Reauthorization. 
(a)  The authority shall report, in writing and in person, its operational results, practices and policies to the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven on an annual basis. 
(b)  Commencing with the third anniversary of the enactment of the ordinance from which this article derives, and on a triennial basis thereafter the board of aldermen shall review the operational results of the authority for the preceding three-year period in addition to the authority's practices and policies to determine if the authority's actions and results remain in the best interest of the City of New Haven and its taxpayers. 
(Ord. No. 1566, § XIV, 4-22-08)  
Secs. 30¾-53—30¾-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PROHIBITING WASTE ASSOCIATED WITH NATURAL GAS AND OIL EXTRACTION 
 
Sec. 30¾-71. - Purpose. 
The prohibition of waste associated with the drilling and extraction of natural gas and oil is hereby declared necessary for the protection of the health, safety, welfare and property of the residents of the City of New Haven pursuant to the provisions of C.G.S. Section 7-148 that pertain in any way to the protection of health, safety, welfare and property, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1834 , 3-19-18)  
Sec. 30¾-72. - Definitions for the purposes of this article. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings given here, unless otherwise clearly indicated by the context: 
Application shall mean the physical act of placing or spreading natural gas waste or oil waste on any road or real property located within the City of New Haven. 
Hydraulic fracturing shall mean the fracturing of underground rock formations, including shale and non-shale formations, by manmade fluid-driven techniques for the purpose of stimulating oil, natural gas, or other subsurface hydrocarbon production. 
Natural gas extraction activities shall mean all geologic or geophysical activities related to the exploration for or extraction of natural gas, including, but not limited to, core and rotary drilling and hydraulic fracturing. 
Natural gas waste shall mean: 
(a)  Any liquid or solid waste or its constituents that is generated as a result of natural gas extraction activities, which may consist of water, brine, chemicals, naturally occurring radioactive materials, heavy metals, or other contaminants; 
(b)  Leachate from solid wastes associated with natural gas extraction activities; 
(c)  Any waste that is generated as a result of or in association with the underground storage of natural gas; 
(d)  Any waste that is generated as a result of or in association with liquefied petroleum gas well storage operations; and 
(e)  Any products or byproducts resulting from the treatment, processing, or modification of any of the above wastes. 
Oil extraction activities shall mean all geologic or geophysical activities related to the exploration for or extraction of oil, including, but not limited, to core and rotary drilling and hydraulic fracturing. 
Oil waste shall mean: 
(a)  Any liquid or solid waste or its constituents that is generated as a result of oil extraction activities, which may consist of water, brine, chemicals, naturally occurring radioactive materials, heavy metals, or other contaminants; 
(b)  Leachate from solid wastes associated with oil extraction activities; and 
(c)  Any products or byproducts resulting from the treatment, processing, or modification of any of the above wastes. 
(Ord. No. 1834 , 3-19-18)  
Sec. 30¾-73. - Prohibitions. 
The application of natural gas waste or oil waste, whether or not such waste has received beneficial use determination or other approval for use by the Department of Energy and Environmental Protection ("DEEP") or any other regulatory body, on any road or real property located within the City of New Haven for any purpose is prohibited. 
The introduction of natural gas waste or oil waste into any wastewater treatment facility within or operated by the City of New Haven is prohibited. 
The introduction of natural gas waste or oil waste into any solid waste management facility within or operated by the City of New Haven is prohibited. 
The storage, disposal, sale, acquisition, transfer, handling, treatment and/or processing of natural gas waste or oil waste is prohibited within the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. No. 1834 , 3-19-18)  
Sec. 30¾-74. - Bids and contracts. 
Provision to be included in bids and contracts related to the construction or maintenance of publicly owned and/or maintained roads or real property within the City of New Haven: 
All bids and contracts related to the retention of services to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the City of New Haven shall include a provision stating that no materials containing natural gas or oil waste shall be utilized in providing such a service. 
All bids and contracts related to the purchase or acquisition of materials to be used to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the City of New Haven shall include a provision stating that no materials containing natural gas or oil waste shall be provided to the City of New Haven. 
The following statement, which shall be a sworn statement under penalty of perjury, shall be included in all bids related to the purchase or acquisition of materials to be used to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the City of New Haven and all bids related to the retention of services to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the City of New Haven: "We ___________ hereby submit a bid for materials, equipment and/or labor for the City of New Haven. The bid is for bid documents titled ___________. We hereby certify under penalty of perjury that no natural gas waste or oil waste will be used by the undersigned bidder or any contractor, sub-contractor, agent or vendor agent in connection with the bid; nor will the undersigned bidder or any sub-contractor, agent or vendor agent thereof apply any natural gas waste or oil waste to any road or real property within the City of New Haven as a result of the submittal of this bid if selected." 
(Ord. No. 1834 , 3-19-18)  
Sec. 30¾-75. - Penalties. 
This article shall apply to any and all actions occurring on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives. In response to a violation of this article, the City of New Haven is empowered to: 
(a)  Issue "cease and desist" orders demanding abatement of the violation, 
(b)  Seek any appropriate legal relief, including immediate injunctive relief, as a result of any violation of this article; 
(c)  File a complaint with any other proper authority; and 
(d)  Require remediation of any damage done to any land, road, building, aquifer, well, watercourse, air quality or other asset, be it public or private, within the City of New Haven. The City of New Haven may recoup from the offending person(s), jointly and severally, all costs, including experts, consultants and reasonable attorney's fees, that it incurs as a result of having to prosecute or remediate any infraction of this article. 
For any violation of this article, the City of New Haven may also impose fines in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per violation per day, or such other amount as is allowed by law, and seek any other remedies allowable under the law. 
(Ord. No. 1834 , 3-19-18)  
Sec. 30¾-76. - Enforcement. 
The City of New Haven's Department of Public Works is hereby empowered and authorized to, if appropriate, issue orders and other directives under this article and refer matters in connection therewith to the City of New Haven's Office of the Corporation Counsel. City of New Haven employees, officers and officials are not required to personally carry out testing of waste products to determine chemical contents, as this work may be done via contacting the State of Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection or the appropriate analytical laboratory or laboratories. If appropriate, the City of New Haven's Department of Public Works may request that the State of Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection pursue civil penalties allowable under the law. 
(Ord. No. 1834 , 3-19-18)  
Chapter 31 - WEIGHTS AND MEASURES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1405, adopted January 3, 2006, amended and restated provisions contained in of former Ch. 31 in its entirety. The legislative history notes in parentheses following the sections of this chapter include the section number formerly used in the 1985 reprinting, as amended. 
 
Sec. 31-1. - Sealer of weight and measures, created. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 43-6 as amended from time to time, the mayor shall appoint a sealer of weights and measures for New Haven. The sealer of weights and measures shall perform the same duties and have the same powers within the city as the State Commissioner of Weights and Measures, except those powers and duties exempted and reserved to the State Commissioner by regulations promulgated under the provisions of Conn. General Statutes section 43-3 as amended from time to time. 
(b)  When the mayor fails to appoint a sealer of weights and measures, or when an appointed sealer fails or neglects to perform his/her duties, the State Commissioner of Weights and Measures may direct his/her inspectors to perform the duties of the municipal sealer. Under such circumstances, and upon notification by the Commissioner of Weights and Measures, the city shall reimburse the state for the cost of such services rendered. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-2. - Mayor to procure a complete set of standards. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 43-4 as amended from time to time, the mayor shall procure at the city's expense, and keep at all times, a complete set of weights, measures and other apparatus as directed by the Commissioner of Weights and Measures. All such instruments shall have been tried and accurately proven by said Commissioner, and sealed and certified by him/her, and thereafter deposited with and preserved as public standards for the city by the sealer. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-3. - Sealer of weight and measures, powers. 
Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 43-7 as amended from time to time, the sealer of weights and measures shall have the following powers: 
(1)  To arrest, without warrant, any violator of the laws relating to weights and measures; 
(2)  To seize, without warrant, for use as evidence, any false or unsealed weight, measure or weighing or measuring device, or package or amount of any commodity, found to be used, retained, offered or exposed for sale or sold in violation of law; 
(3)  To issue stop use, hold and removal orders with respect to any such weights and measures commercially used; 
(4)  To issue stop sale, hold and removal orders with respect to the weight or measure of any such packaged commodities or bulk commodities kept, offered or exposed for sale; 
(5)  To apply a condemned tag to any false weight, measure or weighing or measuring device; and 
(6)  To apply a condemned tag to any weighing or measuring instrument or device to which he/she has attached a seal or tag which has been tampered with, marked, defaced, removed, forged or counterfeited. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-4. - Police to assist sealer; report of violation by sealer to prosecutor. 
Every police officer shall assist the sealer of weights and measures when necessary, and report any violation of this chapter within his/her knowledge to such sealer. The sealer of weights and measures shall report all such violations to the prosecutor of the Superior Court for the Judicial District of New Haven. 
(Code of 1928, § 1004; Code of 1985, § 31-1; Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-5. - Printing, distribution of laws concerning weights and measures. 
The sealer of weights and measures shall have printed and distribute copies of state statutes, city ordinances and charter provisions concerning weights and measures to all persons requesting them. 
(Code of 1928, § 1006; Code of 1985, § 31-2; Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-6. - Annual report. 
The sealer shall report the number of scales, weights or measures inspected by him/her, and the condition and disposition of such instruments to the city's health director at the end of each fiscal year. Said director shall transmit such information in an annual report to the mayor. 
(Code of 1928, § 1001; Code of 1985, § 31-3; Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-7. - Inspection of weights and measures. 
Any person having scales, weights or measures that are used in buying or selling goods or merchandise may take them to the office of the sealer of weights and measures to have them inspected and stamped by the sealer. Alternatively, such person may request that such an inspection be conducted at his/her place of business. 
(Code of 1928, § 997; Code of 1985, § 31-4; Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-8. - Register to be kept. 
The city's sealer of weights and measures shall keep a register of the name of each person for whom he/she has inspected any weight or measure, including the kind and size of each weight or measure inspected, and the result of such inspection. He/she shall note which, if any, weights and measures were approved, and which, if any, were condemned. This register shall be kept in the sealer's office, and shall be open to public inspection during the sealer's office hours. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-9. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
(a)  Capacity shall mean measure of capacity as rated by the manufacturer. 
(b)  Commercial weighing and measuring equipment shall mean weights, measures and measuring devices commercially used or employed in establishing the size, quantity, extent, area or measurement of quantities, things, produce or articles for distribution or consumption, purchased, offered or submitted for sale, hire or award, or in computing any basic charge or payment for services rendered on the basis of weight or measure. 
(c)  Crane scale shall mean a weighing device having a nominal capacity of five thousand (5,000) pounds or more, and designed to weigh loads which are freely suspended from an overhead, track-mounted crane. 
(d)  Hopper scale shall mean a weighing device designed for bulk commodities, and whose load-receiving element is a tank box or hopper mounted on a weighing element. 
(e)  Load-rack dispenser shall mean a measuring device affixed to a loading platform at which a vehicle tank is filled. 
(f)  Motor fuel dispenser shall mean a device designed for the measurement and delivery of liquids used as fuel for internal combustion engines. 
(g)  Scale shall mean any weighing device used in commercial trade, and not otherwise covered by this chapter. 
(h)  Vehicle tank dispenser shall mean a measuring device which is affixed to a vehicle-mounted tank. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-10. - Annual license required. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes sections 43-1 through 43-9, as each is amended from time to time, it shall be unlawful to operate any commercial weighing and measuring equipment within the city unless the sealer of weights and measures licenses it. The license shall be valid for one (1) year from its issuance date. 
(b)  The sealer of weights and measures shall not issue a weighing and measuring device license unless: 
(1)  The sealer has inspected and approved such device within six (6) months of the application date; 
(2)  Each applicant furnishes such information relative to the application for a weighing and measuring device license as the sealer requires; and 
(3)  Each applicant pays an annual license fee as listed in the Licenses and Permits Chapter of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-11. - Exemption. 
Any city-owned weighing and measuring device is hereby exempted from the licensing and fee provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Sec. 31-12. - Penalties. 
(a)  Pursuant to Conn. General Statutes section 43-16q (d) as amended from time to time, the Commissioner of Agriculture and Consumer Protection will conduct a hearing in accordance with Chapter 54, Uniform Administrative Procedure Act, and may impose a civil penalty up to the maximum amount authorized by state statutes or this Code for the first and subsequent offenses. Each violation with respect to each such unit, certificate, device or scale shall be considered a separate offense. 
(b)  The penalty for a violation of any provision of this section shall be a fine up to the maximum authorized by state statutes or this Code per device. Each day of noncompliance shall be considered a separate violation. The penalty established herein shall be in addition to any penalties established by state statutes and this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 1-3-06)  
Chapter 32 - ENFORCEMENT BY CIVIL OFFICERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ch. 32 was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Authorized; citations. 
(a)  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes section 7-148(c)(10), as amended by Public Act 88-221, the City of New Haven may enforce the violation of the ordinances [Code sections] designated in section 32-2 hereof by the issuance of a citation. Each citation shall be issued by a designated municipal officer or employee, who shall issue a written warning providing notice of the specific violation before issuing the citation. Such citation may be appealed through the citation hearing procedure established in section 32-3 hereof. 
(b)  Each municipal officer or employee who is designated to issue a citation under this chapter shall be so designated by the director of public works. 
(Ord. of 10-17-88, § 1)  
Sec. 32-2. - Code sections to be enforced.[2] 
The following sections of the Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, Connecticut, are hereby designated for enforcement pursuant to the provisions of section 32-1 et seq. 
Section 9-1. 
Section 9-2(a). 
Sections 16-13 [Section 31¼-4] through 16-15. 
Sections 16-17 through 16-17.3 [Section 31¼-12 through Section 31¼-14. 
Section 16-19 [Section 31¼-16]. 
Section 16-20 [Section 31¼-5. 
Section 16-26 [Section 31¼-1]. 
Section 18-1. 
Section 18-10. 
Section 18-20. 
Section 18-25 and 18-26. 
Section 18-40. 
Sections 27-8 and 27-9 [Sections 27-31, 27-32]. 
Sections 27-11 and 27-12 [Sections 27-33, 27-32]. 
Section 27-14.1 [Sections 27-35 through 27-42]. 
Sections 27-18 [Section 27-44] and 27-19. 
Section 27-29. 
(Ord. of 10-17-88, § 1) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Some of the sections listed below were renumbered and reenacted by the 2006 selective chapter review project. The editor has provided new corresponding section numbers in brackets where possible. 
 
Sec. 32-3. - Citation hearing procedures. 
The following citation hearing procedures are adopted for all ordinances designated by the City of New Haven pursuant to Public Act 88-221 and enforced by citation. 
(a)  The mayor of the City of New Haven shall appoint one or more citation hearing officers, other than police officers or employees or persons who issue citations, to conduct the hearings authorized by this section. 
(b)  At any time within twelve (12) months from the expiration of the final period for the uncontested payment of fines, penalties, costs or fees for any citation issued under any ordinance adopted pursuant to section 7-148 of the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended by section one of Public Act 88-221, for an alleged violation thereof, the City of New Haven shall send notice to the property owner. Such notice shall inform the owner and other person cited: 
(1)  Of the fines, penalties, costs or fees due;
