If any owner-occupant of a one, two, or three family home communicates in writing to the city/town clerk of the City of New Haven his desire to be excluded from the district, the boundaries of the district shall automatically be deemed to exclude the property owned by such owner. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 7; Ord. of 6-1-87, § 2; Ord. No. 1435, 1-16-07; Ord. No. 1630, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 1718, 9-3-13 )  
Sec. 35-8. - Adding properties to the district. 
A parcel of real property shall be included in the district among the properties already within the district if: 
(1)  The owner(s) of such parcel shall notify the board of commissioners in writing of their intention to join the district, in a request which must be signed by the property owner(s) constituting a majority interest in said property, or a representative of such owner(s) authorized to sign such a request; and 
(2)  The board of commissioners of the district shall approve the inclusion of said parcel in the district; and 
(3)  The board of aldermen shall amend this chapter to include said parcel in the district. Such amendments shall be submitted to the board of aldermen during the months of March and/or September. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 8)  
Sec. 35-9. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms are defined as follows: 
(a)  Holder of record of interest in real property: The owner, in part or in whole, of an interest in real property as shown on the New Haven Land Records. For the purpose of the election of the board of commissioners, at the organizational meeting only, under section 35-3 hereof, holders of record of an interest in real property shall be determined by the city/town clerk as of 5:00 p.m. on the eleventh day preceding said first organizational meeting to elect commissioners. Thereafter, any notices, for whatever purpose, shall become the responsibility of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Assessment, assessed value: Seventy (70) percent of the market value of a parcel of real property as shown on the real property field card for said parcel on file at the office of the tax assessor of the City of New Haven. 
(c)  Holder of taxable interest in real property: The owner, in part or in whole, of an interest in real property as shown on the New Haven Land Records which such interest is assessed for taxation on the last completed grand-list of the city. For the purpose of the referendum on whether this chapter shall take effect, taxable interest in real property shall be determined by the city clerk as of 5:00 p.m. on the day this chapter is adopted by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 9)  
Sec. 35-10. - Property of district. 
All interests in real property and all interests in personal property held by the district are not subject to the city property tax to the extent that the use of such property by the district is for a "public purpose" pursuant to section 12-81(4) of the Connecticut General Statutes; except that real property on the tax rolls either as of the time of the enactment of this chapter or as of the time of the transfer of the property to the district and parking facilities within or without the district shall be subject to the city property tax unless prospectively abated by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 10)  
Sec. 35-11. - Dissolution. 
(a)  At any time after the district has been established, the district may be dissolved by the enactment of an ordinance repealing the ordinance establishing this district or by the holding of a referendum by the board of commissioners among all the holders of record of taxable interests in real property within the district on the question of whether the district shall be dissolved, provided a majority of such holders shall respond affirmatively or provided the holders of taxable interests in real property the assessments of which shall constitute more than one-half of the total of assessments for all taxable interests in real property within the district shall respond affirmatively. The board of commissioners shall determine the manner in which the referendum to dissolve shall be held. Any such referendum may be conducted by mail. 
(b)  If the district is dissolved pursuant to section 35-11(a) of this chapter, the board of commissioners shall proceed to wind up the affairs of the district as to the end of the then current fiscal year of the district. If, after the dissolution of the district, the district shall have liabilities, whether fixed or contingent, the board of aldermen of the city shall have the authority to impose, in addition to the regular municipal levy, a levy on the real property within the district, in the same manner as is provided for the determination of the levy by the board of commissioners of the district pursuant to section 35-4(b) of this chapter, for as many years as such liabilities shall remain outstanding, and such levy shall be calculated to produce enough revenues to satisfy and release such liabilities as they become due, and such revenues shall be deposited into the general fund of the city and shall be disbursed by the city, at the discretion of the mayor, solely for the purposes stated herein. If, after the dissolution of the district, the district shall have liabilities, whether fixed or contingent, the board of aldermen of the city shall have the authority to impose, in addition to the regular municipal levy, a levy on the real property within the district, in the same manner as is provided for the determination of the levy by the board of commissioners of the district pursuant to section 35-4(b) of this chapter, for as many years as such liabilities shall remain outstanding, and such levy shall be calculated to produce enough revenues to satisfy and release such liabilities as they become due, and such revenues shall be deposited into the general fund of the city and shall be disbursed by the city, at the discretion of the mayor, solely for the purposes stated herein. If, after the dissolution of the district, the district shall have assets which remain following the winding up of the affairs of the district, such assets shall be transferred to the city. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 11)  
Sec. 35-12. - Annual report. 
Annually on January 15th or the next business day thereafter, the board of commissioners of the district shall submit to the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven an annual report of the operation and activities of the district. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 12; Ord. of 7-6-93; Ord. of 9-23-98, § 14)  
Sec. 35-13. - Annual audit. 
The board of commissioners of the district shall have an independent financial audit conducted of the district's annual financial affairs by a certified public accountant on or before the thirtieth day of September. A copy of the audit shall be forwarded to the controller of the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 13)  
Sec. 35-14. - Insurance. 
The district shall, to the extent reasonably available, maintain at its own expense for itself and the City of New Haven as additional insured, public liability insurance covering personal injury and property damage in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) with an insurance company approved by the state insurance commissioner. To the extent of such insurance coverage, the district agrees to indemnify and hold the city harmless from any liabilities, obligations, claims, actions, judgements, damages, or debts which are a direct result of the establishment of the district or its operation. A certificate evidencing such insurance shall be filed with the controller of the City of New Haven, and such insurance shall not be cancelled or modified without the express written consent of the city. The insurer may not terminate or refuse to renew the policy until thirty (30) days' notice has been given to the city. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 14)  
Sec. 35-15. - Conflicts, severability. 
(a)  The Code of Ordinances of the City of New Haven, except as amended herein, remains in full force and effect. Any provisions of the Code inconsistent herewith, to the extent of such inconsistencies and no further, are hereby repealed. 
(b)  If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of the chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-15-86, § 15)  
Chapter 36 - TOWN GREEN SPECIAL SERVICES DISTRICT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ch. 36 was not affected by the selected chapter review and re-enanctment project begun in 2006 and derives unchanged from the Code of 1962, reprinted in 1985, as amended. 
 
Sec. 36-1. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established a Town Green Special Services District (hereinafter the "district") as a body politic and corporate, in accordance with the powers vested in the City of New Haven (hereinafter the "city") under Chapter 105A of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision). 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-2. - Referendum. 
(a)  This chapter shall not take effect unless, within sixty (60) days of the enactment of this chapter by the board of aldermen, a referendum shall be held and approved. 
(b)  The referendum shall be held among all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district on the question of whether this chapter shall take effect. The city/town clerk of the city shall determine the identity of such holders in the city's land records and shall give notice of the referendum to such holders. 
(c)  The referendum shall be approved if a majority of all such holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district, voting one vote per property, respond affirmatively and if such holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district, the assessments of which constitute more than one-half (½) of the total of assessments for all taxable interests in real property within the district, shall respond affirmatively. 
(d)  The referendum shall be conducted by mail for a period of two (2) weeks ending at 5:00 p.m. on the third (3rd) Tuesday following after the enactment of this chapter. The city clerk of the City of New Haven shall supervise the referendum and shall certify the results of the referendum. The referendum shall comply, to the extent applicable and practicable, with Chapter 145 (Absentee Voting) and Chapter 152 (Referenda) of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision), except as Chapter 105A of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision) and the terms of this chapter may otherwise permit or direct. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-3. - Board of commissioners. 
(a)  The business of the district shall be conducted by a board of commissioners (hereafter the "board") consisting of not less than fifteen (15) members elected as provided in the following subsections. The board may designate such agents, including a district manager, as it deems necessary and advisable to act on its behalf in the conduct of the business of the board. The board shall be comprised as follows: 
(1)  Class A commissioners: Six (6) members representing separate holders of taxable interests in real property in the district not qualifying as Class B commissioners. 
(2)  Class B commissioners: Five (5) members representing separate holders of taxable interests in real property in the district which are among the twenty (20) largest such holders, by assessed value, in the district. 
(3)  Class C commissioners: Four (4) members not qualifying as Class A or B commissioners who reside in the district or operate a trade or business or lease real estate in the district or who represent a business entity or trust which operates a trade or business or leases real estate in the district. 
(4)  Class D commissioners: Each governmental or non-governmental organization which contributes and/or pays in the aggregate at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to the district for its next following fiscal year may designate a representative of the organization to serve ex officio with a vote. 
No member of one (1) class maybe a member of another class. 
(b)  In order to elect an interim board to serve until the first annual meeting of the district in the February following the effective date of this chapter, the city clerk shall give at least ten (10) days notice of the first organizational meeting of the district. Such notice stating the time and place of and business to be conducted at the meeting shall be by mail, effective upon mailing, to all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district and by publication in a newspaper having circulation in the district. Any holder of record of taxable interest in real property in the district may propose one or more candidates qualifying for Class A or Class B commissioner to the city clerk who shall preside over and conduct balloting at the meeting to elect the board of commissioners. The election of each commissioner of the board at the first organizational meeting shall be determined by plurality of the qualified voters present and voting. Class A and Class B commissioners shall be nominated at large. Class C commissioners shall be elected by the Class A and Class B commissioners at their first meeting of the board following their election. Each Class D commissioner shall take office upon represented organization's commitment called for in the foregoing subsection 36-3(a)(4). After the notice for the organizational meeting, any notices, for whatever purpose, shall become the responsibility of the board, except as provided in section 36-12. 
(c)  The first annual meeting of the district in the February following the effective date of this ordinance shall be held for the purpose of electing commissioners and shall be upon at least twenty (20) days notice by mail, effective upon mailing, to all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district and by publication in a newspaper having circulation in the district. The notice shall contain a slate of Class A and Class B commissioners proposed by the interim board, together with the term of office of each as set forth in subsection 36-3(d), allocated as evenly as possible among each class. Any holder of record of taxable interest in real property in the district may propose one or more alternate candidates for the class and for the term of the candidate or candidates proposed by the board. The election of each candidate for commissioner shall be determined by a plurality of the qualified voters present and voting. 
(d)  Each Class A and Class B commissioner shall be elected for a term of three (3) years and shall hold office until a qualified successor is elected; provided that, in accordance with the notice in subsection 36-3(c) for the first annual meeting of the district, each commissioner elected as proposed by the interim board or as an alternate proposed by a holder of record shall be chosen for a term of one (1), two (2) or three (3) years as determined by the interim board to enable two (2) of the six (6) Class A commissioners to be elected annually and two (2) of the five (5) Class B commissioners to be elected in each of two (2) years and the other in the third year of the rotation. Each Class C commissioner shall be elected by the board for a term of three (3) years and shall hold office until a qualified successor is elected; provided that at the first board meeting following the first annual meeting of the district, each such commissioner shall be chosen for a term of one (1), two (2) or three (3) years as determined by the board to enable one of the four (4) Class C commissioners to be elected in each of two (2) years and the other two (2) in the third year of the rotation. Each Class D commissioner shall serve in the discretion of the designating organization until changed by such organization or until such time when its commitment set forth in subsection 36-3(a)(4) is not renewed for the fiscal year in question. Except as provided in subsection 36-3(f), upon completion of two consecutive full terms by a Class A, B or C commissioner, such person shall not be eligible for re-election until one (1) year has elapsed; and for purposes of determining eligibility for re-election such a commissioner who has served more than one (1) year of a three-year term shall be deemed to have served a full term. 
(e)  The interim board and each board thereafter may revise the initial at large allocation of Class A commissioners such that at the next election two (2) of the six (6) Class A commissioners be elected from each of the three (3) specified subareas into which it divides the district for this purpose, and may from time to time vary the composition of the subareas, or may eliminate them, as the board determines. 
(f)  (1)  The resignation of any commissioner from the board shall be in writing addressed to the board at its address. If no effective date is stated, the resignation shall be effective upon receipt. Acceptance of the resignation shall not be necessary to make it effective. 
(2)  Any Class A, B or C commissioner may be removed for any reason or for no reason at a meeting called for the purpose upon vote of two-thirds of the commissioners then in office, provided that the commissioner in question shall not be counted either in determining the number of commissioners or two-thirds ( 2/3 ) thereof. Notice of the proposed removal shall be given to the commissioner in question at least ten (10) days prior to the meeting at which the matter will be voted upon by the board. 
(3)  Vacancies in the board of commissioners for any reason shall be filled by the board for the unexpired terms, provided that Class A commissioners be chosen to fill Class A seats, Class B commissioners be chosen to fill Class B seats and Class C commissioners be chosen to fill Class C seats on the board. 
(g)  (1)  A majority of the number of commissioners of all classes then serving in office shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business at any meeting of the board. The act of a majority of the commissioners present at a meeting at which a quorum is present at the time shall be the act of the board of commissioners unless a greater number is required by this ordinance. 
(2)  The board shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman who shall be members of the board and such other officers of the board as the board shall determine. 
(3)  The board may appoint such committees as it may determine, including an executive committee of not less than seven (7) commissioners with representation of each of the Class A, B and C commissioners and at least one of the Class D commissioners. The executive committee may act for the board in between its meeting only when the executive committee determines (a) that action is required on a matter prior to the next meeting of the board and (b) that if such action is not taken, the district will be disadvantaged. Other committees may include persons who are not commissioners, but each such committee shall be chaired by a commissioner. 
(4)  The fiscal year of the district shall commence on July 1 in each year. 
(5)  The board may adopt and subsequently modify bylaws or rules to carry out the provisions of this chapter, as it may determine. 
(6)  No commissioner shall receive any compensation for service as such, but may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred on behalf of the district as determined and approved by the board. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-4. - Real property levy. 
(a)  The board shall, at its first meeting following the initial election of members of the board, and thereafter at the annual meeting and following the election of members of the board, meet for the purpose of recommending to the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven the imposition of a levy upon the taxable interests in real property within the district. 
For those levies and budgets subsequent to the initial levy and budget resultant from this section, the said levy shall be based on an estimated annual budget for the provision of services within the district, which budget shall be approved by a majority of the board, who shall hold a duly noticed public hearing within the district on said proposed budget at least thirty (30) days prior to transmitting said recommended tax levy to the board of aldermen, which transmission shall be at least sixty (60) days before the budget takes effect. 
(b)  The board at such meeting may recommend to the board of aldermen a levy on each taxable interest in real property in the district, which for each taxable interest shall be the total recommended levy multiplied by a factor equal to the assessed value of the particular property divided by the total assessed value of taxable property in the district. Special assessments to be levied on behalf of the district shall not exceed three-quarters of one percent (0.75%) of the assessed value of properties of the district appearing on the City of New Haven grand list, unless upon prior approval by a majority of all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district. Upon revaluation of the property in the district, the figure "three-quarters of one percent (0.75%)" in the foregoing sentence shall be reduced or increased to that number yielding the equivalent amount of revenue on the revalued grand list. 
(c)  When the board shall, in a timely manner, recommend to the board of aldermen a levy upon the taxable interests in real property within the district, pursuant to subsections (a) and (b) of section 36-4 of this chapter and to subsection (e) of Section 7-339n of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision), it shall be the obligation of the board of aldermen to impose such levy as a municipal levy. Such levy shall be in addition to the regular municipal levy, and it shall be the obligation of the City of New Haven to collect such levy for the benefit of the district. The city shall transfer to the district only such funds as shall be collected. 
(d)  All moneys, including but not limited to levies or any income, proceeds or fees issuing from the provision of services by the district or other business conducted by the district received by the board or by the city on behalf of the district shall be paid into the general fund of the city where an account shall be maintained of such moneys for the benefit of the district. Any provisions of the city's general statutes, special acts or charter to the contrary notwithstanding, the treasurer of the city shall disburse such moneys in accordance with an annual budget adopted by the board. A quarterly financial report, based on the fiscal year July through June, of all district revenues and expenditures shall be submitted to the controller of the City of New Haven within thirty (30) days of the end of each fiscal quarter. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-5. - Powers. 
(a)  The district shall have the following powers: 
(1)  To sue and be sued; 
(2)  To acquire, hold and convey any estate, real or personal; 
(3)  To contract; any contract or order for expenditure to the extent required by State statute or by City Charter which is greater than five thousand dollars, or such amount as may from time to time be provided under Section 7-399q of the Connecticut General Statutes, shall be awarded to the lowest responsible qualified bidder only after public invitation to bid which shall be advertised in a newspaper having circulation in such special services district; 
(4)  To borrow money, provided any obligation incurred for this purpose shall be discharged not more than one (1) year after it was incurred, and such district may pledge any revenues it shall receive against any such obligation; 
(5)  To recommend to the board of aldermen of the city the imposition of levies upon the taxable interests in real property within the district, the revenues from which may be used in carrying out any powers of the district; 
(6)  To construct, own, operate, and maintain public improvements; 
(7)  To provide, within the boundaries of the district, some or all of the services which the city is authorized to provide therein, other than elementary or secondary public education services, and other than services which are being provided in any portion of the district by any multi-town body or authority; 
(8)  To construct, acquire, or obtain leasehold interests in motor vehicle parking facilities, within the district or within any block immediately adjacent to the district, subject to the requirements of section 36-5(b), below; 
(9)  To operate a motor vehicle parking facility within the district or within any block immediately adjacent to the district, subject to the requirements of section 36-5(b), below; 
(10)  To lease (as landlord) or sublease to other parties motor vehicle parking facilities subject to the requirements of section 36-5(b), below; 
(11)  To enter into, fund and perform agreements which reduce the costs of motor vehicle parking to residents of the district and to employees of, retail customers of, and others doing business with, business located in the district. 
(b)  No parking facility open to the public shall be constructed, acquired, leased, subleased, or operated by the district, without prior approval of the board of aldermen, which shall request the opinion of the city plan commission and the New Haven Parking Authority before giving such approval. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-6. - Agreements. 
(a)  The district and the city may within forty-five (45) days of the effective date of this chapter enter into a contract setting forth the services to be provided by the city to the district pursuant to section 36-4 of this chapter, and the compensation for such services. 
(b)  The city may enter into a contract with the district in which the city is excused from providing within the district some or all of the services which the district is authorized to provide pursuant to section 36-5 of this chapter and in which the district agrees to provide all such services from which the city has been excused. The city may agree, in any such contract, to make an annual grant to the district, in a fixed amount or based upon a formula in the contract, for the purpose of compensating the district for the services from which the city is excused and for which the district is to become responsible. Any such contract is pursuant to section 7-339(t)(e) of the Connecticut General Statutes. The city and the district may also enter into contracts in which the district is given the right to elect to purchase from the city some or all of the services for which the district has become responsible. Any such contract is pursuant to section 7-339(t)(b) of the Connecticut General Statutes. Any contract between the city and the district pursuant to this section 36-6(b) shall be first approved by the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96; Ord. of 7-7-97)  
Sec. 36-7. - Properties included within the district. 
The properties to be included in the district are listed by map/block/parcel number as shown on the maps of the tax assessor of the City of New Haven and enumerated in Attachment A. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-8. - Adding properties to the district. 
A parcel of real property shall be included in the district among the properties already within the district if: 
(1)  The owner(s) of such parcel shall notify the board in writing of their intention to join the district, in a request which must be signed by the property owner(s) constituting a majority interest in said property, or a representative of such owner(s) authorized to sign such a request; and 
(2)  The board of the district shall approve the inclusion of said parcel in the district; and 
(3)  The board of aldermen shall amend this chapter to include said parcel in the district. Such amendments shall be submitted to the board of aldermen during the months of March and/or September. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-9. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms are defined as follows: 
(a)  Holder of record of interest in real property: The owner, in part or in whole, of an interest in real property as shown on the New Haven Land Records. For the purpose of the election of the board, at the organizational meeting only, under section 36-3 hereof, holders of record of an interest in real property shall be determined by the city/town clerk as of 5:00 p.m. on the eleventh (11) day preceding said first organizational meeting to elect commissioners. Any tenant on common or joint tenant shall have a vote equal to its proportional share of the property's ownership, and its owners shall not have more than one (1) vote in aggregate. 
(b)  Assessment, assessed value: Seventy (70) percent of the market value of a parcel of real property as shown on the real property field card for said parcel on file at the office of the tax assessor of the City of New Haven. 
(c)  Holder of taxable interest in real property: The owner, in part or in whole, of an interest in real property as shown on the New Haven Land Records which such interest is assessed for taxation on the last completed grand list of the city. For the purpose of the referendum on whether this chapter shall take effect, taxable interest in real property shall be determined by the city clerk as of 5:00 p.m. on the day this chapter is adopted by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-10. - Property of district. 
All interests in real property and all interests in personal property held by the district are not subject to the city property tax to the extent that the use of such property by the district is for a "public purpose" pursuant to section 12-81(4) of the Connecticut General Statutes; except that real property on the tax rolls either as of the time of the enactment of this chapter or as of the time of the transfer of the property to the district and parking facilities within or without the district shall be subject to the city property tax unless prospectively abated by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-11. - Dissolution. 
(a)  At any time after the district has been established, the district may be dissolved by the enactment of an ordinance repealing the ordinance establishing this district or by the holding of a referendum by the board among all the holders of record of taxable interests in real property within the district on the question of whether the district shall be dissolved, provided a majority of such holders shall respond affirmatively or provided the holders of taxable interests in real property the assessments of which shall constitute more than one-half (½) of the total of assessments for all taxable interests in real property within the district shall respond affirmatively. The board shall determine the manner in which the referendum to dissolve shall be held. Any such referendum may be conducted by mail. 
(b)  If the district is dissolved pursuant to section 3611(a) and (c) of this chapter, the board shall proceed to wind up the affairs of the district as to the end of the then current fiscal year of the district. If, after the dissolution of the district, the district shall have liabilities, whether fixed or contingent, the board of aldermen of the city shall have the authority to impose, in addition to the regular municipal levy, a levy on the real property within the district, in the same manner as is provided for the determination of the levy by the board of the district pursuant to section 36-4(b) of this chapter, for as many years as such liabilities shall remain outstanding, and such levy shall be calculated to produce enough revenues to satisfy and release such liabilities as they become due, and such revenue shall be deposited into the general fund of the city and shall be disbursed by the city, at the discretion of the mayor, solely for the purposes stated herein. If, after the dissolution of the district, the district shall have assets which remain following the winding up of the affairs of the district, such assets shall be transferred to the city. 
(c)  Not later than forty-two (42) months immediately following the district commencement of the first fiscal year of the district the city/town clerk shall hold in the manner prescribed in section 36-11(a), hold a referendum among all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district on the question of whether the district shall be dissolved. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-12. - Annual report. 
Annually on January 15th or the next business day thereafter, the board of commissioners of the district shall submit to the board of aldermen an annual report of the operation and activities of the district. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96; Ord. of 9-23-98, § 15)  
Sec. 36-13. - Annual audit. 
The board of the district shall have an independent financial audit of the district's annual financial affairs conducted by a certified public accountant on or before the thirtieth day of September. A copy of the audit shall be forwarded to the controller of the city. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-14. - Insurance and indemnity. 
(a)  The district shall, to the extent reasonably available, maintain at its own expense for itself and for the city as additional insured, public liability insurance covering personal injury and property damage in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) with an insurance company approved by the state insurance commissioner. To the extent of such insurance coverage, the district agrees to indemnify and hold the city harmless from any liabilities, obligations, claims, actions, judgments, damages, or debts which are a direct result of the establishment of the district or its operation. A certificate evidencing such insurance shall be filed with the controller of the city, and such insurance shall not be canceled or modified without the express written consent of the city, acting by its controller. The insurer may not terminate or refuse to renew the policy until thirty (30) days' notice has been given to the city. 
(b)  The commissioners, officers, agents and employees of the board shall be entitled to indemnification against judgments, fines, penalties, amounts paid in settlement and expenses including attorney's fees, in accordance with the standards and provisions of and to the extent that such indemnification is authorized by Section 33-454a of the Connecticut General Statutes, as such statute is presently worded or as its wording may be amended from time to time. The board may purchase insurance providing indemnification in such amounts and with such coverage as the board may from time to time determine, the right of all indemnification provided for shall be in addition to and not exclusive of all other rights to which any commissioner, officer, agent or employee may be entitled, and such right of indemnification shall inure to the benefit of the heirs and personal representatives of such indemnified person. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-15. - Conflicts, severability. 
(a)  The Code of General Ordinances of the city, except as amended herein, remains in full force and effect. Any provisions of the Code inconsistent herewith, to the extent of such inconsistencies and no further, are hereby repealed. 
(b)  If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not effect the validity of the remaining portions of the chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-3-96)  
Sec. 36-16. - Ninth Square Special Services District. 
The Ninth Square Special Services District has by referendum among all the holders of record of taxable interests in real property within the Ninth Square Special Services District voted to dissolve the Ninth Square Special Services District on or before June 30, 1997. 
All parcels of real property which comprise the Ninth Square Special Services District have been included in the Town Green Special Services District. 
It is anticipated that the City of New Haven will issue the first levy on taxable real property for the Town Green Special Services District effective January 1, 1997. In the event of the issuance of such levy, the City of New Haven, in order to avoid duplicative taxation, shall not issue a levy on the taxable real property for the Ninth Square Special Services District, any other provisions of this Code of General Ordinances notwithstanding.

Chapter 37 - GRAND AVENUE SPECIAL SERVICES DISTRICT 
 
Sec. 37-1. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established a Grand Avenue Special Services District (hereinafter the "district") as a body politic and corporate, in accordance with the powers vested in the City of New Haven (hereinafter the "city") under Chapter 105A of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision). 
(Ord. No. 1584, 2-9-09)  
Sec. 37-2. - Referendum. 
(a)  This chapter shall not take effect unless, within sixty (60) days of the enactment of this chapter by the board of aldermen, a referendum shall be held and approved. 
(b)  The referendum shall be held among all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district on the question of whether this chapter shall take effect. The city/town clerk of the city shall determine the identity of such holders in the city's land records and shall give notice of the referendum to such holders. 
(c)  The referendum shall be approved if a majority of all such holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district, voting one vote per property, respond affirmatively and if such holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district, the assessments of which constitute more than one-half (½) of the total of assessments for all taxable interests in real property within the district, shall respond affirmatively. 
(d)  The referendum shall be conducted by mail for a period of three (3) weeks ending at 5:00 p.m. on the fifth (5th) Tuesday following after the enactment of this chapter. The city/town clerk of the City of New Haven shall supervise the referendum and shall certify the results of the referendum. The referendum shall comply, to the extent applicable and practicable, with Chapter 145 (Absentee Voting) and Chapter 152 (Referenda) of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision), except as Chapter 105A of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision) and the terms of this chapter may otherwise permit or direct. 
(Ord. No. 1584, 2-9-09) 
Editor's note— Approval of the voters was granted on March 29, 2009.  
Sec. 37-3. - Board of commissioners. 
(a)  The business of the district shall be conducted by the board of commissioners. The board may designate such agents as it deems necessary to act on its behalf in the conduct of the business of the board. In particular the board may designate a district manager of the district as its agent. 
(b)  The board shall consist of eleven (11) members elected in accordance with subsection (c) hereof. 
(c)  Election of the nine (9) members of the board shall be conducted at the annual February meeting of the board, except for the initial election, which shall be held within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this chapter at a public meeting. Each voter shall be holder of record of taxable interest in real property interest in the district. 
(1)  Four (4) of the members, known as "Class A" commissioners, shall be individuals, partnerships and partners thereof, corporations or stockholders thereof, or trustees and beneficiaries of trusts who are holders of record of interests in real property in the district. 
(2)  Four (4) of the members, known as "Class B" commissioners, shall be individuals, partnerships and partners thereof, corporations or stockholders thereof, or trustees or beneficiaries of trusts operating a trade or business, or leasing real estate or residing in the district, or original Incorporators of the Grand Avenue Village Association and not qualifying as a "Class A" commissioner. At least one (10 such member shall be a resident of the district. 
(3)  One (1) of the members, known as "Class C" commissioner, shall be an individual, or representative of a government organization within the boundaries of the district, which contributes twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or more in aggregate per fiscal year. 
Said amount to be increased pro rata with any increase in overall Special Services District mill rate. 
(4)  Two (2) of the members, known as "Class D" commissioners, shall be an individual, or representative of a nonprofit organization within the boundaries of the district, which contributes one thousand dollars ($1000.00) or more in aggregate per fiscal year. These two (2) members shall represent two (2) separate and distinct nonprofit organizations. 
(5)  At the initial election, two (2) Class A commissioners and one (1) Class B commissioner shall be elected for three-year terms; one (1) Class A commissioner, one (1) Class B commissioner, and one (1) Class C commissioner shall be elected for two-year terms, and one (1) Class A commissioner, one (1) Class B commissioner, and one (1) Class D commissioner shall be elected for one-year terms. 
(6)  Thereafter, except in the case of filling vacancies, one (1) Class A commissioners, one (1) Class B commissioner, one (1) Class C commissioner and (1) one Class D commissioner shall be elected for three-year terms at annual meetings of the board, as vacancies become available. Vacancies on the board of commissioners created by resignation or death shall be filled by the board of commissioners, with the provision that Class A commissioners be chosen to fill Class A seats on the board, and Class B commissioners be chosen to fill Class B seats on the board, Class C commissioners be chosen to fill Class C seats on the board and Class D commissioners be chosen to fill Class D seats on the board. No member of one class maybe a member of another class. 
(d)  The city/town clerk of the city shall give notice of at least ten (l0) days of the first organizational meeting of the board to elect commissioners. Such notice shall be by mail to all holders of record of interests in real property in the district and by publication in a newspaper having circulation in the district. Any qualified voter may propose one or more candidates qualifying under subsection 37-3(c) hereof for the board of commissioners to the city/town clerk of the city who shall preside over and conduct balloting at the meeting for the initial election of commissioners. Thereafter, any notices for whatever purpose, shall become the responsibility of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1584, 2-9-09)  
Sec. 37-4. - Real property levy. 
(a)  The board of commissioners shall, at its first meeting following the initial election of members of the board, and thereafter at the annual meeting and following the election of members of the board, meet for the purpose of recommending to the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven the imposition of a levy upon the taxable interests in real property within the district. For those levies and budgets subsequent to the initial levy and budget resultant from this section, the said levy shall be based on an estimated annual budget for the provision of services within the district, which budget shall be approved by a majority of the board, who shall hold a duly noticed public hearing within the district on said proposed budget at least thirty (30) days prior to transmitting said recommended tax levy to the board of alderman, which transmission shall be at least sixty (60) days before the budget takes effect. 
(b)  The board of commissioners at such meeting may recommend to the board of aldermen a levy on each taxable interest in real property in the district, which for each taxable interest shall be the total recommended levy multiplied by a factor equal to the assessed value of the particular property divided by the total assessed value of taxable property in the district. Special assessments to be levied on behalf of the district shall not exceed three-quarters of one percent (.75%) of the assessed value of properties of the district appearing on the City of New Haven Grand List, unless upon prior approval by a majority of all holders of record of taxable interests in real property in the district. 
Upon revaluation of the property in the district, the figure "three-quarters of one percent (.75%)" in the foregoing sentence shall be reduced to that number yielding the equivalent amount of revenue on the revalued grand list. 
(c)  When the board of commissioners shall, in a timely manner, recommend to the board of aldermen a levy upon the taxable interests in real property within the district, pursuant to subsections (a) and (b) of section 37-4 of this chapter and to subsection (e) of section 7-339n of the Connecticut General Statutes (1958 Revision), it shall be the obligation of the board of alderman to impose such levy as a municipal levy. Such levy shall be in addition to the regular municipal levy, and it shall be the obligation of the City of New Haven to collect such levy for the benefit of the district. The city shall transfer to the district only such funds as shall be collected. 
(d)  All moneys, including but not limited to levies or any income, proceeds or fees issuing from the provision of services by the district of other business conducted by the district received by the board or by the city on behalf of the district shall be paid into the general fund of the city where an account shall be maintained of such moneys for the benefit of the district. Any provisions of the city's general statutes, special acts or charter to the contrary notwithstanding, the treasurer of the city shall disburse such moneys in accordance with an annual budget adopted by the board. A quarterly financial report, based on the fiscal year July through June, of all district revenues and expenditures shall be submitted to the controller of the City of New Haven within thirty (30) days of the end of each fiscal quarter. 
(Ord. No. 1584, 2-9-09)  
Sec. 37-5. - Powers. 
(a)  The district shall have the following powers: 
(1)  To sue and be sued; 
(2)  To acquire, hold and convey any estate, real or personal; 
(3)  To contract; 
(4)  To borrow money, provided any obligation incurred for this purpose shall be discharged not more than one year after it was incurred, and such district may pledge any revenues it shall receive against any such obligation; 
(5)  To recommend to the board of aldermen of the city the imposition of levies upon the taxable interests in real property within the district, the revenues from which may be used in carrying out any powers of the district; 
(6)  To construct, own, operate, and maintain public improvements; 
(7)  To provide, within the boundaries of the district, some or all of the services which the city is authorized to provide therein, other than elementary or secondary public. 
(Ord. No. 1584, 2-9-09)  
Sec. 37-6. - Agreements. 
(a)  The district and the city may within forty-five (45) days of the effective date of this chapter enter into a contract setting forth the services to be provided by the city to the district pursuant to section 37-4 of this chapter, and the compensation for such services. 
(b)  The city may enter into a contract with the district in which the city is excused from providing within the district some or all of the services which the district is authorized to provide pursuant to section 37-5 of this chapter and in which the district agrees to provide all such services from which the city has been excused. The city may agree, in any such contract, to make an annual grant to the district, in a fixed amount or based upon a formula in the contract, for the purpose of compensating the district for the services from which the city is excused and for which the district is to become responsible. Any such contract is pursuant to section 7-339(t)(b) of the Connecticut General Statutes. The city and the district may also enter into contracts in which the district is given the right to elect to purchase from the city some or all of the services for which the district has become responsible. Any such contract is pursuant to section 7-339(t)(e) of the Connecticut General Statutes. Any contract between the city and the district pursuant to this section 37-6(b) shall be first approved by the board of aldermen of the City of New Haven. 
(Ord. No. 1584, 2-9-09)
